Sheet1.Title: 6 Tricks to Master Your Eating Habits
Sheet1.Content:
There are all kinds of reasons we eat: happiness, sadness, boredom, excitement, stress, exhaustion. If we're doing it right, we might be really focused on fueling our workouts. If we're feeling indulgent, we might eat just to enjoy the simple, luscious pleasure of the taste of a favorite food.

The best emotional gift I've received from eating paleo is that 95% of the time, I don't eat solely for pleasure. That doesn't mean my food isn't pleasurable. But thanks to the things I've learned about my eating patterns, most of the time, I eat to thrive. And on those rare occasions when I do eat treats for the pure pleasure of it, I enjoy them immensely. I’ve learned how to avoid pandering to my emotions with food, and you can, too!   Food Will Not Permanently Change Our Emotional State The numero uno thing that's helped me is the realization that eating "comfort" food will not change my emotional state in the way I want. It might provide a momentary distraction – and momentary pleasure – but whatever I'm dealing with... happiness, frustration, anger, fear, worry, excitement, boredom... whatever emotional state I'm in will still exist after I've eaten the food. And in most cases, depending on what I ate and how much, I could make my emotional state worse. The food, usually, will not make it better. The exception to this rule, of course, is if I'm eating because of real hunger. So the trick becomes (1) feeling the difference between hunger and emotional appetite; and (2) feeding the hunger with real, paleo food; and (3) feeding the emotional appetite with something other than food to recognize and validate those emotions. That's pretty simple to understand, but it can be tricky to put into practice. The key is to be as present and mindful as possible because it's about so much more than eating. It's about knowing ourselves, understanding our emotional storms, and thinking our way out of behaving in a way that's driven by emotions. Practically speaking, here are some tricks that have helped me   1. I never have anything in the house that's not on the paleo-approved list of foods. That way, if I have an unpleasant "grazing" session, I'm at least overeating on foods that won't hurt me.   2. Drink a glass of water. Or two. I know it sounds like an old dieters' trick, but it also helps me slow down and think about what I'm doing. It's the breather to help determine the difference between true hunger and emotional appetite.   3. Make it a challenge. Sometimes the brat in me wins, and I think I don't care if I'm just feeding my emotional appetite. When that happens, I appeal to that bratty side and make it like a workout. I set a 20-minute timer and challenge myself to not eat a damn thing until the timer goes off. If at the end of those 20 minutes, I'm hungry, I eat a paleo snack. If at the end of the 20 minutes, I just still "really want something," I give myself a stern talking to and ban myself from the kitchen. Sometimes it really is just about muscling it out. It's unpleasant, but I refuse to be ruled by false messages sent to my body by my fickle emotions.   4. "Kitchen's closed.” I tell myself that after dinner... or in the afternoon when I want the pleasure of eating, but I'm not actually hungry. I say it out loud, "Kitchen's closed." I pretend I live on a cruise ship or at a resort with ridiculously tight-fisted rules about the pantry, and when the kitchen is closed, it's closed. Yes, it's maybe a little silly, but the imagination is a very powerful tool. (I do the same thing when it's time for me to go to bed, but I don't feel sleepy. I say to myself, "It's time to get sleepy." and start tricking my body into believing it.)   5. Meditate, dance, cry, talk it out. Emotions will not be denied, so when I realize I want to eat because of an emotional appetite, I know I need to find a way to deal with those emotions. Sometimes it's as simple as telling someone I trust what's on my mind. Other times, I need to crank some music or indulge in a really good cry. Emotions are like a vampire; they will have their due and the best way to move through them is to give them attention but not the food they want. You don't want that food, the emotion does. Let it go calorie-hungry and feed it with attention instead.   6. Enlist an ally. Everyone I work with and all of my blog readers and all of my Twitter and Facebook peeps know that I'm committed to taking good care of myself with paleo food. And I know that if I turn to them for a word of encouragement, I'll get it. Use the tools and people around you for support. Reach out to likeminded people on Twitter and Facebook. Recruit your co-workers. Enlist a family member. It's totally OK to complain about wanting to eat; most people will sympathize... and then they can help you sort out if you're really hungry or if something else is going on. I'm always amazed at how once I’ve said, "I really want to eat [insert the name of something that doesn't make me healthier]" the hold it has on me evaporates. Try it! Cooking and eating quality food is among the most caring things you can do for yourself and others — and learning the difference between emotional appetite and true hunger will help you make food choices that nourish you, body and soul.

By: Melissa Joulwan

Melissa Joulwan is the author of Well Fed: Paleo Recipes For People Who Love To Eat, Well Fed 2: More Paleo Recipes For People Who Love To Eat, Living Paleo For Dummies, and the blog The Clothes Make The Girl.

Sheet1.Title: Lessons Learned from My Journey to Best Self
Sheet1.Content:
I’ve had a weight loss goal since I was 13 years old.

That’s more than 30 years of living with a number hanging over my head. From Weight Watchers summer camp to the rice diet to Kathy Smith’s Fat Burning Plan to Weight Watchers to the Zone to Paleo… with aerobics videos and step aerobics and triathlons and boxing and Roller Derby and half marathons and CrossFit along the way. My motivations have been many. Fear of being fat. Health concerns. Peer pressure to conquer the 200# deadlift. A personal sense of pride. Unadulterated vanity. Those motivations shaped my behavior. I ate “right” so I would reach my Weight Watchers goal weight. I set my alarm for 5:00 a.m. so I would some day see my name on the RX or PR board at my CrossFit gym. I was driven by a sometimes debilitating fear that I would never be “better.” Then a thought began to flicker in my subconscious. It started, I think, on holiday in Prague when I realized I liked exploring narrow, winding stairways. I was starting to loosen my grip on “destination” and reveling in the “getting there.” That idea tickled me again when I was upside down during a handstand at the gym and during a (totally fun, stopwatch-and-music free) run around the lake. What if my goals have been backwards? What if I’ve been looking at this thing from the wrong direction all along? My underlying motivation for all of it – the weight loss, the physical challenges, the healthy eating – has always been that I wanted to be the best version of myself that I could possibly be. Happy, healthy, fit, strong, attractive. But that pure motivation got bastardized into numbers and external measures that divorced what I wanted from what I did. So I got this notion to try something different. For the first time in more than three decades, what if I don’t set a physical goal? No weight loss, no "leaning out," no target time on the clock or weight on the bar. Instead, what if I just behaved like the best version of myself? Then I would become her. The best me eats clean and sleeps well and trains hard and smiles a lot. She’s free of worrying about what number might appear on a scale or a measuring tape. Instead of being intimidated or threatened by stronger, faster, leaner classmates at the gym, she delights in their capabilities. And she remembers to encourage the people around her to be their best versions. Finally, the best version of me knows that she's not required to eat clean or meditate or practice yoga or lift heavy or get solid sleep. There is no accounting ledger keeping track of exemplary behavior for a reward later. There is no intrinsic value in checking off tasks on a list to earn a metaphorical gold star. The clean eating and training meditation and lifting and sleeping are the reward. They are the thing. So I’ve banished my “concrete” fitness goals. I know that “Be the best version of me” doesn’t follow the SMART goal format. I don’t care. I’ve done it the conventional way. Now I’m doing it my way. Because the best version of me refuses to be measured by some external yardstick. The best version of me happily goes to bed early, wakes up refreshed, eats paleo, trains wisely, lifts heavy things, remembers to take a fun run and to play a little every day, spreads love, looks up, leads with the chin, makes up new recipes, and sings out loud. Not because I must. Because I want to. Because that’s me. The best me. What is the best version of you? Not the one you think other people want to see or the one the media thinks you should be... but the one you desire, deep down, to be? Can you live the best version of you, without judgment? Without punishment? Without reward? Can you revel in the you-ness of you?

By Melissa Joulwan

Melissa Joulwan is the author of Well Fed: Paleo Recipes For People Who Love To Eat , Well Fed 2: More Paleo Recipes For People Who Love To Eat, Living Paleo For Dummies, and the blog The Clothes Make The Girl.

Sheet1.Title: Wake Up Refreshed: 3 Paleo Breakfast Foods to Start Your Day Right
Sheet1.Content:
Breakfast is the most important meal of the day, so people say. You have heard it time and time again, yet somehow this meal seems to be the one that people skip most often due to busy schedules or lack of hunger in the morning. But reaching for something nutritious first thing in the morning can give your body the jumpstart it needs to power through the day and leave you minus the cravings, drops in energy levels and low metabolism. When you want to keep your body moving throughout the day, here are three easy and fast breakfast foods to reach for that will fit in with your Paleo diet regime.
  1. Eggs – Eggs are rich in protein and are the perfect way to start your morning. This highly nutritious ingredient can be served up in a variety of ways, including scrambled, in an omelet packed full of vegetables, or baked for a quick nutritious bite on the go. We love the protein found in eggs so much that we have even added egg white protein to our AMRAP Refuel bars to give our athletes the energy boost they need from this power food.
  2. Sweet Potatoes – While you may think sweet potatoes make for an odd breakfast choice, consider mashed sweet potatoes for breakfast over your regular bowl of oatmeal. This food is rich in complex carbohydrates giving you an energy boost and leaving you feeling full throughout the morning. Add a small amount of honey, cinnamon and coconut milk to give it the creamy texture with a touch of sweetness.
  3. Green Vegetables – Eating spinach for breakfast may seem like an odd idea but putting it in your favorite smoothie combined with some water, fresh fruit juice or coconut milk can help you get your veggies without sacrificing your appetite. There are hundreds of smoothie recipes that make getting your greens in the morning easy. One of our favorites is coconut milk, a handful of spinach leaves, half a frozen banana and some frozen berries. Eat this together with an AMRAP Refuel bar and you will be fueled up with energy that will last you all morning.
Breakfast is an easy meal to overlook but eating a healthy breakfast can help you get a head start to a great day. When you fuel up with these top Paleo breakfast ingredients, you get the nutrition you need to feel refreshed, energetic and ready to take on the day. What is your favorite Paleo breakfast food?

Sheet1.Title: 10 Reasons why Paleo is Not a Fad Diet
Sheet1.Content:
You’ve tried dieting before and many times without success. Whether you have counted points, calories or any other metric, dieting just seems too difficult to last for longer than a month or two. So why wouldn’t you feel the same about the Paleo diet?

Many people are rightfully leery about trying a new eating regime like the Paleo diet. Still, the Paleo diet has helped millions of people get healthier, lose weight and ultimately feel better overall. Here are a few reasons why you can believe that the Paleo diet is not just a fad.
  1. Our caveman ancestors ate Paleo – People have consumed a Paleo diet for centuries dating back to when humans were living in caves. Biologically, we are still cavemen and we should continue to eat like our caveman ancestors did. Our bodies continue to need the same types of nutrients found in the foods cavemen ate, and our bodies still do not know how to process the types of ingredients found in many of the foods that fill our grocery store shelves today.
  2. You get all the nutrients you need – It has been said that the Paleo diet contains less calcium than diets consisting of dairy products. However, grass fed beef, spinach and other Paleo foods actually contain more calcium than a glass of milk that you would buy in the grocery store. This is true of other essential nutrients as well.
  3. You always know what you are eating – Being able to pronounce all of the ingredients in the food you consume helps you to know exactly what you are putting into your body. Instead of eating chemically enhanced foods filled with ingredient lists that are enough to intimidate anyone without a PhD in science, the Paleo diet allows you to choose clean ingredients so that you know exactly what you consume each and every meal.
  4. You get to try a variety of foods – Eating too much of anything can get boring very quickly. That’s the reason why so many diets fail over time. But with the Paleo diet, boredom is never a factor. With the variety of seasonal fruits and vegetables and the abundance of Paleo recipes available, this diet is constantly varied.
  5. Insulin levels stay in line – There are certain types of food that cause insulin levels to go out of control and spike suddenly. This can lead to chronic and life threatening diseases, such as Diabetes or obesity. With the Paleo diet, you are able to keep your insulin levels at a much more reasonable level and avoid the risk of chronic illness.
  6. You have more energy – When you eat right, you feel better. Your body has more energy to get work done, your cognitive functions are enhanced and overall you can tell that you feel right. This is enough to keep you on board with the Paleo diet for longer than a few weeks or months.
  7. Meals are easier to prepare – When you have simple ingredients, there is far less chaos in the kitchen. Therefore, sticking with Paleo meals means easier and faster preparation of daily foods.
  8. You won’t have a lingering feeling of hunger – When you eat protein rich foods and the right types of carbohydrates and fats, you are left to feel full and satisfied for longer. Unlike fast foods or foods high in processed sugars that can cause your body to crash, you feel full for longer and don’t have that nagging feeling of hunger that you get with many other diets.
  9. You can always order at restaurants – Although you may seem limited in your choices with other diets, there are always Paleo options on the menu. Salads, steaks or burgers without the bun are easy ways to stay on board with your diet making this a lifestyle more than a fad.
  10. You will have more confidence – A little vanity goes a long way when it comes to sticking with something new like the Paleo diet. When you look good and feel good, it is hard not to be confident. This confidence is a sure fire way to keep yourself strong and loving the Paleo diet.
Now that you know how easy and effective this diet can be, when will you make the switch to eat like our hunter and gatherer ancestors once did?

Sheet1.Title: 3 Paleo Foods to Eat Before a CrossFit Workout
Sheet1.Meta Description: Pre-workout food is tricky for athletes. Because CrossFit workouts are known for their high intensity, identify good food to eat before a CrossFit workout
Sheet1.Content:
Crossfit workouts are known for their high intensity. Athletes that enter the Crossfit gym expect to push their own limits and get stronger. Some even make a trip to the notorious bucket affectionately titled “pukie”. To fuel your body through one of these grueling, yet addicting styles of workouts, you need the right type of nutrition before you enter the gym. Pre-workout food can be tricky for many athletes. While some athletes cannot tolerate eating anything before a workout, particularly in the morning, there are others that feel they need some sort of nutrients in their body before starting a workout. Regardless, the idea of hitting the mat doing an unusually high number of burpees on a full stomach sounds less than appealing. Pre-workout foods tend to vary from person to person but there are still certain nutrients you will want in your stomach before you work out to help you power through - especially if you are aiming to beat your personal best or get on the whiteboard. Here are the top three foods you should eat before a Crossfit workout.
  1. Almond Butter – Almond butter is a favorite for many Crossfit athletes because it serves multiple purposes. First, it is high in protein which is essential to build stronger muscles and to help your muscles recovery properly from a workout. It is also a healthy type of fat which can give you some much needed energy throughout your workout. Eating almonds in a butter format will be easier on your stomach to digest than having to break down the nuts in their raw form and will still give you the nutritional benefits found in raw almonds.
  2. Banana – Bananas are a carbohydrate that are packed full of potassium. This potassium serves as a much needed energy boost before a workout, as well as an essential nutrient to help your muscles heal once the workout is over. Depending on your weight, fitness level and goals, you may want to only eat a third or a half of a banana before a workout. Even this small amount of food will give you the energy boost and nutrients you need to feel your best during a Crossfit WOD.
  3. Dates – This is another type of sugar that many athletes consume before a workout. Just a small amount can go a long way which can help you eat less and still get the carbohydrates in your body that will help you push you to your limits. Just eating one date may be able to give you enough of a boost to get you through a tough WOD without leaving you feeling overly full or bloated.
Keep in mind that because CrossFit workouts are known for their high intensity, you are best served to identify good food to eat before a CrossFit workout. Pre-workout nutrition tends to vary with each person, but for those who like to have something in their stomach before hitting the gym these tips can help you get the most out of your workout without feeling too full. What other pre-workout foods do you love to consume? Leave us a comment below.

Sheet1.Title: How the Paleo Diet Benefits Runners
Sheet1.Meta Description: Learn a few of the ways the Paleo diet benefits runners, and helps achieve their maximum performance and reach new personal records in their race times.
Sheet1.Content:
In Crossfit boxes across the world, the Paleo diet is one of the core teachings. After all, Crossfit is about functional movement and the Paleo diet involves functional nutrition consisting only of the cleanest foods that can be found through a quick hunting and gathering trip outdoors. But Crossfit athletes are not the only ones who benefit from this type of nutrition. Endurance lovers who enjoy feeling their feet hit the ground as they glide over trails or along the pavement can also benefit. If you are that person, take this opportunity to learn how the Paleo diet benefits runners. Here are a few of the ways the Paleo diet can help runners achieve their maximum performance and reach new personal records in their race times.
  • Reduced inflammation – One chronic problem runners have is inflammation in their joints from the repetitive pounding their body experiences each time they take a stride. With the Paleo diet, inflammatory foods, such as sugars, grains and rice are eliminated. Instead, the body is left with minimal inflammation from a diet filled with natural anti-inflammatory agents, such as Omega-3’s.
  • Faster recovery times – When you ingest foods, such as fruits, vegetables, lean meats, nuts and seeds, you are serving your body a higher dosage of branch chain amino acids. For runners, this means more muscle strength and faster recovery of sore or painful muscles. For any runner who has taken on a marathon, you know that fast recovery time is important to your training regimen. With the Paleo diet, your body is better equipped to bounce back faster after a race or a long run allowing you to hit the ground running more often and feel your best.
  • Leaner body – Weight loss is a nice side effect many people see with the Paleo diet. For runners, this can be extremely useful as running with more pounds around your mid-section or legs can slow you down and make it harder to do your best. The Paleo diet makes it easy to lose weight as the lean proteins boost your metabolism and keep you feeling full for longer so you are less likely to give in to your cravings.
  • Better structure for a healthy diet – Runners are often times seen reaching for energy drinks and gels to keep their glucose levels going. For some athletes, these gels constitute the extent of their nutritional intake leaving their sugar levels in a chaotic state and making it more difficult for their bodies to regulate this important level. With the Paleo diet, people are able to eat a healthier diet and keep their body filled with the nutrients they need to power be strong, recover quickly and feel their best overall.
The Paleo diet is followed by people around the globe and has been for years. Now, more athletes and runners in particular are seeing the benefits of eating Paleo and use this diet as a guide to keep their nutrient levels high and their bodies feeling their best.

Sheet1.Title: Energy Boost: Top Paleo Ingredients that Deliver
Sheet1.Meta Description: Average snack items are chalk full of sugar additives. It's time to consider paleo energy snacks that promote long-lasting energy without a sugar hangover.
Sheet1.Content:
You’re running low on energy at about 2:00 in the afternoon at work, what do you reach for? Chances are you are likely to grab the most convenient thing to give you a quick caloric boost and increase your energy levels at least until the end of the day. At many offices quick snacks often times consist of candy bars at the receptionist’s desk, chips from the vending machine or a soda from the refrigerator in the kitchen. But each of these items can actually have an adverse effect and while you may get a temporary sugar boost, you will quickly crash feeling worse off over time. It's time to consider paleo energy snacks that promote long-lasting natural release energy for your busy day. The Paleo diet, or the diet of our caveman ancestors, has been around for years and for loyal followers to this diet, consistent energy levels, as well as a whole host of other benefits, has been a driving factor for people to continue eating hunter/gatherer style. The foods listed above, chips, candy or sugary soft drinks, all give you a quick energy rush because the sugar is let into your blood stream far too quickly. Then, your blood sugar levels drop and you are left to crash and burn without energy putting you in a vicious cycle. With the Paleo diet, the foods you consume were meant to be eaten by humans and are therefore processed differently in your body leaving your blood sugar levels neutralized and more under control. Here are a few of the foods you can reach for to help fuel you when you are in need of a boost of energy.
  • Lean protein – Most people believe that reaching for something sugary is the best way to get an energy boost, but in many cases protein can have an even longer lasting impact on your overall energy levels. Lean protein, such as turkey or chicken, can give your metabolism a boost and leave you feeling full for longer. This means no crash and better health overall for your body.
  • A handful of nuts – Nuts of any kind, almonds, cashews, sunflower seeds, contain protein and healthy forms of fat that can give your body a much needed energy boost without the risk of a spike in your sugar levels. You do not need many nuts to achieve the results you are after, so reach for a small handful and get back to being productive.
  • A cup of tea – If you are used to reaching for your double espresso filled with 12 pumps of sugar, you are only hurting yourself. Instead, drink a cup of tea. Tea is filled with less caffeine and more nutrients than any other soft drink or sugary coffee beverage which will keep you going for longer and leave you feeling lighter and better overall.
It is important to note that the first few days of eating a Paleo diet, you may feel reduced energy levels as your body gets used to not having the spike in sugars and glucose. But as your sugar levels even out, eating Paleo ingredients over grains, sugars and salts will help you maintain steady glucose levels leaving you to feel healthier and more energetic overall. If you find yourself tempted, keep an AMRAP refuel bar close by for when those cravings hit so you can have clean, nutritious energy to fuel you through the rest of your day.

Sheet1.Title: The 4 Most Damaging Types of Training
Sheet1.Meta Description: Bodybuilding, CrossFit, Running, and Powerlifting are very risky based on recent opinion. Through training risk analysis, plan around these potential risks.
Sheet1.Content:
Are NOT Running, Crossfit, Powerlifting, and Bodybuilding.

This is a lesson in training risk analysis.

Here’s what you need to know...

  • Just read this article titled “The 4 most damaging types of training and I disagree with John.
  • Remember that all types of training come with a benefit and a risk. This article will help point out the benefits and risks of running, crossfit, powerlifting, and bodybuilding.
  • With bodybuilding, there are some serious risks associated with steroid use that should be considered.
  • When done correctly, rates of injury in powerlifting, crossfit, and running can be significantly reduced.
  • Running and crossfit may top the list for injuries, but don’t buy the hype. There are more people participating in running than any other form of training followed by crossfit, then powerlifting, then bodybuilding. With smart training you can significantly reduce the rate of injury in any of these forms of training.
  • Mobility and better self-myofascial release techniques are the key to reducing injuries and improving performance.
Just a post on T-nation called “The 4 most damaging types of training”. I think the article might have been a little biased. Call me crazy. Written on a bodybuilding site.  Lets take a look at the risks, one more time shall we:  

Fourth most Risky Training: Bodybuilding

Here is a quote from John Rusin, the author of the article: “Sure, bodybuilding has continued to draw some negative attention due to the blatant and obvious use of performance enhancing drugs, even within the "natural" divisions.” Performance enhancing drugs? What do you mean, like steroids? So, it’s not natural to look like this: I did some really in-depth research (a quick google search “the risks of bodybuilding”) and found some concerns you may not have been aware concerning “performance enhancing drugs”: Anabolic steroids come with serious physical side effects as well. Men may develop:
  • Prominent breasts
  • Baldness
  • Shrunken testicles
  • Infertility
  • Impotence
Women may develop:
  • A deeper voice
  • An enlarged clitoris
  • Increased body hair
  • Baldness
  • Infrequent or absent periods
Both men and women might experience:
  • Severe acne
  • Increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture
  • Liver abnormalities and tumors
  • Increased low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (the "bad" cholesterol)
  • Decreased high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (the "good" cholesterol)
  • High blood pressure (hypertension)
  • Heart and circulatory problems
  • Prostate gland enlargement
  • Aggressive behaviors, rage or violence
  • Psychiatric disorders, such as depression
  • Drug dependence
  • Infections or diseases such as HIV or hepatitis if you're injecting the drugs
  • Inhibited growth and development, and risk of future health problems in teenagers
Source: http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-living/fitness/in-depth/performance-enhancing-drugs/art-20046134 I guess each man and woman has their own priorities. But I personally don’t like manboobs in my future. That is just me. It’s helpful that you can breastfeed your child when you get older, so I am sure your future wives will appreciate that in the middle of the night when its your turn to feed the baby. I hope myfascial release is effective for manboobs.  

3rd most Risky Training: Powerlifting

It seems that T Nation published another article where Louie Simmons describes how they avoid overtraining. The article seems to make a pretty convincing case that powerlifting is safe and Louie is producing the strongest powerlifters in the world who are setting records in powerlifting without getting injured. In fact, overtraining is something that Louie seems to have considered before. Louie quickly addresses some of the issues of overtraining in this video:   

2nd most Risky Training: Crossfit

The amount of people doing crossfit now is much higher than the number of people doing bodybuilding.   So just by a numbers game, you are going to see more crossfit injuries because you are drawing from a larger pool of people participating in this style of training. The myofascial techniques outlined here are so kindergarten. Crossfit athletes have a real expert that we look to for advice: Kelly Starett. Most crossfit athletes have a lacrosse ball and a roller to do Myofascial release.

Average to Elite

The simple fact is that crossfit is taking the average Joe and helping them achieve elite fitness. The graph above shows the facts. Average people are getting in shape and former collegiate and professional athletes are achieving elite fitness and are competing at a level of fitness that most people will never come close to.

More Ignorance

Another great qoute from your site: “If you insist on losing your gains through light load, high-rep Olympic lifting, make sure to limit some of the trashing your body is about to endure with self-myofascial release. “ You need to get your facts straight bro. Light load? When was the last time you had a max load on overhead squat. Probably a long time, I took a look at your legs and it looks like you are riding a chicken. Maybe you should skip Bi’s and Tri’s and actually workout your leg muscles. Bro. The problem is you have no idea what crossfit actually is. Take your panties off and go step into a gym and see if you handle the heat...SON!  

The most risky training: Running

One more graph: According to Google, running is substantially more popular than bodybuilding. Even though runners may look like T-rex, they definitely don’t have to worry about the risks mentioned above with bodybuilding. My wife is a runner, so I take it back. She doesn’t look like T-rex. You look great princess! About 40% of runners do NOT stretch. This culture of not stretching after your run can definitely impact your longevity and lead to injuries. This could be a contributing factor in the overall scope of things. Changing the no-stretching mentality will be the first step to getting runners back out on the road. Runners need someone like Kelly Starett who can relate to them and show them the benefits of mobility in terms of running, health, and overall performance. Who will step up? Only time will tell.  

What is the REAL Risk

The real risk is that you do nothing. Yes, bodybuilding, powerlifting, crossfit, and running all have risks associated with them. But doing nothing is the greatest risk. Once you decide how you want to achieve your level of fitness, just look at what will work best for you and what your goals are. Then look at the top athletes in each sport and decide who you want to model. Don’t listen to self promoting physical therapists who don’t actually know what they are talking about.  

Featured Image: Bestbuildmuscleguide, insidetheboxbook, neverstopexploring

Sheet1.Title: Fat Battle: Finding Omega 3 Rich Foods
Sheet1.Meta Description: Learn how to incorporate Omega 3 rich foods into your diet and trim bad fats. The benefits to your health and fitness performance improve with these foods.
Sheet1.Content:
Our newfound society has a habit of looking down upon fat consumption within the human diet. It wasn’t until new and further research was conducted that we’ve found that healthy fats are a essential in order for your body to perform at its full potential. Now that the importance of healthy dietary fats is valued within a growing percentage of the educated health and fitness community, we can finally understand and enjoy the benefits of these marvelous dietary fats, particularly Omega fatty acids. Omega-3 fatty acids, are prime sources for the healthy dietary fat your body needs for long-term high function. Studies have measured the mental and physical growth our bodies sustain when provided the nutrient benefits of Omega fatty acids. The impact is tremendous in the right dose. Often, the biggest argument against dietary fats claims the cost in high calories is not worth ingesting for the nutritional benefits certain fats provide. If you are one to carefully count calories, stop now. The reality is your body will benefit more with proper nourishment than it will by withholding calories from your body. Although the high amounts of calories within these fats have not changed, we now know that the benefits outweigh the 9 calories per gram. For your better understanding, N-3 fatty acids (Omega-3’s) are considered polyunsaturated fats, commonly what we call “healthy fats”. These polyunsaturated fats can be primarily found within plants and oils, with benefits that include a decrease in risk for type-2 diabetes, improvement in blood cholesterol levels, cognitive function, and rheumatoid arthritis. The other healthy type of fat is monounsaturated fat, which has the same benefits as polyunsaturated fats but can also decrease your chance of heart disease, benefit insulin levels, and improve blood sugar control. 1 Omega-3’s are comprised of two different types of rich fatty acids, the first being alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), and the other consists of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). While EPA and DHA can only be found in fatty fish, ALA can be found in multiple sources, like:
  • Flaxseed (ground or oil)
  • Walnuts
  • Canola oil
  • Soybean
  • Green Vegetables: Kale, Brussel Sprouts, Spinach
While ALA is partly converted into EPA and DHA within the body, fish provide the pure form of EPA and DHA that can be quickly processed within the body and can maximize absorption. Salmon, tuna, trout, mackerel, sardines, herring, krill, and cod are the best sources of fatty fish for your Omega-3 requirements. While the average American diet consists of large amounts of saturated and trans fats, most people don’t know the effects these two types of fats can have on the body. These two fatty acids are associated with increasing low-density lipoprotein (LDL) within the body, otherwise known as “bad” cholesterol.2 Saturated fats has been known to raise your blood cholesterol levels, while trans fats will actually lower your high-density lipoproteins (HDL) or “good” cholesterol. While the health benefits of saturated fats is debatable, the combination of these two fats can increase the likelihood of cardiovascular disease. Manage your cholesterol levels by completely ridding trans fats and moderate your intake of saturated fats. Since omega-3 fatty acids are so crucial to your health, it’s critical that you consume the proper amount of omega 3 rich foods within your diet. Based on a 2,000 calorie a day diet, you will want to consume about 20 to 35 percent of your calories from those healthy fat sources, which comes to around 44 to 78 grams of fat.3 If you are going to count anything, count grams over calories. Those measurements are more reflective of your body’s nutritional needs. Naturally occurring fatty acids are friendly to your body, but not always to your wallet, so be discerning about which fish oils deliver true unpolluted nutritional value. Athletes and health advocates alike, invest in a quality fatty acid supplement. Finding a solid EPA and DHA derived oil will help you reach those daily requirements, and will push you in the right direction to achieve your health goals.

By Michael Dorey  | Featured Image: Justin Fitzmartin

Sheet1.Title: How a Daily Dose of Beetroot Transforms High Blood Pressure
Sheet1.Meta Description: Beetroot health benefits are extensive. Beets have a high concentration of nitrates–compounds that increase blood flow to the brain, heart, and muscles.
Sheet1.Content:
Have you been eating your beets? If not, we won't hurt you. However, it might be time to reevaluate and look into what these little maroon monsters have to offer. Beetroot health benefits are impressive and far-reaching. Beets are a great nutritional choice for numerous reasons–from fighting cancer, to providing essential vitamins, and regulating blood pressure–these guys will make your body smile from the inside out. What’s especially magical about beets is that they contain manganese and potassium–which are important for blood-pressure regulation. They also contain vitamin-C, magnesium, iron, copper and phosphorus–essential vitamins and minerals your body needs for proper function.1 High blood pressure is a very common health concern. However, it is one that can be addressed through natural means, like beets! They help stabilize your blood pressure and return you back to the healthy range. So, how exactly do they do it? Beets have a high concentration of nitrates–compounds that help to increase blood flow to the brain, heart, and muscles. Once nitrate enters your body, it is converted into a powerful gas called nitric oxide. Nitric oxide relaxes the smooth muscles in your blood vessels and helps your arteries stay properly dilated–maximizing blood flow. Nitrate also has an antiplatelet effect that helps prevent blood from thickening and clotting.2  So what does that mean? It means that these work together to support easier blood flow and may lead to significantly lowered blood pressure. Studies have also found that beets lower systolic blood pressure–the force that drives blood out of the heart–by 4-5 points. While that drop may seem small, when viewed on an overall public health level it would equate to a 10% reduction in deaths due to heart disease.3  Beets are also awesome for working out. Their organic properties provide your body with long-lasting energy and help to vastly increase stamina–due to their ability to increase your natural blood flow. You might not be a huge fan of beets, and to be honest, many of us aren’t. Nevertheless, there are simple and creative ways to incorporate beets into your diet. One of the more common ways is juicing. Throw in some beets and add carrots, cucumbers, apples, and some lemon for a tasty, powerhouse drink. Beets are also beneficial raw or cooked. Slice ‘em up and add them to your favorite salad. Our personal favorite is natural concentrated beetroot supplements, often called Nitric Oxide activators; combine with 8 ounces of water and quickly gulp the nitrate rich benefits of beets. However you decide to get these little guys into your system is up to you, we just hope you can show them some love and get them in your daily diet. Beets are an excellent addition to a natural regimen to help combat high blood-pressure and increase your daily energy and overall stamina. It is a powerhouse food that will add leaps and gains to your long-term health.

Featured Image: TheWebConsole

References

  2. David Williams, (February 6, 2014). One Food Can “Beet” High Blood Pressure. Retrieved from: http://www.drdavidwilliams.com/beet-high-blood-pressure/

Sheet1.Title: 3 Tips To Rock Your Running Endurance
Sheet1.Meta Description: Aspiring competitive runner? If you want to get fit faster and boost your explosive power, you need to develop your running endurance in 3 key areas.
Sheet1.Content:
Improving running endurance is the key to a champion’s continued success. We only have so many years to achieve our very best, so let’s make them count. Let’s unleash our potential. If you’re like me, then you’re pretty impressed when watching running pros win race after race, year after year. How do they do it? Well, when it comes down to it, we’re all human. And, as human beings, we were born runners–the efficiency of our cooling systems and having upright posture maximizes our lung capacity. Unlike animals, we don’t have in-born endurance. We have a very high-energy cost of running.1 We have to train for that endurance. We have to prove to our bodies–through our mind–that we are capable of our anything. It’s not impossible. But anything worth anything takes time and sacrifice. Try these 3 tips to turn you into the super-athletes you always knew you could be.
  1. Elevation Runs
When we return to sea level after training in upper elevations, we’re more powerful. We’re significantly stronger. This is due to the increased mass of our ever-looping red blood cells. The effects of elevation training has on our body can include an increase of endurance, reduced recovery time, weight loss, as well as a natural increase in human growth hormones–which stimulates growth and cell reproduction It also increases our overall red blood cell count. More blood in our bodies, means more oxygen for our muscles. Your mitochondria literally improve–this is where your muscle cells get their power. Basically, we get more bang for our buck, letting us work out harder, better, faster, stronger.2
  1. Track Sprints
If you want to get fit faster and boost your explosive power, adding high-intensity efforts–30-seconds track sprints–will give you impressive results. Plus, it makes you look cool. For those of us who may not have time for long, steady endurance exercises, but want the same–and even better–cardiovascular benefits, consider track sprints for workouts. Quick, high intensity sprint workouts will vastly improve your aerobic capacity and endurance in half the time of traditional endurance exercises, such as long runs.3 Alternate timing and running with a training partner–it’s perfect for rests in between your explosive sets. And, a little healthy competition is always fun
  1. Interval Training
High-intensity interval training is extremely helpful. And it’s crazy fun. HIIT consists of insanely intense, short bursts of exercise with active recovery–much less intense exercise, or complete rest in between. Both aerobic-cardio and anaerobic-strength workouts qualify. They will get your heart pumping and fire up your metabolism thanks to the phenomenon known as afterburn–excessive post-exercise oxygen consumption Basically, higher metabolism, more calories burned. Trust me, it’s a good thing. You can get a super effective workout in just 20 minutes or less—even in as few as four minutes if you do–20 seconds high intensity, then 10-seconds low intensity. Push hard and fight through it, then rest and recover.4 You see, improving our running endurance is as easy as 1-2-3. With just a little bit of time and sacrifice geared towards maximizing efficiency, we will see exponential results. Perhaps we can even start winning some races and keep up with the pros. We may not be super-human, but we can at least train like the titans.

Sheet1.Title: Why are CrossFitters So Jacked?
6 Areas To Assess If You're Regularly Tired In WODs
Sheet1.Meta Description: Do you regularly feel fatigued, lethargic, fatigued, weak, or “out of gas” during your workouts? Likely, you need to consider mental training for CrossFit.
Sheet1.Content:
Do you regularly feel fatigued, lethargic, fatigued, weak, or “out of gas” during your workouts?  You could be noticing mental warning signs, like negative self-talk or feelings of discomfort. You might be recognizing physical  warning signs, like sloppy form, messing up/no-reps, slow movement or poor body language. If you don’t feel like you’re able to push as hard as you’d like, or if you’re struggling to stay motivated, focused, or consistent, take a few minutes to look at your habits. In order to get the most out of your training, you want to regularly feel energetic and recovered. Here are 6 areas to assess if you've been feeling lethargic or unmotivated 1. Rest - Are you on a regular sleeping pattern of 8 hours or more a night? Could you do a better job at making sure that you’re well-rested and recovered? More HERE 2. Fuel – Are you eating enough nutrient-dense food? Are you getting adequate protein, carbs and fat in your diet? More HERE 3. Life Balance – Is your schedule jammed and requiring too much from you? Could you make some adjustments with how you spend your time and energy? More HERE 4. Emotional-Energy – Are you giving out too much of yourself and is your tank feeling empty? Could you make some changes to feel more rejuvenated and full? More HERE 5. Training Intensity – Are you going nuts every time you train? Are you trying to move too fast for what your body can handle? Could you do a better job at managing your training intensity so that you can actually get more out of your workouts? More HERE 6. Mental Skills – Do you use effective self-talk strategies when you begin to feel fatigued? Have you worked on developing specific performance goals and understanding your purpose, so that you can push when it feels tough? Do you know how to use your thoughts to help you battle discomfort? More HERE Remember, if you’re wiped after a workout that you’ve put full effort into, it’s great and normal to be tired. If you push yourself and work your ass off, then the WOD will be challenging, and that’s how you know you’re giving it your all. But, if you’re constantly feeling like you just don’t have “enough to give”, then you’ll want to make some improvements to the areas listed above. You may need to take some time away from the gym, so that you can focus on making your habits more healthy and sustainable. Mental training for CrossFit athletes is equally important to physical training; give your whole body needed attention. After you've regained some energy, you'll feel much better about attacking your workouts and you'll likely see more results!  

Featured Image By: FitBandits

Sheet1.Title: Why Honey is King of Natural Workout Recovery Foods
Sheet1.Meta Description: The health & nutrition benefits of raw honey are buzzworthy. See five quick reasons honey tops the list of the best workout recovery foods plus meal ideas.
Sheet1.Content:
Honey: The heavyweight champion for natural packed workout recovery.

  “Float like a butterfly, sting like a bee.” Nothing threw a right cross or a punchy quote like Muhammad Ali. The best in his boxing game, and built rhyming fame, his words had a sting, and he was unbeatable in the ring. Apparently he loved bees as much as boxing and poetry. Ali knew it, and so do we–honey is money. Raw honey happens to be one of the single best foods an athlete can take for a natural food-based workout recovery.   Why raw honey? Commercial honey is heavily processed and may even have been chemically refined. Excessive heat destroys the natural enzymes, vitamins, and minerals in honey. Filtering/processing eliminates many of the beneficial phytonutrients including pollen and enzyme-rich propolis. Avoid the golden syrup-like honey in favor of opaque organic raw honey.1 Raw honey is the most original sweet liquid that honeybees produce from the concentrated nectar of flowers. Collected straight from the extractor; it is totally unheated, unpasteurized, unprocessed honey.2   The health and nutrition benefits of raw, organic golden bee goo are pretty buzzworthy. Here’s five quick reasons for your honey pot.
  1. Makes great workout fuel: Raw honey is an excellent source of energy because it comes with superior nutrients. The National Honey Board recommends adding honey to your bottle of water for a workout energy boost. Honey-snacks can be eaten before and after, even honey-sticks can be consumed during endurance events.3
  2. Treats wounds: In numerous studies, honey has been found effective in treating wounds. It is uniquely low in moisture and extremely acidic, making it a forbidding environment for bacteria and microorganisms. On top of that, bees add an enzyme, glucose oxidase, to it that creates hydrogen peroxide as a byproduct. Antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and has remarkable debriding action.3
  3. Provides nutrients: Honey contains “small amounts of a wide array of vitamins and minerals, including niacin, riboflavin, pantothenic acid, calcium, copper, iron, magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, potassium and zinc.” Thus, using honey instead of sugar provides you with more nutrients for your calories.3
  4. Helps you lose weight: Drinking, with warm water, lemon and honey is a top component every detox programs. Doing this on the daily also helps cleanse the liver, remove toxins, and flushing away fat.4
  5. Reduces the risk of heart disease: Honey mixed with cinnamon has been shown to revitalize the arteries and veins of the heart and reduce cholesterol in the blood by up to 10%. When taken on a regular basis, this honey-cinnamon mixture may significantly reduce the risk of heart attacks.4
  So, the next time you're in need to feed your sweet tooth, choose honey before sugar. It’s an easy substitute. Honey can be twice as sweet and thrice as healthy. Honey has an entire hive of yummy uses. In your day-to-day cooking, it can be used in marinades–meats such as chicken or duck, and pork chops. It can be tossed into smoothies and even salad dresses. Plop it in your your tea or breakfast yoghurt. Drizzle it over thin slices of cheese as deliciously sweet and salty end to meals. Add tablespoons of honey with raw cinnamon to warm water, drink daily.5   The overall bee-nefitts: A Lot of honey is available on the market, but not all of them have the same healthy attributes. For optimal nutrition and performance–make raw honey your best, only option. Honey raw–unheated and organic–means it contains vitamins, minerals, enzymes, antioxidants and all of the precious insulin-type substances.   Heated and filtered honey is turned into pure sucrose, which loses a majority of its nutritional value and healing benefits. “All the honey in the world is nothing without the confirmation of the bees.” Honey is money. Healthy and healing. It’s super sugar–Glucose is Greek for “sweet wine”. We won't argue with that. As often as you can, utilize the best workout recovery foods available and incorporate honey into your post workout ritual.

Sheet1.Title: Why Athletes Still Choose Egg White Protein Powder
Sheet1.Meta Description: Egg white protein powder is the dominant supplement that athletes relied on before whey and casein protein were introduced; it continues to deliver results.
Sheet1.Content:
We all have tried our fair share of random supplements, diets, routines, and fads when staying fit or reaching a personal goal. While many of these have come and gone-- one deserves to stay. Egg white protein powder is the original shake that athletes and fitness gurus alike have harnessed before the development of whey and casein protein in the 90’s. Many still consider egg whites to be the “perfect protein”.1 With a little over three grams of protein per egg white, you are able to consume one of the purest forms of protein available in the human diet. An individual cage-free egg contains about ⅔ of its mass from the protein albumin, the rest being the yolk. Albumin contains several types of protein, all of which are responsible for different functions such as nourishment, blocking digestive enzymes, binding iron, binding vitamins; as well as providing the essential vitamins, minerals, and amino acids. When separating the white from the yolk you are ridding much of the high concentration of fats and cholesterol contained in the yolk that can give you those added calories you may not desire. Still, many would argue that the body performs better with a full nutritional profile received in the yolk. From experience, athletes understand that one egg (yolk included) is just not enough for their high protein demands. Most need additional protein to supplement their food intake. By providing yourself with a high quality egg white protein powder you can get around 25 grams of protein in just a 30 gram scoop. Lactose free products are in rising demand and as egg white protein has zero lactose, fat, cholesterol, and minimal carbs it is a productive supplement option for athletes.2 In the world of protein powder, egg-white promotes the same performance boost and lean muscle mass to those athletes with strict dietary needs. Now, protein powders rule the supplement industry as we know it, with whey and casein becoming the primary sources. These two dairy based proteins being much less costly, as well as coming in a wide variety of flavors have made them the popular choice amongst consumers. But little do many know that they can contain vast amounts of artificial flavors, colors, and preservatives-- plus random chemicals.2 Every supplement has a possible downside, with some egg white proteins having one. That problem is the non-use of pasteurization. Pasteurization commonly rids most harmful organisms that may be held by the eggs themselves, such as salmonella. Free-range and hormone free chicken eggs are always the safest bet when consuming them in either cooked or powdered forms to decrease the likelihood of health risks. When egg whites are cooked they are nearly a perfect source of protein, but when consumed unpasteurized or uncooked the protein avidin binds with available biotin within the body to create a large array of health issues.3 To enhance the effects, try cooking or baking with the egg white protein powder to increase healthy protein intake. AMRAP Nutrition has established this with growth-hormone free chicken eggs, and deriving their egg white protein powder from these quality sources. Every individual bar contains almost 15 grams of cooked/pasteurized egg white protein powder, with various amounts of other vital ingredients to increase your health.

Sheet1.Title: Swim Against The Grain: 10 Better Alternatives to Replace Grain
Sheet1.Meta Description: The traditional American diet is heavy on refined grains. Understand better alternatives to replace grain that are heavily processed.
Sheet1.Content:
Albert Einstein believed, “Everybody is a genius. But if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid.” It’s about going against the grain. Trading up mediocrity, the ordinary for the extraordinary. Thinking against the grain is the first step. The next is acting upon it. Understand better alternatives to replace grain. The traditional American diet is heavy on grains. Can you blame us–pastas, pizza, cereal, oatmeal, pretzels, rice–these foods are delicious–they’re good, not great. You are what you eat. Gluten-free may be a fad, but Paleo isn’t. It’s been around for well….since human beings have. The Paleo diet is derived from the Paleolithic era, before the Neolithic era–the beginning of the agricultural revolution. Grain is basically any food made from agronomy and cultivation–wheat, rice, oats, cornmeal, barley, and cereal grain. And, bread, pasta, oatmeal, breakfast cereals, tortillas, and grits are examples of grain products. Grains are divided into two subgroups, whole and refined. Whole grains contain the entire grain kernel, the bran, germ, and endosperm. Examples: whole-wheat flour, bulgur, oatmeal, whole cornmeal, brown rice. Refined grains have been milled, a process that removes the bran and germ. This is done to give grains a finer texture and improve their shelf life, but it also removes dietary fiber, iron, and many B vitamins. Examples: white flour, cornmeal, white bread, white rice.1

Benefits from reducing grain intake:

  • Grains Aren’t Good For Your Joints. Due to their inflammatory nature grains are linked to joint pain and arthritis. Because both synovial tissue and grains are chemically similar, your body has difficulty differentiating between the two. So, when your immune cells get bent out of shape by inflammation caused by grain and begin to attack it as a foreign invader, they also begin to attack the soft tissue in your joint since the grain’s amino acid composition mirrors that of the soft tissue in your joints. This may leading painful autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and, of course, more inflammation.2
  • Grains cause inflammation: Due to high starch content, grains are inflammatory foods. The more refined the grain, the more inflammatory it is. Chronic inflammation is linked to modern diseases: arthritis, allergies, asthma, cardiovascular disease, bone loss, emotional imbalance and even cancer.2
  • Grains can prevent mineral absorption: When improperly prepared they can inhibit vitamin and mineral absorption. Grains contain substances like phytic acid, which binds up minerals and prevents adequate absorption. Essentially, though your diet might be rich in iron, calcium and other vital nutrients if you consume too much grain, you’re not fully absorbing nutrients from the foods you eat.2
  • Grains aren’t good for your skin: Grains have a high carbohydrate content. Although they’re complex carbs, they are still broken down into sugars. These sugars instruct your body to produce more insulin elevated insulin leading to hormonal responses that activate glands in your skin–encouraging them to produce oil, which leads to acne.2
  • Some more nutritional alternatives to grain: Quinoa. It’s complete protein that offers a respectable serving of all nine essential amino acids as well as a strong showing of manganese, magnesium, iron, copper and phosphorus.3
Squashes and sweet potatoes, both nutrient loaded, can serve as a respectable grain alternative. Likewise, lower glycemic beans such lentils can be a decent fill-in. Eggplant, an ingredient that takes on the flavor of any sauce you make. Eggplant slices can serve as substitutes for pizza crust, and bread sticks.3 Mushrooms can offer the warm, pleasantly mild taste that we might crave from grains. Crustless quiches work too. Strips of cabbage and spaghetti squash can serve as a “pasta” for both light and meaty sauces.3 Einstein was a pretty smart guy. Thinking outside the box and against the grain served him rather nicely–as well as the rest of us. If we want to be serious about our health, we not be conscious of it. Let’s defreat the wheat. We can be ordinary, or we can discipline ourselves to be extraordinary. The key to peak physical form isn’t how many rounds we can go in the gym, but how much health we can put into our bodies. it’s Remember, “We can not solve our problems with the same level of thinking that created them."-Einstein  

Featured Image: www.theironyou.com

Sheet1.Title: How to Guarantee Your Quality of Life
Sheet1.Meta Description: Incorporate health-promoting habits into your daily routine—take a multi-vitamins, drink lots of water, crossfit, and adhere to a fairly paleo lifestyle
Sheet1.Content:
If you care about staying healthy, you are probably already incorporating a variety of health-promoting habits into your daily routine—taking a multi-vitamins, drinking lots of water, crossfit, and of course a fairly paleo diet and paleo lifestyle that adheres to YOUR own body’s entity inclination. The paleo lifestyle not only includes eating healthy at home but includes a healthy travel routine of diet and exercise. Many who have adopted a paleo lifestyle keep a paleo travel or gluten-free travel regiment in when they are out of town, whether for business or pleasure. While these healthy living routines have great benefits for health and longevity, if you’re not exercising somewhat regularly, you may be missing out on a key way to keep encroaching pain away. Not only does exercise improve your muscle tone and help you maintain a healthy weight, making you look great in your jeans, bikini, halter top or tanks (men!), it offers important health benefits, decreases your chances of developing serious health conditions such as osteoporosis and cancer, and can lengthen your life span. It’s important for us all to understand the benefits of exercise in our overall physical and mental well-being and how it’s easy to get started on implementing a routine that can be adhered to. Probably what drives people to exercise and crossfit more than any other reason is weight control and looks, but what about HEALTH! Studies show that overweight women are more likely to develop serious health risks such as heart disease, cancers, and stroke. Men need this to keep hormones balanced and the heart in tip-top shape. By using up oxygen and causing the body to burn some stored fat (increasing the metabolism), exercise can help you get that healthy lean look that is so appealing to many people these days, but along with BEING EVEN MORE HEALTHY. Furthermore, exercise, by strengthening muscles, increases your metabolic rate, allowing you to burn more calories and FAT, and we all love to see that melt off with ease, or hard work. Studies estimate that for each pound of muscle you add to your body, you will burn an additional thirty-five to fifty calories per day; an extra five pounds of muscle will burn about 175-250 calories a day, or an extra pound of fat every two to three weeks, or about twenty pounds a year. This explains why men burn calories faster and lose weight more easily than women; they have more muscle mass, which allows them to burn more calories. The benefits are more than rewarding the more we gravitate to muscle mass as opposed to JUST fat loss and working towards strengthening our skeletal system, while enhancing the beautiful body we have now; all with the health benefits well in mind. Another healthy benefit of regular exercise is stronger bones. Regular, moderate exercise, in particularly weight-bearing exercises such as dancing, crossfit, fast walking, running, and jogging, as well as resistance training (strength-training or again crossfit) increases bone mass, making them stronger. This makes those who exercise on a regular basis less likely to develop osteoporosis and arthritis and suffer debilitating accidents such as falling, while helping you to stay active and graceful as you age. Exercise can also help women deal with stress better and improve their mood. Studies show that regular exercise reduces the release of stress hormones, keeping the heart pumping at a comfortable rate, blood vessels relaxed, and blood pressure low. It also produces chemical changes which affect your mood, reducing symptoms of depression and other psychological disorders. Research suggests that lower stress levels and a happier mood boosts immune function and lengthens the life span significantly. Hey men, listen to that! Now who wants an unhappy, hormone wild woman? Another great benefit is better skin. Dull, wrinkled skin is a tell-tale sign of your age. Luckily, exercise can improve complexion by increasing circulation, the delivery of nutrients, and detoxification of skin-dulling poisons. As it boosts oxygen to the skin, it increases the natural production of collagen, the connective tissue you’ve probably heard a lot about as it is responsible for giving your skin its youthful plumpness. Skin color also evens out and improves due to the increased blood circulation. Having that teenage glow in your 20’s, 30’s, 40’s and beyond. Along with a paleo diet that works for you, you will have the skin you should have. The formula for this is really terribly easy. As you can see, there are many ways to gain from exercise. So how do you get started? Stay on course and make it a priority. No matter your age or your fitness level, you can get started now and soon see your work pay off. Remember, though, to check with your doctor before starting an exercise regime if you’re currently experiencing any health conditions or if you have a concern. The benefits of exercise are clear. Not only will it allow you to live a longer life with a lower risk of serious health concerns, but it will increase your quality of life as you find yourself happier, more energetic, better-looking, and less stressed out.

Featured image by: The Marco Corporation

Sheet1.Title: The Paleolithic Diet: Paleo Foods for Athletes
Sheet1.Meta Description: Eating paleo promotes lean, healthy muscle growth. Paleo foods for athletes is an investment in performance and long term health.
Sheet1.Content:
I’ll never forget my first Crossfit experience. I was in a part of the world that was once conquered by Alexander the Great. Where my mountain vistas turned into the Himalayas and the world’s greatest soldiers fought like ancient warriors with herculean strength. It was the Memorial Day ‘Murph Challenge’–a grueling WOD–in honor of Lt. Michael Murphy, a fallen Navy SEAL and posthumous Medal of Honor recipient.
  • 1-mile run
  • 100 pull-ups
  • 200 push-ups
  • 300 squats
  • 1-mile run
  • (Wearing 20 lb. vest or body armor)
My first WOD introduced me to the crazy-awesome world of crossfit. Where modern everyday athletes with incredible passion and endurance get fit and have fun along the way. Shortly after this, I started hearing about this wild diet fad that everybody was talking about: Paleo. What the heck is Paleo? Paleolithic “Paleo” diets include ingredients our human ancestors were eating for thousands of years. They ate real, whole, unprocessed foods that they had hunted for and gathered. More recently in human evolution, we've come into the Neolithic period–where farming and numerous technological and chemical advancements have changed the human diet and became detrimental to our health. It was “in many ways a catastrophe from which we have never recovered…the worst mistake in the history of the human race.”1 Exaggeration? Maybe. However, when the Neolithic diet came into our sapien race, so did overpopulation, autoimmune diseases, and obesity–all cloaked by centuries of poor eating habits. Paleo may sound like a fad. It’s not. You could argue that it’s really just the reverse–on the millennial timescale of evolutionary history, agriculture advancements are actually more of a fad.2 The Paleo diet consists of “meats, fish, eggs, vegetables, fruits, nuts, and seeds, and probably ought to include human flesh–however, we don't advise this. –Cavemen Ate Some of This:
  • Meats: Beef, lamb, chicken, turkey, pork
  • Fish/Seafood: Salmon, trout, haddock, shrimp, shellfish
  • Eggs: Free-range, pastured eggs
  • Vegetables: Broccoli, kale, peppers, onions, carrots, tomatoes
  • Fruits: Apples, bananas, oranges, pears, avocados, strawberries, blueberries
  • Nuts/Seeds: Almonds, macadamia, walnuts, hazelnuts, sunflower/pumpkin seeds
  • Healthy Fats/Oils: Lard, tallow, coconut oil, olive oil, avocado oil
  • Salt/Spices: Sea salt, garlic, turmeric, rosemary3
–Cavemen Did Not Eat Much of This:
  • Sugar/High Fructose Corn Syrup: Soft drinks, juices, sugar, pastries, ice cream
  • Grains: Breads, pastas, wheat, spelt, rye, barley
  • Legumes: Beans, lentils, potatoes
  • Dairy: Milk, cheese
  • Vegetable Oils: Soybean, sunflower, cottonseed, grapeseed, and corn oil
  • Trans Fats: Margerine, processed foods, hydrogenated oils
  • Processed Foods: Laneled diet/low-fat, etc.4
The Paleolithic diet has been around for thousands of years. We gotten sidetracked with agricultural advancements and processed foods for a while, but we’re getting back on track. Eating paleo promotes lean, healthy muscle growth. Paleo foods for athletes is an investment in performance and long term health. From club-wielding cavemen to Crossfit enthusiasts, its nutritional value has benefitted us with the the strength to endure herculean challenges from hunting wooly mammoths to fighting like Navy SEALs. They don’t call it beast-mode for nothing.  

Featured Image By: Deep Ecology Hub

References
  1. Dolson, Laura (2014, May 16). Paleo Diet: Overview. Retreived from: http://lowcarbdiets.about.com/od/paleodietcavemandiet/p/paleodietintro.htm
  2. Kolbert, Elizabeth (2014, July 28). Stone Soup: How The Paleolithic Lifestyle Got Trendy. Retreieved from: http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/07/28/stone-soup
  3. Tam, Michelle; Fong, Henry (2014, September). What’s The Paleo Diet? Retreived from: http://nomnompaleo.com/paleo101
  4. Gunnars, Kris (2014, September). A Paleo Diet Meal Plan and Menu That Can Save Your Life. Retreived from: http://authoritynutrition.com/paleo-diet-meal-plan-and-menu/

Sheet1.Title: Build Muscular Endurance Where It Counts
Sheet1.Meta Description: Endurance is the act, quality, or power of withstanding hardship or stress. Reinforce strength training and build muscular endurance for targeted gains.
Sheet1.Content:
In the current day of health and fitness we get in the middle of a very controversial battle—strength or endurance? Whether you’re the enthusiastic 5-mile daily runner, or the max press specialist who’s all about the weight—you too can benefit from the other side. With certain performance benefits being provided from both sides, getting a mix of the two can make you one of the biggest beneficiaries. Strength can be defined as the ability to resist being moved or broken by force. Endurance is the act, quality, or power of withstanding hardship or stress. So if you’re an individual who can’t jog to the end of the driveway, or lift the milk jug back to the top shelf, now’s the time to switch-up your training regime. You need to build muscular endurance. Muscular endurance is the new training category in the fitness world, and the health benefits you can receive from this mix of training will create a more functional, athletic you. Muscular endurance is related to both cardiovascular endurance and muscular strength, and is utilized by athletes all over the world. The muscles are affected by this type of training in a different fashion than most other methods, by primarily developing your slow twitch muscle fibers, as well as improving your fast twitch muscle fibers. Slow twitch fibers are fit for low levels of force over relatively long periods of time. They are much more resistant to fatigue than our fast twitch fibers. Though the time required to generate force is much greater in slow-twitch fibers. 1 There is a level of F.I.T.T. (frequency, intensity, type, time) where a training effect will take place. With that being said, this applies to two types of muscular endurance: dynamic endurance and the other static endurance. Dynamic endurance is a muscles ability to contract and relax repeatedly, represented by the number of repetitions you can carry out on a particular body movement in a given time frame. A better way to describe this in relation to muscles is the common formula of lower total resistance and a higher repetition count. There is an overload principle that states that physiological adaptations to exercise occur when individuals subject their body to demands greater than what the body’s already adapted to. Static endurance is a muscle’s ability to remain contracted for a long period of time. But for a static muscular approach you must apply the overload principle by increasing the length of time the muscles remain contracted against that force or resistance.1 By incorporating these two types of muscular conditioning  you can increase your endurance and strength to apply to your athletic career or every day life. Many ways to get a great start is to find a workout plan that implements high-rep low weight/ high weight low-rep methods such as crossfit, or a sports specific routine.  

Featured Image By: Arbor CrossFit

References
  1. Dixie State University (September, 2014), Muscular Endurance http://fitness.dixie.edu/readings/1088/1088_3.pdf

Sheet1.Title: 3 Easy and Inexpensive DIY Paleo Bars
Sheet1.Meta Description: Paleo doesn't have to be time consuming. Make a batch of any of these three easy diy paleo bars for fast, flavorful, and nutrient dense food.
Sheet1.Content:
Power bars. Candy bars. Monkey bars. There are so many options, but they aren’t all awesome. Why not try something that is. I’m talking Paleo Bars. They’re healthy, tasty, and fun–go, baby go. You can even make them yourself. Hop on over to your kitchen and whip up some of these paleo bars. 1-Three-Ingredient Energy Bars: Make some delicious and inexpensive paleo bars–a perfect triangle of paleo goodness. Here’s what you’ll need in your kitchen: Dried fruit (raisins), nuts, pitted dates. They’re chewy, nutty, fruit filled, and fantastic. Now, get whisking! How To: 2-Prague Cinkova Energy Bars: they’ll get you to your next full meal and provide you with a ripe boost of energy. You’ll love them, and you’ll thank us later! Here’s what you’ll need in your kitchen: Banana, nuts, dried fruit (cherries, mangoes, apples, etc.), sunflower seeds, vanilla raw protein powder, arrowroot starch, almond flour. An ingenious recipe of great paleo. Now, get cooking! How To: 3-Nut-Free Paleo Chewy Granola Bars: Perfect to the taste best describes these little high-in-energy granola bars. Here’s what you’ll need in your kitchen: Eggs, vanilla, honey, shredded unsweetened coconut, honey, pepitas, sunflower seeds, sesame seeds, dried apricots, dried cranberries, mini chocolate chips (dairy-free), flaked coconut, sea salt, cinnamon. They’re chewy and fantastic. Now, get cooking! How To: We know you can make some of these. You’re smart. But hey, you’re pretty busy too. Spend some more time in the Crossfit gym–it’s your cathedral. Let us help you out. We’ve got some pretty tasty things in our kitchen, too. If you don’t feel like cooking, try one of our Paleo Bars–we made them ourselves. #AMRAP  

Featured Image By: The Kitchn

Sheet1.Title: Make This SEAL Qual Your Workout of the Day
Sheet1.Meta Description: Here’s the physical screening test for Navy SEAL candidates. Make it your hardest workout of the day. (Passing rates are as low as 35% ladies and gents.)
Sheet1.Content:
No Easy Day. This Workout is All or Nothing.

  We all know who Navy SEALs are. They are the ghost and the darkness, the elite warriors that our country calls upon to go to the cold, dark places where the bad things live. The SEAL motto is this: “The only easy day was yesterday.” Meaning everyday they push themselves harder than the day before. There is no easy day girls or guys; it's a continuous grind. And they're not the only ones who live for the grind. Over the last decade, CrossFit has become deeply rooted into SEAL culture. Go ahead and ask David Werner of Crossfit Seattle (davidatcrossfitseattle.com)  for his Benchmark workout of the day (WOD): Helen, btw. It's game on with CrossFit's high intensity training. Among the Hero WODS like my personal favorite, the Murph Challenge, I like to occasionally throw in some more SEAL exercises for a little bit of "fun", it's an exciting challenge. Here’s the physical screening test for SEAL candidates. Make it one of the hardest WODs you do this week and see if you can compare with the soldiers who train for a living. (Passing rates are as low as 35% ladies and gents.) Physical Screen Test:
  • 500-Yard Swim, 10 Minute Rest
  • Max Push-Ups in 2 Minutes, 2 Minute rest
  • Max Sit-Ups in 2 Minutes, 2 Minute rest
  • Max Pull-Ups in 2 Minutes, 10 Minute Rest
  • 1.5 Mile Run
Required Pass Times:
  • Swim 12:30
  • Push-Ups 50
  • Sit-Ups 50
  • Pull Ups 10
  • 1.5 Mile Run 10:30
Keep this quote in mind when you feel like you want to vomit. It’s part of the SEAL Creed, their Ethos: “I lead by example in all situations. I will never quit. I persevere and thrive on adversity. My Nation expects me to be physically harder and mentally stronger than my enemies. If knocked down, I will get back up, every time.” It's this kind of thinking that drives success. Of course, I shouldn't have to say this but I will. Know your limits, but push towards them as fiercely as possible. So, maybe you're not a Navy SEAL, you can at least train like one. "Push 'em out."  

Featured Image By: Boxrox.com

 
References 1. SEAL, SWCC (2014, Oct 10). SEAL Ethos, Forged By Adversity. Retrieved from: http://www.sealswcc.com/navy-seals-ethos.html#.VDeCFL6RNFI 2. Boss, Jeff (2014, March 21). 10 Inspirational Quotes From Navy SEAL Training. Retrieved from: http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/232209

Sheet1.Title: Try This CrossFit Benchmark WOD-Frogman
Sheet1.Meta Description: Healthy exercise is a lifestyle choice, not a hopeful insertion. Try This CrossFit Benchmark WOD-Frogman a long intense workout.
Sheet1.Content:
One of my friends once told me he’d “try to work out more if he could fit it into his schedule.” I thought that was ridiculous. You fit movies and laundry into your schedule. You fit shopping and parties into your schedule. You don’t try to fit exercise into your schedule. Healthy exercise is a lifestyle choice, not a hopeful insertion. Take some advice from Jedi master Yoda: “Try not. Do, or do not. There is no try.”1 The only thing I try to fit into to my weekly workout schedule is a Benchmark WOD. In CrossFit, It’s all about improvement. It’s about getting faster and stronger. What’s your go-to benchmark? Here’s my favorite benchmark. It’s an enhanced physical screening test for candidates of naval Special Forces training.2 I usually do it about once a month. Not all CrossFit affiliates have swimming pools. So if you live near an ocean or a lake that will work. Or heck, just stop by your local YMCA and let them know what real athletes look like. This workout doesn’t have a WOD name so I’m calling it:077 WOD-Frogman:
  • 1,000-Yard Swim-With Fins     (20-Minutes or Under)
  • Push-Ups: At Least 70                (2-Minute Time Limit)
  • Pull-Ups: At Least 10                  (2-Minute Time Limit)
  • Curl-Ups: At Least 60                 (2-Minute Time Limit)
  • 4-Mile Run                                    (31-Minutes Or Under)
Remember, "You don't have to like it, you just have to do it." Do you have what it takes? Well, if it were easy, everybody would do it. Like I said, exercise is a lifestyle choice, thats all there is to it. Besides, if you don’t have your health, what good is anything else in your life? I can tell you one thing when it comes to living healthy, "it pays to be a winner."3 If you're feeling froggy see if you can keep up with me. (Pull-Ups are dead-hang by the way, ladies and gents, not kipping.) My Times:
  • 1,000-Yard Swim-Fins: 14:48
  • Push Ups: 90
  • Pull Ups: 14
  • Curl Ups: 75
  • 4-Mile Run: 27:15
 

Featured Image: crossfitie.typepad.com

References 1. Lucas, George (2014 Oct 8). Good Reads: Quotes About Jedi. Retrieved from: http://www.goodreads.com/quotes/tag/jedi 2. SEAL, SWCC (2014, Oct 10). Stages Overview.
