Sheet1.Title: Fuel Performance: 18 Nitrate Rich Foods For Nitric Oxide Production
Sheet1.Content:
Include Nitrate Rich Foods in Your Daily Routine for Nitric Oxide Production.

  Nitric Oxide benefits are proven (check out our full spiel here). While you can get access to nitric oxide supplements, its a smart idea to incorporate foods into your regular diet routine that are high in nitrates and promote continuous nitric oxide production in the body. Start with these 18 nitrate rich foods:  
18. Dark Cocoa
Several studies have documented that cocoa, especially the raw kind, increases nitric oxide production and lowers blood pressure. There is also evidence of cacao healing the endolethium (the thin layer of cells that lines the interior surface of blood vessels) by increasing the amount of cells that repair it. The crucial part in choosing right kind of cacao is the quality. If possible you should always buy raw unprocessed kind, because the ones they sell on markets are so over-processed that they shouldn’t be even called chocolate anymore.  
17. Watermelon
Watermelon contains a lot of the amino acid L-Citrulline that is one of the best natural compounds to increase nitric oxide, proven by countless of studies. Read this post to learn more about L-Citrulline and how it converts into nitric oxide in the body.  
16. Pomegranate
If I would have to choose the best food for nitric oxide production and testosterone levels, it would be pomegranate. Pomegranate has been performing perfectly in every single study that it has been researched for, producing effects such as reducing arterial plaque thickness by 30% and increasing testosterone levels by 22% in peer reviewed studies.  
15. Walnuts
Walnuts are packed with vitamin E, which helps you arteries and testosterone levels. Also it has been recently studied and proved to increase nitric oxide production and also to lower blood pressure, significantly. This is probably due to the high amounts of L-Arginine found in walnuts, which has been linked to an increase in nitric oxide production, more about L-Arginine here.  
14. Spinach
Spinach is known to have one of the highest nitrate contents of all plants, which means that it’s a pretty awesome food to eat if you are looking to increase nitric oxide production. Learn more about nitrates in foods and how those convert into nitric oxide, here.  
13. Oranges
Oranges and orange juice contains high amounts of vitamin C, which has been shown to protect your precious nitric oxide molecules from free radicals. So ideally there would be no point in increasing your nitric oxide levels without consuming vitamin C and antioxidants at the same time, because without the vitamin C, your beloved nitric oxide would just oxidize away before really doing anything in your body.  
12. Beets
Beetroot is one of those foods that contain nitrates as explained here. The thing that really makes beets so amazing is the fact that it is one of those foods that has highest nitrate count in all of plants, and at the same time beets are capable to lower your estrogen levels by acting as a methylate, as explained here.  
11. Cranberries
There are countless of health benefits that link back to cranberries. Possibly one of the less known ones is the fact that cranberries increase nitric oxide production, while lowering blood pressure significantly at the same time. This was found out by a study conducted back in the year 2000.  
10. Garlic
Researchers say that garlic is a potent activator of NOS (nitric oxide synthase), and produces same kind of effects as Cialis or Viagra. In one study it was noted that garlic decreased systolic and diastolic blood pressure by 8 points on subjects with high blood pressure. That’s a very impressive result from a food, as it shows to be working even better than most of the high blood pressure medications.  
9. Black tea
contains caffeine, which acts as a vasoconstrictor, and that’s the main reason why black tea is not something you usually see on a list of foods that increase nitric oxide. But despite black teas caffeine content, it still has some major vasodilation effects. Many studies claim that black tea significantly increases nitric oxide production and lessens the arterial stiffness. On top of that there is this study done back in 2009 which claims that more black tea = more blood flow.  
8. Cayenne pepper
contains high amount of capsaicin, the compound that makes all chili’s hot. One study noted that capsaicin has a dose dependent effect, meaning that more the subjects consumed capsaicin, the more their nitric oxide levels increased and arteries relaxed.  
7. Honey
One animal study claims that honey significantly increases nitric oxide production. Either the high enzyme content probably causes this, or the high nitrate content that honey has.  
6. Pistachios
Like almost all nuts, pistachios are also packed with L-Arginine, a precursor of nitric oxide that is known for its ability to increase nitric oxide production significantly.  
5. Salmon
Wild salmon is a very good source of co-enzyme Q10, enzyme that can be spotted on moisturizer adds for women. Co-enzyme Q10 is not only great for soothing wrinkles; it’s also a very good nitric oxide booster as it has been shown in dozens of studies to increase nitric oxide production significantly.  
4. Kale
Kale is also a very good source of co-enzyme Q10 that boosts nitric oxide. Kale also has very high nitrate content, which makes it very good nitric oxide booster. There are also many other health benefits linked to kale, such as increased testosterone levels and improved arterial health.  
3. Animal Organs
One of the greatest foods that every man should be consuming are foods like animal liver. The organs contain high amounts of cholesterol and healthy fat-soluble vitamins that boost your testosterone levels. Those organs are also very good source for co-enzyme Q10 that increases nitric oxide levels, so it’s a win-win situation if you eat organs!  
2. Onions
Onions are not only good for your testosterone levels, as they have been shown to increase nitric oxide production in 2 different studies. They are also a very good source of vitamin C, which as explained above protects your nitric oxide molecule from free radicals. Onions also contain a compound called Quercetin, explained briefly here. Quercetin is well known for its ability to boost nitric oxide levels.  
1. Shrimp:
One of the best sources of dietary L-Arginine, as mentioned above L-Arginine is an amino acid and precursor of nitric oxide. By consuming shrimps you are essentially increasing the amount of L-Arginine in your body which then converts into nitric oxide.  

Featured Image By: UWS - University of West Scotland
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Interesting Other | Nutrition Hacks | Performance Advice

Sheet1.Title: How to Get Started in The Paleo Diet
Sheet1.Meta Description: Learn how to get started on the paleo diet and tailor its key diet principles to better your nutrition and overall health.
Sheet1.Content:
The “Caveman Diet,” aka Paleo diet has one simple goal–to eat like our paleolithic ancestors did. If they couldn’t eat it, then neither can you. The Paleo diet has gained loyal followers and people who swear by this lifestyle due to its exceptional health benefits–including overall bodily efficiency, lean muscular growth, and increased energy levels–that positively stimulate your mental health.   Even if you are not the type of athlete to regiment your diet in such a radical way, there are huge benefits to your health and fitness from grasping the fundamental guiding principles of the Paleo template. Learn how to get started on the paleo diet and tailor its key diet principles to better your nutrition and overall health.   This diet is based on what our hunter-gatherer ancestors thrived on. It rids our bodies of all of the genetically modified and processed foods that add excess loads of sugar and fat–then replaces them with fresh, natural, (and healthy!) ingredients.   If we look at our caveman ancestors, what were their body types? They were lean, muscular, agile, and athletic. And, what are we now? Many of us are overweight and out of shape. Obesity is at an all time high. We also suffer from stress, sleep deprivation, and a myriad of preventable diseases.1 Our ancestors didn’t have problems with obesity, cardiovascular disease, cancer, Type-2 diabetes, osteoporosis, or other autoimmune diseases and ailments.2 Clearly something is not right. The Paleo Diet is an effort to go back to eating what we were biologically designed to eat–allowing us to tap into our genetic potential and start living healthier immediately.1   So, how do you get started? Eat clean, eat well, eat plentiful. Paleo is based upon anything that we can hunt or find and is unprocessed. Including:
  • Lean meats, fish
  • Eggs
  • Leafy greens, veggies/fruit
  • Healthy fats
  • Nuts/seeds
  Does not include:
  • Dairy
  • Grains
  • Legumes,
  • Excess sugar
  • Vegetable Oils
  Paleo diets should be high in healthy fat, moderate in animal proteins, and low to moderate in carbohydrates.3 Saturated fats like coconut oil, avocado oil, olive oil, and macadamia oil are important to know. Also, your body needs time to adapt to this new diet so don’t be shocked if there is an initial drop in energy levels as your body gets used to not having spikes in sugars and glucose. Over time you will find that levels are restored and improved. Also, if you are need of a quick Paleo snack, proteins like turkey, chicken, or nuts are great. But, if you feel the cravings coming on–grab some AMRAP bars (100% Paleo), they provide you with clean, nutritious energy that will help you refuel and power through your day.   Paleo eating is naturally devoid of high concentrations of sugar, salt, dyes, dairy, preservatives, gluten, and grain. Paleo foods are rich in nutrients, phytochemicals, and mineral profiles. They can also increase the body’s ability to become stronger, healthier and more ready to express an improved physiologic and athletic performance. These fresh food groups are better for our bodies since they provide antioxidants, energy, and the potential to improve the immune system, decrease inflammation, and improve digestion as well as cognitive function.4   The Paleo diet will take getting used to. Turning back the dial is hard, but we know that you’ll see tremendous changes in your overall health: with higher energy levels, improved athletic performance, sharper cognitive abilities, and a better body composition. A smart Paleo diet is designed to help you become the best version of yourself. Its not for everyone–if it were easy, everybody would do it. It’s a commitment to a healthy diet and lifestyle. So, if you’re up for the challenge, then the Paleo diet is the right choice for you!  

Featured Image: EasyPaleo.com

Sheet1.Title: 5 Paleo Snacks to Blow the Lid off Carrot Sticks
Sheet1.Meta Description: What’s the best option to fight drowsiness and hunger? Paleo snacks! These recipes are designed to keep your blood sugar levels stable and energy high.
Sheet1.Content:
A Peak Into our Pantry: The Most Mouthwatering Meals You'll See This Week.

We know that life gets hectic and busy; sometimes it feels like there just aren’t enough hours in the day. While you’re on the go or at work, you don’t always have the time to eat a delicious and nutritional meal. You might go for what is most convenient; perhaps an energy drink, candy bars, or chips in the snack machine at the office. The problem with those is that they actually do more harm than good. While they do give you a short sugary energy boost, you will end up finding yourself crashing hard shortly after and feeling worse off over time. Why? The sugar from those products is let into your blood stream far too quickly, then your blood sugar levels drop and you are left to crash and burn. So, what’s the best option to fight drowsiness and hunger? Paleo snacks! They process differently in your body and are designed to keep your blood sugar levels stable and under control. They pack in the nutrition and give you clean raw fuel and consistent energy to power through your day. They are tasty little treats that will make your tummy happy. Whenever hunger strikes, keep these snacks in mind when you want some Paleo deliciousness:

Smoothies: Who doesn’t a love delicious and fresh smoothie? Packed with antioxidants, vitamins, and minerals, smoothies are a perfect pick me up. Try Parsley and Pear (with apple, plum, banana, and avocado) or a refreshing Paleo Peach Coconut Smoothie. Can you say, YUM! Add a hard boiled egg on the side for some extra protein and you’re good to go! How to

Tomato Pesto Bites: Grab some cherry tomatoes with some extra-virgin olive oil, garlic, basil, and grated Parmigiano-Reggiano. Slice a section from the bottom (enough for them to stand up) then slice off the top, scoop out the seeds and stuff them with the blended pesto/basil/garlic/Parmigianino Reggiano. Drizzle some olive oil and a dash of salt and pepper to taste! How to

Avocado Egg Salad Lettuce Wraps with Bacon: Easy and oh so delicious. Lettuce wraps with bacon, avocado and egg. Grab an avocado, 4 hard-boiled eggs and some other simple ingredients with some bacon and your mouth, as well as your body, will thank you. Are you salivating yet? I am! How to

Fig and Strawberry Cashew Bars: Figs and strawberries, some sweet and succulent honey and coconut oil. Add some cashews and that’s all you need for a healthy and scrumptious snack. Life can’t get much better. How to

Paleo Hummus and Veggie Slices: All you need is cauliflower florets, some yummy spices, lemon juice, garlic cloves, olive oil and an oven and you’re set! Then, add all of your favorite veggies and dip away into mouthwatering bliss. How to

These snacks are just a few of the hundreds of delicious and amazing Paleo foods out there. Think of your body as a fancy sports car, in order for that car to run properly and smoothly-it must have the best fuel. Now picture your body as that car- by eating Paleo, you are filling up your vehicle with the best, raw, and healthiest ingredients there are. Don’t forget your AMRAP 100% Paleo Refuel Bars for some added awesomeness. By all means, eat up and enjoy all of them-we probably will beat you to them. Note: For full recipes and instructions visit references below.

Sheet1.Title: 2 Pieces of Advice for Running Endurance Training
Sheet1.Meta Description: As a ultra and marathon runner, I used the Boston Bound program for 13 weeks. Based on my experience, here are the best tips for endurance training running.
Sheet1.Content:
Endurance sports are pretty popular these days. Marathons, Triathlons, Spartan Races, GoRuck Challenges, the list goes on and on. Most inspiring athletes that I meet want to attempt their first marathon, and some of the wilder ones want to try a full on Ironman or Ultramarathon.   I’ve run five marathons, four half marathons, and an ultra marathon. I’m a healthy amateur, a naive enthusiast. I’m your average American endurance athlete. Recently I started endurance training under the Boston Bound marathon program. The good news is I made it to the end; the better news is I learned a great deal about myself from it. I will tell you that if I can do it, so can you. The first thing I will say before we move forward is this--Have some standard. It’s important for endurance training–it’ll keep you moving forward. It’ll make you faster. It’ll keep you healthy. Constant moderate athletic training literally strengthens your DNA on a cellular level. Your cells will replicate less frequently–all 37.2 trillion of them.1 You’ll actually live longer.   Second, Endurance training is a lot to take in and you need to be informed. You will improve your performance gains if you learn a few key concepts before training. There may be a quiz afterwards. Here are some the concepts I found most useful: Anaerobic: Short-term endurance exercise. This will be exercise that is performed very close to lactate threshold (higher intensity) and lasts for a much shorter period of time, usually around 1 to 3 minutes. Aerobic: Long-term endurance exercise. This is exercise that is performed further from the lactate threshold (lower intensity) and lasts for a much longer period of time, usually more than thirty consecutive minutes. VO2 Max: A measurement of how much oxygen your body is able to consume and use efficiently while exercising. Stated in milliliters of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute. Solely having a high VO2 max does not necessarily mean you will be extremely capable in terms of endurance performance, as performance will also depend on your individual lactate threshold.2, 3 Lactate Threshold: How rapidly your body is able to remove the waste product of lactic acid (produced in higher intensity). If your body is efficient at removing this waste, then you will be able to exercise for a much longer period of time. If you are looking to improve upon your performance, training to increase your VO2 max and lactate threshold is beneficial. It’s like recovering from the sprint while you’re still in the marathon.4, 5 Glycolysis System, Endurance training relies largely upon this, the energy system that takes place with the presence of oxygen and can burn carbohydrates and fat compounds for fuel. It’s only when you push it to high intensity that you’ll begin to approach your lactate threshold or VO2 max. Glycolysis is the sugar breakdown, the energy releaser, and the pyruvic intermediate.   Now that you know your body, let’s hit the road and pound some pavement. The Boston Bound program will get you Boston Strong in no time. Well, maybe in about 13 weeks. Here are a few pointers from the great Hal Higdon for Boylston Street success in Boston.6   Monday: Easy. Days with short runs that begin at 3 miles in the first week, and then move upward to 4-5 miles. The main purpose of the workout is to do some easy miles while recovering from a hard workout and getting ready for another one. Do this on a treadmill, and then do some strength training. Run between 65-75% of your maximum heart rate (MHR). Tuesday: Fast. Run fast 800 repeats at the track, or hill repeats that could be almost any length between 200-800 meters, as long as running up it pushes you into the 80-90% maximum zone. Because Boston is a downhill course, run every 3rd repeat downhill to strengthen your legs for the gravity pounding they’ll get in the marathon–that’s a lot of net force. You can’t fight it, but you can train for it. Wednesday: Easy. Similar to Mondays, do a short and easy run today, coupling this run with some stretching and strength training (weightlifting, calisthenics). Stay in the 65-75% comfort zone. Thursday: Fast. You’ll do a Tempo Run these days. Tempo Runs are where you start easy at a jogging warm-up pace 60-70%, then after 1-2 miles, begin to gradually accelerate to 80-90% of your maximum heart rate. Then, after holding that fast pace for 3-5 minutes, gradually decelerate and finish the run at the same pace you started. Friday: Rest. This is your R&R day in the program. You need to be well rested to obtain maximum benefit from the tougher workouts on the weekends. You’ll thank me later. Trust me. Get injured and your dreams fall faster than a miler’s pace. Saturday: Pacing. Runs vary from 4-8 miles with half of them done at marathon pace, aim for 75-80% MHR. Do several test races, measure your fitness level and to provide motivation. Do a 5K or 10K and even a half marathon. Pace yourself, do the laps. Make ‘em count. Sunday: Long. Run your best effort. It doesn’t matter how far or fast you run in your allotted time; just get running. Stay in the 65-75% MHR zone. Your goal at Boston also should be to finish faster, or as fast, as you started out. Aim for negative splits, it’s what the pros do.   So now you’re educated and you have a plan. Here are some tips: Shorter runs are from 2-12 miles. Longer runs are from 12-24 miles. You never run 26 milers until race day. It’s bad luck. Plus, runners always need a little naivety during their marathon. It’ll keep you jovial, and competitively arrogant. You’re going to need it. Running 26.2 is crazy. To some it may even seem insignificant. But it’s very important that you do it. As for me, I follow suit with the legendary Ultra runner David Goggins: “I’ve done a lot of things that I thought were impossible. And, nothing’s impossible anymore.”   Featured Image By: Gregory J Fisher

Sheet1.Title: Fight Inflammation with A Single Plant
Sheet1.Meta Description: Fight inflammation with food. Beets have a high dose of antioxidants in combination with a complete range of amino acids help your body process and repair.
Sheet1.Content:
If you were told that you could eat a single plant that could fight inflammation, lower your blood pressure, boost your stamina, protect against cancer, rid your body of harmful toxins, and nourish yourself with a wide array of nutrients; you would want a bite, wouldn’t you?   Well let’s start with a little introduction to this magical red vegetable. While holding to the many health benefits above, beets introduce a new class of vegetable that no athlete or health conscious mind could refuse. With a full spectrum of vitamins, minerals, amino acids, and other beneficial nutrients in just a single serving—you too can enjoy the little things. For a single serving of just one cup, beets will provide you a few initial perks: 1  
  • 75 calories
  • 3 grams of protein
  • 16 grams of carbohydrates
  • 4 grams of fiber
  • 148 grams of water
  It's not the macronutrients that deliver the most impressive health benefits. It’s the micronutrients that are going to blow you away. Take this table of benefits for example.   Table 1- Vitamin and mineral values for beets
Vitamins/Minerals Amount/serv. DRI/DV
Folate 136mcg 34%
Manganese 550mcg 27.5%
Potassium 518mg 14.8%
Copper 130mcg 14.4%
Magnesium 39mg 9.7%
Phosphorus 65mg 9.2%
Sodium 131mg 8.7%
Vitamin C 7mg 8.5%
Iron 2mg 8.0%
Vitamin B6 110mcg 6.5%
Vitamin B2 70mch 5.4%
Vitamin B1 50mcg 4.5%
Selenium 1.2mcg 2.2%
Zinc 600mcg 5.4%
  From a health standpoint, beets are a force to be reckoned with when it comes to a nutrient dense food source. With a high dose of manganese and vitamin C, these antioxidants in combination with a complete range of 18 different amino acids help your body process and repair. With branch chain amino acids (BCAA), Essential amino acids (EAA), and Non-essential amino acids (NEAA)—they’ve got your muscles covered. 1   But the most important health aspect to beets is their phytonutrient contents. Beets have a very unique phytonutrient that goes by the name of betalain. There are two basic types of betalains, one being betacyanins and the other betaxanthins. These two phytonutrients are responsible for the true color of the beets themselves. Betacyanins give the red-violet color you commonly see, while the betaxanthins give off a certain yellow color. You can tell just by the color of the beet which of the two phytonutrients is most dominant. The two most reputable, and highly studied betalains within beets are betanin— a betacyanin, as well as vulgaxanthin—a betaxanthin. These two phytonutrients are what provide the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and detox support within this single red plant. 1   You can do more than fight inflammation with food like beets. One of the more popular topics of conversation with the beet is their high nitrate content that can attribute to lower blood pressure and an increase in stamina. In the human diet we receive about 60-80% of nitrates (NO3-) from plant and vegetable sources. Oral consumption is the most efficient way to increase nitric oxide production within the body. By ingesting inorganic nitrates the body is then able to convert those nitrates into nitrites from enzymes within the mouth and throat, and finally the stomach takes those nitrites and produces nitric oxide. Just with the nitrate consumption from a serving of beets, you are able to reduce the O2 cost of submaximal exercise and improve the efficiency of your muscle’s oxidative metabolism.2

Sheet1.Title: Flavored Nut Butters: Spiced Cashew
Sheet1.Meta Description: Flavored nut butters are an easy way to add healthy fats and delicious tastes to snacks and meals. Ready in minutes and packed with nutrition.
Sheet1.Content: Nut butters — like almond, cashew, and sunflower seed — are a delicious way to get healthy fats into your belly! There are some creative commercial blends out there, but they can be expensive. Here's the wonderful secret: flavored nut butters are SUPER DUPER easy to make. This recipe uses cashews, which get nice and creamy when blended, with cumin (my favorite spice!), a touch of cayenne, and a hint of honey. The result is a spicy-sweet-salty combination that's tasty and good for you. In less than 5 minutes, unsalted nuts go from bland to BAM! and this recipe is friendly and forgiving; you can make it with almonds, pecans, sunflower seeds, or a blend of nuts to create your own personal flavor.   Spicy Cashew Butter Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups unsalted, dry roasted cashews 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1/4 teaspoon ground cayenne pepper 3/4 teaspoon salt 1/2 – 1 tablespoon honey, to taste Directions: 1. Place the cashews, cumin, cayenne, and salt in a food processor, and process until it forms a paste, about 6-10 minutes. 2. Add the honey and process until combined and smooth. 3. To eat it, a spoon is really all you need, but you could also spread this on pear and apple slices, or top a roasted sweet potato with a spoonful for a luscious, nutrition-packed side dish. You can also use it in this recipe for a burger topped with nut butter and jelly, or go classic with ants on a log.

Sheet1.Title: How to Crack a Fresh Coconut
Sheet1.Meta Description: Easy steps to crack a fresh coconut. Sweet, creamy, delicious, and an excellent source of healthy fat.
Sheet1.Content:
Dried, unsweetened coconut cannot compare to the fresh, tender, lightly sweet, oh-so-creamy texture of fresh coconut that you've cracked and grated with your own two hands (and some very common tools). Until recently, my "technique" for cracking open a coconut was to put it in the sink, hope for the best, and bash it with a hammer until it stopped being so darn stubborn. Now I've found a better way. Good news! You still get to use a hammer. How to Crack a Fresh Coconut 1. Preheat the oven to 350F. 2. Place the coconut on a kitchen towel for traction. Pierce the three “eye” holes on top of the coconut by gently tapping a clean screwdriver with a hammer. This is much easier than it seems. 3. Drain the water from the coconut— you can catch it in a glass and drink it, if that's your thing — and put the coconut in the oven, directly on the oven rack, for 10 minutes. 4. Remove the coconut from the oven, wrap it in a kitchen towel, place it in the sink, and smack it with a hammer to crack the shell. The white coconut meat should easily pop out of the thick shell. You might need to hit the pieces a few more times to break them into smaller, more manageable chunks; wrap the pieces in the towel every time. 5. You can either remove the thin brown skin with a vegetable peeler or just leave it on. (It doesn't seem to affect flavor or texture if you leave it on.) 6. Now you can either shred the coconut in a food processor or with a box grater, or make “chips” with a mandoline slicer (so later you can make these Caramelized Coconut Chips). Store the fresh coconut in a covered container in the refrigerator until you’re ready to use it. It holds up for 10-14 days. To toast fresh coconut: Spread it on a baking sheet in a single layer and toast in the 350F oven for 5-8 minutes. Keep an eye on it! Coconut browns quite quickly.  

Featured Image: Myfitnesspal

Sheet1.Title: Cocoa-Toasted Cauliflower
Sheet1.Meta Description: Toasted in the oven with cocoa and the warmth of paprika, cauliflower overcomes its good-for-you reputation.
Sheet1.Content: Hypothesis: Cauliflower is the most versatile vegetable in the kitchen Proof: It can be (1) grated in a food processor and sautéed with fat and spices to make Cauliflower Rice; (2) boiled in broth and mashed with coconut milk (or a dollop of homemade mayo), to make a luscious substitute for mashed potatoes; (3) added raw to salads to add a big crunch; (4) puréed with a little coconut milk and bone broth to make a comforting soup and (5) roasted in the oven to become crisp-tender and way more exciting than you ever thought cauliflower could be. Cocoa-Toasted Cauliflower Serves 2-4 | Prep 10 minutes | Cook 30 minutes Ingredients: 1 head fresh cauliflower 1 teaspoon paprika 1 teaspoon unsweetened cocoa 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper 1 clove garlic, minced (about 1 teaspoon) 2 tablespoons coconut oil Directions: 1. Preheat the oven to 400 F. Cover a baking sheet with parchment paper or aluminum foil. With a sharp knife, remove the core of the cauliflower and break it into florets. Place the florets in a large mixing bowl. 2. In a small microwave-safe bowl, mix the paprika, cocoa, salt, pepper, and garlic with a fork. Add the coconut oil and microwave for 15-20 seconds until the coconut oil is melted and the spices are fragrant. 3. Drizzle the spiced coconut oil over the cauliflower in the bowl, then toss with two wooden spoons until well coated. This should take at least 2 minutes. Name a food for every letter of the alphabet to amuse yourself while you toss. Do a taste test and adjust the seasonings. 4. Spread the cauliflower in a single layer on the baking sheet and roast in the oven for about 25-30 minutes, until it’s tender and starting to get nice brown spots.

Sheet1.Title: Jalapeno Cranberry Sauce
Sheet1.Meta Description: Forget about the magenta-colored, "is it really food?" stuff that wiggles its way out of the can every November. This jalapeño cranberry sauce is real food.
Sheet1.Content:
Spicy, Tart, Sweet, and Tangy

Forget about that magenta-colored, "is it really food?" stuff that wiggles its way out of the can every November. This cranberry sauce is real food. And it's spicy, tart, sweet, and tangy — perfect with roasted chicken or pork any time of year. Why wait for Thanksgiving to celebrate this nutrient- and flavor-packed berry?! You can make this cranberry sauce several days in advance; the flavors mix, mingle, and mellow after a day or two in the fridge. Jalapeño Cranberry Sauce Makes about 2 cups | Prep 20 minutes | Cook 15 minutes Ingredients: 4 dried dates 1 large orange 12 ounces fresh cranberries 1 tablespoon coconut oil, melted 3/4 teaspoon salt 4 whole cloves 2 sticks cinnamon 1 small jalapeño, stemmed and thinly sliced Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 450F. Cover a large, rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper or aluminum foil; set aside. 2. Remove the pits from the dates and place in small bowl. Cover with boiling water and allow them to soak until soft, about 10 minutes. Drain off the water and place the dates in a food processor; purée until smooth. 3. Using a peeler, remove the peel from the orange, taking off as little of the white pith as possible. Cut the peel into very thin strips about 1 1/2 inches long. Squeeze the juice from the orange and set aside. 2. In a bowl, combine the peel, date purée, cranberries, coconut oil, salt, cloves, cinnamon sticks, and jalapeño. Toss well and transfer to the baking sheet. Roast until the cranberries begin to burst and release their juices, about 10-15 minutes. 3. Transfer the cranberries to a bowl and stir in 2-3 tablespoons of the reserved orange juice. Let the flavors meld for at least an hour, but you can store in the refrigerator for a week or so. Remove the cinnamon sticks before serving.

Sheet1.Title: CrossFit Walter Reed
Sheet1.Meta Description: CrossFit Walter Reed is a non-profit affiliate gym with a social mission: to put the swagger back in athletes injured in the military.
Sheet1.Content:
CrossFit Walter Reed - Therapy for Military Veterans

[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bGSmbh1nCnY[/embed]   CrossFit is Therapy for Military Veterans This not your usual story about CrossFit and injuries. In fact, most viral stories revolve around the controversy over the high rate of injury related by the fitness model.  Instead, CrossFit is now a space for injured military athletes rehabilitation. CrossFit Walter Reed is a non-profit affiliate gym with a social mission: to put the swagger back in athletes injured in the military.  A missing leg, a brace, emotional duress—these are no longer a reason for able-bodied athletes to regain their fitness and health pre-injury. The affiliate is owned and run by trainers who are not just certified, but have a military service background as well. These trainers work through unique and differing challenges with all injured athletes in their gym. How do they do this? CrossFit’s corporate office helped—donating all the equipment to this unpretentious box space. But really the methodology guides most of the work. The daily workout for gym members is the same.  And this is where the genius of CrossFit’s methodology gets special. The fundamentals of training offer ultimate scalability and are applied to each athlete in respect to their injury or limitation. The workouts may be modified, but these athletes get to business. For the first time since their injury, military athletes are building their bodies back to 100% pre-injury fitness levels. Some even surpass their previous fitness levels. It’s almost unimaginable for Not many therapy programs like this exist for wounded military veterans. CrossFit Walter Reed offers more to military men and women than physical regeneration; it gives athletes a chance to regain the blow to their ego and build an empathetic network. In a group environment, where everyone is subjected to similar duress and physical struggle, a renewed camaraderie is created with the gym community; something many of these athletes lost after their service career ended. This video demonstrates hope and genuine satisfaction. CrossFit has become an invaluable place for our country’s servicemen and women to regain what has been lost.  The trainers at CrossFit Walter Reed are inspiring a movement, and we at AMRAP support it wholeheartedly. Share what they are doing well. That’s the best way you can help.
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Lifestyle Design | Viral Videos

Sheet1.Title: CrossFit WOD - 18 Signs You're addicted to CrossFit
Sheet1.Meta Description: Even if you are not overtly insane about CrossFit, you will be surprised that a number of these still describe you. Probably more than you would like to...
Sheet1.Content:
18 Signs You are Addicted to CrossFit

Wake up thinking about the CrossFit WOD? Okay, yeah this list is spot on.  Tell yourself that self-awareness is a good thing and keep reading. Even if you are not overtly insane about CrossFit, you will be surprised that a number of these still describe you. Probably more than you would like to admit. We are right there with you. Like number 8. Yes, we do get nervous before workouts. The difference is, we sit in our office or our car, not basements. Also, who is ever excited about a jog? Maybe your dog, but he gets just as excited about poo. A simple jog means little especially if you don’t have the common sense of urgency and duress as you get in the CrossFit group. And to be fair, summer swim team meets in sixth grade were just as exhilarating. At AMRAP, we have to ask, isn’t it nice to feel revved up about something as much as you were as a hormonal pre-teen? Yes. It is. So don’t feel completely ashamed. There are good elements to this list. You’ll see. Like number 12. This is one we have serious beef with and thank you Greatist for pointing it out. Protein shakes are bad, why?  CrossFit at its fundamental level has always intended to differentiate athletic performance from the rest. Good nutrition has always been at the core of CrossFit. Yet, with time bad habits have formed. And it really needs to stop. Athletes are not making informed choices. Most of their supplements stink At AMRAP, we have made a concerted effort to return ourselves and other CrossFit back to basics. There is no reason to be eating a milkshake disguised as a health supplement or snickers disguised as a protein bar. In fact, we made our own nutritional supplement solution. A full line of nutrient dense supplements to deliver our bodies the fuel necessary for continued long-term performance. Not to brag, but the gains our bodies have seen on this stuff compared to the thinly disguised sugar pills put is in “beast mode”. Yes, we just went there. Alright, you’ll want to see all 18 by now. So read them all HERE.

Sheet1.Title: Lindy Barber - A Recovery Comeback
Sheet1.Meta Description: After collapsing in a workout, Lyndy was diagnosed with 3 spinal diseases and told to take up a different sport with less impact on her lower back...
Sheet1.Content:
Lindy Barber - Spina bifida, Scoliosis, and Spondylosis

I Just Want To Be A Games Athlete, Said the Girl with a Split Vertebrae Lindy Barber was told she could never squat again. Never great news, even if you are not training for the CrossFit Games. After collapsing in a workout, Lindy was diagnosed with 3 spinal diseases and told to take up a different sport with less impact on her lower back--like endurance running for example. Not exactly sure where the logic came for that conclusion. However, we do know that Lindy Barber competed in the 2013 CrossFit Games. What the what? How did she manage it? That was the first question I thought. Almost immediately, the second question came to mind: is she being reckless? No, not exactly and here’s why. Lindy took a calculated risk coming back to CrossFit after her injury. Emotionally, I get her. She has been an athlete her entire life; Lindy loved competition. She lived for it. Naturally, she was unwilling to accept her diagnosis as a crutch that would rule her daily decisions. She had a mission to overcome injury. The end of that mission was the finish line of 90 foot weighted lunge at the CrossFit Regionals competition. What she did with her fitness before then made all the difference. She recovered slowly and rebuilt her body gradually. Lots of walks, lots of pushups and pullups--strict to build muscular strength again around her injury. Lindy allowed two years of recovery and physical strengthening. She refused to have an injury refine her potential and worked consistently to make her solution. After two years she made it to the Games. [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MWwobEbaac4[/embed] The will not be everyone’s story. Some injuries or limitations might make it impossible to get to your pre-injury potential. The keyword is might. You have more control over your fitness and health than anyone else. Deal with everyday, but don’t allow injury to define who you are or who you can be in life. That’s our philosophy at AMRAP Nutrition. We are in the business of helping our community of athletes reach their potential through good food and quality information. Join our newsletter for more inspiring messages to fuel your personal goals. Video Compliments of: ShaughnTillmanFilms

Sheet1.Title: Crossfit Training - Fight Fatigue the Way you Fight Fires
Sheet1.Meta Description: “In Crossfit, just like firefighting, we use every muscle in our body. The workout literally defines itself as a program that will best prepare….
Sheet1.Content:
CrossFit Training and Firefighters

Male or Female -- Fight Fatigue the Way you Fight Fires I don’t think many of us are called fat and predicted for failure on our first day to a job. It happens. That’s what Scott Ziegler was told the day he walked into a Detroit Fire Department. It just so happened to be true. That first day was trial by fire; house after house, his six man crew stomped out fires. Ziegler was nearly overrun. He put his crew was at a terrible disadvantage. The firefighting industry is inscrutably team-oriented. Each member is essential to the process and continued stamina of the group. There’s no time or energy to spare for extra weight. Zieglar’s weight needed to go. In this case, it was actually life-threatening to the whole group. Today, Zieglar is still a firefighter. He is also a CrossFit coach. Why did he choose CrossFit to get in shape? What about running or weightlifting? Here’s how he put it: “In Crossfit, just like firefighting, we use every muscle in our body. The workout literally defines itself as a program that will best prepare trainees for any physical contingency.” If Zieglar had followed a more conventional path to weight-loss and muscle strengthening, his body composition would surely improve especially if paired with proper nutrition. Still, he would be lacking the most important component of fitness: functional movement and high intensity endurance. “Every workout you do in a Crossfit gym will push your body in a way similar to what a house fire does. It will push you to the point of pure exhaustion. And if you train your body to push past that while you are off duty, you will be that much better at doing it when it really matters.” The only way Zieglar can say that he has the best job in the world is if he is physically prepared to meet its demands. CrossFit helped him get there. More than that, CrossFit’s constant variance keeps it interesting and engaging. Our company uses the fitness methodology to get more out of our day. We aren’t slaying fires in urban Detroit, but we are mobbing down mountain bike trails, hiking with our kids, and skiing in the backcountry. Enjoy the active parts of your life; follow AMRAP to get more insight and support for your improved health and fitness.   Read the Original article HERE

Sheet1.Title: How to Supplement Your Diet Without Hidden Reverse Effects
Sheet1.Meta Description: Comparing fast food to performance supplements sounds dramatic, but the American health crisis is proof of this problem. Avoid common unhealthy supplements.
Sheet1.Content:
The Similarities Between Fast Food and Performance Supplements is Shocking

If you won’t eat fast-food because of how unnatural and unhealthy it is, why would you take supplements without checking the ingredients? Television ads, magazine articles, and promotional marketing peddle some pretty horrific chemicals looking for a quick-buck for "fools" seeking a quick-fix. Even if you make the added effort to read the label on your protein powder or pre-workout, manufacturers often hide chemical additives. While it sounds dramatic comparing fast food to performance supplements, the health crisis in America is proof of this problem. First, remember that there are no shortcuts to a healthy lifestyle. Results aren’t instantaneous. The tortoise beats the hare, the rabbit is smarter than the panther, and all things worth achieving takes hard work and sacrifice. Learn how to avoid health traps via bad supplements by first understanding the risks of processed performance supplements. Nutritional supplements and various medications may have severe side effects on your body. Don’t buy them without thinking of the consequences of these products. One quick Google search, and you'll find  that most supplements are never as healthy as as they seem.1 Consuming them can lead to common side effects:
  •      Liver Damage
  •      Kidney Failure
  •      Heart Attacks
  •      Risk of Cancer
  •      Addison’s Disease
  •      Anosmia
  •      Weight Loss
  •      Erectile Dysfunction
  •      Odorous Gas
Here’s what the American College of Physicians have to say about the supplements you’re using: “Their use is not justified, and they should be avoided. Supplementing the diet of well-nourished adults with (most) mineral or vitamin supplements has no clear benefit and might even be harmful. These vitamins should not be used for chronic disease prevention...In fact, some supplements even cause harm, such as high doses of vitamins A and E that may increase risk of death.”2 Stop taking supplements that you don't understand or can't trust. Go for natural unprocessed nutrient rich foods. Eat Paleo! Eating food with high-quality meats, seafood, fruits, vegetables, nuts, and seeds provide you with nearly all the vitamins, minerals, and nutrients your body needs. That said, there is a place for select food-based supplements, like omega oils, super greens, beet concentrate, that can make up for nutrient deficiencies in your diet and promote positive changes in the body. A tried and true rule of thumb: If you can’t even pronounce the ingredients on the back labels–you shouldn’t consume them–they’re probably made in a laboratory. Don’t be a lab-rat.  
References: 1. Parulkhani, (2014, March 12). 10 Reasons to Say No to Those Health Supplements. Retrieved from: http://listdose.com/10-reasons-to-say-no-to-those-health-supplements/ 2. Guallar, Eliseo, MD (2013, Dec 17). Enough Is Enough: Stop Wasting Money on Vitamin and Mineral Supplements. Retrieved from: http://annals.org/article.aspx?articleid=1789253

Sheet1.Title: Shari Keener - Changing the Pattern
Sheet1.Meta Description: 75 Pounds and Addicted to Meth, Shari Keener Changed Her Life Through CrossFit
Sheet1.Content:
Shari Keener - Back Story

75 Pounds and Addicted to Meth, Shari Keener Changed Her Life Through CrossFit If you take a look at Shari Keener, you would never guess her past. The woman is a chisled. Healthy skin, healthy hair, excellent fitness--she looks and performs like a lifetime athlete. The real story though is not so neatly written. Shari will be the first to admit, at one point in her life she was a wreck. She lost the first half of her life to addiction, and now she’s starting over. “If I don’t do something, I am going to die.”  Shari came to a point in her life where she needed to find a way to dig herself out of her current pit. Shari got clean at 24. At first she started running. Drug addicts have a gap for the yearning. For her, running started to fill the yearning gap. then came CrossFit. “You are going to be addicted to something in your life. The only way you change negative behavior is to channel that energy in a positive direction.” [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_vkOCqVM3E4[/embed] For Shari, CrossFit was a positive extension for her addictive personality. It is highly intense and constantly challenging. CrossFit is an outlet for natural human tendencies to reach a full color experience, so to speak. It can be made even more powerful when it changes the pattern of someone’s downward spiral and turns them into a force for good. Today, the bad in Shari’s early life fuels her daily efforts. She overdosed, dumpster dived, lost her fiance to drugs, but Shari found a way to use those experiences to empower herself and others. She is thankful to run, to work for clients that can identify with her experience, and mostly to have the energy to raise her kids. Its up to her to change to pattern for her kids. She ensures their future with her honest past experience and positive outlook. Her daughter graduated with honors and is going to college and her son is on the same track. We believe that fitness is a powerful tool for every person, no matter when they recognize it. Shari is the perfect example of that.   Video compliments of: CrossFit®
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Health Tips | Success stories | Viral Videos

Sheet1.Title: Box of Salvation - A Story About Eating Disorder Recovery
Sheet1.Meta Description: Cheryl was hospitalized and placed into rehab for a third of the year in 2009. This is a story about her eating disorder recovery through CrossFit training
Sheet1.Content:
A Story About an Athlete with an Eating Disorder

 

Not many stories change pace like Cheryl Nasso’s. For five years, Cheryl fell deeper and deeper into an eating disorder. At 85 pounds, she was in the worst shape of her life and in critical condition. Cheryl was in rough shape.   Cheryl was hospitalized and placed into rehab for a third of the year in 2009. The most productive rehabilitation turned out to be when she started training with CrossFit. This is a story about her eating disorder recovery.   In two years, Cheryl went from a malnourished fragile lady to one of the top 50 fittest women in the world. She made it to the CrossFit Games in the pinnacle of health. And she didn’t do it alone. Here's a peak at her story in a minute forty: [embed]http://vimeo.com/35354976[/embed]   In one light, Cheryl is making up for lost time. CrossFit training gives her the opportunity to channel her frustrations and disappointments in a positive direction. Along the way of her transformative health journey, Cheryl found a compelling new sport and a tight-knit community.   Everyone in the gym is Cheryl’s coach, guide, and friend. Their love and support gave her the strength to shift her mindset and work towards her full fitness potential.   To us, the most special and unique feature of this story is Cheryl’s newly found family. Cheryl is a testament to the powerful support network that comes from the health and fitness community, especially CrossFit.   That is a major reason AMRAP Nutrition is in business. Actually, it is the top reason. From the CEO to the customer service and sales department, we are members of the fitness community dedicated to providing athletes the best source for convenient nutrient dense foods.   The Box of Salvation is a powerful documentary. Add it to your must watch list. Full Length: [embed]http://vimeo.com/82749462[/embed]   Now that you have a reinforced appreciation for good food and great nutrition, check out another weight transformation success story of an AMRAP guest blogger and get her killer Paleo Apple Crumble recipe.

Sheet1.Title: 33 Paleo Snacks That Help Fuel Fat Burn
Sheet1.Meta Description: Satiate your hunger with paleo snack foods that deliver nutrients and healthy fat for long-lasting fuel. Fat-adapted bodies use high fat low carb for energy
Sheet1.Content:
Become Fat-Adapted: Your Body Will Shed Weight With the Right Foods

  One of the biggest benefits from the Paleo diet is that the foods that you will be eating will cause you to want to eat less. This is not a joke. Its time to understand how you are feeding your body and how it should be nourished.   Taken from Paleolithic history, human bodies have adapted by learning to hold onto their most efficient fuel source until it was most needed. And that is why we store fat on our bodies. But we can teach our bodies to use this stored fuel instead of just holding onto it. Once you’ve become fat adapted, you’re body will literally begin to shed excess weight.   “By switching to a high fat, low carbohydrate Paleo diet, you can teach your body to begin using it’s fat stores as energy. Essentially you become a fat burning machine.”   One caveat.  Losing weight requires a calorie deficit.  Most of the foods listed below are higher in calories due to their high fat content. The biggest benefit to these foods is that they will satiate your hunger, making you want to eat less.   Long lasting fuel for the busy athlete is the main focus at AMRAP Nutrition. Using the same ideal carb to fat ratio, AMRAP Bars come in three flavors and offer you the nutrition to become fat adapted and churn fat stores into energy.   Your body demands variety as much as it does fat. AMRAP Bars are loaded with natural foods, oils and spices. The combination of flavors is cleverly crafted to be silky and bold. Order from one of the three flavors of AMRAP Bars--Almond Honey, Cashew Vanilla, or Fig and Cacao, HERE.   Don’t forget to supplement your AMRAP Bars with more snack ideas for added variety. Skim the 30 Paleo snacks that can help get your fat burning furnace started, listed HERE.

Sheet1.Title: Back to Basics: Clever Paleo Meal Planning
Sheet1.Meta Description: If healthy living was easy, everyone would do it. My most valued piece of advice, especially when first transitioning to Paleo, is to keep meals simple.
Sheet1.Content:
One of the things that I have had difficulty with on the Paleo diet was how much effort it took incorporating it into my life. I currently work a full-time job and have hobbies and activities on top of that, as I'm sure most people do. Completely changing your lifestyle can not only be stressful, but it can make it easy to revert back to old habits due to the simple fact that it may not be sustainable in the long run. Well, I'm here to tell you that the Paleo diet can not only be sustainable, it can actually be stress-free and less time-consuming when planned appropriately! It's time to be clever about meal planning if you want to establish a reliable routine. When beginning any new task, I tend to over-organize. My job requires me to micro-manage everything, and I take pride in accomplishing that most of the time. Because I enjoy it and am successful at it, I tend to have this same mentality in my personal life as well. I have learned that by pre-planning and by tackling the biggest time-consuming tasks at a time when you have the most free time, it can make for a smooth and organized work week. Here are some steps that I still continue to practice to this day that have made it that much easier to stick to my health routines:
  1. Make a plan. Create a meal plan for the week so that there are no surprises, and so you know what you need to purchase when buying groceries for that week. Not only will you save money by only buying what you need, you also won't be tempted to eat that chocolate ice cream you bought at the grocery store "just in case" because it won't be on your list (at least we hope!). Making a list also means less time at the grocery store aimlessly wandering the aisles, wondering what the best choices are (you can find me doing that at any given time I don’t take the effort to write down what I need beforehand).
  2. Prepare as much as you can in advance. Twice a day, for breakfast and lunch, I have a fruit salad. Every Sunday, I wash, prepare, and cut all of my fruit so that I won't have to spend so much time throughout the week doing it. You wouldn't believe how much time this saves! It also keeps me accountable. I won't be tempted to make excuses as to why I didn't eat healthy ("I didn't have time to prepare!" If you're anything like me, you've used this excuse at some point). Sometimes I'll even portion out my fruit into smaller containers for each meal so that they are more grab-and-go. I also pack my lunch the night before so I'm not trying to put something together when I'm half-asleep in the morning. It wouldn't be a pretty sight. I'm in no way, shape, or form a morning person.
  3. Make multiple servings of everything. If you're planning on cooking one of your meals that week, cook it the night before or the first night that you start your work week and make plenty of leftovers! It's so much easier and quicker to only have to spend one night cooking away in the kitchen, as long as you don't mind the repetitiveness of having the same meal for dinner more than once a week.
  4. Don't try to be the next Emeril right away. I'm always so tempted to try and cook something extravagant from my meal plan the first week I've started. What ends up happening is me realizing that I don't have enough time laid out in the week to cook such complicated recipes, so I end up finding something quick, easy, and not that healthy to eat for dinner. Instead of reaching for the stars right away, ease into a routine. Once it becomes easy to manage, then tackle those recipes! It'll seem a lot easier to manage once you've adapted to the Paleo lifestyle.
  5. Always have something quick and easy to grab in an emergency. I used to make portioned bags of my own homemade trail mix that were super simple to throw together and were great to take with me just about anywhere. Just mix together a combination of any of these Paleo-friendly ingredients:
    • Almonds
    • Pecans
    • Walnuts
    • Pumpkin seeds
    • Sunflower seeds
    • Dried cherries
    • Dried apricots
    • Raisins
    • Apple chips
    • Shredded coconut
My favorite trail mix combination is almonds, apple chips, raisins, and dried cherries. Yummy! It's really important to plan when practicing any healthy lifestyle. If it were easy, everyone would do it! My most valued piece of advice, especially when first transitioning to Paleo, would be to keep it simple! Here's an example of one of my typical Paleo meal plans: Breakfast: -2 microwaved eggs ("over hard") seasoned with salt and pepper -2 cups of fresh fruit salad -Black coffee with Stevia and coconut milk Snack: -Trail mix (see above for ideas!) Lunch: -Garden salad (greens, onions, tomatoes, cucumbers, shredded carrots) with olive oil and balsamic vinegar "dressing" -1/2-1 whole cooked sweet potato with cinnamon and butter Dinner: -Grilled chicken breast seasoned with dried seasonings -Steamed vegetables (broccoli, carrots, zucchini, summer squash) seasoned with salt and pepper The Paleo diet can sometimes be hard to start, especially with some of the restrictions that the diet requires. By going "back to basics" and keeping it simple, you can make some lifestyle changes that will stick with you, and not quick "fixes" that may lead to going off-plan. Once you see the benefits of eating whole, real foods, the rest will fall into place! Happy planning!  

Featured Image By: nomnompaleo.com

Sheet1.Title: Round out Your Endurance Training With This Shark-Weekly WOD
Sheet1.Meta Description: Swimming is crucial to any well-rounded athlete. Evaluate your current endurance training, and build on it with this proven CrossFit swimming endurance WOD.
Sheet1.Content:
Are You a Shark or a Guppy? Analyze Your Endurance Level and Progress

  As apex predators on land, we’re unstoppable. We trap grizzlies, hunt lions, and ride bulls. Hell, we even do CrossFit. But get us into open water, and we’re no longer on the top of the food chain. Great White Sharks are the apex predators of the deep blue sea. They’re carnivorous. They're hungry. And they’re even Paleo (okay, I'm kidding).1 Although I don’t recommend going all ‘shark week’ on your Paleo diet, you ought to be diving into the pool and turning your guppy-like endurance into some serious apex strength. Swimming is crucial to any well-rounded athlete. The healing properties of water are fantastic, the fluid motion for your body is opulent and tranquil. The sub-surface elements can be exerting, but they’ll help build the inner shark inside of you too. In fact, your body exerts 75% more energy moving through water than it does air. Talk about a tough training session! If you can fight the fluid friction of the pool, you’re athletic prowess on land will increase exponentially–talk about beast-mode. Great White Sharks swim about 25 miles/hour. While our finest Olympian, Michael Phelps, clocks in at about 5 miles/hour. However, sharks only have a cruising distance of about 1.5 miles in one hour, which means we’ve got them beat in endurance–ask any triathlete. You may not be able to outswim a shark, but you can out-train them! Let’s build up that endurance, shall we. In order to boost swimming endurance you need to hop in the pool three times per week, allowing moderate rest in between and cross training. No need to speed through these workouts, just keep building on this water WOD with efficient form. Here’s a freestyle workout to get you started. As the weeks pass, continue to increase your mileage. When you’re ready, start swimming some different strokes.2 Here's a great workout to start (and scale as needed): WOD Shark-Weekly
  •      Warm-up: 300 yards
  •      3 x 100 yards — easy
  •      Intervals: 400 yards
  •      2 x 200 yards — build speed
  •      Endurance: 400 yards
  •      1 x 400 yards — moderate
  •      Warm-down: 200 yards
  •      4 x 50 yards — easy
  •      Total: 1300 yards — easy.3
Get ready to swim with some Great Whites! (Kidding again). Although, while many people consider sharks to be the world's deadliest animal, you're actually more likely to be killed by hornets, wasps, bees, or dogs.4  Just follow this challenging weekly WOD and boost your much needed swimming endurance. Every week can be shark week!
References: 1. Bullock, Nicole (2012, Aug 14). Shark Speed: The World’s Fastest Sharks. Retrieved from: http://visual.ly/shark-speed-worlds-fastest-sharks 2. Robertson, Doug (2014, Oct 30). 6 Sets To Build Swimming Endurance. Retrieved from http://www.active.com/swimming/articles/6-sets-to-build-swimming-endurance 3. Bibb, Emily (2013, Oct 17). Kick Start: Work Up To Swimming A Mile! Retrieved from: http://www.popsugar.com/fitness/How-Build-Endurance-Swim-Mile-7215546 4. Facts, Sharks (2014, Oct 30). Shark Week: Shark Load of Facts. Retrieved from: http://www.discovery.com/tv-shows/shark-week/shark-facts/top-100-shark-facts.htm

Sheet1.Title: The Anti-Inflammatory Diet Grocery List
Sheet1.Meta Description: Eating healthy is important; follow an anti-inflammatory diet and give your body an opportunity to repair and rebuild inflamed areas.
Sheet1.Content:
And Why You Should Have Gone Shopping Yesterday

  Inflammation isn't cool-- in most scenarios. It’s a common thing that we’re all too familiar with. Any daily WOD or endurance race is bound to leave us feeling a little sore. Our muscles and bones are always at a constant war with gravity and friction. Earth is a rough place. And, since we can’t partake in Zero-G CrossFit just yet, we’ve still got to fight the furious flames inside of our bodies. Pain, heat, redness, swelling, loss of function, and general soreness are all common types of inflammation.1 Ever wonder how pro athletes train, compete, and repeat for a living? They’re experts at controlling the inflammation in their bodies that would otherwise hinder their ability to trounce their competition. They eat right and in turn, their bodies allow them to train 6-7 days a week as hyper-successful athletes. Inflammation is your body’s attempt to protect itself from harmful stimuli. Not only does it affect your body, but it impairs your cognitive abilities and can lead the declination of your overall mood. It’s also linked to Arthritis, Rheumatoid Arthritis, and Alzheimer’s. If you don’t play it safe and fight inflammation with the right food, you might as well quit playing. “You don’t get another chance, life is no Nintendo game.”2 But, you've got me, so lucky you. When you stuff the right stuff into your stomach, inflammation becomes both preventable and treatable, and Autoimmune diseases may, in fact, become self-treatable. (A close friend of mine, was diagnosed with arthritis, after a paleo-nutrition makeover, she's now 100% arthritis-free. True story.) So listen up, this may just save you from the fire inside you.  

Foods that cause inflammation:

  •  White Sugar, Sweets
  •  Alcohol
  •  Iodized Salt
  •  Fried Foods
  •  Dairy
  •  Wheats, Grains
  •  Processed, Packaged, and Not Paleo!

Foods that fight inflammation:

  • Veggies: asparagus, beets, broccoli, carrots, cauliflower, celery, cucumber, kale, mushrooms, onions, parsley, radish, spinach
  • Fruits: apples, apricots, avocados, blackberries, blueberries, cantaloupe, cherries, honeydew melon, kiwi, lemon, lime, papaya
  • Protein: chicken, eggs, turkey, trout, salmon, halibut,
  • Beverages: herbal tea, green tea, purified water, coconut water
  • Oils: coconut, grape seed, flax seed, avocado, & walnut oil
  • Nuts/Seeds: almonds, walnuts, cashews, macadamia nuts, and sesame, hemp, sunflower, & ground flax seeds
  • Condiments: fresh herbs, spices, sea salt, peppercorns.3
  Eating healthy is important; follow an anti-inflammatory diet and give your body an opportunity to repair and rebuild inflamed areas. Many autoimmune diseases are completely preventable through proper diet; don't kid yourself into thinking this is another fad or the flavor of the week. Fast, fried, packaged, and processed food–you might as well just go to the doctor and ask for influenza. Remember, “if you don’t recognize an ingredient, your body won’t either.”4 Instead of getting old and flamey, let’s get wise and strong. Every passing minute is another chance to turn it all around.5  
References: 1. Dombrowsky, Stacey (2013, April 24). Inflammation and Nutrition. Retrieved from: http://staceylovenlife.wordpress.com/2013/04/24/inflammation-and-nutrition/  2. Valpone, Amie (2014, Oct 30). Amie’s Anti-Inflammatory Grocery Guide. Retrieved from: http://thehealthyapple.com/anti-inflammatory-grocery-guide/  3. Mathers, Marshall  (2014 Oct 31). Eminem: Love The Way You Lie Lyrics. Retrieved from: http://rap.genius.com/Eminem-love-the-way-you-lie-lyrics#note-18675 4. “Fit Foodie” Lisa (2013, May 29). Clean Eating For The Food Lover. Retrieved from: http://fleurtyfitfoodie.blogspot.com/2013/05/if-you-dont-recognize-ingredient-your.html 5. Crowe, Cameron (2001). Vanilla Sky Script - The Dialogue. Retrieved from: http://www.script-o-rama.com/movie_scripts/v/vanilla-sky-script-tom-cruise.html
