Sheet1.Title: Winning Kettlebell Strength Training
Sheet1.Content:
If you buy nothing else, invest in a kettle bell. Here's why...

  CrossFit is the only reason I’ll step foot inside of a gym anymore. I’m not much of a gym guy; maybe you're the same. I love the outdoors. Nature is rough and beautiful. The elements are uncompromising. A rowing machine isn’t on a river. A treadmill is not the open road. I can’t run 26.2 on a quarter mile track. The stair stepper is not a mountain. But it makes my time outdoors actually enjoyable. I'm not huffing up the mountainside, like my lungs will burst from my chest at any given moment. The one  piece of gym equipment that stands superior to most exercises either inside or outside of the gym is the kettlebell. No other device offer the kind of cast-iron, heavy feel, and ballistic benefits an active body needs. Kettlebell strength training will make you earn it. You’ve got to train hard and dirty, until your muscles bleed lactic acid. (Then cool down).  

Where did kettlebell strength training originate from?

“Nobody owes nobody nothing. You owe yourself.”

Kettlebells made their way to Russia at the beginning of the 18th century, the kettlebell was used as a weight to measure grains and other goods. Russian culture views strength as an honorable quality so Russian Dr. Vladislav Kraevsky, the founder of heavy athletics, travelled through Europe gathering info about the physical culture of sports intending to find new ways to improve health, well-being, and physical education. Upon returning to the Motherland, the doctor introduced exercises with kettlebells and barbells to the Russian athletic community. The rest, as they say, is history.1 The best solutions are often the simplest, so no matter how technologically advanced gyms become, athletic technology peaked with the kettlebell. It has lead the pack of old-school training implements. Kettlebell  swings are metabolically demanding. They recruit a large muscle area, and reinforce key athletic movements like hip flexion and extension. Power exercises, like cleans and snatches will help you build champion coordination total-body strength. They’re not the easiest to master and require adequate technique as strength.2  

How to apply kettlebells to your strength training regimen

“Going in one more round when you don’t think you can, 

that’s what makes all the difference in your life.”

Kettlebell Swing–targets shoulders, back, hips, glutes, and legs. (Lightweight) How to: Stand up straight, with feet a bit wider than hip-distance apart. Grab the handle with both hands, keeping your palms face down and your arms in front of the body. Maintain a slight bend to the knee and drive the hips back, lowering the body. In a fluid motion, explosively drive the hips forward while swinging the kettlebell, keeping the glutes and core engaged. The motion should come from the hips as the body returns to standing. Lower the weight back down between the legs and keep this swinging motion going for more reps.

Goblet Squat–targets legs, glutes, and back. (Welterweight). How to: Stand up straight, holding the kettlebell in front of the chest with both hands, keeping the elbows close to the body. Start squatting by driving the heels into the ground and pushing the hips back until the thighs are parallel to the ground or just below. Return to standing, and repeat.

Russian Twist–targets abs, and obliques. Level: (Middleweight). How to: Sit with the legs bent and feet flat on the floor, about hip-distance apart. Hold the kettlebell with both hands at the chest, and then lean back to a 45-degree angle. Rotate the torso from left to right by twisting at the waist and swinging the kettlebell across the body.

Single-Arm Snatch–targets: Shoulders, chest, back. (Heavyweight). How to: Start with a kettlebell between the feet with the knees bent. Explode onto your toes the kettlebell until it reaches your chest with your elbow tucked in. From there, bring the weight overhead, then bring it back down close to the ground.3

“The world ain’t all sunshine and rainbows….You, me, or nobody is gonna hit as hard as life.

But it ain’t how hard you hit; it’s about how hard you can get hit, and keep moving forward.

How much you can take, and keep moving forward. That’s how winning is done.”

References: 1. Wesley, Corey (2014, Nov 7). Kettlebell Science: History Of The Kettlebell. Retrieved From: http://www.kettlebellscience.com/kettlebell-history.html 2. Cotter, Steve. (2014, Nov 7). Full Body Kettlebell Workout. Retrieved from: http://www.muscleandfitness.com/workouts/workout-routines/full-body-kettlebell-workouts 3. Schwecherl, Laura (2014, Sep 19). 22 Kick-Ass Kettlebell Exercises. Retrieved from: http://greatist.com/fitness/22-kick-ass-kettlebell-exercises 4. Stallone, Sylvester (2014, Nov 7). Top 7 Rocky Balboa Quotes. Retrieved from: http://make-me-successful.com/top-7-rocky-balboa-quotes/

Sheet1.Title: 3 Cycling Training Tips to Boost Power
Sheet1.Meta Description: Cycling is key to building leg muscles that are energy efficient and meticulously strong. Combat poor performance with 3 cycling endurance training tips.
Sheet1.Content:
Cycling endurance training meets powerlifting

Cycling is key to building leg muscles that are energy efficient and meticulously strong. Building this endurance is your salvation to fighting poor cycling performance. To endure when you’re fatigued. Cycling is an aerobic activity. It involves free oxygen and denoting exercise that improves the efficiency of your body's cardiovascular system when absorbing and transporting oxygen. As your bike fights through the friction of the wind, your body fights for oxygen, thrives on it. Strengthening cycling endurance improves your muscles intake valves, those organically mechanical machines that fuel your muscles and fan your wheel power. It also improves your efficiency, as your stronger muscles work together with increased finesse, their movements more fluid. It's actually pretty cool. Trust me, there's a science to all of this.  

Cycling Anatomy:

Power Phase–From the top pedal position, cyclists utilize their hip extensors, the gluteus maximus muscle,  initiating the power-phase. Then, the knee extensors activate, vastus lateralis and vastus medialis, generating force, which is prominent while out of the saddle on vertical gradients. Then, plantar flexion occurs due to the gastrocnemius muscle, pointing the toes outwards. Recovery Phase–The tibialis anterior draws the toes up towards the shins, a dorsiflexion motion. Then, the semimembranosus, semitendinosus and biceps femoris pull the heel upwards toward the buttocks. Finally, your hip flexors of the liacus and Psoas finish off the pedal stroke.1 Equilateral Efficiency: Cycling Strength–push pedals past that high resistance marker. Athletes with slow-twitch muscles possess serious pumping power–good for grinding up those vertical roads. Cycling Speed–turn pedals rapidly for those revolutions per minute. Athletes with fast-twitch muscles possess serious cheetah speed–highly developed–up to 150 rpms. Cycling Power–the bridge between both strength and speed: maximum force, minimal time. Think of it like equilateral efficiency. Tweak your muscles, and turn your wheels.2  

Training Regimen:

Long Rides: 25-50% Your cycling training  needs one weekly long ride. The target of a long ride is to build up basic endurance by cycling long distances and building up mileage. Cycling long distances at this level  helps build your endurance by developing muscles that can push on for hours. Interval Rides: 50-75% Interval rides develop speed, and aerobic/anaerobic capacity, and resistance to fatigue at high speeds. Keeping short recovery periods between the sprints allows more training at these speeds. A great target is to develop maximal speed for shorter endurance distances.This is beneficial for lowering your heart rate. Tempo Rides: 75-100%. Tempo rides develop powerful aerobic capacity and resistance to fatigue. The tempo parts recommended to be ridden at top speeds in order to build fatigue resistance at typical racing speed and to improve performance in the lactate threshold.3  

Lesson Learned:

Knowledge about cycling endurance is a win-win scenario. You’ll become a smarter, more efficient cyclist. Your body will thank you later as the benefits of cycling are profoundly healthy. “The bicycle is the most efficient machine ever created: converting calories into gas, a bicycle gets the equivalent of three thousand miles per gallon.”4 Now, that's cool.  
References: 1. Hallam, Liam (2014, Nov 7). Leg Muscles Used In The Cycling Pedal Stroke. Retrieved from: http://hubpages.com/hub/Muscles-groups-used-while-cycling 2. Burner, Feed (2014, Nov 7). Speed, Strength, and Endurance. Retrieved from: http://cyclingtips.com.au/2009/09/speed-strength-and-endurance/ 3. Electro, Polar (2014, Nov 7). Endurance Program For Cycling. Retrieved from: http://www.polar.com/us-en/support/tips/Endurance_Program_for_Cycling 4. Strickland, Bill (2013, Mar 26). 25 Quotes About Urban Cycling. Retrieved from:  http://www.slideshare.net/recuperandolacalle/25-quotes-about-urban-cycling

Sheet1.Title: 5 Types of CrossFit Athletes
Sheet1.Meta Description: There are many different types of CrossFit athletes at your local box. Here are 5 types of CrossFit athletes we all know and respect.
Sheet1.Content: No two CrossFit athletes are exactly the same. However, just about every one of these workout beasts fits into one of several categories. Here are 5 types of CrossFit athletes we all know and respect: Old-School Warrior (OSW) He attacks the box like a badger on a juicy grub. He’s been like that since he was a teenager — about three decades ago. He’s not the biggest guy, and his hairline leaves something to be desired, but OSW is a stone-faced warrior who never even considers giving up. This guy wears tube socks and a ratty Talking Heads T-shirt, but what he lacks in style he makes up for in positive energy. He keeps the whole room excited about the WOD. Strong, Silent Type (SST) You know that guy who never smiles and rarely speaks? Yeah, he might have the last laugh. He’s all about the business at hand: Becoming a fire-breather. SST lets his reps do the talking — and it seems to be working for him. He’s quick to help, never verbose and devoted to his workout. Tough Mother (TM) The Tough Mother is that tiny 35-year-old mom of three who roars into the box at the speed of light. She still needs to get home, make dinner, help the kids with homework and prepare for that big presentation at work. TM is 5-foot-nothing, 100-and-nothing, but she juggles a career, marriage, kiddos and much more with ease — so 3, 2, 1, GO doesn’t make her nervous. Not even a little. New Guy (NG) The New Guy is really nervous as he tries to avoid embarrassing mistakes and stay out of people’s way. Little does he know that everyone around is simply super stoked that he decided to improve his lifestyle. NG is afraid to ask questions but eager to learn, so offer good tips whenever possible. Loud and Proud (LP) At first glance, Ms. Loud and Proud is all show. She grunts, screams and wails like a madwoman. She treats the box like her own personal megaphone. But don’t be mad at her. She’s not trying to be the center of attention. It’s just that screaming works for her. It’s the best way for her to attack her GPP. You probably know CrossFit folks who fit in these categories and others. Let’s value their differences. After all, we’ve all pushing toward a common goal: great health that maximizes our abilities.

Sheet1.Title: Avoid Sugar, Live Paleo During Holidays
Sheet1.Meta Description: Sugar becomes quite popular during the holiday season. You can live paleo during holidays by avoiding the refined sugar frenzy.
Sheet1.Content:
Enjoy Your Holiday Celebrations Without Sacrificing Health or Fitness

From workplaces to living rooms throughout the U.S., refined sugar is ready for its close-up. The holiday season is upon us, which means more cookies and cakes than you can shake a sleigh bell at. For those of us devoted to CrossFit fitness and the Paleo lifestyle, this seasonal sugar craze is pretty gross and alarming. It’s like a bonanza of refined sugar, and it comes at us from all angles:
  • Office parties
  • Family gatherings
  • School programs
  • Church fundraisers
  • Appealing grocery-store displays
As Paleolithic eaters and serious athletes, we know the pitfalls of refined sugar. We know that to be better than yesterday, we have to be serious about how sugar affects our health, regardless of what our friends and family members are doing. We recognize that refined sugar increases risk of heart disease and many, many other health problems. Plus it drastically limits our day-to-day energy and vitality. But seriously, unless you live in a cave, it’s impossible to put sugar completely outside your line of sight during the holidays. Here are a few ways to enjoy this special time of year while keeping your nutrition principles intact:
  • Find recipes that are healthful and flavorful — The Internet is your friend as your search for Paleo-friendly holiday treats. That means you can have Christmas cookies or Pancakes at Christmas morning brunch, just like everyone else, except without the guilt.
  • Bring fruit, not fudge — If you’re on your way from the WOD to the office party, stop at the grocery store for some fruit. Yes, that’s sugar — but at least it’s the kind our ancestors were eating.
  • Concentrate on working out — When your lazy uncle is sitting down to watch a third consecutive football game, why not head to the box? Even without refined sugar, chances are you’re eating a bit more food than usual. So, make up for the extra calories with a killer, beast-like performance at the gym.
  • Grab a bar on the run — In a pinch, don’t rely on whatever “naughty” food might be lying around your mother’s house. Be “nice” with a blitz of energy from a bar or veggies.
No one ever said the holiday season would be easy for Paleo eaters. But it doesn’t have to be a bummer, either.
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | How To | Nutrition Hacks | Rant/Rave

Sheet1.Title: Beets by Paleo: How to Make Beet Juice
Sheet1.Meta Description: Making beet juice is easy and simple. Juicing or blending beetroot allows you to get all of the vitamins and nutrients in a condensed form.
Sheet1.Content:
Making beet juice is easy and simple. With all of health benefits it provides such as lowering blood pressure, increasing blood flow, it’s anti-inflammatory properties, not to mention it is loaded with antioxidants and is rich in nitrates, you are probably wondering why you’ve gone so long without this magic juice. Juicing or blending beetroot allows you to get all of the vitamins and nutrients in a condensed form. Here are some easy ways to get juicin’!1 With a Juicer:
  •      One to three fresh beets
  •      Paring knife
  •      Juicer
Instructions: Wash beets well and remove any dirt or mud from the surface. Cut them into quarters- you can keep the greens and use them for later or discard them. Turn on the juicer and insert beets until you have your desired amount of juice. With a Blender:
  •      One to three fresh beets
  •      Blender
  •      Pairing knife
  •      Vegetable peeler
  •      ¼ cup water
Instructions: Wash, clean, and peel beets. Chop as finely as you can-it will be easier for blending. Add beets with ¼ cup water and blend well.  If it is still too thick…add some more water until desired consistency. Strain the juice through a piece of cheese cloth to get the pulp and any large pieces of vegetable out. If you aren’t crazy about the taste- fear not. There are always ways to add some delicious and nutritious yumminess to your beet juice. Throw in an apple and a pear for some added nutrition and sweetness. If you’re looking for an added antioxidant boost-throw in a carrot, apple, a cup of green tea, one orange, and some fresh ginger! Pineapples and half a cup of papaya are also great to add to your juice for optimal digestion and cleansing out the liver. Beets are amazing to incorporate into your diet based upon their optimal health properties so have some fun, mix it up, and get juicing!
References
  1. Beth Assaf. (2006-2014). How to Make Beet Juice. Retrieved from http://vegetarian.lovetoknow.com/How_to_Make_Beet_Juice
  2. Pina LoGiudice ND, LAc and Peter Bongiorno ND, LAc Co-Medical Directors of Inner Source Health in New York. ( May 14, 2013). The Benefits of Beet Juice. Retrieved from http://www.doctoroz.com/article/benefits-beet-juice
Sheet1.Categories: Interesting Other | Nutrition Hacks | Paleo Recipes

Sheet1.Title: Foods that Fight Inflammation in the Body
Sheet1.Meta Description: foods that fight inflammation in the body
Sheet1.Content:
Reverse Harmful Inflammation for Better Mobility and Performance

  Many of us think of the world inflammation and assume that it’s bad. But, inflammation is part of the body’s natural immune response, it’s how we heal – it brings nourishment and immune reinforcements to the site of injury/infection. However, issues start to arise when inflammation persists and has no real purpose, often causing damage to the body and leading to illnesses such as chronic inflammation or rheumatoid arthritis. There are steroids and other treatments to try to combat chronic inflammation, but diet plays a very large role as well. Specific foods aid in reducing inflammation and it is important to be educated about which are the best for containing it and reducing your risk for future disease. Here at least seven of the best foods that fight inflammation in the body.1  
  • Fatty Fish- Oily fish such as salmon, mackerel, tuna, sardines. Their high content of Omega-3 fatty acids aid in reducing inflammation, to get benefits it must be eaten several times a week. If you’re not a fish fan, fish oil supplements are something to consider as well.
 
  • Dark Leafy Greens- Vitamin-E is essential for fighting inflammation. Get your leafy greens on with dark green veggies such as spinach, kale, broccoli, and collard greens. Darker veggies also have higher concentrations of vitamins and minerals such as calcium, iron, and other disease fighting phytochemicals (occurring in plants).
 
  • Nuts- Almonds are high in fiber, calcium, and vitamin-E. Walnuts have alpha-linolenic acid, a type of Omega-3 fat. Nuts are packed with antioxidants that can help your body repair the damage caused by inflammation.
 
  • Peppers- Color, color, color! Colorful veggies are important to your diet in general. They are high in antioxidants and help lower starch levels. Bell peppers come in many colors, and chili and cayenne pepper can be used as toppings. Despite their fiery flavor, they actually turn down the heat on inflammation!
 
  • Fruit- Especially berries. Fruits are low in fat and calories, high in antioxidants. Berries have anthocyanins, which aid in reducing inflammation and give them their rich color.
 
  • Beets- or beet juice. You have to forgive these guys for their less than desirable Earthy flavor because honestly- they are simply amazing. Loaded with antioxidants, they reduce inflammation, protect against cancers and heart disease, lower blood pressure, and are even rich in fiber and vitamin C–what can’t these guys do? You need them in your life, and your body will continually thank you.
 
  • Other Options- Ginger and turmeric, garlic and onions, soy, tomatoes which contain lycopene that help reduce inflammation in the lungs, tart cherries, tea, and extra virgin olive oil are all excellent.
  What’s important is that most of these foods need to be eaten consistently. You can’t eat some fish and veggies for a night and expect to see dramatic changes. These foods are intended to help your body maintain optimal health while influencing the inflammatory process with the ultimate goal of reducing harmful inflammation. Incorporating these wonder foods into your diet is something to consider. Not only will your health improve because of the great benefits of anti-inflammatory foods, but they are the key to fighting the fire from the inside!  

Featured Image By: Breakingmuscle.com

References:
  1.  Amanda MacMillan (2013, June 19). ABC News: 14 Foods that Fight Inflammation. Retrieved from http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Wellness/14-foods-fight-inflammation/story?id=19421185#
  2.  Jessica Chia (2014 Oct 31). 10 Foods that Fight Inflammation. Retrieved from http://www.prevention.com/food/food-remedies/10-foods-help-fight-inflammation?s=9
  3.  WebMD (2014 Oct 31). 4 Inflammation-Fighting Foods for Rheumatoid Arthritis. Retrieved from http://www.webmd.com/rheumatoid-arthritis/ra-foods

Sheet1.Title: Happy Tummy: Paleo Snacks For Kids
Sheet1.Meta Description: When it comes to food, we all know children can be tricky, not to mention picky. These Paleo snacks for kids deliver nutrition, fun, and flavor.
Sheet1.Content:
So you’re all about Paleo. You’re eating right and feeling good. Life couldn’t get much better, right? However, there is one pressing question if you have kids or watch kids….what are some good Paleo snacks for them? When it comes to food, we all know children can be tricky, not to mention picky. So, how do you give them proper nutrition without sacrificing flavor, funds, and fun? These Paleo snacks for kids will take pain away:
  • Organic Applesauce – Try “Go-Go Squeeze” and their delicious flavors.
  • Grapes – Most kids love these tasty purple berries.
  • Hard Boiled Eggs – Protein for kids. You can get creative with this option.
  • Paleo Blueberry Muffins, Banana Bread – mouthwatering.
  • Fruit Kabobs – Stack your little ones favorite fruit in this style, healthy and happy!
  • Pudding – We know the kiddos love this! Paleo friendly chocolate pudding or oatmeal raisin
  • Paleo Trail Mix – Perfect for car rides.
  • AMRAP Bars - convenient, crazy healthy, and tasty. Our kids love all 3 flavors
  • Avocados – Add some lime juice, throw ‘em on top of a salad, or in an easy on-the-go wrap.
  • Fruit with Almond Butter – Try “Justin’s All Natural” pouches for delicious flavors including chocolate and    honey-maple syrup.
  • Gelatin Snacks- Homemade fruit snacks and gummies to Kombucha Jell-O. “Great Lakes is a great brand.
  • Smoothies- Add some fruit, or fresh spinach and kale, or coconut milk into your kiddo’s favorite smoothie.
  • Paleo Thai Chicken Pizza- A personal favorite of complete, yummy, deliciousness.
Whether its Paleo tortilla chips, or guacamole, Paleo chicken strips, or Jimcama fries, there’s a plethora of possibilities. Sometimes it gets hard to be creative and keep your kids’ meals interesting among the midst of a crazy work-week, school, and the daily stressors. We know it gets hectic. These are just a few examples we love. Eating right and showing your kids the importance of Paleo nutrition from a young age will start them with a solid foundation for the rest of their lives. You shouldn’t have to break the bank. There is so much fun and easy Paleo out there. Enjoy this time with your little ones, create things together, and experience how fun and beneficial Paleo is for everyone. The links for full recipes are found below. Get your creative juices flowing, happy Paleo and enjoy!  
References:

Sheet1.Title: Fish Oil Benefits Brain Function
Sheet1.Meta Description: Fish oil benefits brain function in a large capacity and influences long term health and physical performance. Learn the extent of fish oil body benefits.
Sheet1.Content:
Optimal benefits of fish oil when you can't stomach the taste

  Why fish oil pills? First, fish are an important component to a healthy diet. Oily fish like salmon, mackerel, tuna, and sardines should make up a regular portion of your meals because of their optimal health benefits. However, we know that not everyone is a fish fanatic. If you are one of those people and worry that you wont receive the health benefits, fish oil supplements are a great alternative to consider without having to taste our little fish friends.   Fish oil contains high levels of Omega 3-Fatty Acids, including Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) and Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA). These acids are especially important to obtain from our diet because our body does not produce them naturally on its own.   It is great for your heart and blood, balancing cholesterol levels, protecting your bones, and promoting healthy brain function. We need Omega-3s as well as Omega-6s for healthy body function. It’s important to keep these two types of omegas in balance as they both work together in reducing inflammation and promoting cardiovascular health.1 Here are some more awesome benefits of fish oil:2  
  • Helps prevent heart disease
  • Lowers blood pressure
  • Reduces inflammation
  • Boosts immune system
  • Lowers Triglycerides (fats related to cholesterol) for improved balance of cholesterol levels
  • Promotes bone health and bone density
  • Used to prevent Glaucoma, dry eyes, age-related Macular Degeneration
  • Aids with autoimmune diseases such as Rheumatoid Arthritis and Lupus
  • Used for Diabetes, Asthma, and pain and swelling
  • Great for hair, skin, and nails
  • “Brain food” – improves brain function, aids in mental health, boosts Serotonin production, manages stress
  The last bullet may be the best singular benefit of fish oil supplements. Fish oil benefits brain function in a large capacity and influences your long term health and physical performance. To reach your full potential, you need your wits about you. One thing to be cautious of is the quality. When looking for fish oil pills, be sure to check for the highest quality and brands that have EPA and DHA content. With all of above benefits, it will help support the quality of your workouts and most importantly, improve your overall health. It’s okay to not like fish! What is important, however, is that you are getting all of the awesomeness that is fish oil into your body! For a healthy heart, mind, and body, fish oil pills are your answer.  
References
  1. Mark Sisson (2009). The Definitive Guide to Fish Oils. Retrieved from: http://www.marksdailyapple.com/fish-oil-health-benefits/#axzz3DQbGrQY3
  2. (2014) Fish Oil: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions and Dosing. Retrieved from: http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-993-fish%20oil.aspx?activeingredientid=993&activeingredientname=fish%20oil

Sheet1.Title: Rest Days Are Important Too: Don’t Leave Them Out
Sheet1.Meta Description: Rest days are important for athletes. Overworked muscles result in muscle exhaustion and poor form that leads to injury. Recognize signs of overtraining.
Sheet1.Content:
If you are sleep-deprived and striving for better fitness, this is for you.

  So you want to make some changes in your life; you decide to start eating healthy and working out. Perhaps you find Paleo and CrossFit, which, here at AMRAP is our go to, or you simply start buy more veggies and Zumba more often, we don’t discriminate! Great food and great exercise? We are all for it. However, what we will scold you about is rest. You aren't giving your body enough of it. Lack of rest has a huge impact on your muscles, body, and athletic performance. Many people are focused on “getting big”- spending hours in the gym and pushing their bodies to the limits through intense strength training or cardiovascular exercise, which in turn can increase your strength and stamina and even improve your mental health. And while we do love your go-getter attitude, over time, you will find yourself in a mean confrontation with the symptoms of overworked muscles. Overworked muscles can result in muscle exhaustion and breakdown, poor form that leads to injury, and cause harm to your body - which is the exact opposite of what you are striving for. In order for your muscles to grow and expand, they need time to rest and repair.  Often, if you haven't given your body adequate rest, you'll actually see more benefit from skipping your daily workout. Rest days are important; when ignored, you'll have these symptoms to be aware of. 1   Physical & Mental Signs of Over-stress: It is common to experience sore muscles and joints. Overtraining can lead to increased fatigue, irritability, feeling out of sorts, and in extreme cases-heightened anxiety and depression. It also affects performance, for example: If you can normally perform 12 squats with a 40-pound barbell, you might only manage 8 to 10 squats.   Other things to take note of are changing moods, having trouble relaxing or sleeping, sickness and injury, aches and pains affecting work performance and increased appetite. Overtraining can happen to almost anyone-fit or unfit, young or old- that develops an imbalance between training and recovery. 2 Fatigue, soreness, injury, irritability, affected performance- it is easy to see the toll that poor rest takes on your body. Luckily, there are very easy and healthy ways to combat overtraining. Getting enough sleep, 8-9 hours a night is recommended and most importantly, if you are noticing signs of overtraining, be sure to take your rest days- at least one to two days between intense training to give your body proper time to recuperate. My best advice? Listen to your body, it won’t steer you wrong. Our bodies are simply amazing, they can handle just about anything we put them through- but we must not forget they need their rest too. They support us from the moment we are born until it is our time to go, so don’t forget to love your body and give it the proper rest it deserves. Get your rest days in, your body will thank you and in return- it will allow for your continued success.      
References
  1. William McCoy (January 3, 2014). How to Know if I’m Overworking Muscles. Retrieved from http://www.livestrong.com/article/512309-how-to-know-if-im-overworking-muscles/
  2. Shannon Clark (August 15, 2014).  How to Combat CNS Overtraining. Retrieved from http://www.bodybuilding.com/fun/how-to-combat-cns-overtraining.html
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Lifestyle Design | Performance Advice

Sheet1.Title: What the Gluten-Free Diet Fad Teaches You About Healthy Eating
Sheet1.Meta Description: If you have celiac disease or not, adopt a form of the gluten free diet fad to avoid mass amounts of starchy carbohydrates and processed foods
Sheet1.Content:
Learn to Avoid Starchy Carbohydrates and Processed Foods Through Gluten Free Guides

  The gluten free diet is considered the new fad in health and nutrition. Many of you may be thinking how much you love (or hate) being gluten free, and how your health isn’t at risk anymore since switching over. But the truth is, most of people don’t know why they need a gluten-free diet, or even what celiac disease is. Celiac disease is severe. It is also very rare. You may be telling yourself “I have celiac disease”, but the reality is only 1 in 100 individuals have it. That said, this autoimmune disease can have severe impacts on your health in the long haul, but if you’re diagnosed in your early years you can save some health issues by switching over to the gluten free diet. Whether you have celiac disease or not, you can all benefit from taking on a form of the gluten free diet. This structure will allow you to avoid mass amounts of starchy carbohydrates and processed foods that you probably don’t need to consume in the first place. Gluten is a protein that will be found in a few types of grains such as wheat, rye, barley, and triticale (cross between rye and wheat). So avoiding these types of grains really isn’t that complicated in the big picture. But the majority of us aren’t aware of "healthy" products that may be mixed with gluten containing grains, additives, or preservatives. The majority of food consumed in America’s diet contains some sort of these gluten filled grains and proves it hard to stray away from. Though most of your previous meals consumed bread, cereals, and grains; you can have a large selection of other types of grains and starches to choose from, these may include:
  • Amaranth
  • Arrowroot
  • Buckwheat
  • Corn and cornmeal
  • Flax
  • Gluten-free flours (rice, soy, corn, potato, bean)
  • Hominy (corn)
  • Millet
  • Quinoa
  • Rice
  • Sorghum
  • Soy
  • Tapioca
  • Teff
If your goal is to eat a gluten free diet to completely stay away from starchy carbs and grains then there may be a better alternative for you. This alternative has been around for thousands of years and has recently been reintroduced to our society. The Paleolithic diet, or “Paleo diet” have focused on the caveman foundations of health and recall the days of our hunting and gathering ancestors. The diet is simple and straightforward, this “Eat” or “Don’t Eat” structure can give you the general idea of how to eat and prepare meals. Try out these tasty Paleo recipes and snacks.  
References
  1. Mayo Clinic Staff (2011, Dec 20) Nutrition and healthy eating: Gluten-free diet: What’s allowed, What’s Not. Retrieved from: http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-living/nutrition-and-healthy-eating/in-depth/gluten-free-diet/art-20048530
  2. Loren Cordain, Ph. D. (2014, Oct 17) What to Eat on the Paleo Diet. ThePaleo Diet.com. Retrieved from: http://thepaleodiet.com/what-to-eat-on-the-paleo-diet/
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | Lifestyle Design | Nutrition Hacks

Sheet1.Title: Two Peas in a Pod: Paleo Diet and Exercise for Weight loss
Sheet1.Meta Description: paleo diet and exercise for weight loss
Sheet1.Content:
Two peas in a pod, butter and a biscuit, Batman and Robin, you get the point -whatever clever idiom you can think of, one that we go-getters love is Paleo and Exercise. They fit together flawlessly and make a perfect combination that incorporates eating right and staying active to live a long and healthy life. We all know that exercise is important, and we will talk major benefits later, but why Paleo? Why eat like a caveman? Well, to put it simply, our caveman ancestors were studs. They were lean, toned, strong, agile and healthy. They didn’t have near the levels of diabetes, obesity, or other major health problems and ailments that we face today. Their diets didn’t consist of processed and genetically modified foods loaded with artificial ingredients and excess sugar and fat. They also didn’t consume mass amounts of fast food. They ate clean, raw, nutritional foods that fueled their active lifestyles.  Paleo is fun and incredibly simple; it helps you do what you’re designed to do and eat the way that you were built to eat. Here are some more awesome advantages of going Paleo: 1 -       Consume whole foods that are unprocessed which reduces intake of artificial ingredients, preservatives, hidden sugars, sodium, and who knows what else! -       Rich in nutrients, vitamins, and minerals -       Rich in healthy fats and protein -       Provides stable and consistent energy levels -       Anti-inflammatory effects -       Muscle growth and improved endurance -       Lower risk of heart disease, diabetes, and cancer -       Better moods, mental clarity, clear skin, reduced allergies Living this lifestyle not only helps you look better, but you will feel better and improve your overall health, so what’s not to love? Going Paleo and exercising should be fun. Through a variety of new and exciting foods and exercises, you won’t get bored and it is something you can stick with for the long haul. Take a look at some benefits of daily exercise as well:   Exercise2 -Combats health problems and disease such as: diabetes, heart disease, osteoporosis, stroke, high blood pressure, and certain types of cancer, depression, and arthritis -Controls weight -Improves mood and boosts energy -Promotes cardiovascular health, increases longevity, reduces stress -Improves memory and helps you sleep better Can we get a WOW?! Combine the Paleo diet and exercise for weight loss and a myriad of other health benefits. These two as a pair are a match made in heaven and these are just some among the many and incredible benefits of Paleo and exercise. When looking at the rewards of what this combination can do not only for your body, your health, and your mind, it is clear to see that they are the simple key ingredients to the recipe for a long, healthy, and happy life.  
References:
  1. http://eatdrinkpaleo.com.au/paleo-benefits/
  2. http://paleoleap.com/exercise-and-paleo-lifestyle/
  3. http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/staying-active-full-story/
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Health Tips | Nutrition Hacks

Sheet1.Title: What is hidden in your supplements?
Sheet1.Meta Description: With dietary supplements launching in the health and fitness industry, we are vulnerable to bogus health products. Learn what is hidden in your supplements.
Sheet1.Content:
Warning Signs About Healthy versus Harmful Supplements

  With dietary supplements as popular as ever in the health and fitness industry, we are vulnerable to consuming everything labeled with promises and made up statements that guarantee unbelievable results in just one scoop. In reality, you probably have no idea what you are consuming or what it truly does to your body, but hey, getting huge right? It's time to learn what is hidden in your supplements. Have you ever heard the saying, “if you can’t spell it don’t take it?” Well this is a pretty good guideline to follow when taking many of these mysterious supplements. If you’re looking on the back of the bottle and notice an ingredient list with 46 words that appear to be in some other language, then you’re taking the wrong stuff. Consuming harsh chemicals and preservatives essentially poisons your body if consumed in large enough amounts. Though you may notice nothing when taking a small dose, the effects can start to take a toll on your body when taken for a long period of time. Many of these supplements actually mention to quit using for a few weeks after you have consumed the whole bottle. A few simple statements to be aware of when taking a product are:
  • An alternative to (or claiming to have similar effects to) an FDA-approved drug—e.g., “All natural alternative to JKL.”
  • “Do not take if you have any medical condition, if you are taking any prescription medications, or if you are pregnant.”
  • “May cause a positive result in a performance-enhancing drug test.”
So, when some of these companies sneak into the industry with their false claims and dangerous products, how do you know whom to trust? Well there are now some third-party certification programs that will take supplements and rate their ingredients on quality and purity. Though this isn’t the FDA, it will be your next best option for safety and information about supplements. USP, NSF International, Informed-Choice, and Consumerlab.com are the most trusted, and should be present on all your supplements. If you don’t see any of those third-party approval stamps, be aware of a few banned or dangerous ingredients you that you shouldn’t be consuming. A few popular substances that have been known to cause harm to your body when repeatedly taken include:
  • Ephedra
  • DMAA (1,3 dimethylamylamine)
  • Cathine
  • 1-androstenediol
With such a large product category and hundreds of options to choose from, finding the right supplement is something that should be taken seriously. It is important to know what you are putting into your body and finding a product with the best ingredients is key for your success. Your body supports you in everything that you do, show it some love and consideration when choosing supplements. For a complete list and recommendations, attached is the 2014 U.S. anti-doping agency prohibited list. Click here.   Featured Image: breakingmuscle.com
References
  1. Human Performance Resource Center. (October 17, 2014) Dietary Supplements: What you need to know to stay safe and avoid fraud. Retrieved from: http://hprc-online.org/dietary-supplements/dietary-supplements-what-you-need-to-know-to-stay-safe-and-avoid-fraud
  2. U.S Anti-Doping Agency. (September 11, 2013) The World Anti-doping Code: The 2014 Prohibited List International Standard. Retrieved from: http://www.usada.org/wp-content/uploads/2014-wada-prohibited-list.pdf
