Sheet1.Title: Skin Rashes – Determining if Gluten or Celiac Related?
Sheet1.Meta Description: I am a celiac who advocates to increase awareness of gluten intolerance skin rash issues and transitioned from a standard “gluten-free” diet to Paleo.
Sheet1.Content: Your happily living life and BAM, you are hit with these odd skin disorders out of nowhere. What is happening? Perhaps you have tried topical ointments or creams, antibiotics, or a plethora of other products in an attempt to clear up some skin disorder, they may have worked or not but the temporary solution is just that. Did it start due to your sudden change in diet or increase in exercise? This skin disorder came without warning; you maybe now feel that there must be something else as you have tried everything! It is possible that Gluten Intolerance or Celiac Disease may be at the root of your skin problems. Dermatitis Herpetiformis (DH) is one such skin ailment that occurs as a result of gluten. It is one of the “itches” that won’t go away without proper treatment. With a proper, simple and pain-free skin test (biopsy) your practitioner or nutritionist can determine if you have the auto-immune disease commonly termed Celiac Disease. As a Paleo recipe developer, researcher, writer, health advocate and author, I have a strong interest in issues relating to people of all ages and I like to see people properly informed and properly diagnosed. Anyone can get this skin disorder. Although dermatitis herpetiformis usually occurs for life once it appears, permanent remission is reported to occur in 10-20 percent of patients, usually after long-term adherence to a gluten-free diet. I am celiac, I have three kids, two with CD and the one has Dermatitis Herpetiformis (DH). Why all of a sudden may an adult get a gluten intolerance or celiac disease? Why are you just now experiencing a gluten intolerance skin rash? There are various reasons it can “turn on” in adulthood or the baby-boomer. One very common reason may be a stressful situation in one’s life. There is also the possibility that it had been there yet it surfaced with symptoms crying out louder now. Being properly diagnosed is the first and proper door to a correct handling, and once any ailment is correctly diagnosed life become much simpler. I was 7 years misdiagnosed and my life, my health and my well-being has been incredible ever since, upwards and thriving! DH was first described as a distinct clinical entity in 1884 by an American dermatologist, Louis Duhring. But it wasn’t until 1967 that is was actually linked to gluten sensitivity/intolerance. Instead of digesting gluten, the body fights it with an antibody (called IgA) that is produced in the lining of the intestines. When IgA combines with ingested gluten, the combine antibody/gluten substance circulates in the bloodstream and eventually clogs up the small blood vessels in the skin. The clog attracts white blood cells brought in by the body to fight the invasion. The white blood cells, in turn, release powerful chemicals that create the rash. Typically, DH is characterized by small groups of itchy blisters, often on red plaques, located on the back of the elbows and forearms, on the buttocks and in the front of the knees. But, the rash can occur in other places on the body, including the face, scalp, back and trunk. With a gluten intolerance or celiac disease the body has a greater inability to properly absorb and distribute nutrients and deficiencies in vitamins and minerals develop. You can do all the diets and exercises in the world and think you are doing the best for your body, but if you have this underlying gluten issue and are eating any gluten you will remain with this internal flare in your body - inflammation. The result will be a remaining rash. Vitamins A and D contribute to healthy skin. Vitamin A is consumed in controlling inflammations, so Celiacs need more Vitamin A to begin with. A case of dry or flaky skin, or chronic split heels could suggest either mal-absorption from undiagnosed gluten intolerance or malnutrition. A solution to these ailments may be a gluten free diet and even better, the Paleo diet! There are also creams and treatments that will aid in the healing and itching but the real culprit may be the gluten and the ailment will not truly go away until the culprit is determined. I highly suggests if any skin ailment is non-responsive to all you have tried, talk to your practitioner or nutritionist about testing for gluten sensitivities or celiac disease. Your world can change with the proper diagnosis and treatment. For more information email me. I welcome your feedback and questions always. I have worked in this field and with many groups, professionals, research scientists, universities, authors and organizations for many years. I am a celiac, one who has worked as an advocate to increase awareness of gluten intolerance skin rash issues and one who made the change from the standard “gluten-free” diet to Paleo. I have quite a bit of experience in these areas and I walk the talk and love to see others do very well, and be happy with their bodies.

Sheet1.Title: CrossFit Retrospective on Rhabdomyolysis Symptoms Onset
Sheet1.Meta Description: While athletes train to expand their limitations, bodies have a breaking point. Learn from Lewis Parker's retrospective on rhabdomyolysis symptoms onset.
Sheet1.Content:
Increase Fitness without Reaching Your Body's Breaking Point

Early signs of kidney failure and mild Rabdo are major red flags for a CrossFit Games athlete. Lucas Parker was facing this situation during the 2014 CrossFit Games.  Signs of extreme muscle fatigue, ketchup-colored urine, and disorientation plagued Parker's performance. He even kissed a stranger in the crowd, believing it was his girlfriend. It definitely was not. Now it is not uncommon for professional athletes to be under major duress during intense competitions. Heat exhaustion happens, but it's how athletes respond to these setbacks that inform our decisions about supporting serious competing in the CrossFit arena. You'll want to see how he describes the experience and his decision-making process to withdraw from the competition. As athletes we can learn a lot from the setbacks of other intelligent and driven professionals. AMRAP Nutrition staff utilizes the CrossFit methodology daily. It is a key component that drives our fitness goals and expands our potential.  Understand, that while we strive to expand our mental and physical limitations, our bodies have a breaking point. You don't want to hit that point, like Lucas Parker. Learn from his thoughtful retrospective. Parker experienced rhabdomyolysis symptoms onset from at least severe exertion and dehydration under hot temperatures. The more in-tune you are with your body's needs and current capacity, the faster you'll make progress without the continual stream of injuries and other setbacks. That starts with nutrition and hydration. To push harder, your body needs energy, strength, endurance; your mind needs clarity and grit. Turn to clever solutions devised to enhance athletic performance. We've created our own answer to the shortage of optimal athletic nutrition and our passing the bounty on to you.  Invest your health with our full line of nutrient-dense unprocessed food and supplements and experience the difference in your training. Without further ado, watch Lucas Parker's reflection on performance and setbacks at the 2014 CrossFit Games: [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3roT9Tt5E18[/embed]
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Nutrition Hacks | Performance Advice | Top 10

Sheet1.Title: How to Decline Food Without Declaring War
Sheet1.Meta Description: Health goals are often derailed during holidays, especially if others can't supportive or understand your goals. Use these tips to decline unhealthy food.
Sheet1.Content:
4 Graceful Tips to Decline Unhealthy Food During the Holidays

Not only is it difficult to stay on track during during holidays, it's difficult to have to say no to food temptations, especially when uncle Steve has made your favorite cookies, or Aunt Meredith has whipped up a batch of her famous loaded mashed potatoes. It's even harder to say no when these relatives then say, "Come on, just try a bite!" "One day won't make a difference!' Or my favorite one: "I made this just for you!" It can be so hard to not only overcome the temptation of the food itself, but the temptation to just say yes for fear of offending your family or friends. If your family is like mine, declining food is akin to rejecting your mom's love. [Tweet "If your family is like mine, declining food is akin to rejecting your mom's love."] By now, I have come up with a bag of tricks to skirt around such awkward confrontations. If you're choosing to stay on your healthy course throughout this holiday season, here are a few tips on how to say no to unhealthy food without being harsh.  
  1. Practice a polite exit strategy. I like to practice exactly what I'm going to say when someone offers me food before I even step foot into the event. It's important to make the conversation about your goals and your plan, without making it seem like you're not eating their food because it's not the best healthy option. Saying something like, "That looks delicious, but I'm limiting my plate to three choices today" doesn't insinuate that their dish doesn't look good or you don't want to try their food or that it isn't healthy enough; you're just giving yourself a limit. By keeping the conversation focused on you, you will avoid upsetting anyone.  
2. Put it on your plate, and leave it there. This may be too tempting to some people, but if you are in a situation where uncle Steve just won't let you leave without trying his baked beans, just put some on your plate and walk away. Later, when he's out of sight, either throw it away or give it to someone else. Sometimes you just have to fake it in order to save face, and although I'm a firm advocate of honesty, honesty may not be the best policy here. [Tweet "Pro tip: Don't want to offend foodies? Put it on your plate, and leave it there."]
3. Bring your own dish and pile it on your plate. Bringing your own plan-friendly foods not only makes it easier for you to stay on track, but it can also serve as a buffer between you and pushy party-goers. Pile a large portion of your dish on a small plate so that way when you are asked to sample another dish, you can say that you may try it later but already have a lot of food on your plate at the moment. [Tweet "Bring your own paleo-friendly foods makes it easier for you to stay on track and buffer between you and pushy party-goers. "]
4. When all else fails, fake it until you make it. Again, lying is never something I recommend, but telling a fib may be the only way to nip nagging questions in the bud. Tell them that you already tried it, and it was delicious/good/great/etc. Sometimes desperate times call for desperate measures, even if it requires you to tell a small "untruth." [Tweet "When all else fails, fake it until you make it. "]
It's extremely difficult to be on-plan during the holidays, especially if there are people in your life that may not be supportive or understand your goals. Be aware that they most likely mean well, it's just human nature to want to feed everyone and be a caretaker and good host or hostess. Hopefully by utilizing these tips to decline unhealthy food, you can avoid any miscommunication or hurt feelings and be able to enjoy the season for what it is all about: being around those you love, and cherishing timeless traditions.

Sheet1.Title: How to Combat Your Stress and Anxiety
Sheet1.Meta Description: Don't let stress or anxiety effect your health and performance goals. Realize that there are specific practices that will combat your stress and anxiety.
Sheet1.Content:
Neutralize Dizzying Affects Stress for a Productive Workout

New to CrossFit, or a seasoned athlete, your fitness journey will eventually hit some stress barriers. Don't let that effect your health and performance goals. Realize that there are specific practices that will combat your stress and anxiety. You can learn to coach yourself when you’re feeling stressed or anxious. If something is bringing about negative feelings and emotions, be quick to identify it and realize that it doesn't have to fully control you. You'll want to be able to bounce back quickly especially if you are in the middle of a big event or competition. If you don’t want to continue feeling negative emotions, you need to train your self with positive self-talk. Once you get used to changing your thoughts and actions, you can ease your anxiety almost instantly. If you’re feeling stressed, negative, anxious or just uneasy, you can practice combatting these feelings once you know what works for you. You can be proactive in trying  to calm yourself down instead of getting frustrated or upset that you're feeling a certain way.   Just focus on taking control of your actions and your thoughts. 1. Actions – "What positive thing can I do, to ease these negative feelings right now?" Once you identify something, begin to do it immediately. You might need to try a few things to see what works, but begin taking action as soon as you can. Examples: Taking deep breaths, moving in a particular way, laying down,  smiling, getting physical touch from a loved one   2. Thoughts – What can I think, or remind myself of, to ease these negative feelings right now? Identify the thoughts that you know will provide you with some relief and comfort and begin telling yourself those immediately. Continue to use the thoughts that you know will make you feel more positive. Examples: Quotes, thinking about what you can control, thinking about what you’re grateful for, thinking about how you’ve gotten through harder things in the past, reminding yourself of your purpose, meditating or praying, reminding yourself to just take the next best step or to break it down   You might continue to feel slightly uneasy, but you'll likely feel better once you focus on what you can control to improve your situation. Always choose to be proactive with your thoughts and actions instead of feeling like a victim paralyzed without much choice. You can choose your thoughts, and so can I. We must constantly focus on improving our mindset, so that we can perform our best.  

Featured Image: Burnmorefat.com

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Oven-Fried Salmon Cakes
Sheet1.Meta Description: Paleo Oven-Fried Salmon Cakes — made of salmon, sweet potato, almond flour, and spices — are fast and easy to make from ingredients.
Sheet1.Content: How great would it be if we could eat cake after a workout?! Well, we can... kinda. These little cakes — made of salmon, sweet potato, almond flour, and spices — are fast and easy to make from ingredients you probably already have in your paleo pantry. They're crisp, light, and very satisfying — full of flavor and Omega-3s. You can make a batch ahead of time, then eat them cold, room temperature, or hot for any  meal or snack. They're delicious any time and any temp. And they're awesome post-workout, hockey-pucks-of-nutrition, too. But you can call 'em cake. Paleo Oven-Fried Salmon Cakes Serves 2-4 | Prep 25 minutes | Cook 30 minutes Ingredients: 1 (14.75 ounce) can wild-caught pink or red salmon 1 cup cooked (or canned) sweet potato, mashed 2 large eggs, beaten 1/2 cup almond flour 1/2 cup fresh parsley leaves, minced (about 2 tablespoons) 2 scallions, white and green, very thinly sliced 1 tablespoon Old Bay Seasoning 1 teaspoon salt 1 teaspoon hot sauce 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper zest from 1 lemon 2 tablespoons ghee, melted (or your favorite cooking fat) Garnish with any of these: Olive Oil Mayo Paleo Ranch Dressing minced fresh parsley fresh lemon juice Directions: 1. Preheat the oven to 425F and cover a large baking sheet with parchment paper. 2. Drain the liquid from the salmon and using your fingers, crumble the fish into a large mixing bowl, removing the bones and flaking the fish. Add the sweet potato, eggs, almond flour, parsley, scallions, Old Bay Seasoning, salt, hot pepper sauce, paprika, black pepper, and lemon zest. Mix well and refrigerate for 10 minutes. 3. Brush the parchment paper with some of the melted ghee, then use a 1/3 measuring cup to scoop the cakes and drop them onto the parchment. The patties should be about 2 1/2 inches wide and about 1 inch thick. Brush the tops of the cakes with ghee, then bake for 20 minutes. Carefully flip each patty with a spatula and return to the oven. (Brush with more ghee if that tickles your fancy.) Bake an additional 10 minutes until golden brown and crisp. Serve with a squeeze of lemon juice and your sauce of choice. Tasty Variations: Replace the Old Bay Seasoning in the recipe above with these spices and toppings! Indian: 2 teaspoons curry powder Middle Eastern: 2 teaspoons cumin; top with Tahini Dressing Mediterranean: 2 teaspoons dried rosemary leaves; top with diced tomatoes Tropical: 1/2 teaspoon powdered ginger, 1 clove crushed garlic; top with diced mango and Olive Oil Mayo Asian: 2 teaspoons Chinese five-spice powder and a splash of coconut aminos Tex-Mex: 2 teaspoons chili powder, 1 teaspoon ground cumin, lime zest; top with Lizard Sauce Jerky: 2 teaspoons Jerk Seasoning

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Cranberry Waldorf Salad
Sheet1.Meta Description: Paleo Cranberry Waldorf Salad gets its sweetness from apples, grapes, and dried apricots. The fruit is wrapped up in a fluffy cloud of whipped coconut milk.
Sheet1.Content: Cranberry Waldorf Salad is a holiday tradition in our house. We're not quite sure where the recipe originated, but we think it was clipped from a magazine by my favorite aunt: Aunt Polly. (She almost always wore a stylish hat and knew her way around a snappy comeback.) My glamorous, somewhat eccentric aunt gave my mom the scrap of paper from a ladies' magazine and the recipe made it into our permanent holiday rotation. We always ate this "salad" along with our dinner, even though it's more like a dessert. The original recipe included a 1/2 cup of white sugar, a bag of mini marshmallows, and a whole container of Cool-Whip! This version gets its sweetness from apples, grapes, and dried apricots. The fruit is wrapped up in a fluffy cloud of whipped coconut milk. It's a mixture of flavors and textures that, to me, tastes like family and fun. Happy  holidays! Paleo Cranberry Waldorf Salad Makes enough for a party! Ingredients: 1 can full-fat coconut milk (Thai Kitchen works great!) 12 ounces fresh cranberries 16 dried apricots 1 pound seedless grapes, cut in half 2 medium apples, cut into bite-sized pieces 1/2 cup pecan halves 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract Directions: **This requires a bit of preparation: Place a can of coconut milk in the refrigerator, ideally overnight, but 3-4 hours will do. Also, this salad works best if you do the prep, let it sit overnight, then assemble shortly before eating. Prep 1. Preheat the oven to 350F. Put a mixing bowl and beater from an electric mixer in the freezer. 2. Wash the cranberries and set a few aside for garnish. Place the rest in the bowl of a food processor with the dried apricots and grind them until the mixture has the consistency of relish. (Go ahead… sneak a little bite. It’s tangy and delicious!) 3. In a large bowl, toss the cranberry-apricot relish with the cut apples and grapes. Cover tightly and place in the refrigerator so they can get to know each other. Forget about them until the next day. 4. Meanwhile, spread the pecans on a baking sheet in a single layer and toast for 5-7 minutes until golden. Keep an eye on them; they can burn quickly. When they’re cool, chop the pecans and set aside – be sure to save a few unchopped for garnish. Resist the urge to eat them immediately. If you’re feeling lazy, you can use untoasted pecans; it will be fine.   Assembly 1. When you’re ready to assemble the salad, take your can of coconut milk out of the fridge — don’t shake it. Remove the mixing bowl and beater from the freezer. Turn the can of coconut milk upside down, open with a can opener, and pour off the liquid. Now scoop the thick, coconut cream into the chilled mixing bowl. Add the vanilla extract and beat the mixture on the highest speed of your mixer until it looks like whipped cream. This takes about 5-7 minutes. 2. When the whipped cream is done, place the chopped pecans and fruit relish in a large bowl. Gently fold in the whipped cream and garnish with whole cranberries and nuts.

Sheet1.Title: Cinnamon Beef Stew
Sheet1.Content: A warm, comforting stew is almost always a good idea. And one of the great pleasures of eating a hearty stew is that while it simmers, you can almost forget you were the one who made it. Then, when it’s time to sit down and eat, it feels as if someone else cooked for you. What a treat! In this flavorful stew, the cinnamon and herbs create a mellow, earthy gravy. It’s sophisticated comfort food that's equally good for lunch, dinner, or even breakfast, with a nice fried egg on top. Like all great stews, this one improves with age. It tastes even better on day 2 and 3 (and 4),  and it freezes/defrosts beautifully. Cinnamon Beef Stew Serves 6-10 | Prep 30 minutes | Cook about 90 minutes Ingredients: 2-3 pounds beef stew meat, cut into 1-inch cubes salt and black pepper 3 tablespoons coconut oil (or your favorite cooking fat) 1 medium carrot, peeled and finely chopped (about 1/4 cup) 1 medium onion, diced (about 1 cup) 1 medium celery stalk, finely chopped (about 1/4 cup) 2 cloves garlic, minced (about 2 teaspoons) 2 tablespoons tomato paste 1/2 cup beef broth 2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar 3-5 cups water 2 teaspoons salt 1 teaspoon ground black pepper 2 bay leaves 1 sprig fresh rosemary (or 1/2 teaspoon dried) 1 sprig fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoon dried) 1 sprig fresh sage (or 1/2 teaspoon dried) 2 cinnamon sticks extra-virgin olive oil, for garnish (optional) Directions: 1. Sprinkle the beef generously with salt and pepper. In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat the coconut oil over medium-high heat, then add the meat in batches and sear on all sides. It’s important that you don’t crowd the pan. The meat needs air around it to achieve a crisp brown crust. With tongs or a slotted spoon, remove the browned pieces to a bowl to catch their juice. Repeat with the remaining cubes. 2. In the same pot, sauté the chopped carrot, onion, celery, and garlic for about 2 minutes, stirring with a wooden spoon. Add the tomato paste and stir for about 1 minute. 3. Add the broth and vinegar, then stir with passion, scraping up all the wonderful brown bits at the bottom of the pan. Keep stirring until the mixture starts to thicken. 4. Put the meat and its drippings back into the pot. Add 3 cups water, 2 teaspoons salt, a healthy dose of pepper, the bay leaves, rosemary, thyme, sage, and cinnamon sticks. 5. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer with the pot only partially covered for about 90 minutes. This is not a soupy stew, but if the stew starts to dry out, add more water, about a 1/2 cup at a time. Simmer until the meat is fall-apart tender and the liquid in the pan has been reduced to gravy-like status. 6. Remove the cinnamon sticks and herb stems from the stew pot. Ladle the stew into deep bowls — bonus points if you also add a light drizzle of olive oil.

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Savory Granola
Sheet1.Meta Description: There is not enough holiday magic on the planet to get me to eat Chex again. Instead use this Paleo Savory Granola for a blend of spicy, crispy, and chewy.
Sheet1.Content:
Make Granola Healthy and Exciting Again

  I grew up in the '70s and '80s, so Chex-Mix was a Big Deal. I remember seeing it on every holiday buffet and party table, and I had very firm opinions about what I liked in mine (pretzels, lots of Chex) and what I didn't (peanuts). I considered it an honor, responsibility, and privilege to help make our batch for our annual Christmas Eve family reunion. Even now, I can close my eyes and taste the worcestershire sauce and salt — and I can hear that epic crunch-crunch-crunch. But it's all in my imagination now because there is not enough holiday magic on the planet to get me to eat Chex again. Luckily, there's an Indonesian condiment called serundeng katjang that tastes enough like Chex-Mix to fill the void. And between us friends, it tastes even better than Chex-Mix ever did. Made from nuts, coconut, and spices, this is a festive blend of spicy, crispy, and chewy. Happy holidays! Paleo Savory Granola Makes 1 1/2 cups | Prep 5 minutes | Sauté 10 minutes | Bake 45 minutes Ingredients: 1/2 tablespoon coconut oil 1/2 medium onion, finely minced 1 clove garlic, crushed 1/2 teaspoon powdered ginger 1/2 teaspoon cumin 1/2 teaspoon coriander 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon turmeric 1/2 tablespoon lemon juice 3/4 cup unsweetened coconut flakes 1/2 cup dry-roasted almonds 1/3 cup dry-roasted cashews Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 300F and cover a large baking sheet with parchment paper. 2. Heat coconut oil in a large skillet over medium heat until melted, then add onion, garlic, and ginger. Cook 2-3 minutes until the onions begin to soften. 3. In a small bowl, mix the cumin, coriander, salt, and turmeric. Add to the onions, stir to combine, and cook an additional 5-7 minutes until the onions are very soft. Add the lemon juice and cook until the mixture forms a paste, about 2 minutes. 4. Add the coconut chips to the pan and stir until they’re coated with the onions and spices. Transfer to the baking sheet and bake for 30 minutes. Stir with a wooden spoon and add the nuts to the baking pan. Roast an additional 10-15 minutes until the coconut/onion flakes are very brown and the nuts are toasted. 5. Allow to cool completely, then mix together and store in an air-tight container. Eat as-is or chop in a food processor until it’s the texture of coarse sand and use as a flavoring condiment on cooked vegetables, meats, soups, and salads.

Sheet1.Title: Practice Emotional Control For Optimal Performance
Sheet1.Meta Description: Emotional Control For Optimal Performance: between workouts or competing events, it's important that athletes know how to get fired up, and how to relax.
Sheet1.Content:
For all your athletic potential, the one thing that separates unrelenting athletes from the rest of the gym is their reactions to failure or success. Emotional control for optimal performance is paramount to your potential growth. You may not be going to the CrossFit Games or running the Leadville Ultramarathon, but you can obtain the same level of physical performance with the right mental training. From my experience as a certified trainer in the CrossFit space, here is key pieces of advice to unfold your fitness potential. In extreme fitness sports, it is important that you know how to get yourself fired up, and how to calm yourself down. Between workouts or events in a competition, you will want to get relaxed and stay calm. When something goes wrong in a WOD, or you miss a rep, you may need to chill out to make sure you don’t waste useful energy. There are other times during your workouts, or before them, that you'll want to get pumped up, and increase your energy. Before a max effort lift, or when you need to use high intensity, you'll likely want to get more fired up. Find what works best for you, so that you know what amount of arousal will help you perform your best

Ways To Get Calm

  • Practice taking deep breaths
  • Use  relaxing visualizations
  • Listen to calming music
  • Relax your muscles
  • Reminding yourself what you can control
  • Think about comforting thoughts (people, memories, prayers)
 

Ways To Get Fired Up

  • Listen to fast music
  • Take quicker breaths
  • Clapping
  • Jump around, stomp or do quick motions with your body
  • Think about something that gets you pumped, angry or excited
  • Yell
  • Use visualizations that get you going
  Realize that you're in control of your thoughts and your body language, and you can get them both to work for you to help you feel the right amount of arousal. Try different techniques, and continue to use the ones that you like and the ones that help you perform your best. The more you practice, the better you'll be at quickly implementing these strategies to stay in control of yourself.

Sheet1.Title: 3 Training Journal Tips that Ensure Higher Fitness Results
Sheet1.Meta Description: Follow these three Training Journal tips that help you set fitness habits and realize your health and performance goals.
Sheet1.Content:
What To Include In Your Training Journal

  Are you starting a new training program and ready to get results? Have you been wondering what others include in their journals? Have you never used a journal to track and record anything? I'm here to give you practical training journal tips. Read more... There really is no right or wrong way to use a training journal. Still, the psychology of our mind has a proven record of better performance when we record our fitness and diet activities. It helps our mind internalize what we have done and track goals that we aspire to achieve. The first takeaway here is write your training down. I suggest that you take some pre-workout notes and post-workout notes for at least 30 days, to see what you can learn about yourself. If you’ve never done it, keep it simple and stick to the basics. If you're a more seasoned athlete then you may want to record even more details, so that you can fine-tune your performance and improve on every level. Try setting journal habits that are simple, then build on them.   Here are some different types of journaling I suggest: Very Minimal Info:  the date, what you did, and (possibly) bullet points on how you felt. Some More Info: the date, where you were, what you did, how your energy and mood were before the WOD, a couple of positive points from the workout, a couple of things you’d like to improve on from the workout. Lots of Info: Some people just love information and prefer to take very detailed notes. Here’s a list of info you could add – time of training, what you did, results, rate of effort during training, highlight of training session, any muscle soreness or pain, nutrition (pre/post workout), quality of sleep the night before training, energy levels before and after training, level of stress, level of confidence, level of motivation, any negative thoughts.   I typically suggest something similar to the middle option, as it’s important to get used to tuning into how you feel before the workout, as well as after it. I like to help athletes asses their physical and mental condition, so that they have a better understanding that it’s all connected. Try out some different note-taking strategies, and review it with a coach or training partner to see if you have any gaps, or are seeing any trends.

Sheet1.Title: Refractory Celiac Disease Incidence May Be Higher Than Once Thought
Sheet1.Meta Description: Refractory celiac disease, a condition in which a celiac doesn't respond well to the GF diet is unfortunately on the rise. Fortunately there's a treatment.
Sheet1.Content:
How to Ensure Favorable Response to a Gluten Free Diet

  For most celiac patients, treatment on the gluten-free diet marks the turning point for their health. It can take a few months for the villi of the small intestine to heal, but eventually their symptoms are alleviated and they are able to absorb the nutrients in their food. Unfortunately, there is a percentage of celiacs who don’t respond to the gluten-free diet, which is the only current treatment for the disease, resulting in a condition known as refractory celiac disease, also known as nonresponsive celiac disease (NRCD). Although celiac experts have stated that actual refractory celiac disease, whereby damage to the small intestine is irrevocable, is rare, a preliminary study reported by Med Page Today suggests that the condition is more common than the medical community once thought. Fortunately, the study also showed that refractory CD patients did respond favorably to medical treatment. Celiac disease, an autoimmune disease caused by gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, affects three million Americans, or 1% of the U.S. population. Patients with refractory celiac disease experience abdominal pain, severe malabsorption of nutrients, and intestinal damage. A single-center preliminary study suggests that “more patients with celiac disease may stop responding to their gluten-free diets,” as reported by Med Page Today. The researchers studied nonresponsive celiac patients treated at the University of Virginia Medical Center over the past decade. According to Med Page Today, “Overall, patients were diagnosed with refractive disease a mean of 4.7 years following their initial diagnosis of celiac disease.” Furthermore, refractive celiac diagnoses seemed to occur more recently, mostly within the last five years and almost half of them within the last six months. The researchers, which include Christopher Hammerle, MD, and Sheila Crowe, MD, of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, found that the refractory celiac disease patients did end up responding to treatment with thiopurines. "These agents are my treatment-of-choice for refractory celiac disease to avoid long-term steroids," Hammerle told MedPage Today. According to Shailaja Jamma, MD, and Daniel Leffler, MD, MS, in Real Life with Celiac Disease, there could be many explanations for a failure to respond favorably to the gluten-free diet. In their chapter on NRCD, they write, “you would need to be on a GFD for at least 6 months without significant improvement before we would decide that you were not responding and look for other reasons.” This is due to the fact that recovery times vary from person to person, and as long as a patient seems to be improving continually over time, no matter the speed, nonresponsive celiac disease is usually an unnecessary label. Jamma and Leffler found that the most common causes—designated “very common”—are gluten exposure and Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). The next most common causes of NRCD, labeled as “somewhat common,” are lactose intolerance or fructose malabsorption, microscopic colitis, and small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. “Rare” causes include actual refractory celiac disease, which can be confirmed with a biopsy of the small intestine, an eating disorder, inflammatory bowel disease, which can also be confirmed with a biopsy as well as imaging studies of the small or large intestine, pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, and motility disturbances, that is, when food moves too fast or too slow through the intestine. Finally, a food allergy and cancer are “very rare” causes of NCRD. According to the Mayo Clinic, as reported by Celiac.com, “gluten contamination is the leading reason for non-responsive celiac disease,” and estimates that 18% of non-responsive celiac disease cases are due to actual refractory celiac disease. The Mayo Clinic researchers recommend that before making a refractory celiac disease diagnosis, additional diseases as well as gluten contamination should be eliminated as causes. Acccording to Jamma and Leffler, “The first step is often to get confirmation that you do indeed have celiac disease,” since “celiac disease can be mistakenly diagnosed when the true problem is something else.” Med Page Today points out that most of the patients with refractory celiac disease responded favorably to a thiopurine medication rather than the conventional method of treatment for the condition, steroids. This form of treatment doesn’t carry with it the risk of steroid dependence. If you have some concerns regarding your response to the gluten-free diet, it’s recommended that you talk to your doctor about a non-responsive celiac disease evaluation. A diet evaluation may very well confirm that you are still ingesting gluten, but if this isn’t the case, other causes can be explored by your doctor. Thiopurine seems promising as a treatment to those who do in fact have actual refractory disease.   Tina Turbin  
Resources: About.com: Refractory (Unresponsive) Celiac Disease http://celiacdisease.about.com/od/symptomsofceliacdisease/a/refractorysprue.htm Celiac.com: Causes of Non-responsive Celiac Disease - More than 50% Continue to Ingest Gluten Unknowingly http://www.celiac.com/articles/741/1/Causes-of-Non-responsive-Celiac-Disease---More-than-50-Continue-to-Ingest-Gluten-Unknowingly/Page1.html Jamma, Shailaja, MD, and Leffler, Daniel A, MD. “Nonresponsive Celiac Disease.” Real Life with Celiac Disease: AGA Press, 2010. http://www.reallifewithceliacdisease.com Medpage Today: ACG: More Celiac Disease May Be Refractory http://www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingCoverage/ACG/22866

Sheet1.Title: Surprising Ways CrossFit Helps to Beat Addiction
Sheet1.Meta Description: Addiction is a difficult enemy to fight regardless of your age. Adam Huston is an ordinary guy who discovered CrossFit helps to beat addiction. You can win.
Sheet1.Image Alt Text: crossfit_addiction_recovery_prevention | Adam Huston CrossFit Helps Beat Addiction

Sheet1.Title: Beet Juice: Why it Works Best for High Intensity Interval Training
Sheet1.Meta Description: Beet Juice: Why it Works Best for High Intensity Interval Training. Learn from expert Andy Jones on the effects of beet juice performance enhancers.
Sheet1.Content:
What You Should Know About Beet Juice Performance Enhancers

  Beet juice is presently one of the favorites these days when it comes to sports drinks. The usefulness of this frothy beverage was brought to the forefront by Andy Jones, one of the main researchers about the effects of beet juice.  To read his full analysis, click here, or get the abbreviated key points of his research.  

How does beet juice work?

The nitrate content is extremely high in the juice. The body changes the nitrate to nitrite, eventually forming nitric oxide. For an athlete, it goes a long way in boosting their performance due to these reasons: ·       The blood vessels widen, thus increasing the flow of blood through them. ·       The functionality of mitochondria is enhanced, so they can produce more energy by using up less oxygen. The extra oxygen will be useful during the performance. We are generally advised to steer clear from nitrates and nitrites as the might bond with meat proteins, resulting in carcinogenic compounds that are harmful, but Jones has clearly proved that understanding how nitrates and nitrites work is still in its nascent stage. Since beet juice has nitrate in it, the protein is missing that assists in forming carcinogenic elements. However, it should be consumed in moderation or else there are chances of gastric issues.  

What are the results of the research?

Jones’s study comprised of 8 cyclists over a 50-mile cycling time trial. When they reported their findings in the first phase, they came to the conclusion that there wasn’t any significant improvement in cyclists. The data showed that the improvement in the case of each rider doing two-time trials – after drinking half a liter of normal juice, and then consuming half a liter of juice without nitrates. The improvement was just 0.8%, which isn’t that great in terms of statistical importance.

Jones refutes the statement by saying that a 0.8% improvement could be beneficial during an event. Another strange occurrence was that five of the cyclists experience an increase in their level of plasma nitrite while the other three showed a decrease. The research showed that beet juice had a greater ergogenic effect on regular athletes than in the case of elite performers. It is safe to assume:

  • Beet juice should be consumed for better performance if you participate in events that take place for 5 to 30 minutes. But you can try it for endurance events over 30 minutes as well.
  • Although a lot of studies have to be conducted for sports with teams, the juice does help to boost performance in such cases.
  • It is best to record your own data so you can monitor the performance accordingly to check if it is benefiting you.
Sheet1.Image Alt Text: beet juice best for HIIT training

Sheet1.Title: 4 Tips: What to Know About GMOs
Sheet1.Meta Description: Learn what to know about GMOs. In most countries, GMOs are considered to be harmful; there are restrictions or complete bans on products with GMOs in them.

Sheet1.Title: CrossFit Training Regimen for Cancer Survivor Recovery
Sheet1.Meta Description: Josh Bonilla, a prostate cancer survivor, turned to a CrossFit training regimen for cancer survivor recovery. Learn what he did and why it worked.
Sheet1.Content:
CrossFit Can Help to Overcome the Aftermath of Cancer

  Cancer is the one nightmare that we wish never happens to us or our loved ones. It takes a lot of strength and courage to face the fact that one has cancer and make an effort to fight it instead of breaking down. However, it is possible to get back on your feet with the right kind of fitness regimen. Here is the story of a 73-year old CrossFitter, prostate cancer survivor, and overall inspirational athlete. From the video, this is what you'll takeaway from the story.

Bravery comes from within

Jacinto Bonilla is a role model for us as he is a brave survivor of prostrate cancer but throughout the entire ordeal he has remained true to his commitment to bodybuilding. He was always into exercising and fitness, so when he discovered CrossFit Virtuosity in Brooklyn, it was too good of an opportunity for him to pass up. He is a force to reckon with – when he learned that he had been diagnosed with cancer he didn’t fold inward and question, “Why me”; on the contrary he asked the doctor how he could fight it. That shows the mental strength he possesses and the years he spent indulging in exercises helped to hone his mind in that way.   He was used to heavy weights and other rigorous exercises, but was in for a surprise when he came into CrossFit for the first time. Keith Wittenstein, the head coach at CrossFit Virtuosity in Bonilla’s own words – “Busted him”. However, this didn’t deter Bonilla in the least, and he kept coming back to master all exercises in his fitness regimen. Even his cancer failed to dampen his enthusiasm towards CrossFit. He had hernia after he returned to heavy exercising post his cancer operation, but he managed to bounce back with zest.  

Age doesn’t matter!

The Filthy Fifty workout was developed as a set of ten exercises, each of which had to be done 50 times. Bonilla modified the regimen on his 68th birthday by challenging everyone to perform six of those exercises 68 times. With each birthday, he increases the total count by 1. The workout, consisting of squats, pushups, and wall balls is now known as “Jacinto Storm” in his honor. He keeps on testing his limits and records his scores to check if he fared better than the previous year. Bonilla at his age is proud that he is in great shape to beat younger men with far more stamina and gumption. He motivates youngsters to stick to their fitness regimen by saying if he can do it, so can they!   Thus you can see how CrossFit is beneficial for people of all ages. All you need is determination to follow through the fitness regimen. The AMRAP Nutrition Newsletter can be helpful for you in a lot of ways. To subscribe, just click this link and enter your email.
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Health Tips | Success stories

Sheet1.Title: Top Reasons Why Extreme Fitness is a Good Thing for Americans
Sheet1.Meta Description: Reviewing common criticisms from the New York Times recent article, and explaining the top reasons why extreme fitness is a good thing for Americans.
Sheet1.Content:
Criticism without Proof Doesn’t Hold Water.

There are so many benefits associated with CrossFit, and everywhere you look there are several success stories that state how this form of exercise has helped them to be fit and gain a fresh perspective on life. But an article in the New York Times by New York Times Magazine contributor and Bookforum columnist Heather Havrilesky, has severely criticized functional fitness routines such as CrossFit, by stating that it causes bodily injuries, is unnecessarily tough, and is very boring. Here is our honest reasoning as to why CrossFit or ultra running hold merit and benefit our society. This is an argument for why extreme fitness is a good thing for Americans.  

Let us journey back…

It is worth a mention that CrossFit has been designated as fitness fad that is in no way related to health and fitness. Havrilesky goes way back to the 1960s or more precisely the era when people began to switch to less active jobs as compared to labor intensive ones. As the years went by, more people started to purchase automobiles, lifts were introduced, and individuals began spending more time in front of the television. Fitness was no longer a priority – it became an option. The only form of exercise practiced frequently was jogging. Moving to the ’70s and ’80s, Havrilesky credits Jane Fonda and Richard Simmons as the pioneers behind the mindset of associating exercises with fun and enjoyment. According to her, even the ‘90s were way better in terms of fitness because people took some interest in getting great looking bodies. But CrossFit, as a mode of functional fitness, is apparently not helping in any way – on the contrary it is preparing the bed for a disaster that is unknown and unpredictable, which is a passive-aggressive dig at the mission statement of CrossFit.

Why reviewers are off the mark

The major benefit of functional fitness has been given a total miss, which drives people to follow a workout routine and stick to it. This so-called fad has achieved a great success rate with little investment in terms of money and has worked wonders in motivating thousands all over the world. Researchers have come up with evidence that CrossFit targets both physical and mental health and strives for all round development. Even the portion of the article that talks about injuries due to this extreme and rigorous form of fitness is supported by little proof and vague results. Criticizing CrossFit can be equated to taking a shot in the dark based on guess-timates. If you wish to get useful tips about health and fitness, subscribe to AMRAP’s newsletter, by clicking on this link – find out what functional fitness actually about!

Sheet1.Title: Top 5 Weight Loss Pointers to Remember
Sheet1.Meta Description: Losing weight is a necessity for all around fitness. Understand the most common misconceptions circulating and the top 5 weight loss pointers to remember.
Sheet1.Content:
Avoid Common Weightless Pitfalls This Year

  Weight loss is not an easy task and it doesn’t occur overnight. You have to be patient and dedicatedly go for workouts. Although you don’t have to starve, you definitely need to cut down on some of your favorite foods due to the unhealthy fat content being excessively high in them. Losing weight is not a trend or fad anymore – it has become a necessity in order to achieve all round fitness. However, there are a lot of myths and misconceptions circulating, which can steer you in the wrong direction. Take a look at these classic weight loss pitfalls and five weight loss pointers to remember:
  • As stated before, any change takes a certain amount of time, so drastically cutting down on your food intake will not help in any way. It has taken you a while to build up habits such as gorging on pizza twice a week, so it will take some time before you can modify it. Start slow and build up the pace towards a healthier lifestyle as you go along. Give your body sufficient time to adjust.
  • Even if you end up buying products that claim to be gluten-free, farm-raised, sugar-free, organic, or fat-free, they still contain calories. The trick to shedding excess fat is to ensure you burn more calories than you eat. Don’t get taken in by fancy words – do a bit of calculation before eating anything. Or better, turn to nutrient-rich whole foods that don't demand counting calories.
  • Skipping breakfast is one of the most common myths when it comes to weight loss. You will often come across people proudly proclaiming that they don’t eat breakfast in order to lose weight. This leads to a reverse reaction – skipping breakfast, which is your first meal of the day, increase your hunger pangs causing you to eat much more at lunch and dinner.
  • Trans and excess saturated fats can lead to heart diseases and boost your bad cholesterol. That doesn’t all fats are harmful or they contribute to weight gain. Monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats help to reduce heart-related risks and prevents the bad cholesterol levels from going up. Fat is needed for your body to function, so you need to consume it in moderation.
  • You should steer clear from artificial sweeteners as they cause major gastrointestinal problems and increase the risk of diabetes. Zero-calorie colas also contain artificial sweeteners, which don’t aid in weight loss in any way. Substitute sodas and colas for green tea and water.
Always remember that weight loss routines are a combination of eating balanced meals along with regular exercising. These AMRAP bars are a perfect example – nutrient rich ingredients with a substantial flavor your body will love. Place your order them now.  
  References http://www.bodybuilding.com/fun/avoid-these-5-weight-loss-pitfalls.html
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | How To | Interesting Other | Lifestyle Design | Nutrition Hacks

Sheet1.Title: 1 Training Takeway From the World of CrossFit Women
Sheet1.Meta Description: The CrossFit Butt Test is a fun way to determine which areas need improvement and the type of exercise necessary in order to achieve the target.
Sheet1.Content:
Do You Know about the CrossFit Butt Test?

  CrossFit is termed as the all round workout since it combines all kinds of exercises such as wall balls, kettle bells, long jumps, 10K runs, gymnastics, weightlifting, aerobic conditioning and much more. Not only do you get to become physically fit but you can also relieve stress and tension thanks to CrossFit. Have you heard about the CrossFit Butt Test?  

What does it mean?

To put it in crude terms, the CrossFit Butt Test is exactly how it sounds – it involves measuring your Gluteus Maximus muscles, which means checking how big the butt is. You need to lie flat on the ground with your face down while a barbell attached to standard size bumper plates is rolled over you. There are three possible outcomes in this scenario:
  • If the barbell doesn’t come in contact with your derriere and rolls over it, you don’t pass the test.
  • If the barbell just touches the butt, you have passed the test.
  • Excellent is when your glutes stops the barbell and brings it to a halt.
This is a fun way to determine which areas need improvement and the type of exercise necessary in order to achieve the target.  

What are the benefits of CrossFit?

CrossFit was initially used for professional purposes such as training the policy, military, and fire academy, but now the use of such exercises is more widespread. You should definitely try it because:
  • Let us start with the most obvious reason – you get to achieve a fit and muscular body within a short span of time. It includes several high-intensity interval training (HIIT) exercises, which help to increase metabolism, shed excess fat, and tone the body at the same time.
  • You learn to be more confident about your body. Such exercises are not to make you stick thin, but to fashion your body to a lean and slender frame. You will be able to tackle tough exercises with better poise, coordination, and balance due to improved flexibility.
  • Your heart becomes stronger and it prevents cardiovascular problems. People with respiratory problems have managed to bring it under control thanks to CrossFit.
If you go online and search for the CrossFit Butt Test, you will be able to see related articles about how these workouts help both men and women get the dream body they always wanted. Find the closest CrossFit centre from where you stay, and enroll right away! [embed]http://youtu.be/4_ymRxOqo8U[/embed]

Sheet1.Title: 3 Points to Weigh the Potential Rewards and Risks of CrossFit
Sheet1.Meta Description: With any extreme fitness, there are potential rewards and risks to CrossFit. Although rare, workouts can lead to Rhabdomyolysis under certain situations.
Sheet1.Content:
Enjoy CrossFit Without Being at Risk for Rhabdo

CrossFit workouts have numerous advantages, but before you go ahead and enroll yourself in the program, you need to know about the possible side effects as well. With any extreme fitness, there are potential rewards and risks to CrossFit. Although the condition is extremely rare, CrossFit exercises involving high intensity workouts can lead to Rhabdomyolysis (rhabdo) under certain situations.  

1. What is rhabdo?

This condition occurs when the muscles face a lot of stress, and being unable to take it, they break down. This might lead to the muscle tissues leaking into the bloodstream. Brown urine combined with muscle pain, weakness, swelling, and soreness is a sure-shot sign of rhabdo. Since, your body’s mechanism goes totally haywire, it causes the kidneys to fail, which is fatal to your health. Keep in mind that a bit of soreness and pain is common after grueling workouts. The small amount of pain doesn’t necessarily mean you have rhabdo.  

2. What is the main cause?

When you keep repeating the same movement for a long time without changing routines or resting in between, the muscles experience a lot of strain. It also happens when light loads are used continuously in long workouts. Contrary to common misconception, heavy lifting doesn’t contribute to rhabdo in any way – in fact it forcibly brings the body to a stop before the muscles start to break down. Individuals are more likely to get rhabdo if they have been away from high intensity routines for some time, and they suddenly start working out with increased vigor and energy. If you have been out of commission for a while, it is important that you take it slow, thus allowing your body to adjust before returning full-fledged to your earlier workouts.  

3. Can CrossFit workouts be performed despite the risk?

At CrossFit centers, your health is their top priority and is taken very seriously. Each program they have developed has been structured in such a way that the possibility of rhabdo occurring is minimized. There are mechanisms in place that help to identify individuals who are at risk and prevent rhabdo before the routine commences. Coaches here are trained to scale workouts and fit them as per your abilities – you will be provided with different scaled versions, and they will help you choose the one that is best suited for you. Cutoff times are incorporated in the high intensity routines, so that muscles are not over-stressed and there is sufficient time for recovery. If there is even the slightest risk, the workout will be stopped immediately. CrossFit is fascinating right? There are several aspects to this wonderful fitness regimen – you can read all about it here.

Sheet1.Title: Gluten Free: 5 Ways to Get on Track
Sheet1.Meta Description: Check in with these common pitfalls on the gluten free diet and how you can remedy them.
Sheet1.Content:
Are you are doing the gluten free thing wrong? Chances are these tips will help you feel better.

  This article was inspired by a recent MindBodyGreen article, detailing the transformative albeit risky nature of a restrictive gluten-free path. Here is the thing--regardless of what others say, leading a gluten-free life makes you healthier. A lot of people who have experienced digestive troubles, immune problems, or suffered from exhaustion and fatigue have managed to turn their lives around after successfully cutting processed grains and gluten-related foods from their dietary routine.   Now being gluten-free doesn’t mean cutting down your food intake for that matter because you can’t skimp on nutrition under any circumstances. Unfortunately, many well-intentioned people use the gluten free path wrong. Take a look at these common blunders made by those following a gluten-free diet, so you can avoid them:  
  • The good news is that there are loads of gluten-free products in the market and several items are being introduced as well. You can stick to a regular eating pattern due to these foods, but most of these lack basic nutritional value as they are filled with refined flours and sugars. Evaluate the percentage of your diet that consists of gluten-free convenience items, so you know if it is time to toss some of them.
  • Vegetables are an important part of your diet – they contain antioxidant, anti-inflammatory phytochemicals that strengthen the body against factors like pollution and stress. Skipping out on veggies isn’t an option. In fact, you must include healthy portions of vegetables in your meal. There are several yummy veggie recipes out there – get creative and whip up something if you are bored of eating vegetables in the same ol’ way!
  • Beans, nuts, seeds and gluten free pseudograins like buckwheat contain fiber that regulates the blood sugar level, act as a source of nutrition to the beneficial bacteria living in your colon, and tones the digestive tract as well. Going gluten-free can compromise your fiber intake, so don’t let it happen as it has numerous health-related advantages such as reducing chances of chronic diseases and producing more energy.
  • Having a sweet tooth is a problem for sure. When we switch to a gluten-free diet, we might have something with added sugars that can increase digestive problems and cause inflammation. When you crave for something sweet, opt for a whole fruit, raw date truffles, or frozen grapes.
  • While it is good to eliminate gluten-laden items from your diet, you shouldn’t forget to replace it with an item that has the same nutritional value or your health can get seriously affected.
  Unnecessary restrictions on your health will always have a reverse effect so stay away from them. Before going gluten-free it is best to consult a doctor or dietician who can guide you properly.

Sheet1.Title: Fed Up, Grumpy & Tired? How (Lack of) Vision Sabotages Your Fitness
Sheet1.Meta Description: There's an answer to why exercise is harder for some people. Social psychologist Emily Balcetis talks about how to reach a solution by altering your vision.
Sheet1.Content:
Breeze through Your Workout Routine by Altering Your Vision

How many times have we seen someone with a killer body and wished the same for ourselves? Have you wondered why you are having a difficult time shedding those extra pounds while others have it easy? Turns out, there is a substantial answer to your question, why exercise is harder for some people? Social psychologist Emily Balcetis talks about how you can reach a solution by changing your entire perspective.   Perception varies Everyone perceives the world differently – each person has a varied outlook and vision on life around us. Emily conducted a study where she showed person’s photograph and asked people to identify the emotion on his face. There were more than 120 people who participated in the survey and when the results were tabulated, it clear proved that one person’s notion differs vastly from another. Although the same photograph was circulated among these individuals, each of them noticed something different. It is a classic case of the glass being half full or half empty!   How do we perceive? Whenever we are given a certain amount of information, our mind processes it instantly, but the accuracy rate is quite low. In order to understand what has been provided to you, the mind fills in the blank spots, which makes perception extremely subjective. It was speculated that strongly motivated individuals tend to see their desired goal closer than those who aren’t that motivated. If there is lack of motivation, people are not likely to put an effort into exercising because according to them, they have already achieved their fitness goals.   Why does changing the vision help? This is what conceptualized vision science and led to the strategy known as Keep your eyes on the prize." The idea is to tailor the minds of individuals so that they focus solely on what they want to achieve without being distracted. They were trained to ignore everything going on in the sidelines and to blur it out. People, who kept their eyes on the ultimate objective, saw the finish line as 30% closer than others who got distracted. So once you learn to actually concentrate, you will notice a marked improvement in your performance while exercising. You are likely to tire less easily and retain energy for a longer period of time.   Keeping the eyes on the prize teaches you to view the world from a more focused standpoint that works wonders when you try to lose weight. You will automatically start to work out harder and faster without realizing it consciously and that is exactly how you can burn those calories and not feel exhausted and drained.   Learn more about fitness psychology to empower your health potential!  First, Join the AMRAP Newsletter for more fresh info. Second, listen to Balcetis' full talk.
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | Lifestyle Design | Performance Advice | Top 10

Sheet1.Title: Do You Know the Key Difference Between Training and Exercise?
Sheet1.Meta Description: Do You Know the Key Difference Between Training and Exercise? Learn to Set Future-Focused Fitness Goals versus Haphazard Daily Exercise.
Sheet1.Content:
Learn to Set Future-Focused Fitness Goals v. Haphazard Daily Exercise

We want to be fit and have a toned body, but we don’t know how to go about it. The problem is we tend to follow any and every fitness trend that strikes and elevate it to cult status. As the hullabaloo dies down, we switch to something different. Most of us aren’t really athletes, which is why we face this issue of cult-like exercise programs. The key to overcoming fads is addressed by Mark Rippletoe.  

Who is Mark Rippletoe?

Coach Mark Rippletoe makes a bold statement by claiming that the fitness industry, whose value is estimated at a whopping $27 billion, is actually out to con you and divest you of a neat sum. Its a controversial topic, and one could even argue hypocritical given his next moves.  Rippletoe owns the Wichita Falls Athletic Club in Texas and has over three decades of experience in grooming weight lifters along with their coaches. He achieved maverick status when he became the first coach to give up his National Strength and Conditioning Association credential; right after parting ways with CrossFit, he developed their barbell program.  

Where do we go wrong?

His message is simple – fitness is nothing without strength. This is the only reason he left CrossFit, because he felt that most exercise programs were being designed so they would be perceived as a fad without actually helping anyone to become an athlete. They mix up training and exercise. Getting stronger is not rocket science – it can be easily done with squats, presses, dead lifts, bench presses, and power cleans. These moves help to build muscle by enabling the body to move anatomically. That is the part that a number of CrossFit gyms forget about, despite (sincere) attempts to offer powerful training methodology to aspiring (lifestyle) athletes.  

What is the difference between training and exercise?

According to Rippletoe, exercises are performed for the results produced today while training is for the long run. The latter is for acquiring physical adaptations for a goal set in the future. For example, consider a jogger who goes for his rounds on a daily basis compared to someone training to run a 5K. The jogger is focused on maintaining good health while the 5K potential runner is focused on giving his best performance on D-Day. Training is a process that has to be mapped out and planned because it requires precision. Knowing the difference is important, so we know what we should do and how to prevent being caught up in a money-wasting fad and risking an injury. Think about what you want to do and then reach a decision. It is your hard-earned money so it should be spent wisely and get you the desired results. Be sure your gym and your trainers are helping you achieve your health and fitness goals.   If you liked this article, subscribe to the AMRAP Newsletter for more fresh content and exclusive deals, or read more.

Sheet1.Title: How to Live a Less Diet-Obsessed Life, Intuitively
Sheet1.Meta Description: One neuroscientist defines why dieting is a bad idea and causes more damage than good. Through her, find a fresh approach to live a less diet-obsessed life.
Sheet1.Content:
Say No to Unreliable Dieting! Here is a Better Way...

  The problem with dieting these days is that people tend to interpret it as cutting down drastically on food intake so that they can lose excess fat and look lean and slender. Everyone wants a healthy body but most of them take the wrong route and end up being bulimic or anorexic. Neuroscientist Sandra Aamodt has now defined clearly as to why dieting is a bad idea and will cause more damage than get fruitful results. Through her, find a fresh approach to live a less diet-obsessed life.  

The problem with dieting

She states how she started dieting at the age of 13 and continued to try different kinds of diets for the next few years. In the middle of all this, she did lose weight only to gain it back again, thus leaving her stupefied as to where she could have gone wrong. The equation was simple – you eat right and then burn it off accordingly. Sandra later figured out that hunger and energy is governed by the brain, which essentially decides what your body weight should be. You can alter your lifestyle to lose weight, but the system works like a thermostat – it regulates the signals in the brain that tell your body to gain weight and those that direct the body to shed off pounds. No matter what you do, the brain will always push the body back to the weight that is considered to be appropriate. The problem occurs when the brain is set to a new normal weight. For example, if you have temporarily gained 10 pounds and you don’t lose it for a couple of years, the brain thinks that is your normal weight now. So a sudden gain in weight can also cause problems.  

What is the solution?

The bottom line is diets are not reliable at all because there is a 90% chance that you will gain back the exact same weight you had lost, and perhaps even more. Combat this issue using a scientific technique by being mindful of what you eat. Listen to your body when it signals for hunger and learn to control your eating so you can stop when you feel full. It might take some time before you can correctly understand what your brain is trying to tell you regarding food habits, but it is the only way to live life in a healthy and happy manner. Eat regular nutrient-rich meals without getting distracted – your appetite shouldn’t be toyed with in any way! Try AMRAP Bars for on-the-go Paleo nutrition, guaranteed to satiate your appetite and deliver long-burning energy.

Sheet1.Title: 5 Subtle Lifting Techniques to Transform Your Clean and Jerk
Sheet1.Meta Description: A recent trend has indicated that a lot of newcomers are facing problems in closing the clean and jerk when it comes to weightlifting. Learn how to fix it.
Sheet1.Content:
Why Athletes have Problems during Clean and Jerk?

A recent trend has indicated that a lot of newcomers are facing problems in closing the clean and jerk when it comes to weightlifting. The issue lies in the dip portion of the jerk when the lifter reaches the bottom of the dip is beginning to change directions by driving upward.   Here are a few points to ensure you don’t have trouble in accomplishing the movement:
  • During a dip, energy is stored in the quads so that it can be released later. The “later” comes within a fraction of a second during which, the strength reflex build up is utilized to drive the bar overhead. The faster you do the dips, the more upward force you can exert. The upward jerk needs to be completed flawlessly will full commitment because a split second delay can cause a significant loss in energy for the jerk drive.
  • Hesitating at the bottom of a dip is a strict no-no. The lifter halts and holds the weight in a quarter front squat position for a second. In order to jerk the barbell, the upward thrust should be made as forcefully as possible. This tiny time gap causes a deficit in the force that could be drawn via a quick jerk, so the overall effort isn’t sufficient to jerk a heavy weight in the correct way.
  • Novice lifters are unable to commit to the lift as they are apprehensive and have a fear regarding the weight. Initially this might not be a hindrance because these lifters don’t have enough strength so they can still accomplish full jerks exerting less force, even with a hesitation dip. But when the barbell gets heavier, it will not be possible for the lifter to maintain consistency.
  • CrossFitters are trained to equate jerk to thrusters that don’t have dip. They skip the “pause” phase between the clean and the jerk, which causes the bar to be driven off the shoulders just after coming out of the clean. The absence of a dip means zero eccentric movement before the drive. The jerk has to be learned under a qualified coach in the case of CrossFit converts.
  • After a certain age, the quad tendons of lifters lose the capacity of handling the same amount of force that they used to when he was younger. They will have to relax on the jerk dip or else it might lead to a ruptured patellar tendon.
  The jerk movement is easier to control and you can move extremely heavy weights overhead – so try to change direction as fast as you can, so that you can jerk anything you can clean.
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | How To | Performance Advice

Sheet1.Title: 5 Health Risks of Zero Net Carbs Hype
Sheet1.Content:
The Bottom Line About Zero Net Carbs Fantasy

  There is a new facet to the rage about having low-carb foods since they make you lose weight and help to achieve a leaner body. It is said that instead of cutting calories, people should focus on reducing the carbohydrate intake in order to reduce the extra fat in the liver. But this type of diet imposes a lot of restrictions, which is why it is difficult to stick to it on a regular basis. While there is no shortage of talk about the correct carb intake a body needs, one carb development is discussed less: food can be made with zero net carbs. The massive elephant in the room is this: the words “net carb” on the packaging is enough to make me suspicious. “Net carb” usually means that someone is trying to sell you stuff by telling you a fairy tale. Unfortunately, marketers have utilized “zero net carbs” as a tool in order to sell off items having low net carbs, even though the FDA doesn’t recognize the term “net carbs”. To put it in a nutshell, products that claim to be having zero net carbs; all of those might not be as harmless as they seem. But let’s not get ahead of ourselves before asking ourselves this question--  

Why Do Zero Net Carbs Seem Sexy?

Per these products’ nutrition claim, the total number of carbohydrates in a food item after deducting the fiber and sugar alcohols is known as net carbohydrates. Zero net carbohydrate products are currently very popular. For instance, The Carb Zero Bread by Julian Bakery is just like a normal slice of bread but without huge amounts of carbohydrates, sugars, and calories. It comprises protein, dietary fiber, and is gluten-free. The fiber and protein keeps the appetite satiated so that there are no sudden hunger pangs that lead to bingeing on snacks. Also remember that fiber and sugar alcohols don’t affect blood sugar adversely. The Smart Carb Bread by the same establishment is also made with similar ingredients and claims to help to shed the excess fat and lose weight at the same time. How do you measure net carbs? Check the sugar and fiber content as mentioned on the labels – if the former is more than grams, subtract half the grams of sugar alcohols from the total carbohydrates and adjust accordingly. For the fiber, subtract half the grams of dietary fiber from the total carbohydrates if it is more than 5 grams and then make insulin adjustments. It sounds great. Almost too good to be true. Which forces you to ask, is this just another health scam, like “diet” soda? Are companies taking an already unhealthy substandard food product and lacing toxic modified ingredients to cancel out the sugars, calories, and carbs? Should you be worried that your body is being starved out of real nutrition in the pursuit of “weight-shedding”? Let’s get to that.  

Zero Net Carbs is not the Correct Term

Right now it is impossible to accept zero net carb marketers’ health claims as accurate. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has not yet set regulations for label claims about carbohydrates. Meaning we know less about the ramifications of this health food trend. However, the fact remains that some products are blatantly misleading consumers by claiming they contain “zero carbs”, thereby omitting the word “net”, which makes a huge difference. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) requires all nutrition labels to mention the total carb count including the full amount of grams from sugar alcohols and fiber. The real problem here is you are highly dependant on insulin management; these products can have a negative impact on blood sugar. In one case, WebMD cited, “When you tell a person 'net carbs' or 'impact carbs,' it's very confusing…A person with diabetes may think, 'It's fine for me to have as much as I want.” In another example, one man measured the spike in blood sugar after eating low net carb bread from Julian Bakery. The results were drastic increases. The companies boasting the nutrition of these products could not give an explanation or convincing rebuttle to explain the negative sugar spikes. After all this, what should you think about zero net carbs?  

The bottom line is that these foods may not be as innocuous as they seem, in terms of blood sugar impact, and most are far from healthy choices. So go easy, test your own response, and then mentally file these products in your “occasional treat” category.

Or better yet, give your body what it really wants and needs—nutrient-rich natural food. Subscribe to AMRAP's newsletter for more fresh ideas, raw myth busting, and exclusive offers.
