Sheet1.Title: How To Make a Health Resolution and Stick To It
Sheet1.Meta Description: Rather than blindly writing down a list of what you'd like to accomplish this year, try to keep these four tips in mind when making a health resolution
Sheet1.Content:
4 Steps to Ensure Your Goals are Realized This Year

It's the most wonderful time of the year: New Years' Resolution time! For those of you that like to start the new year off to a fresh start with new health resolutions and goals to complete, you may find yourself at a standstill once the adrenaline and excitement of a "new year, new you" idea fades away as the months go by. Instead, you may find yourself struggling to achieve those once-desired goals. Rather than blindly writing down a list of what you'd like to accomplish, try to keep these tips in mind: 1. Write down goals that you can actually achieve. If your average running mileage per week is five miles, chances are you may not be able to run a marathon before the year is up. Likewise, it's unreasonable for not only your body but for your mind to set a goal to lose 100 pounds in a year's time. Instead, create goals that you know you will be able to achieve, but will still be somewhat of a challenge. For example, if you'd like to lose a total of 100 pounds, make it a goal to lose 40-50 of those pounds this year. If you'd like to run a marathon in your lifetime, make it a goal to run a 10K or a half in 2015. By making your goals achievable, you will be more likely to stick to them and in turn will feel motivated to create and accomplish more goals after that. 2. Break down your ultimate goals into smaller, more manageable "mini goals." Taking the example of the weight loss goal from above, divide your 40-50 pound loss in a year's time to each week, or each month. Reward each mini-goal achievement by doing something you enjoy, buying yourself something that you need or want, or even blocking out some time to relax and enjoy the moment. You've reached another step towards your ultimate goal, that deserves some recognition! 3. Create an action plan. Want to run that half marathon by the end of the year? Research some training plans that will work for your lifestyle. Once you've chosen something that fits, figure out how you will incorporate said plan into your schedule in a way that will make it seem effortless. When it comes to weight loss, find a health plan that will work for you, or even create your own meal plan based on healthy choices that will help you reach that goal. Write down your meal plan every week so you know what to expect and how to prepare. By creating a plan beforehand, you can avoid the excuses in the long run if it's already woven into your busy schedule. 4. Visualize your goals and see yourself accomplishing them. If that means to post your written goals somewhere where you can see them everyday, do it. If that means creating a vision board so you can envision yourself crossing that finish line or finally feeling healthy and confident, do that. Whatever method you need to take in order to give yourself the confidence and reassurance that you can, in fact, do this, utilize it. If you have an idea, and then a plan, and then the confidence to believe in yourself, this can be the year that you finally get those resolutions accomplished.
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | How To | Lifestyle Design

Sheet1.Title: What To Do After A Celiac Disease Diagnosis
Sheet1.Meta Description: Have you received a celiac disease diagnosis? Read this article for tips on how to successfully live a celiac lifestyle thanks to the gluten-free diet.
Sheet1.Content: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disease triggered by gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, and requires the total elimination of gluten from the diet. Hence, the only treatment for this disease is the gluten-free diet. Paleo and Gluten Free advocate Tina Turbin offers newly-diagnosed celiac patients a step-by-step guide on how to get started eating gluten-free with a surprising ending. A celiac disease diagnosis can bring both relief as well as anxiety, as the standard treatment for celiac disease is the gluten-free diet. As you realize how many commonly eaten foods contain gluten, you may feel overwhelmed by your dietary restrictions. Don’t worry, this apprehension is normal, and short-lived. For soon, with some knowledge and experience, staying gluten-free as a celiac will become a natural way of life and can be a total life saver. The first thing to do is empower yourself with knowledge. (You’re on the right track by reading this article in AMRAP!) Consult professionals and resources, which can be found online (such as Free Tip Sheets) in print. You’ll learn details about celiac disease and the gluten-free diet as well as practical advice on how to deal with some of the common obstacles of the gluten-free lifestyle, such as eating out or surviving the many holidays, and even how to cook gluten-free recipes. I also recommend finding a local support group by searching online to find a national celiac disease support organization. They are all over the world these days. Using your resources, get prepared to go gluten-free grocery shopping. Familiarize yourself with the common sources of gluten and to learn how to read ingredients labels for gluten. Obtain a list of safe and unsafe foods for you to eat and to carry this list with you at all times. Learn about hidden sources of gluten, such as soups, gravies, medications, and cosmetics. Before you go shopping, you can download a helpful Android or iPhone app to help you pick out gluten-free foods, and don’t forget to bring your list of safe and unsafe foods. This first trip to the grocery store is going to be the hardest! Find where and how to shop for gluten-free foods and products. It’s a good idea to check out your local health food store, which should have some options. You can also order gluten-free foods online. Don’t forget to call companies to find out about the gluten content in their products.  That too can change so be sure to read the labels each time. Now it’s time to tell your family, friends, and others with whom you associate such as coworkers and your boss about your celiac disease diagnosis. With the genetic factor behind celiac disease, it’s important that your relatives also get tested for celiac disease. You can bring coworkers and friends materials about celiac disease, so that they understand your new dietary restrictions. If you travel or eat out a lot, learning how to dine out gluten-free is an important skill to acquire. This can be quite the challenge but your online and print celiac resources will provide practical tips on ordering gluten-free food and avoiding accidental ingestion of gluten thanks to cross-contamination. Websites such as GlutenFreeHelp.info are invaluable. While you adjust to being gluten-free, make sure to have some fun. Learn gluten-free alternatives to your favorite foods, sample world-class gluten-free desserts, and throw gluten-free baking parties. If you ever feel overwhelmed, remember that you’re fortunate to have found the answer to your health problems—only 3% of the celiac population in the U.S. are currently correctly diagnosed. In  my next article I will discuss what happens after you’ve tried the gluten-free diet yet you do or did not respond well enough or in other words “recover”. Why could that be? As always, feel free to write me with any questions. Tina Turbin
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | Lifestyle Design | Nutrition Hacks

Sheet1.Meta Description: Maximize your potential in the gym by minimizing factors like rips and injuries. These 7 best fitness accessories will help you become a better athlete.

New Goals, Renewed Energy, Smarter Training

Transforming your body takes time and is guaranteed to happen if you remain dedicated and focused. Often times, there are certain uncontrollable factors that can hinder your training. Strength Wraps tighten down to provide stability for your wrist joints and also allow for full range of motion. Sheet1.Title: Crisp Red Cabbage Salad
Sheet1.Meta Description: Extra-virgin olive oil and fresh parsley make this Crisp Red Cabbage Salad a nutritious, delicious side dish at any meal.
Sheet1.Content:
Packed with vitamins and good taste

We're deep in the heart of a cold, snowy winter in Vermont, so I've been relying on a stash of hearty vegetables from my winter CSA: parships, sweet potatoes, carrots, red cabbage. The red cabbage is particularly good at weathering a long winter — unlike it's green cousin which is best turned into sauerkraut if you want it to survive until spring. It's no slouch in the nutrition department, either. A red cabbage has 10 times more vitamin A (most of it in the form of vega-carotene) and twice as much iron as green cabbage. It also packs a big wallop of Vitamin C: 84% of the RDA, along with helpful amounts of potassium (great for regularing heart beat and blood pressure) andn manganese (a carb converter). Plus, it's a gorgeous color, crispy, slightly spicy, and surprisingly delicious when it's tossed with just a few ingredients. This salad is a breeze to make, holds up well for a few days in the refrigerator, and tastes delicious cold and hot. Fun fact: Red cabbage can turn blue when you cook it! (To keep it red, cook it with a little splash of vinegar.)   Crisp Red Cabbage Salad Serves 3-4 | Prep 10 minutes | Meld 20 minutes | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: half head fresh red cabbage 1/2 cup fresh parsley leaves, minced (about 2 tablespoons) juice of 1 medium lemon (about 2-3 tablespoons) pinch coarse (granulated) garlic powder a few sprinkles salt and ground black pepper 2-3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil Directions: 1. Slice the cabbage on a mandoline slicer set to the thinnest setting; you can also grate it in a food processor or cut it with a knife. The idea is to get it cole-slaw thin. Place in a large bowl. 2. Add the minced parsley, lemon juice, garlic powder, salt, and pepper to the cabbage. Toss with your hands, squeezing the lemon juice into the cabbage. Drizzle the olive oil over the top and mix again. 3. Allow the flavors to meld at room temperature before eating, about 20 minutes. Taste and add more salt, pepper, and/or lemon juice if it needs it. Devour! This lasts in the fridge 2-3 days, then the flavors become muted. If it loses its oomph before you can eat it all raw, toss it in a skillet with some browned ground beef or lamb and stir-fry until everything is hot and caramelized. It's a great last-minute, one-pot meal.

Sheet1.Title: Chinese Slow-Cooker Pork Ribs
Sheet1.Meta Description: Chinese five-spice powder adds Asian flair to slow-cooker pork ribs for fall-off-the-bone meat that's flavorful and tender.
Sheet1.Content:
Super easy, crazy delicious

This is going to seem like an odd thing for a cookbook author to say, but sometimes I just really can't bear to make dinner. Don't get me wrong! I love to play around in the kitchen, I just don't want to spend all my free time doing it. On those days, recipes like this one are super helpful. The slow cooker does all the work here, my friends! Just rub some spices on a good-quality meat, plop it in the slow cooker, and relax until it's done. Magic! This recipe relies on Chinese five-spice powder to give it a bold flavor. A blend of star anise, cloves, cinnamon, Sichuan pepper, and ginger, Chinese five-spice adds a decidedly Asian flair to pork ribs. They taste great over a bed of Oven-Roasted Cauliflower Rice, and the leftovers make a delicious Faux Pho when you toss 'em in a bowl with bone broth and hearty greens like bok choy or kale.   Chinese 5-Spice Slow-Cooker Pork Ribs Prep 2 min. | Cook 6-12 hours in slow cooker Ingredients: 3-4 pounds baby back or St. Louis pork ribs salt and ground black pepper 2 teaspoons Chinese five-spice powder 3/4 teaspoon coarse (granulated) garlic powde 1 fresh jalapeño, cut into rings 2 tablespoons rice vinegar 2 tablespoons coconut aminos or homemade substitute 1 tablespoon tomato paste Directions: 1. Cut the ribs into pieces that will fit standing up in the slow cooker. Lay the ribs on a cutting board and sprinkle generously with salt and pepper. In a small bowl, mix the Chinese five- spice and garlic powder together, then massage onto the meat to coat the ribs. 2. Toss the jalapeño rings into the bottom of the slow cooker, and add the rice vinegar, coconut aminos, and tomato paste. Stir until the tomato paste is combined with the other liquids. Add the ribs, standing up so they’re not lying in the liquid – or use a roasting rack inside the cooker so the ribs are not lying on the bottom – cover, and cook 6 hours on high or 8-10 hours on low. 3. When the ribs are fall-apart tender, remove them from the cooker. Pour the liquid into a heat-proof container and refrigerate until the fat separates from the juices. Remove the fat and bring the remaining liquid to a boil, then simmer for a few minutes. Use as a dipping/drizzle sauce for the meat. 4. Want ‘em crispy? Throw the ribs in a 400F oven for 10 minutes while you boil the sauce.

Sheet1.Title: 3 Tips to Ensure You Crush That Next Workout
Sheet1.Meta Description: It's 3:00. You just got out of work. You're tired, exhausted, and drained. You planned to go to the gym at 4:00; Adopt these 3 fitness habits made easy.
Sheet1.Content:
Fitness Habits Made Easy

It's 3:00. You just got out of work. You're tired, exhausted, and drained. You planned to go to the gym at 4:00. You still have to go home, change up, eat a pre-workout snack, and then get going. Just the thought of merely getting ready to go to the gym makes you sleepy. Does this sound familiar? If it does, it may be a result of poor planning. Even though you may have "planned" to work out, did you really plan it, or was it a thought in the back of your mind? Everyone leads a busy lifestyle. There's lots of other, sometimes more important, things on our mind that can hinder our desire and ability to work out. Fortunately, there are some ways to combat this mindset and get yourself 100% prepared to tackle your next workout. 1. Plan your schedule as early in advance as you can. Write out your workout schedule early to ensure that you won't bail on your health. Write out the workouts you are planning on completing the week before, with the exact time you will be doing them. If you are unable to plan ahead that early, write it down a few days or the day before. By writing down your fitness schedule, you are less likely to skip it. Think of it as a business meeting: if you write it down, and schedule it at a convenient time, don't cancel. You wouldn't cancel an important meeting, so why cancel on a time to improve on yourself? 2. Decide your location. Will you work out from home, or will you go to your gym? Be specific about your location. If you will stay at home, figure out what, exactly, your workout is going to consist of. If you're going to head to the gym, decide if you will take a class, hop on a machine, or take a swim in the pool. The more specific you are, the better planned you will be. 3. Pack your bag. If you are going to the gym for your workout, pack a gym bag with your essentials, including a pre-workout snack if needed. This will save a trip home because you will already have everything you need. If you are going before work, pack clothes and shower necessities as well. If you are working out from home, pick out your clothes the night before. That way, instead of having to waste time picking out clothes, you will be prepared to change quickly and get the workout started. By following these three golden rules, you will be more likely to follow your workout routine the way you want. By planning ahead of time, you avoid spending time thinking about it and mulling it over before it becomes something you skip. Spending more time planning beforehand results in success at the gym or at home.

Sheet1.Title: Must See Coaching on Paleo for Endurance
Sheet1.Meta Description: Nell Stephenson discusses the benefits she's seen using Paleo for Endurance in her own life and among her clients. This article is a must see on nutrition.
Sheet1.Content:
Do you Run Triathalons, Marathons, or even 5Ks? Paleoista talks brass tax...

Over the years, I’ve had the chance to work with clients from every walk of life, from those in the process of recovering from illness to those striving for a lifelong weight loss goal. The fact that all of us can improve our health by following the same common sense way of eating, regardless of our background illustrates how significant what we put in our bodies and how healthy, or not, we are, really is. One of my favorite demographics to work with is those who share the love of the same sport as I do: Ironman Triathlons. I began racing long course in 2001 and it wasn’t until four years later than I learned about Dr. Cordain’s work as well as the collaboration he’d undertaken with Joe Friel, which resulted in The Paleo Diet for Athletes (Rodale, 2005). Up until then, despite having tried nearly every sports nutrition product in the media as well as several popular diets, including Vegan, Blood Type and The Zone, not even the best training regime and what I thought was a sound nutrition plan ever seemed to do the trick of fueling me, keeping me lean and avoiding gastric distress. Once I learned about the Paleo Diet, began incorporating it into my own life and felt firsthand how powerful it was, I simply had to begin sharing the information with my clients. Paleo for Endurance had tangible benefits for myself and my athletes. I didn’t get there in one fell swoop; in fact, I was just gluten-free for a year prior to embarking on my Paleo regime in 2005. But once I learned about True Paleo, and I became a faster athlete who could recover better, perform at a higher level than I ever dreamed, rarely experienced any sort of sickness and witnessed better sleep and recovery than ever before, there was no going back. As I began counseling clients on how to implement Paleo into their lives and saw changes they demonstrated, I became more and more passionate about teaching as many people as possible about this way of eating and living. Admittedly, back then I was probably a bit too dogmatic, but for no other reason than I knew how much benefit there was to be gained from it. I have learned along the way, however, that this is not necessarily the best approach and it can actually put people off if they feel the only approach is all or nothing. While I still whole-heartedly believe that we all do have so much to gain from following this regime at a 100% commitment level, the reality is that even small steps in that direction demonstrates positive change. There are grey areas, both with regard to food choices and situations. To present Paleo as all or nothing, I learned, would imply that when one is in a challenging situation, there’s no choice but to cave (pardon the pun) and go with a low quality food choice. To that end, I began to be a bit more open minded for foods that may not actually be freshly picked, freshly caught or freshly hunted. In other words, there’s a time and a place for something that may be a step or two away from that now and then. As an athlete, I’m always interested in what the new products are on the market and how they might be just what I’ve been looking for. So when I learned about AMRAP, which presented itself as a Paleo friendly bar, I was thrilled. Even more so because, to my knowledge, it was the first one out there that actually was Paleo! I’d seen a few others, but since they were made with pea and rice protein, I wasn’t exactly interested in testing them out. It really is a viable option and I’ve now got many athletes using them for their travel-related races as well as recovery when real, fresh food isn’t an option. And while it may sound like I’m writing this post just to sell a little AMRAP, I’m not. I wanted to support one of the first products I learned about that helps to further what a well rounded, True Paleo approach is all about. For me, and for many of my clients, lifelong balance and staying on track includes sometimes choosing an option that is simply the one that makes the most sense given the situation at hand. The message is not ‘eat lots of bars every day’ but rather, to know which options that call themselves Paleo, and now, there are far too many that are so far from it, it’s hard to see how they can use the word, really are, and to support what they’re doing.

Sheet1.Title: Why Diets Fail and How to Make Yours Work
Sheet1.Meta Description: why diets fail and how to make yours work begins with understanding the difference between a diet and lifestyle. Longterm health is scalable and permanent.
Sheet1.Content:
Longterm Health is Scalable; Your Food Template Makes the Difference.

The problem with dieting these days is that people tend to interpret it as cutting down drastically on food intake so that they can lose excess fat and look lean and slender. Everyone wants a healthy body but most of them take the wrong route and end up being bulimic or anorexic. Neuroscientist Sandra Aamodt has now defined clearly as to why dieting is a bad idea and will cause more damage than get fruitful results.   The problem with dieting There is a clear reason why diets fail. Dr. Aamodt describes how she started dieting at the age of 13 and continued to try different kinds of diets for the next few years. In the middle of all this, she did lose weight only to gain it back again, thus leaving her stupefied as to where she could have gone wrong. The equation was simple – you eat right and then burn it off accordingly. Sandra later figured out that hunger and energy is governed by the brain, which essentially decides what your body weight should be. You can alter your lifestyle to lose weight, but the system works like a thermostat – it regulates the signals in the brain that tell your body to gain weight and those that direct the body to shed off pounds. No matter what you do, the brain will always push the body back to the weight that is considered to be appropriate. The problem occurs when the brain is set to a new normal weight. For example, if you have temporarily gained 10 pounds and you don’t lose it for a couple of years, the brain thinks that is your normal weight now. So a sudden gain in weight can also cause problems.   What is the solution? The bottom line is diets are not reliable at all because there is a 90% chance that you will gain back the exact same weight you had lost, and perhaps even more. Combat this issue using a scientific technique by being mindful of what you eat. Listen to your body when it signals for hunger and learn to control your eating so you can stop when you feel full. It might take some time before you can correctly understand what your brain is trying to tell you regarding food habits, but it is the only way to live life in a healthy and happy manner. Eat regular nutrient-rich meals without getting distracted – your appetite shouldn’t be toyed with in any way! AMRAP offers paleo bars, meal recipes, and easy snack ideas for on-the-go nutrition your body can feel good about.
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | Lifestyle Design | Paleo Recipes | Rant/Rave

Sheet1.Title: 1 Quick Alternative to Your Morning Caffeine Kick
Sheet1.Meta Description: You need coffee healthy alternatives to maintain your energy levels and prevent the risks of over-caffeinating your body. This 1 alternative is your answer.
Sheet1.Content:
You Need Coffee Healthy Alternatives

By the end of this article you’ll be taking the coffee iv drip out of your arm. To work, train, study, and play at our hardest, we drink coffee, and there is sound logic behind it. It is widely accepted that any effects of coffee consumption on sports performance are linked to the caffeine in coffee, rather than to coffee per se. Caffeine is widely understood to be an ergogenic aid i.e. a substance that improves the capacity to do work or exercise. That said, you are likely overdoing it with your morning caffeine intake. Understand the benefits of coffee in the right doses, and use our kickass alternative energy tip to awaken your body.   Benefits of Coffee Clearly not all coffees are created equal. The liquid candy lattes with whip cream won’t give you the benefits that simple coffee can afford, and the latter is what we’re talking about. In small quantities, caffeine from coffee or tea has been linked with increased endurance during workouts and an overall ability to work and exercise with less perceived exertion. Researchers will quickly point out that in higher doses, coffee and the caffeine within it does not improve energy or physical capacity. It does not behoove you to chug gallon after gallon. You’re likely hurting your efforts to live an active lifestyle.   Risks of Coffee Coffee might help you power through a workout or a meeting, but that flip side to caffeine overuse is downright miserable. I’ll say again that caffeine in high doses does not enhance athletic performance any further than low to moderate intake. In fact, if you are overdoing it and your morning coffee bleeds over into lunch and cocktail hour, you’ll likely start feeling--
  • Restlessness
  • Insomnia, and
  • Anxiety
  Recommended Daily Dose Americans drink a shit-load of coffee and tea, but mostly coffee. It sustains us, but with any health advice, people should drink coffee or team in moderation, as too much of a good thing can be…well dangerous. Follow this rule of thumb for your moderating your caffeine intake:
  • 400 MG for men (No more than 4 cups of coffee)
  • 300 MG for women (roughly 3 cups or less).
  So where do you find the other 2 cups of caffeine you've just cut out? I’m glad you asked.   Greatist has a 15 minute, a.m. routine that centers the mind, balances the body, and jolts you awake with more lasting energy than a spike of caffeine can provide. This is beginner friendly feel-good poses that lift your spirits, activates your joints, and lengthens your spine. The combined effect of this 15-minute series will leave you revitalized for the day ahead. [embed]http://youtu.be/lJi17P7iKNM[/embed]

Sheet1.Title: Winter Vegetable Soup
Sheet1.Meta Description: Butternut squash, potatoes, and exotic spices combine to make a Winter Vegetable Soup with a velvety texture and a big dose of good nutrition.
Sheet1.Content:
Delicious, Comforting Recovery Food

Soup is a luscious way to get extra vegetables into your day, and this one — with carb dense veggies like butternut squash and potatoes — is wonderful for a post-workout recovery meal. I also like this for breakfast, topped with an egg fried in ghee or leftover roast chicken. This soup is made slightly exotic with spices inspired by the cuisine of Persia, and the addition of a few potatoes gives it a velvety texture. This recipe is ridiculously easy to make, so it's equally great for weekday meals or a fancy dinner party. Because it has a tomato base, this Winter Vegetable Soup will taste even better on the second and third day than it does on the first, and the spices mellow over time. Winter Vegetable Soup Serves 10-12 | Prep 20 minutes | Cook 90 minutes | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: Soup: 2 tablespoons ghee or other cooking fat 2 pounds butternut squash, peeled, seeded, chopped into 1-inch cubes 2 medium onions, coarsely diced 3 cloves garlic, minced 1 pound organic white potatoes, peeled and cut into 1-inch chunks 4 teaspoons ground cumin 2 teaspoons ground paprika 1/2 to 2 teaspoons Aleppo pepper (or crushed red pepper flakes) 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1 tablespoon salt 1 teaspoon ground black pepper 1 (6 ounce) can tomato paste 6 cups broth (any flavor) Pistachio-Parsley Pesto: 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil 1 cup fresh parsley leaves 1 small clove garlic 2 tablespoons shelled pistachios 1/2 teaspoon lemon juice 1/8 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper Directions: 1. Heat a large soup pot over medium heat. Add fat and allow it to melt, then toss in the butternut squash, onions, garlic, and potatoes. Stir to coat the veggies with the fat and cook, without browning, until the vegetables are beginning to soften and look golden, about 20-30 minutes. You don’t want anything to get brown, so keep an eye on the heat. 2. Add the cumin, paprika, Aleppo pepper, cinnamon, salt, and black pepper to the pot. Stir to combine. Add the tomato paste and cook, stirring occasionally, about 10 minutes. 3. Add the broth to the pot and stir to combine, scraping up any brown bits stuck to the bottom of the pot. Simmer, covered, until squash is tender when poked with a fork, about 20-30 minutes. 4. While the Winter Vegetable Soup is cooking, prepare the pistachio-parsley pesto. Purée all the ingredients — with a blender, food processor, or stick blender — until very smooth. Set aside. (See below for additional, delicious garnishes.) 5. When the soup is done, purée it carefully with a stick blender, blender, or food processor; work in batches, if necessary. When it’s smooth, taste and adjust seasonings. You can add water or broth, 1/4 cup at a time, if it’s too thick. Serve in a shallow bowl and top with your favorite garnishes.

Tasty Garnish Ideas

Winter Vegetable Soup is delicious just the way it is, but if you add a garnish or two, it turns into something really special. Just add a touch of any or all (!) of these on top. In the photo, I used Pistachio-Parsley Pesto and Onion-Raisin Relish, but all of the options listed here are delicious and guaranteed to fight food boredom. Onion-Raisin Relish: Stir-fry half of a onion in 1 tablespoon cooking fat with 1-2 tablespoons raisins until the raisins are soft, and the onion is browned and crisp. Whipped Coconut Cream: Refrigerate a can of coconut milk overnight; Thai Kitchen works really well. When the coconut milk is cold, flip the can upside down and open the bottom with a can opener. Pour off any liquid that’s separated and scoop the thickened coconut milk into the bowl of mixer. Whip on your mixer’s highest setting until the milk is fluffy and has taken on the texture of whipped cream, about 5-7 minutes. (This would be really nice sprinkled with crushed pistachios.) Nuts: Plain pepitas or slivered almonds, or crushed pistachios. Or Spicy-Pumpkin-Spiced Pepitas. Herbs: Minced fresh parsley, cilantro, or both with a drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil or a dollop of ghee. Meat (to make it a meal): Browned ground lamb seasoned with salt, pepper, and garlic; or roasted/grilled chicken. Eggs: A perfect fried egg cooked in ghee — or a few chopped hard-boiled eggs. Coconut: Caramelized Coconut Chips

Sheet1.Title: Perfect Hard Boiled Eggs
Sheet1.Meta Description: This technique for perfect hard boiled eggs will give you tender yolks and whites, plus smooth, glossy eggs that peel perfectly every time.
Sheet1.Content:
Perfectly peelable, every time

Is there anything quite as frustrating in the kitchen as watching half the white of a hard-boiled egg stick to the shell as you try to peel your pastured, organic, expensive, nutrition-packed eggs?! I've tried just about every trick there is to make Perfect Hard Boiled Eggs. I placed the eggs in cold water and brought them to a boil like Cook's Illustrated told me to do. I've used older eggs. I've pricked the shells and added baking soda to the cooking water. I've even baked them. But still: the shell stuck to the white and by the time I was done trying to peel them, they looked like someone had already taken a few bites. Then my husband Dave forwarded me a blog post outlining a technique that promised to work: lower the cold eggs into boiling hot water. It sounded crazy, but I gave it a try — and it works every time. Perfect Hard-Boiled Eggs Ingredients: organic, pastured, humanely-raised eggs water Directions: 1. Place a large pot of water on high and bring it to a rolling boil. The pot should be big enough to comfortably hold the number of eggs you're cooking and enough water to cover them by about an inch or two. 2. Use a large ladle or spoon to lower the eggs into the boiling water, one at a time. Place them gently in the pot so they don't crack. (If they do crack, no biggie. But let's not crack our eggs too soon.) 3. Reduce the heat on the pan to simmer and cook for 11 minutes for hard-boiled, 9 1/2 minutes if you want the yolks to still be a little gelatinous. Set a timer. 4. While the eggs are simmering, prepare an ice bath. You need to shock those eggs! Fill a large bowl with plenty of ice and cold water. Wait for the timer to go off. 5. When the eggs are finished, remove them from the pot with a slotted spoon and lower them into the ice bath. Let them chill out for at least 15 minutes, but you can forget about them for a while, if you want — or put the bowl in the fridge over night. 6. When you're ready to peel the eggs, crack the shells all over; you want lots of little cracks! Then use your fingernails to start peeling. They should be smooth, glossy, and ready to be devoured. Voila! Perfect hard boiled eggs. (Maybe you should make some Scotch Eggs!) NOTE: It's best to keep eggs unpeeled until you're ready to eat them or use  them in a recipe. Unpeeled hard-boiled eggs can be stored in the refrigerator for about a week. If you get silly and accidentally peel all your hard-boiled eggs before you're ready to eat them, don't panic! They can be stored in the fridge in an open bowl of cold water for about a week (change the water daily) or in a sealed container without water for a week.

Sheet1.Title: How to Use Paleo to Balance Your Blood Sugar Levels
Sheet1.Meta Description: Food that spikes blood sugar levels and is void of proper nutrition incites serious concern as obesity and diabetes levels rise. See how Paleo addresses it.
Sheet1.Content:
Find a Balance with Bio-available and Low Glycemic Foods. Here's How...

I’ve decided to approach the topics of the Paleo Diet, also known as the caveman diet and paleolithic diet and how this relates to low glycemic, or man’s blood sugar. How has man’s health been affected? These are topics that directly address man’s ills and physical betterment through the Paleo Diet and low glycemic control. In my research and experiences on my quest to impart more truth concerning greater health and longevity, I’ve explored a variety of diets and health regimens. It has never become so clear to me how much our health and quality of life are dependent upon the food we eat, since seeing in myself and in my family the transformative results just from eating a biologically appropriate diet, the Paleo diet, which is grain-free and thus gluten-free and legume free. This also translates into a low glycemic diet as well. Some have named this simple diet the caveman diet, the paleolithic diet and what-have you, but in essence it has been deemed “man’s original” diet.” So yeah, yeah, there are twenty different ways to describe it, but what will this unique approach to food teach me?  

Paleo Diet's effect on insulin and blood sugar

The paleo diet is based on the premise that humans do best when eating the foods our ancestors ate prior to the advent of agriculture and animal husbandry in 10,000 B.C. This proven theory is that modern humans do best on paleolithic nutrition because human genetics have largely remained the same since the preagricultural era, and thus our genetic makeup is best suited to the ancestral human diet. Taking our current bodily structure and feeding it the ancestral human diet is having profound effects on the general health and wellbeing of those participating in studies, not to mention the fact that this diet has a much lower glycemic impact on our blood sugar. According to research, pre-agricultural humans were free of the diseases of the civilized world such as cardiovascular disease, cancer, obesity, and autoimmune diseases. Modern studies, including clinical studies, have shown as well that eating paleo can help or reduce the risk of a variety of serious health conditions. This includes issues associated with high insulin and blood sugar levels, which can lead to a variety of diseases and health conditions such as hypertension, high cholesterol levels, obesity, type 2 diabetes and gout. That’s because many or most foods on the paleo diet are low-glycemic, which is evidenced in the ills that paleo dieters are void of; ills that are now classified as “normal” or aging. Grains are biologically similar to table sugar, causing an unhealthy spike in insulin upon consumption. Most of the carbohydrates consumed on the paleo diet, consisting of vegetables and fruits, are low-glycemic. Honey, maple syrups etc. are debatable and this is another topic all together.

What’s the big deal about the Glycemic Index?

According to studies, a low-glycemic diet can help with obesity, type 2 diabetes, polycystic ovarian syndrome, cardiovascular disease and other conditions. Some of the benefits of low glycemic eating include: improved weight loss, decreased hypoglycemia, steadier moods, and reduced food cravings, which means less binging. This also means less overweight children with early onset diabetes which is a growing concern. It is to our benefit that we all take a good look at our diets. Let’s determine if what we are eating could be causing health conditions which could possibly be reversed or avoided should we be willing to entertain the idea of change. The change could be as simple as taking a sincere look at man’s original diet, the diet we were biologically designed to live on. Could this be a door we need to open, and step in with our eyes wide open? Tina Turbin Featured Image: Paleoleap.com
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | Lifestyle Design | Nutrition Hacks

Sheet1.Title: How Can Guest Blogging for AMRAP Nutrition Overturn Obesity?
Sheet1.Meta Description: Guest blogging for AMRAP Nutrition gives you the platform to share insights you've learned on becoming better athletes and healthier humans.
Sheet1.Content:
Trainers, Gym Owners, Food Writers, Happiness Aficionados, Registered Dieticians---Let your expertise do the most good.

We're not even being overly dramatic. In one generation the tobacco industry worked together to make cigarettes both strong and sexy - why can't we do this with nutrition? The future that AMRAP Nutrition is helping to build is one where kids feel cool showing up to class drinking green spinach smoothies. The idea that fat accountants are one in the same will be overturned with our renewed focus on the basics of health, fitness and nutrition for optimal athletic performance. We get it--paleo protien bars are not sexy... there is nothing exciting about selling almond butter... but what is sexy is health and the power of education to change an overweight society. The past decades of low-cal, low-fat lies have brought our society from 10% obesity in 1985 to a wild 74% in 2013. ... and we need your help to bring it down. If you find that you are often the most fit, influential and knowledgeable in your social circles when it comes to health and fitness, then we want to partner with you. Guest writing for AMRAP Nutrition gives you the platform to share insights you've studied on becoming better athletes and healthier humans. Share your knowledge, and be the role model you want the next generation to follow, and together we will create the change we want to see. Let us unite with the one common goal of reducing obesity to 10% by 2050.   Lend us your writing expertise, and we'll repay you generously. I'm not talking about poor content thinly disguised as linking building schemes to boost your website's Google ranking (that doesn't work anyways). That won't fly here. I'm talking to those of you who want to deliver quality information for the betterment of real people--our readers. Are you clapping and smiling because this is the social impact you've been looking for in businesses and you have a willing voice to contribute? Perfect; say no more. Click Here to Submit your Guest Writer Application of Interest  I also invite you to email me today at media [at] amrapusa [dot] com with any questions or feedback. I will respond to every email from you. Stay healthy, keep happy. Emily Border

Sheet1.Title: What to Expect from Against All Grain Cookbook
Sheet1.Meta Description: Against all grain cookbook is more than just a bunch of recipes thrown together. If new to Paleo or suspicious of grain-free diets practicality, read on.
Sheet1.Content:
Can You Share Joy in a Grain-Free Lifestyle?

If you just began a Paleo or grain-free lifestyle and are looking for a resource that not only provides a breakdown of the most important things you need to know but also gives you complete, well-balanced meals, Against All Grain: Delectable Paleo Recipes to Eat Well and Feel Great may be your ticket to stay on track. Written by Danielle Walker, this cookbook is more than just a bunch of recipes thrown together. It offers insight into a grain-free, Paleo lifestyle, and tells you exactly what you need to know in order to ditch the grain for good.  

Can you relate to grain-related digestion woes?

After Walker describes firsthand how the Paleo diet virtually eliminated almost all of her digestion issues she was facing, she goes on to provide readers with a “roadmap” of foods to eat, foods to avoid, and additional reading material to check out. She then gives readers more information on tips for maintaining a new healthy lifestyle as well as detailed descriptions of many of the ingredients and equipment featured in the recipes she uses. These sections are crucial to the overall practicality of the book because it provides readers with important background information that is necessary in order to truly see how beneficial this lifestyle is.  

My husband doesn't eat Paleo. Will he like this?

The recipes themselves are fantastic. Not only are they organized by meal type; they are labeled based on your specific dietary needs. Walker categorizes each recipe as being egg-free, nut-free, a specific carbohydrate diet, and/or vegan. That way, not only are you choosing a dish that’s Paleo-friendly, but you can also customize a unique meal plan based on your own health preference. Personally, the berries and cream breakfast recipe and the basic cauli-rice side dish recipe were two of my favorites!  

I need more than a cookbook, I need a meal survival guide. How does this help?

After the grand selection of recipes, there are some great resources that Against All Grain cookbook provides in the back of the book. One section, titled “Menu Suggestions,” offers sample menus of recipes that pair well together for special events. For example, the “Light Ladies’ Luncheon” menu consists of the curried chicken salad, the summer island salad, and the currant scones with the rosemary-blueberry smash beverage. These menu suggestions show that Walker takes pride in her work and offers readers small details to make their lives a little more organized and a little easier.  

How will my health change by following this book?

Another section, titled “Success Stories,” details the gratitude that many of her fans felt after trying recipes in Against All Grain cookbook and seeing a health change in themselves or someone they love. This section really gives personality and meaning to the book. This book is not a simple recipe resource for someone who wants to cook with good health in mind—Walker has changed people’s lives and the way they look at food, which is not an easy feat.

What do you think as an athlete and busy human being?

All in all, I really enjoyed this book. I felt like I gained a wealth of knowledge about living a grain-free lifestyle that I may not have gotten from an ordinary cookbook. Walker breaks down the barrier of the traditional cookbook by offering a dose of personalization and a lot of flair to go with it. This book is not only a resource that provides you with nutritious and delicious recipes; it delivers important health facts and useful tips to go along with it. Walker states, "I hope this book will be a medium to share my healing journey with a greater population that I could ever have reached with my blog, as well as make the transition to a grain-free diet enjoyable." That is one of the most important aspects of the book. To make your journey enjoyable.

Without joy, how can you possibly make it a lifestyle?

Walker truly shines in her ability to create a book that is not only accessible, but adaptable to your life. But that is just one girl's opinion. Read for yourself.

Sheet1.Title: What is 6x stronger than coconut oil? MCT oil
Sheet1.Meta Description: Athletes sometimes use MCTs for nutritional support during training, as well as for decreasing body fat and increasing lean muscle mass.
Sheet1.Content:
MCT Oil on the Rise. Here's Why... 

I started out using coconut oil when I shifted into the Paleo diet, then switched to using Bulletproof Upgraded MCT Oil. I am really happy I have discovered Bulletproof and some of his products. I have my family on the oils and we have been using my version of Bulletproof coffee, as well as his, using ghee. MCT is not just a Bulletproof product. You can buy MCT oil in many stores and online but the strength will need to be researched. Today, however, you can gain a better understanding of what MCT oil is, how it might benefit you, and how I've used it to achieve a better body. To start, Dave, the founder of Bulletproof Exec. site promotes that his Upgraded MCT oil is 6x stronger than coconut oil when it comes to providing medium chain triglyceride free fatty acids. It is a refined version of coconut oil made from coconut and/or palm kernel. Upgraded MCT is 100% Capric and Caprylic Acid. Capric acid is a medium-chain fatty acid found in saturated fats. Small amounts are present in cow’s milk and goat’s milk, but it is abundant in tropical oils such as coconut oil and palm kernel oil. Capric acid, together with other medium-chain triglycerides, is responsible for the health benefits attributed to coconut oil. MCT Oil can cause some interesting side effects such as diarrhea, vomiting, irritability, nausea, stomach discomfort, intestinal gas, essential fatty acid deficiency, and other side effects. Taking MCTs with food may reduce some of these side effects. Interesting MCT Tid Bits:
  • Athletes sometimes use MCTs for nutritional support during training, as well as for decreasing body fat and increasing lean muscle mass. I find it REALLY helps lean me out when I want that!
  • MCTs are a fat source for patients who cannot tolerate other types of fats.
  • Researchers also think that these fats produce chemicals in the body that might help fight Alzheimer’s disease.
  • People use MCTs as medicine.
  • MCTs are used along with usual medications for treating food absorption disorders including diarrhea, steatorrhea (fat indigestion), celiac disease, liver disease, and digestion problems due to partial surgical removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) or the intestine (short bowel syndrome).
If you are interested in improving your health, you may want to start looking into adding this to your diet. Be sure to also take a look at my eBook page where you’ll find helpful information on improving your health, leaning out and eating clean. Tina Turbin

Sheet1.Title: When Not Eating Breakfast Pays Off
Sheet1.Meta Description: Fasted training transforms athletes' ability to use fat as fuel and achieve better performance in the long term. Begin with workouts less than 1 hour.
Sheet1.Content:
Fasted training for higher performance?

Contrary to popular opinion, a hearty morning breakfast may not be your answer. This is the case among high-intensity and endurance athletes. And there is logical and proven reasons behind training in a fasted state. Here to tell you more about the science of sports performance and the positive results he's witnessed from fasted training is a writer and coach; he is known as "The Bull". An Ultramarathon Champion based in Mexico. Enter Inaki Del La Parra.
If you are the athlete training first thing in the morning:  Wake up early (I mean it!), drink at least 24 ounces of water to ignite your metabolism and cognitive functions and begin the day hydrated. I recommend an espresso, but that is always optional. Then go straight for your workout. What will all this do for you? Establishing this daily practice is a way to train your ability to use fat as fuel and achieve better performance in the long term.

Timing is everything.

I recommend starting to workout fasted with any of your trainings lasting less than 1 hour. And build it up month by month, year by year to a personal maximum, in order to get all the benefits of fasted trainings. Hydration = (fluid + electrolytes) should be a must during all your activity, never cut it down! What you will find with the fasted trainings and with patience is:
  • Mind and body. You will develop a body and a mind capable of working in a more uncomfortable environment. The better you become at training in tough conditions, the better athlete you will be and that is when great athletic achievements take place. Be aware that you have to build this “uncomfortable” way of using fat as fuel step-by-step.
  • Body composition. Your body composition will be easier to maintain, especially if you use the post-workout recovery window to really have some quality nutrition in your system after a fasted workout. There is an ideal window of 15 minutes right after you finish a fasted workout when you have to replace the glycogen reserves and remember to include some protein and fat, as well as fluid levels and sodium that you depleted. Your high quality paleo nutrition comes to a very important role here and I've found simple whole-food bars are ideal for that window in my own coaching and elite athlete experience. For me, AMRAP Bars fit my Paleo nutrition requirements.
  • High performance. After some months of doing regular fasted trainings you will start to observe great effects in your over all health, but most importantly you will see an increase in your energy levels, efficiency in the use of your fat & glycogen reserves while training and you will block any possible GI distress while working hard or even racing!
Remember that your brain is great, it will always try to be as efficient and comfortable as possible in all means: easy and relaxed environment (normally not crossfit, triathlon or any hard-core activity), perfect temperature (not sweating like a pig). Notice that while most people rely on sugar for energy, the sugar-burning state is a stressful one, one in which other processes in your body slow down as part of the fight-or-flight response that sugar is so well suited for. Your mind and body will begin to experience more enjoyable and productive training when fat is used as fuel over carbs. From my own experience of taking up to four gels per hour of long or ultra distance training or racing, I managed to train my body and my mind to perform with ¼ of those carbohydrates in really intense or long races, lasting up to 15 hours. It took me three years to build my fasted trainings from 1 hour to up to 6 hours and with great results. What did it take? Patience, long time, paleo nutrition and fasted trainings--longer and longer ones over time. Is that easy? There is no easy way, there are no silver bullets. How to start? Pure determination and proper nutrition.

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Eating for Endurance- Yams Take Center Stage!
Sheet1.Meta Description: Paleo Eating for Endurance: Yams offer the benefits of eating minimally processed plants without the adverse affects of consuming gluten, soy or dairy!
Sheet1.Content:
Enjoy All the Savory Benefits of Minimally Processed Food

You may be wondering how it’s possible to race long distances while following a Paleo regime, given that the foods we’re taught we absolutely need, such as pasta and bagels, soy protein powder and whey-based recovery drinks, not to mention a vast array of ‘sports nutrition’ items are far from Paleo. All we have to do is remember that we can find what we need in nature, and rely on more natural sources of starch to prepare our muscles for endurance training and racing. Yams and sweet potatoes long ago became my starches of choice; all the benefits of eating minimally processed (as in – cooked) plants with none of the adverse affects of consuming gluten, soy or dairy! When preparing for a big day of training or racing, all we need to do is add some of these foods to our meals and we’ll set ourselves up for a high-octane performance. I’ve included yams or sweet potatoes (depending where I happen to be racing and what is locally available) as part of my Paleo ironman fueling for ten years and they’ve never let me down- keeping me strong all day long and being a key part in being able to continue to improve my performance. Now comes the fun part- how to prepare these tubers? While you can certainly bake or boil them, after a while, these methods may become a bit boring after a while. Below are a couple of alternatives, the second of which is a sneak peak into Pocket Paleo, Workout, my latest book which has 50 recipes all geared towards fueling you for whichever type of training you’ll do, all in Paleo fashion. In keeping with a True Paleo regime, they’re both tasty, healthy options that pair perfectly with your favorite proteins and veggies and fat, which should be the mainstay of your every meal. Enjoy!

Paleoista's Baked Yam Fries

Yams are the starch of choice for the Paleo endurance athlete. A bit of salt is acceptable as well on the Paleo Diet for Athletes. These are a hit every time! Ingredients
  • Two large (8 – 10 oz.) yams
  • 2 tablespoons cold-pressed, extra-virgin olive oil
  • Garlic Powder, to taste
  • Cayenne Pepper, optional
  • Salt & Pepper to taste
Instructions
  1. Preheat oven to broil.
  2. Wash, then slice the yams into ½” thick, by ½” wide by 3-4“ long strips (depending on the size of the yam). Most importantly, keep the size of all the slices the same to ensure even cooking.
  3. Toss well with the oil to ensure the yam pieces are evenly coated, then sprinkle on the garlic powder and cayenne pepper if you'd like some heat.
  4. Place on rimmed baking sheet, lined with a piece of parchment paper (makes for an easy cleanup).
  5. Broil for 10’ on one side, then turn over and broil 10’. Yams are done when easily pierced with a fork. Remove from oven, then sprinkle salt and pepper on top.
  6. Let cool 5 minutes before eating.
  7. These will store quite well in the refrigerator and are perfect for right before or after your endurance workout.
Blue Hawaiian Sweet Potato and Maui Onion Hash One of my favorite things when I head to the Big Island to train or race is to partake of and enjoy the local bounty. Blue sweet potatoes and local onions fit the bill perfectly in this tasty version of hash! Ingredients
  • 8 ounces raw Hawaiian blue sweet potatoes (If available. If not, substitute yams.)
  • 1 large Maui onion (If available. If not, substitute white onion.)
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil
  • Small bunch chives, minced
Instructions
  1. Using a cheese grater, shred raw potato.
  2. Dice onion.
  3. Heat oil in skillet over medium.
  4. Sauté onion until browned, roughly five minutes.
  5. Add shredded potato and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until browned.
  6. Serve on two plates with chives scattered on top.
Enjoy this sneak peek into book three of Pocket Paleo: Workout and get it on Kindle or iTunes today!
Sheet1.Categories: Interesting Other | Paleo Recipes | Performance Advice

Sheet1.Title: 5 Tips to Create a Paleo-Friendly Fridge
Sheet1.Meta Description: You're following a Paleo lifestyle, so what should your fridge look like? Use these smart shopper tips to stock Paleo fridge essentials.
Sheet1.Content:
What Paleo Fridge Essentials Should You Shop For?

Paleo friends out there know that one of the first stops during a grocery store trip is the produce aisle. It's important to have a fridge stocked with essentials when practicing a Paleo approach to health. So, what should you be looking for when searching the supermarket for decent fruits and vegetables? Here are some tips that I use when shopping in my favorite aisle of the grocery store:

  1. When shopping for pineapples, the greener the skin, the tarter the fruit. 

    At least, that's what I've found. I don't like my pineapples that sweet, so when I shop for them, I tend to look for ones that are darker green in color.

  2. The firmer the mango, the better. 

    I'm not a huge fan of soft fruits (it's a texture thing), so I look for mangoes that are firm. I've also found that the firmer mangoes, when peeled and chopped, have a longer fridge life.

  3. The same goes for melon. 

    For honeydew melon and cantaloupe, I buy them firmer. Again, I've found that they last longer in the fridge prepared than the softer ones do. I think they taste better as well.

  4. Grab the celery hearts if you're snacking, and the full bundle of celery if you're cooking. 

    I like buying the celery hearts if I'm going to be eating them raw because they take less time to prepare and typically look more appealing than the full celery. If you're cooking with them in soups or other recipes, buying the bundle of celery can be a better choice. That way, you can utilize the portions that you don't eat by saving them for a vegetable broth.

  5. Buy the bag of regular carrots, not baby. 

    I've always found that the baby carrots retain a lot of water in the bags they come in, which can sometimes ruin them faster than the regular bags of carrots. I like to buy the big bags of carrots for cooking and snacking. I've found that they taste fresher.
Keeping in mind the quality of your produce when shopping can not only result in more delicious fruits and vegetables, but ones that last longer too.
Sheet1.Categories: Health Tips | How To | Lifestyle Design

Sheet1.Title: How Hydration Affects Performance - Part 1
Sheet1.Meta Description: In athletics, hydration is close to an exact science. Learn how hydration affects performance to avoid the mistake of underestimating its role in nutrition.
Sheet1.Content:
The Guide to Really Stay Hydrated 100% of the Time

  When we talk about hydration, we have to think about the following formula:

Hydration = Fluid + Electrolytes (also called minerals)

Especially among competitive athletes, our racing and training hydration-nutrition formula will look something like this:

Performance = Hydration + Carbohydrate + Fat + Protein

If we think about carbohydrate and fat usage, we can certainly train our bodies to use them in different ways, becoming more efficient, for example by using paleo nutrition and fasted trainings as we have discussed before. Still, when it comes to hydration, that is one of the few things in sport science that we cannot minimize or cut back. Unlike the positive benefits of training on a carb deficit, hydration is not an area to skimp and expect athletic progress. Yet, much of the time hydration is underestimated, especially under the focus of performance nutrition. Consider this question for a moment: have you ever reflected on the fact that you can actually move, exercise and even race almost without any food or “proper nutrition”---for an extended time period? Even though your performance goes down abruptly, it is likely that you have slugged through a workout without food. The same does not hold true with fluids. You can’t avoid fluid and electrolyte intake in a very short period of time! Don’t forget that we are made of up to 60-75% of water.  The point I am making is to emphasize the importance of hydration, even over the importance of nutrition. I will simplify and give you straight and sharp information, so you will really understand in a practical way this concept and apply it in a personalized way to yourself as an athlete. By understanding this formula, you will be able to adjust your fluid individual needs and electrolytes depending on your very personal genetics, training and racing conditions. Hydration as nutrition is individual and should be personalized to a maximum to achieve great performance. The basis for hydration is the fluid by excellence: water. And of course electrolytes that come to an important role: sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium. Of these four, the key electrolyte for hydration is sodium. Before talking about our key electrolyte, let’s understand the role of the other three to appreciate our bodies important relationship to electrolytes. 1) Calcium. Your body has vast supplies stored in the bones, which are tapped into when needed. Generally in a well-nourished athlete eating a healthy diet with enough vitamin D to help calcium absorption, calcium deficiency during training or racing is rare. Dietary sources are generally better than supplements. Equally important are weight-bearing exercises, especially for lower impact sports such as cycling and swimming. 2) Magnesium. Prolonged exercise and training with poor diet can lead to depletion, although this is rare to surface in an acute setting. Deficiency can lead to dizziness, fatigue and depression. It is interesting to note that there is no evidence that magnesium supplementation in athletes with normal blood levels offers any benefit in sports performance. However, weightlifters, crossfitters and wrestlers tend to be magnesium deficient and may benefit from oral supplementation. 3) Potassium. Low blood potassium (hypokalemia) is usually due to diarrhea, fasting and taking certain drugs such as long-term diuretics. In sports, hypokalemia is rare. Certain ultra-endurance athletes who generally have a poor solid food diet may be prone to hypokalemia leading to nausea, muscle fatigue and weakness. Supplements should always be taken with caution and on the advice of a doctor. Now, although potassium can help athletes avoid cramps, without added sodium, potassium doesn’t maximize hydration. Now let’s talk about the key electrolyte: 4) Sodium. It is not only the most likely electrolyte to be lost, it is also the most likely to be required during training and racing. Sodium is also essential for transport of water in the body. Your body cannot excrete and move free water-instead it moves with sodium. Low blood sodium in sports is mostly due to the dilutional effects of drinking water or low concentration sports drinks in excess of sweat and urine sodium losses. This condition is also known as Exercise Associated Hyponatremia (EAH). With EAH the athlete experiences weakness, nausea, muscle fatigue and cramping. As sodium levels drop even further and water moves into the brain there may be agitation, seizures and occasionally death. Risk factors for EAH include long (4 hr+) races, slow running pace, female gender, low body weight, pre-race excessive water intake, over-drinking (>1.5 l/hr) during racing and abundance of drinks during the event. So now that we understand this we can further simplify our hydration formula to: Hydration = Water + Sodium Now that you have understood the importance of hydration, and the role of water and sodium, my next article, Hydration for Performance Part 2, will guide you on how to personalize your volume of fluid intake or water needed in your sport activity, as well as the concentration you need of sodium per volume of water you drink while pushing your body to the limit to really stay 100% hydrated at all time!

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Peach-Almond Crisp
Sheet1.Meta Description: This Paleo Peach-Almond Crisp is the perfect dessert for a weeknight or a special celebration. Grab a spoon and indulge a little!
Sheet1.Content:
Fruit and nuts magically become "dessert" in the oven. Grab a spoon!

Sweetened with only the natural sugars in the fruit, this delicious dessert is easy to make and works equally well with fresh and frozen fruit, so you can make it any time of year that you need a little dose of sweet sunshine. It tastes great when you drizzle it with a little coconut milk! The warm fruit and crisp nuts mingle with the creamy, cool coconut milk — it's paradise on a spoon. Or get extra fancy and top it with whipped coconut milk; instructions below. Paleo Peach-Almond Crisp Serves 4-6 | Prep 15 min | Cook 40 min Ingredients: 1 pound peaches (2-3 medium), cut into 1/2-inch dice (about 4 cups) 1/2 teaspoon lemon zest 1/2 tablespoon lemon juice 1/3 cup almond flour or almond meal 4 dried dates, pitted 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 1/8 teaspoon nutmeg 1/8 teaspoon salt 1 tablespoon coconut oil, chilled until solid, then diced 1/4 cup sliced almonds Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 350F. 2. In a medium bowl, mix the peaches, lemon zest, and lemon juice with a wooden spoon. Allow to rest at room temperature while you prepare the topping. 3. Place the almond flour, dates, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt in a food processor. Pulse until combined. Sprinkle the chilled coconut oil chunks over the nuts. Pulse about 10 times, then process on high for 5-10 seconds, until there are no lumps. Pour the topping into a bowl and use a fork to mix in the additional 1/4 cup sliced almonds. 4. For an 8-inch square pan: Pour the fruit into the pan, pressing it gently into place with the back of a wooden spoon. Sprinkle the almond topping over the fruit and lightly press it into the fruit with the back of the spoon. For individual ramekins: Place 4 ramekins on a baking sheet covered with parchment paper. Spoon generous 1/2 cup servings into individual ramekins, pressing the fruit into the ramekin with your hands. Press about 2 tablespoons of topping onto each ramekin. 5. Cover the crisp lightly with foil and bake for 30 minutes. Remove foil and bake 5-10 minutes more, until browned. Serve while warm. Bonus points if you drizzle with chilled coconut milk. Variations: Here are some other fruit and nut combinations that are just as peachy as the peaches: 1/2 pound peaches + 1 pound pitted cherries + sliced almonds 1 pound pears + sliced almonds or chopped walnuts 1 pound apples + chopped pecans 2 pints raspberries/blackberries/blueberries + sliced almonds 2 mangoes + chopped macadamias 2 pints strawberries + chopped pecans Whipped Coconut Cream Ingredients: 1 can full-fat coconut milk 1 teaspoon vanilla extract Directions: 1. Place the coconut milk in the refrigerator and the metal mixing bowl and beater from a stand mixer in the freezer for 1 hour. 2. Remove the mixing bowl and beater from the freezer. Carefully open the can of coconut milk without shaking it, and scoop the thick, coconut cream into the chilled mixing bowl. Add the vanilla extract and beat the mixture on the highest speed of your mixer until it looks like whipped cream. This takes about 5-7 minutes.

Sheet1.Title: Bacon-Jalapeño Meatballs
Sheet1.Meta Description: All the goodness of a burger without the unhealthy bun! Bacon, jalapeño, juicy beef, all topped with a tangy sauce and ready to pop into your mouth!
Sheet1.Content:
All the great taste of a burger, without the annoying bun!

Sometimes you just want a big, ol', juicy burger! And these little meatballs are packed with flavor, no bun required. Smokey bacon and jalapeños add flair to juicy ground beef, and a quick pickle relish and Awesome Sauce take it all into finger-licking good territory. The water, cream of tartar, and baking soda are the trick to making meatballs that are light and fluffy with a nice, snappy skin. Grab a big pile of napkins and dig in!   Bacon-Jalapeño Meatballs w/ Dill Pickle Relish & Awesome Sauce Serves 2-4 | Prep 10 min | Chill 20 min | Cook 25 min | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: Meatballs: 4 strips sugar-free, nitrate-free bacon 1 tablespoon grated onion (about 1/4 medium onion) 1/2 fresh jalapeño, seeds and ribs removed, minced 1 pound ground beef 3/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper 1/4 teaspoon paprika 2 tablespoons warm water 1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar 1/4 teaspoon baking soda Relish: 1/4 cup minced dill pickle 1/4 cup minced raw tomato 1/4 cup minced raw onion Awesome Sauce: 1/3 cup Olive Oil Mayo 1 tablespoon Kickass Ketchup 1 clove garlic, minced (about 1 teaspoon) 1 teaspoon cider vinegar 1/2 teaspoon paprika 1/4 teaspoon ground cumin dash cayenne pepper 1/8 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper Directions: 1. Preheat the oven to 425F and cover a large, rimmed baking sheet with aluminum foil. 2. Cut the bacon crosswise into 1/4-inch wide pieces. Place the chopped bacon in a large, cold skillet, turn the heat to medium-high, and fry the bacon until it’s crisp, about 3-4 minutes. Remove from pan with a slotted spoon and drain on a paper towel. Pour the grease out of the skillet, leaving whatever clings to the pan, and place it back on the heat. 2. Add the onion and jalapeño to the pan and sauté until the jalapeño is soft, 2-3 minutes. Set the pan aside until the veg are cool to the touch. 3. In a large bowl, place the ground beef, salt, pepper, paprika, bacon, and the vegetables from the skillet. In a small bowl or measuring cup, mix the water with cream of tartar and baking soda. Pour into the bowl with the meat and mix until all the ingredients are evenly distributed. Cover and refrigerate at least 20 minutes and up to overnight. Meanwhile… 4. Make the relish. Mix all the minced ingredients together in a small bowl and set aside. 5. Make the Awesome Sauce. Mix all the ingredients together in another small bowl and refrigerate until it’s time to eat. 6. Remove the meat dough from the fridge. Moisten your hands with cold water and shake to remove excess. Measure a rounded tablespoon of meat and roll into a ball between your palms, then gently flatten it a little bit so it’s almost like a mini burger patty (that will make it easy to top with relish later). Line up the meatballs on the prepared baking sheet, about 1/2 inch apart. Slide the meatballs into the oven and bake for 15-20 minutes, until browned and cooked through. 7. Serve immediately, topped with a little relish and a drizzle of Awesome Sauce. These meatballs taste great with Crispy Oven-Baked Sweet Potato Fries, and they cook in the same temperature/same timing. No wonder burgers and fries are a classic combination! Hit this link for more awesome meatball recipes and how-to tips.

Sheet1.Title: On Controlling Success
Sheet1.Meta Description: Focusing on results comes most naturally for us, but unfortunately results are not something we can fully control. Or is controlling success possible?
Sheet1.Content:
What is the Role of Success on Mental Toughness and Enhanced Performance?

We have all heard the saying “focus on what you can control.” Well this is a whole lot easier said than done; however, there seems to be some real value in learning to do so. Focusing on results is what comes most naturally for us, but unfortunately results are not something we can fully control. Or are they? I conducted an informal study where I was examining the relationship between the amount of effort an athlete puts into practice/preparation with the results the athlete has in competition. What I found was quite amazing; 80 out of 96 athletes interviewed said effort in practice / preparation was the single most significant factor in controlling success in competition. To get an idea how your effort level compares with competition results answer the following two questions;
  1. On a scale of 1-10 (where 10 is the greatest effort possible and 1 is almost no effort) how much effort have you put in to your practice/preparation this week?
  2. On a scale of 1-10 (where 10 indicates great results and 1 is far less than desired results) how have your results been in competition(s) this week?
The study suggests that 80% of the time effort level in practice/preparation will be within +/-2 on the results scale. This tells me that a person really can control success, at least 80% of the time, and the best way to do it is to focus on practice/preparation effort. Simply put, if you will make the commitment to go to practices and put great energy into preparing yourself both mentally and physically, then you are doing your best to control results. It won’t always happen, however if you are 9 or a 10 on the practice/preparation effort scale, you will put yourself in a position to increase success. Try to get in the habit of defining your success with the level of effort you put into practice/preparation, and in doing so, you will typically find yourself happier and more successful. Be sure that you are putting the preparation into your mental game as well as your physical game. If you are not doing daily mental workouts, it is definitely something you need to do be doing if you want to mentally be prepared for practices and competitions (to develop your own personalized mental workout check out chapters 1-5 in my book 10-MinuteToughness). Remember being great isn’t easy, it’s not supposed to be easy, but it is your choice. Choose to be great everyday!
Sheet1.Categories: Behavioral Training | Lifestyle Design | Performance Advice

Sheet1.Title: 2015 CrossFit Games Competitor's Roadmap
Sheet1.Meta Description: Whether spectator or competitor, it helps to know what you are in for when you go the CrossFit Games. This your guide as a CrossFit Games competitor.
Sheet1.Content:
Do You Want to Get to the CrossFit Games?

Whether spectator or competitor, it helps to know what you are in for when you go the CrossFit Games. Discover all you need to know about the different stages of the CrossFit Games in 2015--from The Open through the Regional competitions all the way to the CrossFit Games finals. We'll give you the 30,000 foot overview and all the dates to mark in your calendar.

CrossFit Games Online Open Workouts & Dates

Over 200,000 Athletes are expected to take part in the CrossFit Games Open in 2015. 5 Open workouts will be released over 5 consecutive weeks through February & March 15.1 – February 26th 15.2 – March 5th 15.3 – March 12th 15.4 – March 19th 15.5 – March 26th  

CrossFit Games 2015 Regional Dates and Areas

The top 660 Athletes from The Open make it through to the CrossFit Games regional competitions, which are spread out throughout 3 weekends in May

15th – 17th May 2015

South Regional – Dallas, Texas South Central (40 Athletes) South West (40 Athletes) Latin America (20 Athletes)   Atlantic Regional – Atlanta, Georgia Mid Atlantic  (40 Athletes) South east (40 Athletes)  

22nd – 24th May 2015

California Regional – San Diego, California NorCal (40 Athletes) SoCal (40 Athletes)   East Regional – Hartford, Connecticut North East (40 Athletes) Canada East (40 Athletes)   Pacific Regional  – Wollongong, Australia Australia (60 Athletes) Asia (20 Athletes)  

29th – 31st May 2015

West Regional – Seattle, Washington North West (40 Athletes) Canada West (40 Athletes)   Central Regional – Minneapolis, Minnesota North Central (40 Athletes) Central East (40 Athletes)   Meridian Regional – Copenhagen, Denmark  Europe (60 Athletes) Africa (20 Athletes)  

The CrossFit Games Final Date & Ticket Date

As a CrossFit Games competitor, this is the most important week of your year. The final stage of the CrossFit Games will be held between July 21st-26th at the StubHub Centre in Carson, California. The Team & Individual competition will start on the 21st of July 2015. Tickets for the games will go on sale on the 29th April 2015
Sheet1.Image Alt Text: Roadmap to CrossFit Games | Road-To-The-CrossFit-Games-Infographic | CrossFit Games Roadmap

Sheet1.Title: Plantain Nachos
Sheet1.Meta Description: Plantain Nachos combine crisp chips with seasoned taco meat to make any meal a fiesta, and they're loaded with quality carbs and protein power.
Sheet1.Content:
Crispy chips, spicy meat, and no forks required.

  I've fallen in love with plantains, a.k.a., plátanos, so hard that I barely remember my previous fling with corn chips. When you start with green plantains, you get crisp chips that deliver delicious flavor, quality carbs, resistant starch, and — get this — more vitamin C, vitamin A, and potassium than sweet bananas. Take that, corn! I always think of nachos as weekend food, but this recipe comes together in under an hour, so it's great for Fiesta Friday and a random Tuesday. The meat is simmered in Tex-Mex spices and packs a punch, especially if you top it with a squeeze of fresh lime juice and jalapeños. Olé! Plantain Nachos Serves 2-4 | Prep 20 minutes | Cook 30 minutes Ingredients: Plantains: 2 green plantains 1 tablespoon coconut oil, melted Taco Meat: 2 teaspoons coconut oil 1/2 medium onion, minced (about 1/2 cup) 3 cloves garlic, minced (about 1 tablespoon) 2 tablespoons chili powder 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1 teaspoon ground coriander 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano leaves 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper 3/4 teaspoon salt 1 pound ground beef 2 tablespoons tomato paste 1/2 cup chicken broth 2 teaspoons cider vinegar Garnish: minced scallions jalapeño slices diced avocado shredded lettuce chopped tomato fresh lime juice Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 350F. Cover two large baking sheets with parchment paper and set aside. 2. Prep the plantains. Cut off both ends of the plantain, then with the tip of a sharp knife, make shallow slits lengthwise along the skin. Use your fingers to pry off the strips. With a mandoline slicer on its thinnest setting, slice the plantains into coins. Use two wooden spoons to toss the slices in a large bowl with the melted coconut oil. 3. Bake the plantains. Use four coins to make each “tortilla:” Lay them flat on the baking sheet with edges slightly overlapping and sprinkle with salt. While they bake, the natural starches make them stick together. Bake for about 30 minutes until very crisp and beginning to brown. Remove from the oven and sprinkle with additional salt, if you’re feeling it. Meanwhile… 4. Make the taco meat. Heat the coconut oil in a large, non-stick skillet over medium heat, about 2 minutes. Add onion and cook until softened, about 7-10 minutes. In a small bowl, mix the garlic, chili powder, cumin, coriander, oregano, cayenne, and salt. Add to the onions and stir until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Crumble the ground beef into the pan and cook, breaking up the meat with a wooden spoon, until no longer pink, about 5 minutes. Push the meat to the side of the pan and drop in the tomato paste, frying until it darkens a bit, about 3 minutes. Add the chicken broth and vinegar; stir to combine. Bring to a boil, then reduce to simmer and cook, uncovered, 10 minutes, until the liquid has reduced and thickened. Add salt and pepper, to taste. 5. Dig in! Pile the meat on top of the plantain chips and top with your favorite garnishes. Your plantains must be GREEN to make chips. If they turn yellow before you can make the chips, use this recipe for pan-fried yellow plantains instead.

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Muffaletta Salad
Sheet1.Meta Description: A salty-tangy combination of olives, celery, carrots, cauliflower, hot and sweet peppers, and lots of garlic. It's a instant trip to the Big Easy on a fork.
Sheet1.Content:
It's the best parts of the famous New Orleans sandwich.

  The best sandwich shop in New Orleans isn't a sandwich shop at all. It's a grocery store, Central Grocery and Deli, to be exact. The ginormous muffaletta sandwiches they churn out to tourists — piled with Italian cold cuts like ham, mortadella, salami, pepperoni, and capicola, plus provolone and Swiss cheeses — are defined by the relish they serve on top. It's the best salad to ever grace a sandwich, a salty-tangy combination of olives, celery, carrots, onions, cauliflower, hot and sweet peppers, capers, and lots of garlic.
