One day, I had a hankering for a muffaletta, but bread and cheese are decidedly off my menu. Why not, I thought, just eat the best part — the salad! — and forget about the rest. And so this Muffaletta Salad was born. You can eat it on its own, or roll it up in slices of Applegate Farms salami and ham for the closest thing you can get to the Big Easy without leaving your kitchen. Muffaletta Salad Serves 4-6 | Prep 15 min | Cook 20 min | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: 1/2 head cauliflower, coarsely chopped (about 4 cups) 2 medium carrots, chopped (about 1 cup) 2 medium celery stalks, chopped (about 1/2 cup) 3 tablespoons red wine vinegar 1 anchovy fillet, minced (or 1 teaspoon anchovy paste) 3 cloves garlic, minced (about 1 tablespoon) 1/2 tablespoon dried oregano leaves 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme leaves 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil 1/3 cup pimento-stuffed green olives, chopped 1/3 cup pitted black olives, chopped 1 roasted red bell pepper (from a jar or freshly roasted), chopped 1/4 cup jarred, sliced banana peppers, drained and chopped Directions: 1. Steam the cauliflower, carrot, and celery until just tender, about 12-14 minutes. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, use a whisk or fork to mix the vinegar, anchovy, garlic, oregano, thyme, salt, and pepper until combined, then drizzle in the olive oil, whisking constantly. 2. When the veggies are just the way you want them, drain excess water and add the hot vegetables to the dressing in the bowl. Toss with two wooden spoons until coated evenly. Add the olives and peppers, tossing again with the wooden spoons until combined. Taste and add more salt and pepper, if necessary. Place in a covered container in the fridge until cool, then adjust seasonings again. Serve chilled. Note: This tastes even better with age. It’s delicious when you make it and mind-blowingly yummy the second and third days. Believe it. Should the leftovers last long enough for you to grow weary of eating it as a salad, heat it in a non-stick skillet, then drizzle it with a little more extra-virgin olive oil, sprinkle it with a handful of chopped parsley, and serve it as a hot side dish.

Sheet1.Title: Beet Juice, Why Are More People At My Gym Drinking It?
Sheet1.Meta Description: Turns out the high concentrations of nitrates found in beet juice enhance vasodilatation, improves endurance, performance, lowers blood pressure and increases...
Sheet1.Content:
If You Can’t “Beet” ‘Em, Join ‘Em. Why You Should Be Drinking Beet Juice...

You may have been seeing more and more talk about using beets, or more specifically, beet juice, as part of your nutritional protocol to support your training regime. Granted, it makes sense that fresh vegetables would play a role in any healthy eating plan, but what is it about beets that stand out more than other veggies?

Health benefits of beets include:

  • Lowering Blood Pressure
  • Boosting Stamina
  • Cancer- Fighting Properties
  • Rich in Valuable Nutrients and Fiber
  • Anti inflammatory properties
Sounds good so far, but how does this food pertain to fueling an athlete in particular?

It’s all down to the nitric oxide content...

The high concentrations of nitrates found in beet juice enhance vasodilatation, (the capacity of blood vessels to dilate, thus increased blood flow). A few years ago, researchers from Exeter University performed a study in which they recruited nine subjects and gave them either regular beetroot juice or nitrate-depleted beetroot juice to drink every day for six days. They found that consuming regular beetroot juice increased blood nitrate levels and reduced resting blood pressure, reduced oxygen consumption during moderate- and high-intensity exercise and increased time to exhaustion at high intensity by 15 percent (which is a lot).

But how many servings of beets are needed to achieve this?

Can we throw one or two in the Vitamix or Blendtec juicer and meet our high-demand for these valuable nutrients? Juicing fresh beets on a daily basis is one way, but what to do if you’re traveling for a race and in a hotel? Or if you’re about to do an evening session straight after you leave the office? What if you simply don't like the earthy beet taste?

Enter Beet Nitrates from AMRAP Nutrition...

With a natural ingredient label (Non-GMO Beet Juice Concentrate, Electrolyte Blend (Potassium Citrate, Sea Salt, Magnesium Oxide), Stevia, Natural Flavor), a very palatable sweet, non-earthy taste, I tested it for the first time just over a month ago and was pleasantly surprised. As a long time Paleo endurance athlete, I want my diet to consist of as much real food (as opposed to the plethora of junk that we are inundated with in the forms of sports drinks made with corn syrup, energy bars made with gluten and soy powder and recovery drinks made with whey and sucralose), and as little manufactured product as possible. To that end, my own training and fueling has changed considerably over the years. Back when I first began racing triathlon (and I’m dating myself now by sharing that I’m embarking on my 18th season!), I tried pretty much every product out there, from drinks to energy chews to powders to brightly colored gels. As I learned more about why these ‘foods’ were not only not helping me dial in my training and nutrition, but preventing me from reaching the lean body weight I’d been coveting and making me sick at the same time, it became more and more evident that a change was in order, which led me to adapt to the principles of a True Paleo Regime, back in 2005. Even since then, my fueling protocol has changed considerably and I continue to test certain products that pique my interest as they arise. Along with becoming more efficient at using fat as my fuel comes fiddling around with macro nutrient ratios, fasted training and what foods I rely on for recovery. The bottom line for me, as well as many athlete clients with whom I work to developer their nutritional game plan, is to keep it as real as possible, as often as possible. And, just as with my love for AMRAP's paleo nutrition bar, similarly, there is a time and place where their Beet Nitrate formula comes in handy.

My final thought to those wanting to achieve their health, fitness or wellness goals.

The message is not to eat as many bars and powders as you can, but rather to keep your eyes open for which products are introduced that are:
  1. Actually made of real food. Please read your labels. ALL OF THEM!
  2. Have legitimate research behind them. Athletes, chocolate milk! Really??
  3. Make common sense. The 'shake' diet, elimination diets; do those make sense? No!
Does it make sense that a plant would have significant properties to help us train, perform and recover better? I’d say so. Try your own set of experiments and find your own best balance.

References
  • Health Benefits Of Beets - Mercola
  • Beetroot Juice: The Drink Of Champions - Competitor

Sheet1.Title: How Hydration Affects Performance – Part 2
Sheet1.Meta Description: Once you understand how hydration affects performance, learn how to personalize your volume of fluid intake and sodium replacement sweated out in exercise.
Sheet1.Content:
The Guide to Personalize your Hydration

  If you haven't read my first post on hydration fundamentals, catch up here, then come back.... Now that we fully understand that water is the fluid par excellence and that the sodium is the key electrolyte for hydration, I will guide you on how to personalize your volume of fluid intake, as well as the concentration of sodium needed per volume of fluid you sweat while exercising. Determining exactly how much fluid intake you need is quite simple. But to discover exactly how much sodium you need to supplement for that volume of fluid you lose via sweat will require a very specific and unique technology operated by the world leaders in hydration consultancy: Precision Hydration.  

How to determine the volume of fluid you lose while exercising?

First we have to figure out your sweat rates by simply replacing what you lose. The simplest way to do that is to weigh your self before, during and after training or racing and replace each 1g loss with 1ml of fluid. So, for example, 1.1 kg loss would be replaced with 1100 ml of fluid.   It is very important to notice that there is a correlation of temperature, humidity and intensity of the physical activity related to that fluid loss. So don’t be overwhelmed at the start. If you are committed enough, in the long term you will be able to get your fluid intake table at different intensities of training and temperatures.  

How to determine the concentration of sodium you lose per volume of sweat?

The methods described in the scientific literature and those currently in use involve placing patches on various parts of the body and exercising until the patches become saturated with sweat. The patch is then squeezed into a bottle and taken to the lab for analysis.   There is a new-patented technology developed by Precision Hydration that involves inducing a sample of sweat using a chemical called pilocarpine on your forearm. The test takes 20 minutes and does not involve exercising. The sweat sample is collected over a small 2 1⁄2 cm (1 inch) area on your forearm and the saltiness of your sweat analyzed to give a number that is unique to you. That specific number is the concentration of sodium you will need to supplement per volume of fluid you need to replace. Curiosity piqued? Watch this video of the test.   The sweat analysis number is unique to you and is part of your genetic code. The number is relatively fixed although with acclimation humans tend to adapt to their surroundings. Heat acclimation in athletes has shown that with repeated exposure to heat and humidity your body will tend to reduce losses of most sweat electrolytes. There is no change with 7 hours exposure so you are unlikely to need to alter your regime even in a very long race. At 4 days exposure sweat sodium levels will drop by about 18%. By Day 10 as you fully acclimatize the drop will be around 40%. However, your sweat rate will increase by around 6%.  

Recommendations

1)   Please be aware that below 1 hour of exercising you can stick to just water, since there is always a preload of sodium in your body. 2)   Don’t fall into the marketing trap of the sport industry, since they have confused the hydration process with the fueling, recovery process and any other you can think of. 3)   Start working on your drink personalization as you do in your nutrition, it is equally important for your performance.

Sheet1.Title: Detox Plan That Doesn't Leave You Miserable
Sheet1.Meta Description: Guilt has no business ruling your life. Ensure your detox plan is positive and follow these 5 steps for a healthier holiday recovery.
Sheet1.Content:
Binge Eating Isn't Pretty, But This Will Help You Overcome It

  I'm going to admit this, and I'm sure that many can agree: we all have those days where we go off-plan, or even binge eat foods that don't support our healthy lifestyle choices. Rather than beating yourself up about it, just dust yourself off and start fresh the very next day. So if you have enjoyed one too many peanut butter and chocolate eggs over Easter weekend, here are some tips for beating the blues and feeling good about yourself a day after poor choices.
 

  1. Drink plenty of water.

    If you ate foods high in salt or sugar, you may feel dehydrated. Drink plenty of water the next day to avoid feeling sluggish or woozy.

  2. Exercise, even if you feel uncomfortable. 

    When I eat the wrong foods, my body physically hurts the next day. I may have a stomachache or other body aches. Even though my mind is telling me it's the last thing I want to do, when I get up and move the day after eating unhealthy, even if it's low-impact, I feel so much better afterwards. Burning a few calories can really help ease the bloat-y feeling you may experience.

  3. Don't fast, but eat less than you typically do. 

    I always feel more balanced when I eat less the day after I've eaten way more than I should have. If you repeat the cycle a second day, you'll feel even worse and it'll be that much harder to get back on track after multiple days off-plan. Eat what your body needs, but don't overeat a second day.

  4. Reflect on your choices, on what you did well and what you could have done better. 

    We all have these days, which is perfectly okay! But I find that it's beneficial to reflect on my choices, good and bad. Was I eating because I was hungry, or because the food was tempting? What could I have done better? What was something that I was really proud I was able to avoid? What was something I'm grateful that I accomplished? I like to reflect on my choices, because it may give me a better insight into the situation and what I could do better next time.

  5. Don't beat yourself up. 

    I mean it! It's no use to sit around and wallow in what you should have, could have, or would have done if the day could somehow be repeated. Just reflect on the day in a positive way, and move on. We all make mistakes, and frankly, we all need a day where we don't hyper focus on eating healthy food. Sometimes you need a break! THAT IS OKAY. The worst thing you can do is beat yourself up over one day, especially if you've had more than one day of successful choices.
  The reality is that we fumble, indulge, overeat, but I have found that as I use these tips during my post-holiday recovery, I feel better faster. Guilt has no business in your life. Ensure your detox plan is positive, venture forward and soon you'll be back on track with your health and fitness goals.

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Pad Thai
Sheet1.Meta Description: Made from ingredients you probably already have in your fridge, this paleo pad thai is creamy, nutty, delicious, and packed with powerful nutrition.
Sheet1.Content:
Even better than takeout. I promise.

Back in the day, there was nothing that removed the stress of a long day at work, than to pick up the phone and order takeout. It was so soothing to eat Chinese or Thai food out of those cardboard cartons, feet propped on the coffee table with a John Hughes movie playing on the TV. But those days are over! No more crappy takeout for me — or for you! This pad thai recipe has the mouth-feel of the original, without the extra sugars, soy, peanuts, and rice noodles that make it a nutritional minefield. My recipe is based on already-cooked ingredients — roasted spaghetti squash, cooked chicken thighs, and creamy-nutty-irresistible Sunshine Sauce made with sunflower butter — so it comes together faster than takeout if you've got the raw materials in the fridge. I recommend a cookup when you're not tired that includes chicken thighs, Sunshine Sauce, and spaghetti squash. That way, when you are tired, you can stir-fry this meal together in about 10 minutes. If you're really in a pinch, you can substitute rotisserie chicken for the home-cooked chicken, or get creative and swap zucchini noodles for the spaghetti squash. This also works equally well with leftover pork, beef, or shrimp. Paleo Pad Thai Serves 2 | Prep 15 minutes | Cook 5 minutes | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: 1 batch Sunshine Sauce 2 large eggs 2 teaspoons coconut aminos (or homemade substitute) 2 teaspoons plus 1 teaspoon coconut oil 1/2 medium onion, thinly sliced (about 1/2 cup) 1 cup snap peas, thinly sliced lengthwise 2 cups roasted spaghetti squash 6-8 ounces cooked chicken thighs, diced garnishes: chopped toasted cashews or almonds sunflower seeds sliced scallions minced cilantro squeeze of lime juice Directions: 1. Crack the eggs into a small bowl, and use a fork to scramble them with the coconut aminos. Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat, about 3 minutes. Add 2 teaspoons coconut oil to the skillet, and when it’s melted, pour in the eggs and let them spread like a pancake. Reduce the heat to medium and cover with a lid, letting the eggs cook until they’re set and beginning to brown on the bottom, about 3-4 minutes. Flip and lightly brown the other side. Remove the eggs from the pan and cut into strips with a sharp knife. 2. Using the same pan, increase heat to medium-high and add 1 teaspoon coconut oil to the pan. Sauté the onion and snap peas, stirring with a wooden spoon, until they’re crisp-tender, about 2 minutes. Add the spaghetti squash, chicken, and cooked egg to the pan and, stirring with a wooden spoon, cook until heated through, about 3 minutes. 3. Add the Sunshine Sauce to the pan and stir-fry until everything is well-blended and hot. Divide among two plates, sprinkle with garnishes, and dig in. Need tips on cutting your spaghetti squash? Take a look at this video.

Sheet1.Title: Grain-Free Meatza Pie
Sheet1.Meta Description: You'll never miss the crust with this delicious Italian meatza pie. Spicy meat topped with garlicky tomato sauce and your favorite veggies. Mange!
Sheet1.Content:
You don't need no stinkin' crust!

When I was a kid, my mom made a version of this meatza pie that included evaporated milk in the meat crust — to make it creamy?! — and tons of cheese. It was ooey, gooey, stretchy, and — I cannot tell a lie — delicious. But if I ate that now, it would leave me in the fetal position with a cannon ball in my stomach, and my workout the next day would be a disaster. But there was a kernel of a good idea in that 1970s meatza pie recipe: meat as crust! This recipe uses a spicy, sugar-free Italian Sausage Seasoning to give the meat crust a kick, and it's topped with garlicky tomato sauce and your favorite veggies. You can even add Applegate Farms pepperoni if you're feeling feisty. Meatza Pie Serves 2-4 | Prep 10 minutes | Bake 30 minutes | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: Meat Crust: 1 pound ground beef or pork (or a blend of both!) 2 teaspoons Italian Sausage Seasoning Sauce: 1 teaspoon olive oil 1 clove garlic, minced (about 1 teaspoon) 1 teaspoon Pizza Seasoning (or dried oregano) 3 ounces tomato paste (1/2 can) 1/4 cup water Toppings: 1/4 cup steam-sautéed broccoli 1/4 cup steam-sautéed bell pepper strips 10 black olives, pitted and sliced a handful of fresh baby spinach leaves optional: Applegate Farms pepperoni Directions: 1. Preheat the oven to 400F. Mix the ground beef and Italian Sausage Seasoning until combined. 2. Make the meat crust. Divide the meat in half, roll into a ball, and press evenly into an 8- or 9-inch round pie pan. Cover only the bottom of the pan and smooth the meat with damp hands until it’s an even thickness. Repeat with the other piece of “crust.” Bake for 10-15 minutes, until the meat is cooked through and the edges are brown. Leaving the oven on, remove the crusts from the oven and allow to cool in the pan. 3. Make the pizza sauce. Heat a small saucepan over low heat, then add the olive oil, garlic, and Pizza Seasoning, stirring with a wooden spoon until fragrant, about 20 seconds. Add the tomato paste and stir until combined, then stir in the water. Bring to a boil, then simmer uncovered for 5 minutes until thickened. Set aside. 4. Make your meatza. Cover a large baking sheet with parchment paper or aluminum foil and place the meat crusts on the baking sheet. Spread about 1/4 cup sauce on each meat crust, leaving a 1/2-inch border around the edges. Arrange the vegetables on top, pressing them gently into the sauce. Pop the pizza back into the oven for 10-15 minutes, until hot and browned to your liking. Bonus! Drizzle each pizza with 1 teaspoon of extra- virgin olive oil when they come out of the oven. Or if you're feeling like a fiesta, try this Tex-Mex version.

Sheet1.Title: 2 OCR Tactics to Run Smarter not Farther
Sheet1.Meta Description: The main goal during training is to run smarter not farther. If you're busy these short workouts help you gain speed and become a better overall runner.
Sheet1.Content:
Speed and Endurance are not Mutually Exclusive. They go Together.

As an obstacle course racer I get many many questions on how to improve times. And while attacking obstacles are a big part of getting through a course, it’s still a runners game out there. The biggest question I get is how many miles do I run per week? My answer is very few and this usually comes as a surprise to most people. To be completely honest I just don't have the time and most people that have a full time job don't either. If you are training for a marathon or an ultra event you would have a completely different training approach which would include some long runs, but for your typical 5-15k OCR race I don't believe you need all those miles in order to improve. So here is my philosophy on some short workouts that will help you gain speed and become a better overall runner.

Reinvent the Incline Run

My main goal during training is to make my miles count. This means that I want my training miles to be harder than my race miles will be. My three main ways of doing this are: running on hills/incline, carrying something heavy, or sprint work. I am not saying never to go for a long run but for the most part I stick to some short but intense workouts. Speed work is very important for any runner. If you want to be able to hold a faster pace for a longer distance you need to get your body used to running faster even if its for a shorter distance.
[Tweet "Speed work is very important for any runner. You want to hold a faster pace for a longer distance."]
Eventually your body will start adjusting and be able to hold that pace longer and longer. Finding a local track or hitting treadmill for some sprint repeats is a super effective way to gain some speed. I do a variety of distances from quarter mile to full mile repeats. One example is a 10x400m repeat with 10 burpees in between because I train for obstacle course racing. Getting used to the transition of running to obstacle back to running without losing a ton of time is crucial in the sport of OCR.

Pack on the Lbs

Another way to intensify your workouts is to add some weight to your runs. I try to keep my weighted runs on some sort of incline whether a local hill or atreadmill because its going to be a bit easier on the joints. If you have a sandbag or a weight vest you should use them with some hill repeats.Find a good hill that is not to long and do 5-10 repeats with the weight, or use the treadmill if you need to. Hill training with or without weight is very useful, but adding the weight will get you ready for your next OCR.
[Tweet "Hill training is very useful, but adding the weight will get you ready for your next OCR. "]
A popular workout for incline training is the 15% 15 min challenge. This workout is done on a treadmill without using the handrails. Treadmill should be set to 15% incline and timed for 15 minutes. Goal is to get as much distance as you can handle in the 15 minutes. You control the speed throughout the 15 minutes. This is a short, very intense workout that will allow you to track progress as well.

Bottom Line

[Tweet "You don't need a ton of time in order to improve fitness, but you do need the desire."]
So again, you don't need a ton of time in order to improve, but you do need the desire. Short intense workouts will help you get better quicker without taking up a ton of time. Don't worry so much about distance and focus more on the intensity of the workout. There are a couple of workouts in this article you can try but feel free to reach out with any questions or for some new workouts. Email me through support@amrapusa.com

Sheet1.Title: How I Became a Paleo Dad
Sheet1.Meta Description: Focus on 5 pieces of advice as you transition to a Paleo family. My family went 100% Paleo when our son was born because the "standard diet" was no option.
Sheet1.Content:
And What I Learned Raising My Son in a Non-Paleo World

  My wife and I have been raising our son in the Paleo lifestyle since he was born a little over three years ago. We made the decision to become a Paleo family about a year before he was born. It seemed like a daunting task when I thought about the all the obstacles we would face.   The alternative to raise him in what we will call “conventional method” just was not an option.   I am here to say that anybody can do it especially when you think about setting your child up for success. Focus on these five pieces of advice when begin your transition to a Paleo family.  

1) Set Your Kid up for Success

I think the thing that could make it hard to raise a child Paleo is if you care what everybody thinks about you. If you already live the Paleo lifestyle for the right reasons chances are you don’t care. People will tell you need to feed your child all kinds of things like whole grains to get their nutrients. Sometimes when it comes to child you might start to doubt yourself, but stay the course.I heard this a lot. Parents told me kids just don’t want to eat veggies.   This could be true if you try to switch over a five year old who as eaten cereal and bagels their whole life. (You can still do it you just might have to try some different strategies.)  

2) Eating Right From Birth

From birth kids don’t have all the preconceived notions about food that we do. If your kids watch you eat veggies and meat then they will eat them as well. My son will eat forks full of lettuce, kale, and broccoli. Some days he will eat tons of veggies then the next day he will eat none. This is probably more like our hunter gather ancestors ate. They couldn’t just run over to the grocery store and get a cart full of veggies, fruit, or meat. My advice: just don’t get into the concept that your child has to finish their plate before they can get down from their seat or treat food as a reward. One day my son will seem like he is eating us out of house and home and the next he barely eats anything. He knows his body better than I do and will eat when he is hungry. This works with a Paleo lifestyle when you are eating good nutritious food. On the other hand, if you were to allow processed food full of sugar this would not work. His body would not be able to control the hunger signal because the sugar has a nasty way of confusing the brain. Sugar triggers an addictive craving in the brain the same way cocaine triggers binges with a drug addict. With a poor diety, a kid would want more and more and until he was overeating. Eventually it would make him obese. The bottom line is this: when eating whole unprocessed food a child can figure out on their own how much they need of what. Whether that is tons of sweet potatoes one day or half pound of grass fed/finished beef another.  

3) Avoid the Attitude and Prepare for the Energy

Clearly, if your body doesn't feel good, you won't feel inclined to be happy or energetic. The greatest benefit about raising my son Paleo is the way his over all general attitude is throughout the day. Yes, he is a three year old so everything is not always rosy, but when compared to other kids who eat a standard American diet, the contrast is night and day. My son has sustained energy all day; he doesn’t have quite the ups and downs other kids have. Most of this is because he doesn’t get sugar bombs in his belly from processed food and candy.   He has spent a couple of days with some relatives and friends. He may not have had exactly the diet we would have wanted for the day. His attitude when we picked him up from these outings was awful until he slept it off and got better food in his belly.

4) Find the Natural Teaching Moments

This happens, but recognize that it gives us parents a great teaching moment. We got to show him how certain foods make him feel--some feel good and some feel bad. One time my son had some gluten free bread at a friend’s house. When we got home he was complaining about his stomach hurting. I mentioned to him about how we don’t eat bread because it make our stomachs hurt. Now when he sees bread he will mention not to eat it because of what it does to our stomachs. Keeping a toddler somewhat even keeled throughout the day is always a plus for me. (My son runs around all day and has no off switch so keeping that in a positive direction is good for everybody. You can probably relate.) Cooking is another great way to get your child involved and learn about the food they are eating. My son has his own knife and other utensils to help us with prep work. It is child knife that will cut through things but will not cut through his skin. He gets excited to help us with cooking. He also enjoys eating it more when he knows he helped make it. This is great when he is young, but will have greater pay offs once he is older. He will be able to help us cook and make his own nutritious meals when he gets out on his own. Basically it all boils down to trying to set him up with skills to lead a very healthy life.  

5) Take Time to Reflect

It has been a great three years raising him so far. Maintaining Paleo is an easier part of our daily routine. It is been hard but a little planning goes a long way. For example, we have had to pack coolers of food to take with us on trips so we knew we would be eating good food. Everything will not always go exactly as you want but keep working and do not give up. We are talking about setting up your child on the right path for life. People will tell me, “You can’t do it without living in a bubble,” or “You don’t have enough time.” The reality is, we make time if it is important, and if you are consistent in your Paleo lifestyle, others will accept it (most of the time). I do extra work because I owe my son a better life. If I can show people it can be done, hopefully they will find the willpower to beef up their nutrition. In our small and meaningful way, parents have the power to turn around child health in America. I promise you can do it. Now just get to it.

Sheet1.Title: 20 Minute Paleo Recipes for Morning, Noon, and Night
Sheet1.Meta Description: These 20 minute paleo recipes are the best tasting staples in my life. Benefit from a properly nourished body without the fuss in the kitchen.
Sheet1.Content:
Satisfy Your Tastebuds With Sweet and Savory -- Guilt Free

  I enjoy spending time experimenting in the kitchen, but maybe you don't. Or most likely, you don't have the time. These 20 minute paleo recipes are staples in my life. Make them a part of your routine to simplify your time in the kitchen and guarantee your body is properly nourished. From morning to night, these paleo recipes have you covered.  

Coconut Pancakes

20-35 grams of dietary fiber a day is best for our bodies according to nutritionists. It's no surprise that coconut, an ideal paleo food, is actually a GREAT source of fiber. It actually contains FOUR times as much fiber as oat bran and TWICE as much fiber as wheat bran or flaxseed meal. Best of all, it tastes good. This pancakes recipe provides your fiber fix and allows you to enjoy breakfast so you start your day off right. Stay regular (you all know what I mean) without having to take additional supplements. Getting as much of our nutrition as we can through the foods we eat is ideal. Although this isn’t the easiest to do it’s better to try our best than not try at all. Get the recipe. [Tweet "Coconut contains FOUR times as much fiber as oat bran and TWICE as much fiber as wheat bran."]

Homemade Almond Milk

You definitely won’t need to add anything additional to sweeten your morning cup of Joe with this almond milk. Great flavor to add to your morning coffee. Although you can find almond milk with few ingredients, they usually have ingredients that thicken them or preserve them. Those ingredients usually aren’t “bad” for you but I wondered what their long-term effects would be if consumed daily for a long period of time. Sure you can find almond milk at your local farmer’s market that is nice and pure but that can get pretty pricey if you go through as much as we do. Get the recipe.  

Pumpkin Medley

This is so easy and flavorful! An incredible side dish or even a paleo meal in itself if you feel like something light for the night and if you are looking for a pumpkin recipe this one may just be the right one. I call it Pumpkin Recipe Medley as it truly is a beautiful blend of flavors. Get the recipe.  

 Simple Mango Tumeric Ice Cream

Whip this up very quickly to enjoy as a quick dessert or mid-day snack – guilt-free. Healthy, brightly-flavored mango year round is available in the frozen section of most markets. I really enjoy the added coconut flakes on top for an extra little crunch and flavor. Look for unsweetened coconut as many coconut flakes are soaked in a sugary mixture, which defeats the purpose of for our bodies or our taste buds! You’ll want to eat this right away and not freeze it. Otherwise it gets rather solid once frozen. This is why ice cream is best made in small batches. Get the recipe. [Tweet "Look for unsweetened coconut as many coconut flakes are soaked in a sugary mixture."]

Sheet1.Title: Who are AMRAP Bars Designed For?
Sheet1.Content:
Who are AMRAP Bars Designed For? AMRAP Nutrition’s focus is on CrossFit athletes primarily. We’ll explain why and how AMRAP bars are uniquely created with high-intensity athletes in mind.   Why Focus Mainly on CrossFit? Cross functional training is crucial for all athletes—runners need to lift weights, and weighlifters benefit from yoga practice. To this end, CrossFit is creating a tidal wave affect with their educated viral workout principles. It focuses on teaching the theories and methodologies that are producing some of the fittest people in the world.   Athletes love CrossFit’s amazing methods that not only change your body, but your life as well. From the physical results, improved health, and the passion and camaraderie shared among fellow CrossFitters, it is a training regimen that pushes athletes to be the best version of themselves.   We love the CrossFit community because it brings together a diverse group of discerning athletes seeking optimal and healthy performance.   There are certainly arguments against the training style, but the industry has demonstrated tremendous progress in the United States and internationally.  
  • In 2005, 13 gyms were open. In 2014, 7,000 affiliate gyms operate.
  • The CrossFit Games have a 166% year over year growth rate.
  • The estimated failure rate of opening a CrossFit gym is 2%
  • 2 Billion is the estimated net of just the CrossFit affiliates in 2013
  • CrossFit has taken the lead with consumer searches on Google while other big name brand gyms have remained relatively flat-lined.
(Reference: By the Numbers: The Growth of CrossFit (channelsignal.com))   Clearly with that much development and newfound focus on high-caliber training, responsible nutrition is in high demand.   AMRAP Nutrition arose from CrossFit athletes looking to replace toxic supplements with a clean appetizing energy bar. The AMRAP Bar (100% Paleo) was born from the vision of athletes.   Is the AMRAP Bar Ideal for Other Athletes? One thing to keep in mind is that CrossFit was originally started as supplemental training to enhance your overall fitness performance. It is not meant to take the place of your sport or recreational activities. Instead, you can use CrossFit to enhance your performance through improved strength, stamina, and endurance.   AMRAP Nutrition designed their bars with cutting-edge Crossfitters in mind, based on the fundamental principle that CrossFit is used by a broad spectrum of athletes looking for solutions to their fitness shortcomings. From that standpoint, multi-sport athletes will manifest the performance benefits of these bars.   Should You Eat It? Aside from CrossFitters, AMRAP bars are a highly effective source of energy for other intense athletics. If you are a:
  • Runner
  • Cyclist
  • Skiier
  • Mountaineer
  • Climber
  • Surfer
  • Martial Artist
  • Dancer
These bar will enhance your performance the same way it elevates the CrossFit athletes that swear by them. They provide athletes with the whole ingredients, unprocessed nutrients, and clean fuel to power their workouts.

Sheet1.Title: Where your food comes from matters...now more than ever.
Sheet1.Content:
AMRAP Nutrition Vision and Values   It’s important to know where you buy your food. Not all companies have your best interest at heart. Here at AMRAP Nutrition we thrive off the knowledge that our customers are receiving the highest quality nutrition and athletic support possible.   Positive, Passionate, Motivated, Focused, Kind. Our values not only define who we are as individuals, but how our company chooses to conduct every order of business to provide a higher quality experience for every individual.   More than anything we need passionate fanatical customers to support and promote our brand, mission, and values. We are off to a good start, but AMRAP Nutrition is not slowing down. As Many Rounds As Possible (AMRAP) defines our philosophy. Through determination, intensity, and focus, we aim to inspire and empower our community to reach their full health and fitness potential.   With whole food nutritional supplements and athletic gear that can get you through any challenge you face, AMRAP Nutrition will help you reach your goals to the fullest extent possible.   Regardless of whether you subscribe fully to the Paleo Diet, the Mediterranean Diet, the Abs Diet, or no specific diet, there is one standard that you need to live by. Nutrient-dense foods are your gold standard. With this, AMRAP Nutrition is here to assist you in finding the highest quality ingredients for your body and life long health. This company believes that nutrient-dense foods are the only alternative to over-processed energy snacks for athletes. We have crafted three Paleo bars from the most raw and natural ingredients to fuel your body the way it was originally designed to. Our three bars are:
  • Almond/Honey
  • Cashew/Vanilla
  • Fig/Cacao
  With our strong community influence we plan to spread the word and benefits of being part of a movement as big as AMRAP. One by one we can help increase the health of every professional, athlete, student, or parent willing to commit their selves to an improved healthy lifestyle.   Join us, and together we will change the world.

Sheet1.Title: My Results with Nitrate Rich Beet Juice
Sheet1.Meta Description: I have used beet juice now a few times. I have used it prior to performing a variety of exercises, such as Zumba, power lifting, and running. The greatest success that I found with using it has been that it has increased my endurance.
Sheet1.Content:
Nitrate Rich Beet Juice Plays a Key Role in Endurance & Performance

Do you call yourself an athlete?

If you are putting in work, maybe it's time you call yourself an athlete. Now, after a lot of work; I can proudly say that I call myself an athlete, I have never been dedicated to the idea of relying on supplements to fuel and enhance my activity. Whether it be for pre-, during, or post-workout, I just have not seen enough benefit of supplements. As a woman, my nutrition needs are not always addressed by a supplement product, aside from an occasional protein powder and beloved paleo nutrition bars. Most supplements do not interest me. Social media is ablaze with supplements toting increased energy, muscle recovery, and growth, and I only vaguely care. At one point, I found myself researching some of these supplements just to see what all the hype was about. I came across warnings such as, "do not consume with coffee" and "may cause a tingling sensation." Yikes! I immediately vowed to not try these supplements because they clearly came with some heavy side effects. Not cool. That is, until recently when I began hearing more chatter around the benefits of nitrate rich beet powder. After some reading and searching, I tried Beet Nitrates from AMRAP. AMRAP's Beet Nitrate formula is freeze dried beetroot powder that, when mixed with water, can be used as an plant-based, Paleo-friendly, pre-workout drink. It is an endurance juice with simple easy-to-digest ingredients. There is nothing scary about this formula; beets, sea-salt, and stevia, and the payoff is big.

 Why beets, you ask?

Since beets are rich in Nitrates (NO3), the mix becomes absorbed into the bloodstream and is secreted into saliva. The bacteria in your mouth converts the Nitrates into Nitrite (NO2). When the NO2-rich saliva gets swallowed, the Nitrite is re-absorbed and loses oxygen to become Nitric Oxide (NO). The NO then boosts your stamina, which helps you exercise for an extended period of time and also improves blood flow and pressure. I've found that AMRAP's Beet Formula allows you to work out to your greatest potential. I have used AMRAP Beet Nitrates now a few times. I have used it prior to performing a variety of exercises, such as Zumba, power lifting, and running. The greatest success that I found with using it has been that it has increased my endurance. Some of my workouts can last as long as two hours depending on the day of the week and the part of the body I am targeting that day, so energy boost I gain from a healthy beet juice is insanely helpful. With this energy increase, I have also found that I am able to endure longer workouts, which has motivated me to increase my workout time. Even though I haven't seen an improvement in, say, my running time in the short term, it certainly makes for an easier and more effective workout. I would highly recommend the Beet Nitrate formula from AMRAP Nutrition for any athlete that is looking for a safe, plant-based alternative to a traditional pre-workouts or endurance powders. It is made by people I trust, and who have my best interests at heart because they use beet juice in the same way.

My Favorite Features

  • All my friends can say a brief prayer to the gods in the sky - as nasty as a instant beet juice sounds, it actually taste really good; it's sweet and not earthy like you would think.
  • It only takes 20 - 30 minutes to kick in and the benefits last upwards of 4 or more hours. Perfect if you have event and you want the edge but not risk a full stomach prior to your race.
  • Boy's this is good for you 'down-stairs', it helps with blood flow and relaxes your blood vessels. You and your partner will be surprised ;-)

 Learn more...

Read these three articles for a terrific grasp of the basics of beets and how to use them in your fitness.
  1. Beet Juice Can Improve Your Performance - Breaking Muscle
  2. How Much Beet Juice, and When - Runner's World
  3. The Truth About Beet Juice - WebMD

Sheet1.Title: Sauna: A Simple Proven Sports Performance Enhancer
Sheet1.Meta Description: Safe sports performance enhancers don't come in capsules. Performance gains achieved by getting into a sauna are far safer and superior to common methods.
Sheet1.Content:
High Performers Integrate Sauna For Marked Results

  Sport performance comes from consistency and adaptation capabilities. Consistency is the discipline, dedication and repetitiveness to achieve a desired goal. Adaptation capability will be correlated to physiological and psychological factors. On the physiological side there are different methods to enhance sport performance, from periodization protocols to high-altitude training. On the same lines, the sauna method is as a simple-proved sport performance enhancer. [Tweet "Consistency is the discipline, dedication and repetitiveness to achieve a desired goal."]

The Science of Sauna Thermotherapy

Tolerance to heat exhaustion is one of those performance capabilities an athlete should have in their repertoire. Temperature is affecting our body in multiple unique ways, so it is important to understand how the temperature process occurs in our body. As well, blood plays a crucial roll in sport performance and is strictly related to temperature changes, so we will dig in that as well.   Thermotherapy entails various techniques like sauna, steam baths, infrared lamps and warm water immersion. It is believed that these methods can increase subcutaneous and cutaneous blood flow as a result of an increase in cardiac output and a lower peripheral resistance. This increase in blood flow increases cellular, lymphatic, and capillary permeability, which can increase metabolism, nutrient delivery, and waste removal from the cells. Much anecdotal and practical information can be found about the proposed benefits of thermotherapy, but still little scientific research exploring its use as a recovery-performance enhancer tool is available (Bompa & Haff, 2009). [Tweet "Increasing your core temperature for short periods may offer dramatic athletic performance improvements. "] According to Ph.D. Rhonda Perciavalle Patrick, increasing the core temperature for short periods, as is done by using a sauna, may offer dramatic improvements to athletic performance. Emerging research suggests that this hyperthermic conditioning has multiple positive effects on your body, from increased endurance to the growth of new brain cells. This video breaks down the science of thermotherapy for athletes: [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aHOlM-wlNjM[/embed] Temperature in the body occurs through the process of radiation, conduction, convection and evaporation. The most important of this heat removal process for the performance athlete is the evaporation of sweat (75%), which releases 580 kcal per liter of sweat evaporated in the skin. While as humans we are well evolved to perform strength, aerobic and endurance exercise, our high sweat rates mean that water is removed from our body at high ratio, and must therefore be replaced at appropriate proportion. Prolonged stay in a sauna may lead to the loss of electrolytes from the body, as after vigorous exercise. The risk of dehydration leading to heat stroke may be reduced by proper hydration. Read about easy hydration in my recent posts: part 1 and part 2.  
Physiologic adaptations that occur from hyperthermic conditioning include:
  • Improved cardiovascular mechanisms: lower heart rate (Hannuksela & Ellahham, 2001)
  • Higher sweat rate (Costa, Moore & Walsh, 2011)
  • Increased blood flow to skeletal muscle (Costa, Moore, et. al, 2011)
  • Reduced rate of glycogen depletion (King, Costill, Fink, et. al, 1985)
  • Increased red blood cell count (Scoon, Hoopkins, et. al, 2007)
  • Increased efficiency of oxygen transport to muscles (Scoon, Hoopkins, et. al, 2007)
  Research done by University of Otago in New Zealand, found that sauna bathing increased run time to exhaustion by 32%, which is equivalent to an enhancement of approximately 1.9% in an endurance time trial. Plasma and red-cell volumes increased by 7.1% and 3.5% respectively, after sauna relative to control. Change in performance had high correlations with change in plasma volume and total blood volume. So for a period of three weeks of post-exercise sauna bathing produced a worthwhile enhancement of endurance running performance, probably by increasing blood volume (Scoon, Hoopkins, et. al, 2007).   The indicated performance gains achieved just by getting into a sauna are far safer and superior to many other methods and practices common in elite sports. So from a cost-effective approach I would advise you to give it a try for a couple of months and measure any performance changes as a result of it. [Tweet "Performance gains achieved just by getting into a sauna are far safer and superior to common practices in elite sports."] Sauna should be integrated as part of your regular high performance lifestyle, as you do with post-workout nutrition, foam-rolling or stretching protocols. Included on a regular basis, sauna could become just another performance enhancer.  
My suggested protocol to start your sauna training and integrate it to your daily life:
  • Base line: Start with 10 minutes of infrared sauna (60-80ºC, 5-15% humidity) two times a week. Include this two sauna sessions right after your hardest trainings.
  • Hydration: Keep hydrated during training, during sauna and after training & sauna. (My articles on hydration cover this in Part 1 and Part 2.)
  • Increase of time and volume: Every week add 5 min to your two times a week sauna session until you reach 30 minutes. Note: I f you still feel really hard to move-up in time, stay another week with the same time of the previous week (up to 3 consecutive weeks).
  • Achieve performance: Once you have got to 2 times a week 30 min sauna sessions, add a third one. Remember try to perform them just after really hard training sessions!
  • Maintain performance: Get 2-3 times a week of infrared sauna (60-80ºC, 5-15% humidity) as part of your routine
  • Racing week, tapering or competition: Cut back to 1 session per week 2 weeks prior to your competition or race. And avoid any sauna 7 days prior to your race or competition.
 

Pro Tips to Play By

Remember that playing with body core temperature should be strictly correlated with hydration; otherwise sauna can play against you if you are not properly hydrated before, during and after the sauna sessions. Also be aware that you will take the best out of a sauna session with consistency and remember that it is always better if you go to sauna immediately after an exhaustive training session. [Tweet "Thermotherapy will play against your athletic performance gains if you do not hydrate properly.  #ProTip"]  

References:

Bompa, T. & Haff, G., Periodization: Theory and Methodology of Training, Human Kinetics, 321, (2009) Hannuksela, M. L. & Ellahham, S. Benefits and risks of sauna bathing in The American journal of medicine 110, 118-126 (2001). King, D. S., Costill, D. L., Fink, W. J., Hargreaves, M. & Fielding, R. A. Muscle metabolism during exercise in the heat in unacclimatized and acclimatized human in. J Appl Physiol 59, 1350-1354 (1985). Lursen, P. B., Long distance triathlon: demands, preparation and performance in Journal of Sport & Excersice ISSN 1988-5202, 1-16, (2011) Ricardo J. S. Costa, M. J. C., Jonathan P. Moore & Neil P. Walsh. Heat acclimation responses of an ultra-endurance running group preparing for hot desert-based competition in European Journal of Sport Science, 1-11 (2011). Scoon, G. S., Hopkins, W. G., Mayhew, S. & Cotter, J. D. Effect of post-exercise sauna bathing on the endurance performance of competitive male runners in Journal of science and medicine in sport / Sports Medicine Australia 10, 259-262 (2007).
