Sheet1.Title: Crispy Roasted Chicken
Sheet1.Meta Description: This is NOT your average chicken folks. My crispy roasted chicken recipe is flavorful, juicy, and crispy to the very last bite. Pair with fresh paleo sides.
Sheet1.Content:
Some Chicken Recipes are Boring, You are Not

  If you are reading this blog, you probably have a passion for fitness and nutrition, OR maybe you are just beginning your journey towards better quality of life through health. What I have come to find throughout my many years in this world of fitness and nutrition as a CrossFit trainer and Certified Nutrition Consultant is that setting unrealistic goals and removing all enjoyment from your life just to achieve them simply will not work long term. Long term success comes from enjoying what you are doing, what you are eating, and how you feel from the inside out (this also includes loving yourself for who you are NOW). So what does this mean? Well, it means that whether you are building your fitness or creating meals to fuel you, the process HAS to be an enjoyable one. It’s simply not worth looking a certain way or reaching a fitness goal if you don’t enjoy the ride. So, whatever fitness routine you choose, make sure it’s one you love: Group CrossFit classes can be a blast. Maybe you’re an outdoors type, and nothing beats a hike in the woods. Or maybe dancing, swinging, or climbing trees is more your style. In any case, though, make sure you move daily and that you enjoy every minute. The same can be said for what you eat too. NO ONE can live a life of chicken breast, broccoli, and coconut oil without missing out on fun (and also some essential nutrients). That meal is boring, and YOU aren’t. Your food needs to be just as nutritious and enjoyable as your workout regime, and that is why I am here to share with you a recipe that is simple to make, and oh so delicious. Follow up a day of moving with a quality meal, and you are set up for success – not only today, but for the long haul too. [Tweet "NO ONE can live a life of chicken, broccoli, and coconut oil. That meal is boring. YOU aren’t. "] Take me for instance; nothing makes me happier than getting outside to play and explore in nature with my friends, family, and pups. And after a long day of moving, exploring, and playing (while getting my fitness in too), there’s no better meal to satisfy hunger and refuel than some deliciously crispy roasted chicken paired with some simple and delicious veggies. And after months of weekly trips to farmers market to buy LOTS of leg, wing, and thigh packs of pastured chicken from our favorite farmers at farmers market, AND after tons of work trying to perfect this recipe, I've finally done it. And today, I'm happy to share this recipe with all of you! So without further ado, I bring to you my finger lickin' crispy roasted chicken. The trick is to get as much moisture as possible off the bird before cooking. Then once it's nice and salty and dry, you smother the bird with a layer of the perfect fat blend. And to really knock it out of the part, you cook it just right, at the perfect temperature with a broil to finish. The result is the crispiest, most delicious salty, bacon fatty chicken skin that hugs the juiciest, most flavorful dark meat chicken ever. Yum! I HIGHLY recommend going with pastured chicken here. The dark meat will have much higher nutrient density, much more flavor, and nothing beats buying and eating happy chickens from the farmers that make it their life's mission to farm and sell sustainably. (Just do not go Foster Farms). This is NOT your average chicken, folks. It’s flavorful, juicy, and crispy to the very last bite. So throw your boring boneless, skinless, and nutrient-less chicken breasts away, and give this recipe a spin. Get your health journey off to a good start today OR continue on your current one. Go outside, move, play, and roast up some of this finger lickin' good chicken. You can't go wrong! [Tweet "Go outside, move, play, and roast up some of finger lickin' good chicken. You can't go wrong!"]
  Finger Lickin' Good Crispy Roasted Chicken (like fried chicken, but so much better) servings=2+ time=2 hours difficulty=easy WHAT YOU NEED:
  • 2 each of skin-on, bone-in chicken legs, wings, and thighs (obviously any combo of this is fine, and just increase the other ingredients for a bigger batch!)
  • 1 TB organic olive oil
  • 1 TB bacon grease, lard, or tallow
  • 2 TB grass fed butter or ghee (use extra lard or tallow for AIP)
  • plenty of sea salt
  • wire roasting rack of some sort (I just use the top shelf of my cooling rack)
WHAT YOU DO:
  • 1-3 hours before it's time to cook, pat your chicken dry with a paper towel, place on a plate, and sprinkle with sea salt until each piece is evenly covered
  • put plate in the fridge (the salt pulls the moisture out of the bird, and the cold air evaporates it away giving you crispy instead of soggy skin)
  • when it's time, preheat the oven to 375 F (I use convection roast setting on my oven)
  • melt the butter and bacon grease in a small pan and add your olive oil
  • pull your chicken out and pat it dry just incase there's any remaining moisture
  • brush it evenly with the fat mixture until fully covered (there should be some leftover)
  • place it on a wire rack sitting on top of a baking sheet
  • sprinkle with a layer of sea salt
  • bake for 10 minutes, then pull it out and flip any pieces with skin on all sides (flip legs, but keep thighs skin side up)
  • give it another brush with the remaining fat till its used up
  • put the chicken back in the oven for 10 minutes then check with a thermometer
  • once the inside hits 165, set your oven to high broil
  • keep an eye on the chicken as it broils, waiting till its nice and crispy before pulling it out (about 5 minutes)
  • eat it hot! And ENJOY every bite.
This pairs great with buttery sweet potato mash and roasted veggies of your choice. We have this every single week because the skin is crispy and delicious, and the inside is just oh so juicy and tender. Recreate. Share. Enjoy! Cheers.

Sheet1.Title: Coconut Almond Flour Coffee Cake + A Pop of Protein
Sheet1.Meta Description: Coconut Almond Flour Coffee Cake is a satisfying paleo dish to spice up your daily breakfast routine. It pairs perfectly with your coffee and egg scramble.
Sheet1.Content:
Your Egg White Scramble Needs Better Company

  I have enjoyed baking since my grandmother first taught me how to make chocolate chip cookies and coffee cake while sitting on the counter. I no longer sit on the counter while I stir the dough, but I probably eat just as much of it now as I did then. For me healthy cookies, snack bars, and breakfast cakes are staples generally consumed with copious amounts of coffee. My coffee is not complete without a small bite of something, and my morning just feels wrong if I don’t make time for both. As a rock climber getting an early start to a long day of hiking and climbing I like to have some healthy fats and protein in my system before I step out the door and this new recipe is quickly becoming one of my morning plate staples. I’m calling it Coconut Almond Coffee Cake best served with coffee (obviously) and an egg white scramble to balance out my breakfast. The soft and crumbly consistency of the Coconut Almond Coffee Cake is similar to that of my grandmother’s coffee cake, but with a more health conscious approach. So if your breakfast or coffee needs some extra love, give this recipe a try!

 Coconut Almond Coffee Cake

Ingredients Wet
  • ¼ cup coconut butter (softened)
  • 1 cup almond butter
  • ¼ cup honey
  • 1 tsp vanilla
Dry
  • 1 cup shredded unsweetend coconut
  • ¼ cup almond flour
  • 1 scoop vanilla protein powder
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • carob chips (optional)
Directions
  1. Pre-heat the oven to 350 degrees Farenheit
  2. Microwave the coconut butter to the point of being soft, but be careful not to burn it.
  3. Mix the wet ingredients together in a large bowl.
  4. Mix the dry ingredients in a separate bowl.
  5. Slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients. This will need some heavy mixing, so when it gets down to the last bit of dry ingredients you might have to use your hands to almost knead the dough.
  6. Spray or wipe down an 8 x 6 pan with coconut oil and pat the dough into the pan.
  7. Bake for 17-20 minutes depending on your preference of crispyness.
  8. Wait to cool and then cut into squares.
Hints If you prefer cookies, you can drop little balls of dough on a cookie sheet, and bake them for about 12 minutes.

Sheet1.Title: A CrossFit Masters Athlete's Guide to Happiness
Sheet1.Meta Description: Are you a CrossFit Masters Athlete or know someone who is? This guide to happiness considers four elements that keep CrossFit fun and rewarding over time.
Sheet1.Content:
4 Elements That Keep CrossFit Fun and Rewarding with Time

  I have been thinking and reading a lot this year about nutrition, programming, injury, and competing. After a lot of reflection and discussion with those I trust, here's some guiding advice to what will make you a happier athlete for the rest of 2015.
Each of the elements I am covering will always begin with two questions.
  • What do you want?
  • What is unique about you that requires consideration?
These two questions are often overlooked, particularly by those writing as experts. In order to show clear expertise and that they "figured it out", there are no questions to be asked, only the final answers. Always ask these two questions.

Nutrition

When it comes to what you put in your body, these initial questions are very critical. If you want to enjoy eating all kinds of food, not be glued 100% to an official diet, or you have a very tough time eating meat, this drives your decisions. You can see where I am going with this. Know basic facts about your eating and lifestyle preferences.
That being said, whether you want to hear it or not, a diet focused mainly on vegetables and fruits is hard to argue against. There is so much evidence around our system's difficulty digesting meat and breads over time that are impossible to deny any more. You need to start listening to the basic science of your body.
Here is the challenge with this: eating enough calories to support muscle growth and energy production through fruits and vegetables is really difficult and often expensive enough and time consuming enough to make it a non-option.
My short recommendation: focus on slowly moving meats and keep starchy carbs to a minimum in your weekly routine. Work to find a good, clean supplement/bar/shake to help you get what you need hit your calorie numbers so you don't walk around feeling hungry all day. To go ultra strict, eliminate snack foods completely from your routine. They are often overprocessed.
[Tweet "Find a good clean supplement to help hit your daily calorie numbers each day so you don't feel hungry all day."]

Programming

This topic rests a lot on what you want, what your performance goals are. Even I have had a difficult time answering this question since I started CrossFit three years ago. I think I am finally able to a better answer for myself and this will change my training programming in a noticeable way.
My considerations are a formerly broken back, a left big toe that has very little range-of-motion anymore, and some neck/shoulder nerve tweaking. What I really want is to better balance my flexibility and strength, then dedicate more effort to competing this year. Ask yourself: What do you really want to achieve? What do you have to consider about yourself and work around?
 
You have to understand that programming is not something you should be borrowing, or sampling temporarily. That might be okay while you are still testing different approaches, but ultimately you are on a program or you're not. You don't "try the invictus workouts" for a couple of months while also throwing in your local box workouts here and there. That is not effective. It will not work.
If your priority is being fit so you can do anything, any day, for random amounts of time, there is nothing wrong with that. Only understand that this type of training will not be the best for you. It will be good, but not the best. Most likely if you compete and this is how you train, you may have consistent issues moving higher in the ranks as a CrossFit Masters athlete.
Know that constantly varied workouts have a SINGLE purpose within the workout and a SINGLE purpose across workouts. Within the workout, it keeps intensity high. If you are static and perform squats all day, then your level of intensity cannot stay high. Across workouts it eliminates isolation and repetition that inevitably occurs around 8-9 weeks. Isolation and repetition can create overuse and increase injury. It also would show you a plateau in performance as another undesirable outcome.
This is controversial advice, but I will say it anyway: You want someone who understands exercise physiology (not just a CrossFit coach) to do programming for you. There are many things to be done this year and committing to a programming strategy will be the structure and incentive to get you what you want.
Recognize that you need to get training in (6-8 days) every two weeks on all three energy systems. If it has been two weeks since you hit the long, aerobic system 6-8 times (which happens in CrossFit) you need to fix the void. Running a mile, a 5k, or rowing similar distances is a good fix. With my bad foot, rowing and airdyne are best for me.

Injury

What injuries have you sustained and now surround with strength and flexibility training? What do you want? To be fit only or to compete? There is no right answer, just identify your considerations and choose your goal.
I've been working on my back recovery since my first CrossFit workout. It has been very tough to get where I am, but I am proud of the goals I have achieved:
  • Squatting heavy weights
  • Increasing squat mobility (below parallel within 15 minutes after warming up!)
  • Training regularly at 5:30am 
Through every miniature goal, I have been healing my back. I've been surrounding it with strength and flexibility. And now it is slowly feeling more and more normal.
Now that I'm turning my focus to not only competing but also to more flexibility, I'm also coming to my own unique conclusion about myself and my relationship with injury. I would normally accept injury at a higher rate if this year I wanted to compete and that's it. Though, with flexibility becoming an equal priority, I will definitely back out of a 90%+ attempt in my weightlifting if I don't feel extremely good that day. Feel it out for yourself, like I have done.
Injuries are nearly inevitable in some form. That doesn't mean that one day you'll go down in a heap with your leg buckling under you. What it means is this: to improve your fitness, you will need to cross over your limits on a weekly basis. If you cross too much you might strain something, hurt something. If you push it way over the line, you'll rip something, and require yourself to heal over many weeks.
It is all about body awareness and I have bad news. After all my years in sports--as an athlete, coaching, and now in CrossFit--the verdict is in. Body awareness is a talent that can only be taught to a certain level of fitness. You know that guy that always gets hurt. That one that constantly rips their hands. That girl that looked like she was being electrocuted when she got her deadlift PR and has been out of commission on and off for the past 3 months since.
[Tweet "Body awareness is a talent that can only be taught to a certain level of fitness."]
Those people are not good at gauging when they should back off, slow down or simply say "that's good. I'm done today". Work on this as best you can. As a 41 year old I do this often. I push myself when I can and slow down, lower the weight, or hang up the bar if my body is feeling off.

Competing

There is a really great satisfaction about competing in CrossFit. You are doing it every day anyway!
The great news: The way your mind and body interact in your competition will be nearly identical to your daily WODs (if you're doing it right). So if you haven't competed, or haven't done very many serious ones, take my word for it: you are more ready than most any other athlete to compete.
Again, you will want to consider your lifestyle and what you want here as well. For example, imagine my goal is: "I would like to do a summer and fall comp this year. And I want to work toward those with my programming. They do not need to be big comps, they just need to be local for convenience." Your goal may be similar or very different from mine, so ask yourself:
  • Do I want to compete?
  • To what scale do I want to compete?
  • What events will I sign up for?
Your story will drive how you handle your schedule this year.
Also, find a way to practice a competition as well because there are subtle activities happening in competitions that are not happening in your daily routine. Example: You are told to get to your two-rep max on overhead squats in 6 min. So look at your weights laying in piles next to your bar.  You are thinking, "Well I would do 45s then a 10... Oh wait, there is no 45. There is two 25s? Wait.. '3-2-1 go!'"
It has happened to us all in a competition. Quick math and quick strategy take practice. The CrossFit group I run does these practices. It can be eye opening, though usually after-the-fact, so you'll want to go through experiences a few times.
[Tweet "My nutrition choices are strongly connected to my programming and my competition goals."]
Clearly these 4 elements interact as well. My nutrition choices are strongly connected to my programming and my competition goals. Just remember to truly take some time to consider what is unique about you and what you really want out of this year. Go get it!
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Interesting Other | Nutrition Hacks | Performance Advice

Sheet1.Title: Redefine Your Fitness Limits
Sheet1.Meta Description: Ever been injured? Recognize the first step to push your fitness limits is to identify them. A key element to your physical recovery is adaptive training.
Sheet1.Content:
You are the product of your surroundings, so compete accordingly.

  The reality is, a majority of your daily gym goers cannot do what this adaptive athlete can. Wouldn't you like to chase fitness goal among equally inspiring athletes? [embed]https://youtu.be/-BddBaQxfIM[/embed] Ever been injured? Recognize the first step to push your fitness limits is to identify them. Did you break your back? Did you lose an arm? a leg? Did you experience a head trauma? However your sustained an injury, the path to physical and mental recovery has been paved by other impossible success stories. A key element to your physical recovery is adaptive training. [Tweet "Wouldn't you like to chase fitness goal among equally inspiring athletes?"] To tell us more about adaptive training--what it looks like, who is involved, how it helps-- is Aaron Throckmorton, veteran, athlete, and founder of The Agoge Challenge. Hundreds of CrossFit events take place every year, but we have not seen anything quite like The Agoge Challenge. It is addressing the needs of injured athletes and veterans to a scale and magnitude that no other gym or event is within the states. Read the Q&A with Aaron. Limited by injury or not, you will be asking “where do I sign up?”  

Q: What is the Agoge Challenge?

A: The Agoge Challenge is a competitive fitness competition formed by military veterans, health care professionals, and strength and conditioning coaches that highlight the resiliency of the human spirit through our athletes. We promote healing, camaraderie, and instill the idea in the community that “the only limits in life are the ones we place on ourselves.” It takes place in Bedford, Texas, with plans to scale in the future.  

Q: What do you teach your participants?

A: There are four main philosophies to this competition that impact both the participants and the audience. They are:
  1. “Push the body to fight or flight mode”
When pushed to the brink of exhaustion the human response is to run or fight. With The Agoge Challenge, we teach everyone to be a fighter. Fight through those breaking points and walk out a more confident, healthy, and happy person. In the end it is not about who finishes where on the podium, but more about finishing.
  1. “Team building”
Athletes endure three demanding W.O.D.s (Workouts of the Day) each designed with a high amount of repetition designed to make our teams division work together in order to finish.
  1. “Shared Hardship”
Shared hardship is a concept our veterans in the staff have learned from military service form bonds that last a lifetime. Implementing this philosophy has done exactly that for last years competitors who have not only grown close to our staff but most importantly each other.
  1. “Create Community”
The Agoge Challenge believes in rewarding our competitors for their hard work with a Warriors Feast, which is held at a select location after the competition. Awards are presented, food and live music is available for the participants and families get to share in the experience by supporting their loved one as they make new friends and connect with those who have faced similar struggles.  

Q: What type of athletes participate in this and why?

A: Everyone from able-bodied athletes competing in teams all the way to individual adaptive athletes compete. I believe that there are numerous reasons athletes compete.
  • Veterans: to reconnect with a different community outside the military and to honor their fallen friends. Both able-bodied and adaptive athletes do this.
  • Athletes in the adaptive category compete for reasons, but the most pronounced reason is that our event gives them the chance to show the world that people are capable of more than they are given credit for. It is inspiring for themselves and others in a similar situation.
  • New-comers come to push their current limits. We help them establish higher capacities beyond old breaking points.
  • All come for the community and camaraderie that is built through shared challenges at this event.
 

Q: What are the top 3 benefits you hope athletes gain from the event?

A: I hope that we can teach the teams to work together. We want to introduce new people--both able-bodied and adaptive--to CrossFit. I hope it humbles people to not make excuses for why they can’t reach their goals both physically and in life. We share some hardships that service members endure through training by incorporating it in the programming, mainly through the team building concepts for able bodied athletes.  

Q: What is unique about this competition from other CrossFit events?

A: We highlight the resiliency of the human spirit through our adaptive athletes competing. In most competitions the adaptive athletes are a part of the competition. We make them the focus of ours. We do this through promoting them as the main focus and offering the biggest cash prizes for them.  

Q: How is this event helping veterans?

A: We use the event to make service members transition to civilian life easier by introducing them to a new community. The community aspect allows the veteran to decompress through new challenges. We allow alternative therapy organizations for veterans to set up at our event. This allows for the veteran to look into these options between WODs. We have also encouraged vet friendly companies to come out to the Agoge Challenge to schedule job interviews.  

Q: Explain what adaptive training is?

A: Miles Knupp, our Head of Programming, will take this one. Miles: "Adaptive training is a safe approach to high intensity functional movement with a creative mind. We strive to exert these athletes nearly to their breaking point, but with a plan. It can be a challenge to program a workout for this type of athlete without damaging components of their body that they need for daily tasks. Our workouts have a large range of variety and complexity. For example, if an upper extremity athlete performs too much overhead movement, he/she can fatigue or injure their rotator cuff thus causing serious side effects in their ability to execute things as easily as brushing their teeth. An upper extremity cannot simply use another limb to complete a task unless they can replicate the missing limb with a prosthetic. Even in the event of a lower extremity athlete if we greatly fatigue one support limb we could easily make them a fall risk."  

Q: Is adaptive training only for injured veterans? Who else might benefit?

A: No ma’m. Everyone fights their own battles in this world. Whether they are on a battle field or in everyday life. There are people out there who may have lost a limb or the ability to walk from a horrific accident in life, but there are those who may have been born with a impairment that enjoy this type of training.  

Q: How is the Agoge Challenge spreading the impact of adaptive training to other gyms?

A: We at The Agoge Challenge spread the impact of adaptive training by raising awareness at the competition for these incredible athletes and encourage other facilities to become educated about how to train these athletes and include them in their facility.  

Q: What does an adaptive workout look?

A: In terms of intensity an adaptive workout will look no different to the untrained eye. This workout will not only include prosthetic application in several of the movements but it will be modified to allow the competing athlete to perform at a level equal to or greater than an able bodied athlete. The range of movement required may be different in degree especially from the area of the missing limb. [Tweet "In terms of intensity, an adaptive workout will look no different to the untrained eye. "] An example could be an athlete that is a lower extremity may still perform squats like an able bodied athlete. He or she may use a box to limit the depth of the squat so that they do not fall over in an attempt to get the required depth. Not only could stops like the box be implemented, but similar or more simple movements could demand the same effort without a range of motion restriction. Like a one legged step up or short range pistol. I am proud to plainly see that these adaptive athletes tend to have more horse power than the average athlete because their bodies operate at a higher capacity to make up for the adaptation.

Q: Agoge athletes--What are their strengths, limitations, background?

A: Our highlighted athletes paint this picture best, starting from newer athletes in the sport to more seasoned athletes. Luke Ericson Luke got his start in CrossFit competitions with us at The Agoge Challenge last year. His mom called last minute and asked if he could register. When I first met Luke, he acted shy, timid, and nervous because he had never done anything like this. I asked him “Hey luke, what about you is adaptive brother?” He told me and we talked, laughed and built a good rapport over the phone. Luke's impairment is that he was born without the majority of his upper left body including his arm. He has an underdeveloped lung on the left side as well as organs open to injury because there is no protection provided by the limbs presence. All this means to us at The Agoge Challenge is he has twice the heart of your average competitor because the workout takes a toll 10 fold on his body. Captain Derrick Carver (Retired) In early 2010, Derrick was serving as a Platoon leader in the 82nd Airborne when he lost his leg in combat. Although he flat lined three times, endured 47 surgeries, and would need 52 blood transfusions he survived. He has since been medically retired as a Captain, opened his first CrossFit facility and they are in their second year and going strong. He has competed at Working wounded Games, WODapalooza (overall adaptive winner). As the captain of the adaptive team that competes head to head against non-adaptive teams (Team Some Assembly Required), he strives to impact his community everyday through the life he lives helping others like himself. His goal is to re build confidence and strengthen their support network through the community fitness events such as The Agoge Challenge. As for limitations, we don’t believe in limitations at The Agoge Challenge so you will never hear us speak of limitations when it comes to our athletes who compete. If there is an obstacle for the athlete they have not mastered yet then we put it on a list or wall and encourage them to train for the goal and come back and face it head on. [Tweet "We don't believe in limits, only opportunity for work arounds. #TheAgogeChallenge"]

Q: You have celebrity support don't you?

A: Our sponsors support us because they believe in improving the overrall quality of life for those that want to enjoy everything that able bodied persons do. For celebrities backing our cause I can think of no better place to start than with the ones who have actually come onboard our staff this year.   Talon Smith- Actor, Model and Programmer for the Agoge Challenge Team divisions “The Agoge Challenge is an event that celebrities could easily get behind simply because it is a true American event. This event is showcases the determination and resilience of America in my opinion, because a lot of the athletes participating are veterans who were wounded in combat. If not wounded in combat, these adaptive athletes display their strength that they have worked so hard for and much like celebrities, who worked hard to get where they are. Celebrities who truly love America, appreciate our veterans and appreciate those who have determination, resilience and resolve to become the best versions of themselves should be behind the Agoge Challenge 100 percent. The question I ask is why aren't more behind this event? Especially with how mainstream media and celebrities are quick to utilize veterans or in my opinion exploit them for their personal benefit. This is a place to empower them.”   Jeff Kyle- Guardian for Heroes Foundation "As a veteran I feel the need to give back and continue to help my fellow veterans. The Agoge Challenge not only allows each individual veteran the chance to prove to themselves that nothing is out of the question but also to show the world that we as veterans are unstoppable. We are strong minded, hard working people that look adversity in the face and punch it!"   David Vobora- St. Louis Rams, Seattle Seahawks Linebacker David Has been The Agoge Challenge's biggest advocate and came onboard as our brand ambassador and our media relations specialist this year. David: “Physical challenges are the best metaphors for life. Life is about competing and trying to become a better version of yourself daily. Just like training there is no destination, you can always become better. The Agoge Challenge is an opportunity for anyone to test themselves and discover a gear beyond their own capacity. The Agoge Challenge inspires all who come across it’s path!” It celebrates those willing to be uncomfortable to find growth. Although the competition is physical, it is very much a spiritual journey that empowers.”  

Q: If readers want to support the Agoge movement, how should they reach out?

A: Contact us via our homesite www.fullcatabolic.com. The best way to support us is to be there; see it for yourself. Ticket sales are up on our homesite and vendors can contact us through this channel as well. We are hosting a WOD party may 23rd in the stockyards in Ft. Worth, Texas; you can find the information under “The Agoge Challenge Crawfish Boil” on Facebook.

Do you have questions of your own? Ask Aaron in the comments below.
Sheet1.Categories: Everything CrossFit | Interesting Other | Success stories | Viral Videos

Sheet1.Title: Maximize Your Fat Burning Potential
Sheet1.Meta Description: Maximize your fat burning potential begins when you avoid common pitfalls or bad advice. These tips give you realistic tips to reach your weight loss goals.
Sheet1.Content:
Burn. More. Fat.

Who doesn’t like the sound of that? Whether you have a significant amount of weight to lose, just need to tone up a little or want better mental focus throughout the day, it’s in everyone’s best interest to give their body the chance to adapt to become a better fat burner. So how does one go about doing this, exactly? Let’s talk about what not to do first, because unfortunately, this category is what many of the go-to means of reaching this goal fall under.

3 Fat-loss Pitfalls to Avoid

  • Don’t wander into the local vitamin supply shop and pick up a bottle of magical ‘fat burning pills’. Often, they nothing more than a blend of stimulants, some of which can actually be quite dangerous[1], that do nothing more than suppress the appetite and cause heart palpitations!
[Tweet ""Don’t wander into the vitamin supply shop and buy a bottle of magical ‘fat burning pills’." -Paleoista"]
  • Don’t read up on how to implement intermittent fasting and/or fasted training and then do too much too soon. If you’re an endurance athlete who’s been training on carbohydrate for years and years, going out for that five hour ride followed by an hour long brick run at threshold on empty isn’t going to result in the workout of your life. Someone who has not allowed their body time to adapt to fat burning is more likely to end up experiencing a horrible bonk[2] which might leave you at the gas station chowing down on anything and everything you can get your chompers on!
[Tweet ""Don’t read up on how to implement intermittent fasting and then do too much too soon." -Paleoista"]
  • Don’t believe the hype…that we athletes must have glycogen stored up in our skeletal muscles and liver to function for even very long bouts of endurance activity, or that our brain can only make the small amount of glucose needed to function from carbohydrate.   In The Art and Science of Low Carbohydrate Performance by Drs. Volek and Phinney[3], we know that we can “train our bodies to burn fat by simply changing the diet over a period of time, thereby turning blood sugar and glycogen into secondary fuels.  Once you make this transition, you can then train harder, perform longer, and recover faster.”
[Tweet ""We can train our bodies to burn fat by simply changing the diet over a period of time." -Paleoista"]
 

2 Tips for a Fat-Adapted Life

And now that we know what to avoid, added to the fact that the human brain functions best based on what to do, rather than what not to do, below are some tips to make your transition even easier:
  • Start out slowly. If you’ve ever just gotten up first thing in the morning and headed out for your run prior to eating, you’ve already begun working in a fasted state.   Now, just build up the time you spend training this way, and before you know it, you won’t even want that smoothie before you head out to sweat!
  • Tweak your macros. Becoming fat adapted isn’t just for workouts; it’s for daily life in general. In a ketogenic approach, it’s important to include some high fat days, with up to 80% of calories coming from an array of fats like avocado, coconut oil and pure MCT oil, olive oil, duck fat and some raw nuts. According to Dr. Perlmutter, MD[4], “Our bodies enter ketosis at the point when blood sugar and liver glycogen are no longer present, and our system resorts to using ketones for fuel. At this point, not only is our body doing the natural thing, and burning off fat, it’s also powering up our brain!”
[Tweet "Pro Tip: To burn fat, include high fat days in your diet, 80% of calories coming from healthy fats."]

How I Did It and You Can Too

On a personal note, admittedly, it took me a long time to begin to test this approach, as I’d been racing ironman quite successfully for years, keeping Paleo since 2005, but always thinking I had to default to the ‘one non Paleo item in my regime’ for long racing and training- the ubiquitous carbohydrate gel. However, after playing around with short bouts of fasted training, only up to about two hours over the last two years, I finally made the switch earlier this season and am seeing marked improvements in wattage output on the bike, speed capability on the run, tremendous recovery and incredible mental clarity. And the numbers don’t lie, either, in a mere six weeks’ time, my triglycerides, already low and in the healthy range, went down by more than half and the extra off-season two pounds slipped right off. It’s not just particular to me, either; clients of mine, athletes and non-athletes alike are finding tremendous success applying these tips to maximize fat burning potential. Curious about learning how?

Schedule a 1-hour consultation with the Paleoista

Contact me for your consult, available globally, and get yourself set up on your path to optimal, fat burning Paleo health!  
References [1] "Harmful Effects of Fat Burners." LIVESTRONG.COM. LIVESTRONG.COM, 16 Aug. 2013. Web. 12 May 2015. [2] "The Science of "Bonking" and Glycogen Depletion - Runners Connect." Runners Connect. N.p., 17 July 2012. Web. 12 May 2015. [3] "The Art and Science of Low Carbohydrate Performance | Art and Science of Low Carb." Art and Science of Low Carb. N.p., n.d. Web. 12 May 2015. [4] "Keep Yourself in Ketosis." David Perlmutter MD. N.p., n.d. Web. 12 May 2015

Sheet1.Title: What is Healing? Answers with Steve Hall, MD
Sheet1.Meta Description: What is healing? The answer: real health is much more than just eating well, taking the right supplements, getting plenty of exercise, and sleeping fully.
Sheet1.Content:
Sore Muscles and Rest Days are Just the Beginning

I’m going to assume that you are here because you want to be the best you can be. You want to be in great shape, you want to do your best at work or school, be the best spouse and parent you can be, you want a sense of fulfillment and meaning and you want to have plenty of happiness and affluence in your life. The big question we all have is “How do I actually accomplish all of this?” I can answer that for you in three words: Seek your health. [Tweet " "Seek your health." - Steve Hall, MD"] That sounds simple enough but how can seeking your health help you have all the things in your life that you want? Isn’t being healthy just a matter of eating well, taking the right supplements, getting plenty of exercise, sleeping well and not stressing out? Real health is much more than that. So what do I mean by “health” and what do you do day-by-day and moment-by-moment to actually seek it? And what are the rewards for finding it? I’m going to answer these questions and more over the next few blog posts. I am a physician in the Seattle area and for the past thirty years I have been combining the best of conventional primary care with the best from many kinds of alternative medicine. I have studied Functional medicine, nutrition, herbs, homeopathy, several kinds of body work, hypnosis, energy medicine and am familiar with Chinese medicine, many forms of Chiropractic and Ayurvedic medicine. I have spent years searching for answers to the questions “what is healing?” and “how can I best help you with yours?” In addition to practicing Integral Medicine, a form of medicine that treats people as whole human beings, my wife and I live on 14 acres in the foothills of the Cascades in Washington. We have raised four children, some of whom we home-schooled, and we organically grow most of our own food. So I am also conversant on topics of natural childbirth, childhood development, education, parenting, soil health and how to make a kick-@$$ hard apple cider. We can agree that the benefits of fermentation are real. Personally I enjoy back-country skiing, scrambling, back-packing, mountain biking and wood working. I like to stay in shape so I can enjoy these things. All this is just so you have a sense of who I am and where I’m coming from. I want to share with you the best of what I have learned. The bottom line: I have learned a simple, reliable way to help you make inner personal changes that are wise, heart-based and last. There is so much information about how to eat right, how to exercise, how to think and feel in order to be relaxed and happy…but how do you actually get yourself to do these things naturally and effortlessly, with no wagon to fall off of? That is what I have learned and that is what I want to teach you. Please feel free to ask any questions you may have that I can answer in future posts. Leave your questions in the comment forum below. Read my next post where I answer: what is healing?

Sheet1.Title: A Guide to Recognize and Maximize Your Healing
Sheet1.Meta Description: The guide to recognize and maximize your healing demonstrates tested methods to define healing for yourself and apply tools that lend to conscious healing.
Sheet1.Content:
Everyday Tools for Everyday Health Decisions

Have you heard the saying, “You have within you the answers to all of your questions?” Do you believe it? I certainly hope so, otherwise you are likely to have a difficult time really healing.  This is the definitive method I use in my daily medical practice to maximize your healing. The sooner you apply these tips, the faster you will empower your body to heal better, and longer.

Define Healing for Yourself

Sometime in my sixth year of medical training I asked myself the question, “What is healing?” and was astounded by the realization that I didn’t know. None of my teachers had ever talked about it. I thought this was ludicrous so I started searching for my own definition. I searched for years through all sorts of medical disciplines, through philosophy, through religious teaching from all over the world. Nothing I found seemed both broad enough to fit for everyone’s experience (health is a perfectly functioning physical body) while being practical enough to actually take into an exam room and apply to a patient and their health issues (health is balance and harmony with the Cosmos.) Eventually I realized that, though I could not define healing, I could recognize it when one of my patients experienced it. I could sense that healing was more than the resolution of symptoms, I just couldn’t put my finger on it. I reasoned this way: if symptoms are clues that healing needs to happen, then the resolution of the symptoms are clues that the healing has happened, it is not the healing itself. So I started watching my patients who healed in an attempt to see what else had changed in them besides their symptoms going away. Quickly I noticed that they had also learned something. For the most part, they learned more about themselves, about how to be in their power, about who they really are underneath society’s domestication, deeper than the woundings, abandonments and disappointments of life. I thought to myself, “I wonder if this learning about one’s self is the healing?” and I came up with the definition that “healing is the process of finding out who you really are and then living true to that.” I have been using this definition now for about twenty years and haven’t outgrown it or found it to be too limiting, so I’m starting to think that there may be something useful to it. I found that most proposed definitions for healing were really just descriptions of some particular result of healing and, in that regard, my definition may be no different, I have just found it particularly helpful. Honestly, I believe that the heart of healing is mostly a mystery and we may never have it within our full control. (But much benefit can still be gained by learning to work with the mystery.)

 Avoid The Urge to Suppress Healing

Once you learn to see life as an educational process--all of your experiences are the curriculum, all of creation is the classroom, your conscious sense of self is the student, the learning objective is to answer the question “Who am I?” and the teacher is your own deep inner wisdom. From this perspective, any treatment that suppresses symptoms without helping you receive the learning buried in that experience actually just prolongs your suffering. Most conventional and even alternative treatments do this. Today I see my role as an MD to help people consult with their own deep inner knowing. “What is that?” you may ask. Have you heard the saying, “You have within you the answers to all of your questions”? Do you believe it? I certainly hope so, otherwise you are likely to have a difficult time really healing. You have within you a deep knowing that, if you could but bring it forward in your life, the results would astound you. Imagine what your life could be like if you could consult with that inner wisdom any time you wanted to. Imagine knowing answers to questions like “what should I do with my life?” or “how do I find real happiness?” or even more day-to-day questions like “what would be best for me to eat right now?” [Tweet "Imagine knowing answers to questions like “what should I do with my life?” or “how do I find real happiness?”"]

Increase Your Conscious Self Awareness 

Deep inside you know the answers to abstract and foundational questions posed above. And there are ways you can let that knowing into your conscious mind. I found a way to help my patients access their inner knowing through the combination of advanced Craniosacral Therapy and clinical hypnosis. Once a person connected with their inner knowing, it took on the role of personal life coach and taught them a set of skills. When my patients applied those newly learned skills to whatever was happening in their life, they found the learning in the experience and healed. I noticed an amazing consistency to these skills: they were the same no matter the person’s age, gender, level of education, religious beliefs, cultural background, diseases they faced or anything else I could observe. I started to call these skills “The Seven Tools of Healing” because, well…there are seven of them, and when people used them, they healed. Soon I learned that if I taught my patients these seven skills and they started to practice them, not only did connecting with their inner wisdom get easier but they could connect on their own without my assistance or the need for hypnosis. They were able to listen to their life and know for themselves how best to respond. They knew how best to eat, to exercise, who to call to spend time with, how to deal with stress, what therapies to use and such. I want you to have that same advantage so I want to teach you the Seven Tools of Healing and encourage you to practice them for yourself. Read my next article on the Seven Tools of Healing.

Questions?

Leave your questions in the comments forum below to learn about real healing.

Sheet1.Title: The Elvis Burger
Sheet1.Meta Description: A rocking tribute to the King, this Elvis Burger is topped with creamy Sunbutter, banana, and bacon for a taste explosion of epic proportions.
Sheet1.Content:
It's a hunka-hunka burning yum (Sorry!)

I grew up in the 1970s and no one was a bigger star than Elvis Presley. By the time I was old enough to sing and dance along to his music, he'd reached the puffier, white-jumpsuit-phase of his career, but I loved him with a pure-hearted devotion. I'd make my babysitter watch me as I stood on my bed, singing "Burning Love" and throwing scarves in the audience, just like Elvis (whom I watched on TV) and the Elvis impersonator my mom took me to see at the State Fairgrounds. Later, as an adult, I learned about Elvis's favorite meal: It was a grilled peanut butter, banana, and bacon sandwich with an optional drizzle of honey. One year for Thanksgiving, my husband and I decided to make Elvis sandwiches instead of the traditional turkey. It was glorious — and a once-in-a-lifetime event. But once I tasted the nutty+bacony goodness, I couldn't forget about it, and this Elvis Burger rose out of the junk food ashes like a phoenix. I replaced the peanut butter with Sunbutter (see ya, legumes!), and ditched the bun for a lettuce wrap. Thanks to caramelized bananas, there's really no need for honey, but if you want to take it over the top, a little drizzle will do the trick. Elvis Burger Serves 2-4 | Prep 10 min | Cook 10 min Ingredients: 1 pound ground beef 3/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper 4 slices sugar-free bacon 2 medium bananas, peeled and diced 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger 1/4 cup sunflower seed or almond butter (no sugar added) Directions: 1. Preheat a gas grill with all burners on high, lid closed, 10-15 minutes. 2. Mix the ground beef with salt and pepper and shape into four patties. Gently press down the center of each patty until it’s about 1/2-inch thick to make a slight depression; this will prevent them from turning bulbous when you cook them. Grill patties, uncovered and without pressing down on them, until they’re seared on one side, about 3 minutes. Flip the burgers and continue grilling to desired temperature: 3 minutes for rare, 4 minutes for medium, and 5 minutes for well-done. 3. While the burgers are cooking, cut the bacon into 1-inch pieces. Place in a cold, nonstick skillet, then turn heat to medium-high and cook until browned and crisp, about 5 minutes. Remove the bacon to a paper towel to drain. Pour all but 1 tablespoon of the bacon fat out of the pan. Add the bananas and ginger to the pan and sauté until soft and lightly browned, about 3-5 minutes. Set aside. 4. Place the sunflower butter in a microwave-safe dish (or saucepan on the stove) and heat until thinned, about 40 seconds in the microwave. 5. When the burgers are good to go, top each with 1 tablespoon of melted sunflower butter and a few tablespoons of the bananas, then sprinkle with bacon. Feel free to sing your favorite Elvis tune while you chow down. Note: You can also pan-fry or bake the burgers. On the stovetop, cook in a nonstick skillet, 5 minutes, then flip and continue to cook: 3 minutes for rare, 4 minutes for medium, 5 minutes for well-done. In the oven, bake at 400F for 20-25 minutes.

Sheet1.Title: DIY Zingy Ginger Dressing
Sheet1.Meta Description: Zingy Ginger Dressing is shockingly delicious -- on salads, grilled meats, and cooked veggies. Simple and fast to make, it's a secret weapon in the kitchen.
Sheet1.Content:
A shockingly delicious way to raise your salad game

This is my favorite recipe from my cookbook Well Fed 2. I know that probably seems like a strange thing to say. How can a salad dressing be a favorite food?! But it's true! When carrots, onions, ginger, and oil are puréed together, they become creamy, light, luscious, and so much more than their individual parts. Every time I make this dressing, I say "It's so good!" — or, really it's more like, "Eet*s thoooo guuuu#*d!" because I'm trying to gleefully say the words while simultaneously licking the spatula. Whip up a batch of Zingy Ginger Dressing and keep it in the fridge for anytime you have a Boring Food Emergency. It's awesome on salads, but it also perks up grilled meat (try it as a dipping sauce for steak!), works great for shrimp cocktail, and adds flair to a baked white or sweet potato. Zingy Ginger Dressing Makes 1 1/2 cups | Prep 10 minutes | Whole30 compliant Ingredients: 1/2 cup light tasting olive oil (not extra virgin!) or avocado oil 1/4 cup rice or cider vinegar 1 tablespoon coconut aminos or homemade substitute 2 medium carrots, peeled and cut into chunks 1/4 medium yellow onion, peeled and cut into chunks 2-inch piece fresh ginger, grated (about 1 tablespoon) 1 medium clove garlic, peeled and smashed salt and ground black pepper, to taste Directions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a food processor and purée until smooth. Add water 1 tablespoon at a time, if necessary, to reach your desired consistency. 2. Allow the flavors to meld about 10 minutes before eating. Store covered in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. Tasty Ideas Unlike a vinaigrette, this dressing works best if you dollop it on top of stuff, instead of tossing it. Tasty Basic Salad: shredded iceberg lettuce, diced cucumbers, diced red bell peppers, lots of salt and pepper Chopped Veggie Salad: diced cucumber, scallion, bell pepper, hearts of palm, parsley Asian Chopped Salad: diced cucumbers, scallions, red bell pepper, shredded red cabbage, cilantro, sesame seeds Shrimp Cocktail: use as a dipping sauce for cold steamed shrimp instead of traditional cocktail sauce (Works with crab and lobster, too!) Chicken Plate: use as a dipping sauce for cold roast or grilled chicken strips, green and red bell peppers, cucumbers, cold steamed broccoli Creamy Zingy Ginger Dressing: mix this dressing with some homemade mayo to make a creamy version and use in all the same ways

Sheet1.Title: 5 Paleo Pointers for Well-Rounded Results
Sheet1.Meta Description: Whether you’re an all-in 100% Paleo powerhouse or an 80/20 sort of person, it’s pretty easy to focus on the diet and forget about balance in your lifestyle.
Sheet1.Content:
Whether you’re an all-in 100% Paleo powerhouse or an 80/20 sort of person, it’s pretty easy to focus on the diet and forget about the overall lifestyle. Achieving clean eating can be a revolutionary feeling! Making sure you have the rest down pat will help you feel even more fantastic. Here are five Paleo pointers to help you get there:  

#1: I’ve got a pocket, got a pocket full of SUNshine…

So you’ve cut out the foods that were holding you back and your body is running on clean fuel like a top speed dragster. With all the good you’re doing for your body, make sure that you don’t miss out on Vitamin D. It’s not found in dietary sources on the Paleo plan[1], so you’ll need to make sure that you get a natural dose every day. The good news is that it’s as simple as getting out in the sunlight! The amount of rays you need depends on a lot of factors like the weather, the season and where you live. For sound advice on getting optimal rays visit www.vitamindcouncil.org.  

#2: Relax. You’ve got time.

Your Paleo lifestyle gives you the energy and the stamina to take on your day, your workout and your life. With all that goodness going on it can be hard to remember to give your body and your mind the time to relax and reboot. Stress wreaks havoc on our bodies, causing disease and even accelerated aging[2]. Some stress is pretty unavoidable, but if you take the time to focus on relaxing for even just a few minutes each day you’ll reap the rewards. Why not meditate for five minutes or take a nap in that lonely hammock out in the yard? For more relaxation ideas visit www.webmd.com.  

#3: Vegetables are your friends!

Noshing on a plate of steak and buttery yams is pretty darn satisfying and not thinking about counting the calories borders on a relaxation activity in itself! The Paleo lifestyle definitely has its perks. It’s easy to fill up on high quality protein and skip the fruits and veggies. Keep balance in mind and be sure to eat plenty of non-starchy vegetables every day. It’s also a great idea to take in some whole fruit, depending on your weight loss goals and your blood sugar balance.[3] To learn more visit paleologix.com  

#4: Sometimes life requires preparation.

You’ve learned to love the time you spend making healthy choices, chopping veggies and grilling like a boss. In a perfect world every meal would be that way. The truth is that sometimes you’re on the go. If you’re combining your Paleo lifestyle with demanding physical activity, it’s more important than ever that you fuel your performance. Keeping ready-made easy access options on hand is a must. AMRAP has the cure for what ails you: delicious protein bars that pack a Paleo punch and taste great too. Get yours at www.amrapnutrition.com.  

#5: Rome wasn’t built in a day, and it wasn’t built alone either.

One of the most unique assets of the Paleo lifestyle is the community. Interacting with other people can really help boost your success. Maybe an online forum member can talk you through a tough spot or share recipes. Someone closer to home might be a motivating workout buddy or a clean eating dinner date. The Paleo community is out there, and you don’t have to look far. If you’re still searching for it try looking for gatherings in your area on paleo-diet.meetup.com.  
[1] Article: The Nutritional Characteristics of a Contemporary Diet Based Upon Paleolithic Food Groups by Loren Cordain, PhD. 2002. https://s3.amazonaws.com/paleodietevo2/research/The+Nutritional+Characteristics+of+a+Contemporary+Diet+Based+Upon+Paleolithic+Food+Groups+The+Paleo+Diet.pdf [2] http://thepaleodiet.com/5-paleo-diet-experiences-to-let-the-good-times-roll/ [3] http://paleologix.com/about/dietary-guidelines/

Sheet1.Title: Creamy Asparagus Soup
Sheet1.Meta Description: This asparagus soup uses farm fresh organic asparagus, which is healthier than its ordinary counterpart. It is only three ingredients and my kids love it.
Sheet1.Content:
Light and fresh with a tantalizing creaminess

  I am always scouting for recipes that are fast, easy, and delicious. I stumbled across this healthy masterpiece in a restaurant, and it had me completely hooked, as it tasted amazing, and used only three main ingredients. I never imagined asparagus soup could be that mouth-watering on its own but I was pleasantly surprised.   Why use organic asparagus?   A slight correction though, this soup uses farm fresh organic asparagus, which is healthier than its ordinary counterpart as it combines the wholesomeness of the vegetable and organic food. It has several benefits such as:  
  • Packed with anti-inflammatory elements like asparanin A, sarsasapogenin, protodioscin, and diosgenin.
  • Prevents chronic inflammation, which in turn is responsible for many chronic illnesses like arthritis, heart disease, and even cancer.
  • It has numerous antioxidants like beta-carotene, vitamin E and vitamin C – your immune system becomes stronger as the body is protected from oxidative stress, which helps it to fight off diseases quickly and effectively.
  • The amino acids in this vegetable are believed to have anti-tumor effects.
  • It contains inulin, a carbohydrate used to feed the good bacteria in the digestive tract, thus helping to promote digestion.
  • It has vitamin B in good quantities that is useful in controlling blood sugar and improving overall heart health. Dietary fibers in it also reduce the risks for heart diseases.
  • Last but not the least; organic asparagus is free pesticides and other toxic chemicals.
  A few serving suggestions…   This soup can be an even bigger hit if you can serve it well. sliced fresh avocado or grilled green and red bell peppers will work great, as it stimulates the taste buds and heighten sensations on the tongue – the soup tastes even more scrumptious.   I have included options for seasoning if you want to experiment with the flavor and taste. If you want to stick to the conventional method, use only sea salt, as that is more than sufficient to bring out the rich, creamy tang. The best part is that my kids loved it and kept on asking me to make it repeatedly! Ready to create this dish? Download my recipe cards here.

Sheet1.Title: Chewy Paleo Chocolate Chip Cookies
Sheet1.Meta Description: As you bite into one of my paleo chocolate chip cookies and feel the warm melty heat of still warm ingredients you'll be grinning wide. This is pure joy.
Sheet1.Content:
A Classic Recipe Made Timeless

If you have a sweet tooth like me, then I am sure you have a fondness for chocolate chip cookies too! When I was a kid, I was always sneaking into the kitchen and emptying the entire cookie jar in a few hours! Despite repeated admonishing by my mother, I kept doing it as I simply couldn’t resist the yummy, crunchy taste. That was certainly a different time in terms of food. The Paleo diet… As I grew up, I got bitten by the health bug. I read many articles regarding the food we eat and its direct effect on our current and future health. That is how I came across the Paleo diet, which is based on imitating the eating habits of our ancestors. It allows you to enjoy robust health by providing natural nourishment free from side effects. Now, the Paleo diet suggests staying away from foods with refined sugar, candy, sweetened beverages and other sugary stuff and it was a huge roadblock for me, as it meant abstaining from one of my favorite treats!   Combining Paleo with cookies… I started researching about Paleo diet in detail, and thankfully came across several variations of chocolate cookie recipes that were in compliance with the principles of Paleo. It is a quick and easy method to stay healthy and also indulge in delicious chocolate chip cookies. I have used organic honey for sweetening instead of sugar. Unlike its non-organic counterpart, this type of honey is free from contamination like pesticides, antibiotics or other synthetic components. It is safe and adds wonderfully to the flavor.   I know that some of you might not be a fan of dark chocolate due to its bitter essence. But trust me; it doesn’t affect the overall taste of these cookies. Moreover, dark chocolate is good for the heart and brain, packed with antioxidants, controls blood sugar levels, and contains lots of nutrients. It also has theobromine that hardens tooth enamel and reduces possibilities of cavities. Adding nuts is optional though I would suggest cashew nuts or blanched almonds. You can try macadamia nuts as well. A bonus is that nuts also boost the fatty acids content in the body.   Chocolate chip cookies are best served with a cool glass of almond milk, but you are welcome to bake a batch and serve it as dessert or starters. Regardless of these factors, I can guarantee this platter of cookies will soon make their way into your bellies!   Click to Download the Paleo Chocolate Chip Cookies recipe cards and enjoy every bite!

Sheet1.Title: Cashew Chicken Stir-Fry
Sheet1.Meta Description: One of my favorite lunches is a cashew chicken stir-fry. It’s quick and easy to throw together, and is a recipe that tastes even better as left-overs.
Sheet1.Content:
20 Minute Prep for a Strong Week Ahead

 

I like most people live a very full busy life. I have a big-girl job that takes up a good 40 hours a week, a second job where I coach little kids climbing two nights a week, community projects, personal projects, a social life, a boyfriend and of course training. Most minutes in my day are accounted for and if I don’t plan out my meals and make an effort to cook ahead of time my week and all the activities suffer. I have found time and time again that my nutrition and my meals are without a doubt the keystone to having a good week. Plus hangry is a real thing!

I will typically shop Sunday afternoon; imagine a cart full of veggies, eggs, chicken and berries, and then spend the evening in the kitchen with a glass of Cabernet Sauvignon doing some food prep and watching rock climbing videos or MotoGP. I will make a week’s worth of breakfasts and lunches and stock the fridge with ready to go dinner ingredients.

One of my favorite lunches is a cashew chicken stir-fry. It’s quick and easy to throw together while you’re drinking wine and it’s one of those meals that tastes even better as left-overs. I prefer the stir-fry over brown rice or quinoa but it’s also fantastic over mashed sweet potatoes. So if you’re like me and appreciate good food for the week without the cook time cramping your style, give this recipe a try and let me know what you think!

Cashew Chicken Stir-Fry

Prep time- 3 minutes; Cook time- 10 to 15;

Serving size- 3 to 5 depending on your size and hunger level ;)

Ingredients

  • ½ Large Onion
  • 1 Clove Garlic
  • 3 Large Chicken Breasts
  • 1 tsp Cinnamon
  • 1 tsp Italian spice
  • ½ tsp Garlic salt
  • ½ tsp Onion salt
  • 1 tsp Chili Flakes (if you like things spicy)
  • 1 tbs Honey
  • ½ c Cashew halves and pieces
  • ¼ Dried Cranberries
  • 1 Organic Orange
  • 3 Celery Stalks

Directions

-Heat a bit of oil in a large frying pan on medium/high heat

-Mince the garlic and finely chop the onion and add them to the frying pan as the frying pan heats

-Dice chicken into ¾ inch cubes and add to hot frying pan

-Add the spices and simmer for about 5 minutes

-Next zest the orange and squeeze the juice into the frying pan

-Add the cashews, dried cranberries, chopped celery, and honey and simmer for another 5 to 8 minutes.

-Devour, dish up, or save for later!

Sheet1.Title: TIME & DIET: My struggle at 42
Sheet1.Meta Description: I have a serious lack of time, and a serious desire to be healthy and fit. These are 5 ways I've addressed my needs for a healthy diet and regular training.
Sheet1.Content:
How I Stay Fit When Time is Tied Up

I recently took on some new work--probably the best opportunity I've had in my life so far. At every level, over the next few years, this opportunity will bring very positive things into my world and I'm very grateful for it.
Compounding on this fact, my father was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, and his situation is serious and requires a lot of action and attention. I imagine this situation is not terribly uncommon at my age.  Our parents are retiring or in their first years of retirement and our careers are in a place where our experience begins to pay off.
All these new developments lead me to a lack in a single resource: Time.
My work situation, to be more specific is: I can no longer take care of strength and conditioning at my CrossFit gym early in the morning as I need to catch an early train. I can no longer workout at any CrossFit box as I get back from the train after anyone has a class running.
The home gym was one option remaining, but not as effective if you perform better in a team environment.
Then there was the issue of eating well, reminding me with every processed bite I took during a busy commute. I was drifting from my path, and it needed to be addressed.
[Tweet "I have a serious lack of time, and a serious desire to be healthy and fit."]

How I Addressed Poor Habits in My Diet

I became very interested in a meat-free, gluten-free diet after years with my son who has managed his autism through diet and also with my exposure to Dr. Gerson and the Gerson Therapy (TIP: watch the documentary "The Beautiful Truth".)
For those of you less obsessed with eating plans and the effect of food on the various organs of the body, I'll spare you details and just summarize it: Eating a lot of red meat, and meat in general, most likely strains the pancreas and puts you at risk for pancreatic cancer. (Source: Cancer.org)
So, I was leaning toward a mostly meat-free and mostly gluten-free diet already, focused on the gradual strategy that involves groceries, food preparation, and other inconveniences and investments. Now it's in my face--my grandfather died from pancreatic cancer and now my father is in the same situation.
This brings me to a combination of issues that we are all facing. I have a serious lack of time, and a serious desire to be healthy and fit.
The passion for the latter, being healthy and fit, motivated me to take action that mitigated my problem.

Here are some steps that I've taken and plan to take (in no particular order):

1. Signed up for a family membership to LifeTime Fitness

I can be hated for this, I'm ready for it.  I laughed at myself, but the reality is it is open 24/7, solving the issue of late evening workouts.  The gym has 90% of the equipment I need to complete my crossfit workouts (minus ropes and rings). On top of this, the price for a family membership (six kids and two adults) was less than a membership for my wife and I at a CrossFit box. Yes, you have tradeoffs, but I like that I can be active with my kids.
What else do we get for our membership?  Access to the outdoor pool all summer for all of us ($600 savings) and access to an indoor soccer field (all my kids play soccer), access to basketball courts, racquetball courts, free yoga and spin classes, and the list keeps going. I signed up for 24/7 access and ended up getting a lot of extra benefits.
I'm doing now creating my own programming. See it here on Beyond the Whiteboard and try it yourself.

2. Get a juicer

Gotta get this. I won't be 100% fanatic, though I bet I'll soon be 90% plant-based.

3. Form a strategy to buy and store large quantities of fruits and vegetables

This is the hardest part. How can I affordably do this? Where do I get the food, how do I store it, and how do I know how much to get?  I'm taking most guidance from the Gerson Institute, and I'm sure I'll get there.

4. Work with LifeTime Fitness to transform their facility into a more functional fitness facility

I think I can help them do this--25% of their floor isn't really being used but is full of ineffective static machines.  We could use that space for better work. I would encourage you to ask for the same changes if you need to go the route of a globo-gym. Lay it out like a CrossFit box!

5. Find the right packaged foods to fill the gaps

I have a lot of experience with this because of two reasons.  I have a lot of kids. And I had one son diagnosed as autistic. As part of his diet, gluten was out, so I became "obsessed" to avoid spending my life chopping vegetables and figure out how to feed this kid while I was in the car for six hours a day on the weekend driving to soccer games.
Not just for myself, but for the kiddos--I need bars, I need protein/recovery shakes, and I need a plan.
I may not have eliminated my time and diet challenges, but I'm just going to start because I know what happens if you start--you always come out on the other side with a smile (and sweat and tears).
Sheet1.Categories: Interesting Other | Lifestyle Design | Nutrition Hacks

Sheet1.Title: Coconut Water for Performance?
Sheet1.Meta Description: Considering fluids, sugars, electrolytes, use coconut water as a healthy treat or a pre/post workout base for your heathy smoothie. Not as a hydration mix.
Sheet1.Content:
We want to know if coconut water delivers hydration like good ol' H2O

It´s completely clear the healthy trend over coconut water. The nutritional composition, antioxidants, potassium, low calorie profile, low acidity, and a very particular taste, make coconut water a must to analyze in a close look for any health and fitness lifestyle advocate. I segmented my analysis in three categories--fluids, electrolytes, and sugar. In my cycling and running, I've found these three to have the most significant factor in overall fitness and performance. So, jumping right in--

Fluid:

The natural coconut water is a transparent liquid that forms inside the coconut. The liquid itself is a unique chemical composition of water, sugars, vitamins, minerals, amino acids and phytohormones.[1]   There are mainly two kinds of coconuts: young (green) and old (dark). When drinking coconut water the preference should be towards young coconut water, since the nutritional contest is far more dense than the dark coconuts; that is because the freshness: the younger, the greenest and when it comes to coconut water: fresher is better!  

Electrolytes:

Electrolyte content of coconut water is high in potassium, but low in sodium, calcium and magnesium. As we remember form Hydration Part 1 and Part 2, the main source for proper hydration is the mix of fluid (water) and sodium (key electrolyte for hydration). When it comes to the high potassium levels in coconut water, is not exactly related with proper daily hydration and should not be your beverage of choice for sport performance.   High potassium levels are required to fight a dehydrated state where the intra cellular fluid of the cells (which is rich in potassium) has been lost, meaning that the dehydration state is dangerous, normally achieved since the hydration protocol of fluid + sodium was not followed.   For keep hydrated on a daily base or in a the moderate to intense exercise activity, coconut water will not constitute a great hydration fluid-electrolyte blend since the connected of sodium is low and high in potassium. Drinking coconut water in excess can lead to hyperkalemia, which is the excess of potassium in the bloodstream and can lead to dangerous, and possibly deadly, changes in heart rhythm[2].   So from the hydration point, coconut water is more considered a supplement, but is far from your best option.  

Sugar:

The sugars naturally contained in coconut are glucose 35 to 50%, sucrose 18 to 35% and glucose 12 to 36%, depending on the maturation of the coconut[3]. That mix of sugars is quiet fine for a pre or post workout healthy shake, but I will never recommend it as a all-day beverage, since it’s still sugar and will raise your insulin response. We want sugar in our body when it needs it: right before or after the moderate to intense exercise.   I recommend coconut water as a healthy treat or as a great pre/post workout base for your heathy smoothie. Never as a hydration mix.

Tips for picking the best coconut water:

  • Always prefer to buy the green coconut, cutting it yourself and drinking directly from the source.
  • Look for 100% green coconut water with no preservatives, added sugars or fancy packages. The simpler, the better.
  • Coconut water is far more delicate to temperature changes than dairy products, so keep it cool always!
  • Use the coconut water as the base for your pre and post workout meals, don’t go crazy with it. Keep drinking water and sodium as your hydration blend, remember that you should think of coconut water as a great source of healthy sugars, vitamins, antioxidants and amino acids more than as a sport drink, hydration beverage or substitute for tap water.
References: [1]http://www.researchgate.net/publication/40768354_The_Chemical_Composition_and_Biological_Properties_of_Coconut_(Cocos_nucifera_L.)_Water [2] http://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/hyperkalemia-causes-symptoms-treatments [3] http://www.scielo.br/pdf/jped/v82n4/en_v82n4a14.pdf
