Sheet1.Title: Paleo Blueberry Peach Cobbler (GF)
Sheet1.Meta Description: Gluten Free and Paleo never tasted so sweet. My paleo blueberry peach cobbler combines fresh seasonal fruit and a winning crust of tigernut & almond flour.
Sheet1.Content:
Fresh Fruit to Kickoff the Summer Season

  Days are getting longer. Sun is shining brighter. And weekend BBQs are becoming more frequent. All of this means that summer is coming, vitamin D is in high supply, and people tend to be a whole lot happier. Perhaps one of the best parts of summer: A WHOLE new crop of amazing fruit at farmers market. Nothing says summer like popping a fresh blueberry bursting with flavor into your mouth, or biting into a sweet, juicy peach for the first time. These two fruits are a match made in heaven, which is why I’ve decided to bring them together to kick off the summer season. (I'll admit, this recipe is an especially great cure for mid-winter blues. Keep it handy for those colder months too.) Bring your loved ones together to celebrate with food, laughter, and fun. And finish off the meal with the most delicious cobbler I’ve made to date. Then. don’t forget to smile, knowing you are nourishing mind, body, and soul! This recipe follows an 80/20 approach to Paleo, as I use gluten free arrowroot flour and give the option to use heavy cream or substitute out with coconut cream. But if you crave a conclusive verdict on arrowroot flour, consider this: "Arrowroot is a starchy tuber, and it can be processed into a powder which can be used as a thickener for stews, sauces, and gravies. Sounds simple enough, right? Well, if you are wondering whether arrowroot powder is Paleo or not, it turns out that the answer is not so simple. According to Robb Wolf, it is Paleo. Mark Sisson of Mark’s Daily Apple gives it approval for people who follow a Primal diet, which is close to Paleo but slightly different." -The Paleo List Nevertheless, cheers to a wonderful summer season with the ones you love most. Enjoy!

Blueberry Peach Cobbler (GF)

  • Servings: 6
  • Time: 45 min
  • Difficulty: moderate
WHAT YOU NEED: for the filling:
  • 1/4 cup raw heavy cream (coconut cream will work too)
  • 1 TB maple syrup
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 1/4 tsp cinnamon
  • 1 TB arrowroot flour
  • 2 cups of local, organic blueberries
  • 2 large or 3 medium peaches (plus boiling water and ice water to remove skins)
for the topping:
  • 1/3 cup almond flour
  • 1/3 cup tigernut flour(you can double the almond flour if you don’t have tigernut flour, but I love the consistency when it’s used)
  • 1/2 tsp cinnamon
  • pinch of sea salt
  • 1/2 cup (8TB) cold grass fed butter or ghee
  • 3 TB coconut sugar
  • 1/2 cup crushed walnuts
WHAT YOU DO:
  • preheat the oven to 350F
  • fill a small pot with water and bring it to a boil and fill a bowl with cold water and ice
  • once the water is boiling, drop in your peaches for 30 seconds, remove with a slotted spoon, drop into ice water for 10 seconds, then remove and peel the skin (it should basically fall off at this point)*
  • slice your skinned peaches, rinse your blueberries and set aside
  • now, in a bowl mix all the filling ingredients until combined, add your fruit, and stir gently until all your fruit is coated (gently now)
  • in a separate bowl, sift together almond flour, tigernut flour, cinnamon, and salt
  • cut your cold butter into small chunks and use your fingers to cut the flour with the butter until it’s combined and you have tiny pearls of flour
  • add your coconut sugar and crushed walnuts and stir it up, until you have a nice crumbly topping
  • pour your filling into a cast iron skillet or crumble dish and cover evenly with topping
  • bake for 20-30 minutes or until the topping is slightly brown and the amazingly delicious fruit filling is bubbling out the sides (holy crap, I’m drooling)
  • ENJOY! We topped it with vanilla ice cream, and enjoyed every last crumb
*let your water cool and then use it to water your garden!

Sheet1.Title: 1 Loaded Concept That Aides Recovery
Sheet1.Meta Description: Are you using healing therapies, like faith conditioning, to improve your fitness psychology? Dedicated belief factors largely in our recovery and health.
Sheet1.Content:
Are you using healing therapies, like faith conditioning, to improve your fitness psychology?

I know. Faith is a loaded word. Believe me, as a conventionally trained MD and science nerd, I had a hard time even saying it at first. And of the seven aspects of how people’s inner wisdom helped them make lasting changes in their lives, Faith was the last one I became aware of, but I had to put it first because of the way our healing/recovery process works. Faith is the foundation upon which everything else you think you know is built. Even scientific knowledge is built on foundational assumptions about Nature, which have to change from time to time, as Thomas Kuhn so eloquently described in his amazing book The Structure of Scientific Revolution. You know your mother is your mother because you believe her. How do you know you weren’t switched in the nursery at birth? [Tweet "When faith reaches the level of certainty, things really start to happen. - Muhammad Ali"] Faith also imbues the object of faith with a greater certainty of manifestation. In other words, the power of your faith is proportional to the power of your ability to manifest, to bring your dreams to fruition. Muhammad Ali, the great spiritual sage, once noted that “when faith reaches the level of certainty, things really start to happen.” Faith is unique from other healing therapies as it needs no proof, no data. In fact, that’s sort of the point of faith. But this property of faith is both a strength and a liability. Because it needs no proof or data, people can use their faith to believe in the wackiest things, or in things that really block their healing. This is a problem because of the power of beliefs, which we’ll get into. But if you mix equal parts faith with equal parts reason, you get a really useful concoction. Within the context of a gym or a race, you have total control over what you choose to believe in. You can have faith your abilities, in your training, and in your future success. Of course reason reminds you that a PR deadlift is out of reach, no matter your absolute belief, if you have not been physically prepping your body. How many people have we seen with the obvious strength to complete a task, but they fail? Or an athlete with a catastrophic injury, make a unexplainable full recovery?  It is mental. So, if faith is a choice, why not choose to believe whatever helps you the most? For example, you can have faith that healing is always possible, and not just for everyone else, but for you, too. Or have faith that if you could just be your true, authentic self, that would be enough in your life. You don’t have to be more than that or settle for less. You can have faith in yourself: that you will know how to handle whatever life puts in your path, that you will always have an ability to respond. Or think of some things that, if you had faith in them, would help you in your life. People’s inner wisdom uses faith as a foundation but it also continually asks people to have faith in it, in other words, it asks people to trust what they know. Trust what you know. If you really admitted to yourself what you know about yourself, the vast majority of the time, you would be right. Most of the time when you get into trouble, you have over-ridden what you know deep inside to be right and gone with what your head wants. Your inner wisdom also uses faith in the process of changing and updating your beliefs. One of the properties of beliefs is they comb through all of your experiences and highlight for special attention those that reinforce or support it. So, over time, you collect up a lot of direct experiential data to prove to yourself that that belief is true (whether it is or not.) When you realize that that belief is too limiting, that it is holding you back, you have to jettison it (the “hows” on that one will be in a future blog) and replace it with a new belief. When you first adopt a new belief, it hasn’t had time to collect any of its own special data so you have to accept it on faith. At first. As soon as the new belief settles into your non-conscious mind and becomes part of your “structure of interpretation,” your world view, it will bring you plenty of experiences to prove itself to you. [Tweet "So, if faith is a choice, why not choose to believe whatever helps you the most? "] Doubt is a test of faith. If the doubt wins, if you start to doubt yourself, for example, that means your faith isn’t strong enough. Go back the faith gym and give it another workout. Pep talks to yourself work great here. Faith is tricky to learn how to use skillfully. It’s a blank canvas; it’s a car you can drive over any terrain. You get to choose where to aim it, how to apply it. Experiment, try different things, give yourself permission to make a few mistakes, just learn as much as you can from them. As I said, faith in cahoots with reason can be a very powerful ally.

Sheet1.Title: Fitness Psychology 101: Practice Awareness
Sheet1.Meta Description: Practice awareness is a skill. With time, you identify cues that help you respond to cues in your life--mental and physical--for better quality of life.
Sheet1.Content:
Avoiding a Rut is Easier When You Can Identify it Clearly

  Awareness is a big topic. The basic premise is that it is much easier to work on an issue in your life, whether it is a physical illness, a bothersome emotion or limiting belief, if you know it is there. Awareness moves something from the not-known over to the known. Remember, healing is the process of finding out who you really are and then making choices that are in alignment with that. So becoming aware of who you are and the details of your personal moment-to-moment truth is critical for healing. Your life is feeding you clues about who you are all day (and night) long. You want to practice awareness of every aspect of your life so you pick up on all the clues you need. Awareness is a skill that gets better with practice. So how does one practice awareness, you ask? In the most basic sense, you can become aware of something simply by focusing your attention on it, but let's take this further.  

Awareness is Mental Data Mining

Wherever you focus your attention, your mind just naturally starts taking in and making conscious sense out of the sensory data. For example, take a moment and just cast your eyes around the room or wherever you are. Notice that wherever your eyes land, you start to take in data about what you are seeing. Then your mind decides what the data means. What is registering on your retinas are just colored patches of light. If you want to get nerdy with me, it is your mind that says “that’s a window” or “that’s the corner of the walls and ceiling,” etc. So if you want to start becoming aware of something, simply focus your attention on it. Where you focus your attention is a choice you get to make. Curiosity about what you are looking at increases how much you take in and retain. FUN FACT: You know how there is wisdom buried in our language, like “health,” “wholeness,” “hale,” “hearty” and “holy” all coming from the same root word? Interestingly, “cure” and “curiosity” also come from the same root word. Then again, how do you focus awareness on the squishy, non-tangible aspects of your life. When it's not a physical three-dimensional object, how can we practice awareness? Moreover how will that focus on the intangible help me recognize something like poor form or a damaging mindset? I would argue that the intangible awareness we cultivate manifests most positively, so let's learn how and what to focus on.

Awareness for Intangibles

These are some of the aspects of your life that you can deepen your awareness of simply by choosing to focus your attention upon them:
  • Physical feelings — what information is my body sending me right now?
  • Emotional feelings — how am I feeling? What belief is behind it? What is a healthy response to it?
  • Thoughts and mental activity — what am I thinking? What stimulated that thought? What belief(s) is/are influencing my conclusions? Are my thoughts in alignment with what I want to achieve? This thought is showing me how I’m currently directing the flow of my Consciousness and creativity. Is this how I want my Consciousness flowing right now?
  • The energetic — both within your body and with regard to your present situation. How is my energy flowing? Are there any blocks? How is my vitality right now? What is influencing it? What is it asking of me?
  • Beliefs – what are the beliefs underlying my thoughts and feelings? What are the beliefs that make up my world view? How do these beliefs look from a higher or Spiritual perspective?
  • Dreams — (dreams can be viewed as an important means of communication between the conscious and non-conscious aspects of the mind) what feelings do the dreams evoke? What symbolic meaning does the dream have?
  • Actions — how do (did) I respond to various situations? What thoughts, feelings and beliefs are influencing my actions? What are the results of my actions? Are they congruent with what I want for my life?
  • Relationships — the eye (I) cannot see itself — what sides of me are being revealed in this symbolic “mirror”? What feelings come up in me as a result of the interactions I have in this relationship? What are the cultural and social influences?
  • Surroundings — how do shapes, colors, textures and the arrangement of the physical environment influence how I feel? How am I influenced by the weather, traffic, world events or other factors in the environment? This one is analyzing the affect of tangible objects on personal psychology.
There may be even more aspects of your life you want to attend to. Every experience you have is a chance to deepen your understanding of yourself.  

One Awareness Practice That Has Helped Me.

I like to go on walks in the evenings. Luckily, I live in the country where the roads are not very busy. As I’m walking, I challenge myself to become as aware as I can of everything I can see: the shapes of the trees in the starlight, the edges of the road, the distant houses and fences and such. As soon as I feel like I am really taking in and registering the visual, I hold onto that and start to add in what I can hear: my feet on the road, the swooshing of my clothing, my dog’s footsteps, wind in the trees, distant cars and such. As soon as I feel comfortable with all I’m seeing and hearing, I become aware of what I am smelling: the night air, the different kinds of trees, the leaves molding on the ground and such. Then I add in what I can feel through my skin: the air temperature, my feet touching the ground, the belt around my waist and such. If at any time I get distracted or lose focus on any particular sensory modality, I just start over. You don’t have to do this kind of exercise only when you’re walking. Adapt it to whatever situation you are in and just set aside a few minutes a day to practice. To summarize, if you see an aspect of yourself that you want to change and you try to force yourself to change it, what generally happens? Right. You get in an arms race with yourself and eventually fatigue, get distracted or otherwise give up. But what happens if you practice a skill? You generally get better at it. Then what you are just naturally able to do changes because you have new and better skills. Tools like faith conditioning and practicing awareness are really skills that you practice and, as you get better at them, healing yourself just becomes automatically easier and more natural to you.

Sheet1.Title: Paleo Birthday Party Guide
Sheet1.Meta Description: I cringe at birthday parties' havoc on my Paleo family, but I'll share what works for me, giving you a good place to start for an A+ Paleo Birthday Party.
Sheet1.Content:
How to keep your kiddo happy, healthy and included in a non-paleo environment

I try not to think "Oh S#@% -  a Birthday Party Invite," but every time presents so many challenges to our Paleo family. You get the invite and all you can think about is kids stuffing themselves with birthday cake. It is the perfect combination of flour and sugars to make any kid do about anything to get it in their mouth. In some circles, this could be a definition of addiction.   What happens next is like a scene from a movie. Kids hanging from chandeliers, parents chasing them around, then the eventual crash when the sugar runs out. I would like to avoid these situations at all costs, but your child has friends...and we like to socialize! Here are some tips to make it through:
  1. Paleo Treat-Bring something with you that your child can have instead of cake. Preferably something they have had before that really gets them excited to eat. You could make some cake, cookies, brownie, or cupcake. I have done this occasionally, but we really don’t want to make a whole batch just to take a piece with us to a party. If you do cookies, you can always freeze the rest for the next party. A lot of times we are busy and don’t remember till the day of that, oh yeah, we need to bring a snack for our son! Our son really likes macaroons and they usually have them at the grocery made with honey or maple syrup. Buying fruit or chocolate could be an option as well, depending what your child really likes.
  2. Prep the situation-Talk to your child before you get to the party about what will be happening. Mention there will be cake but it hurts their tummy. You can tell them about how you will be bringing them something to have instead that will not hurt their tummy. My son is 3 ½ and already knows that all cupcakes are not created equal. Some could have ingredients that are not good for him and some won’t have much effect. Setting the situation up before hand is the key to having success (this goes along with every situation you have when raising kids). If you wait until all the other kids are eating cake, and you tell your child they are having something else instead, there is sure to be a meltdown.   We do this all the time and it works. He has his snack we brought him and then goes back to playing. Also, you can call ahead and figure out what else will be served. Maybe it is going to be a pizza party. My son can tolerate dairy, so we have him just eat the toppings off of the pizza in a pinch. I have also made pizza with cauliflower crust to eat instead. Again, planning ahead and prepping situation will keep you from getting in situations that are no wins for you as a parent!
  3. My son ate cake-I have been to a birthday party and forgot to bring a substitute snack. At first, I was upset at myself for forgetting, but then we decided we could use it as a learning experience for our son. He almost didn’t have any cake because he was so busy playing with someone else’s toys. The parents are the ones that build this up. If we would have just went over to the party, did the activities, and played with some toys, my son would have chalked it up as a great day. Instead, we had to sit down and everybody have a piece of cake. In fact, my son was just playing while all the other kids were eating and someone asked him if he wanted some cake. Of course he said yes! My wife got him a small piece of cake and explained to him that there were ingredients in the cake he doesn’t normally eat. He did not get the mood swing, which he normally does if he gets sugar, but when we got home the flour hit him. His stomach starting aching then he had to sit on the toilet because of diarrhea. We explained to him why he got the diarrhea and talked to him about how he felt. We helped him connect the dots of what you eat and how you feel. Now he will still reference the birthday cake when we talk about things he should eat when we go to parties.
  4. Kindly say no-Friends will not be offended if you don’t eat the cake they made (if they are offended, then they are probably not the best people to be in your tribe). We have recently moved to a new city in the last 2 years and we have gone to many birthday parties. Nobody has made faces or thought we were being mean to our son because he was not experiencing everything. I simply explain to them that we eat Paleo and our son has to avoid grains and refined sugar. I tell them we brought our own food for our son to have while everybody else is eating cake. I once thought I would just tell everybody our son has an allergy.   Then I realized that doesn’t help anybody and to help people on their healthy journey they need to know about the way we eat. Just make sure when you are telling people about the way you eat, avoid saying your way is right and their way is wrong. I feel like there is no quicker way to turn people off. Now at people’s houses, they make gluten free things or make more vegetable options because they know our diet. People want to be accommodating and make you feel welcome.
  5. Make your party Paleo awesome-If your son or daughter is having a birthday party make sure to make everything Paleo friendly. Lead by example. Show people how you can make cupcakes without using refined flour or sugar. Kids will still eat these treats and think they taste delicious. At my son’s birthday party in January, we made all the food for the party. I did not hear one kid complain that the food tasted bad. We didn’t bring any chocolate pie or chocolate chip bars we made for the party home. For us that is usually a good measure of success on offerings when not much is brought home. We do the same if we are just having people over for dinner. We make everything how we want it made and it is usually a success. We want to be the example so people realize they can eat this way and it tastes good too. I wasn’t always a good cook or know how to do anything besides follow a recipe. It took a while of being comfortable with some different ingredients but it gets easier. If you don’t want to cook there are tons of places to get Paleo food and treats. Your local food coop, Natural Grocers, Sunflower Market, or Whole Foods is always a good place to start.
These are things are that have worked for my family. They may not work perfect for yours, but it is good place to start. You can have a Paleo birthday party successfully. The first time you do it could be tough, but I promise it only gets easier after that. The biggest thing to make it work is communication with your child. Get input from them on the situation and treat them with respect instead of just saying you can eat this but you cannot eat that. Explain the why’s and make the food to feeling connection. When your child is more aware, they will feel more confident in the situation, even if they are eating something different from the other kids. Your kid will stay his/her normal self and the other kids will be crying and having meltdowns by the end of the party. Keep your kids on consistent energy level only makes for a happier family for everybody. I am interested to hear what things have worked for your families. Please leave some comments!
Sheet1.Categories: How To | Interesting Other | Lifestyle Design

Sheet1.Title: Grain Free Diet: The Good, Bad, and Ugly
Sheet1.Meta Description: Should I Go Grainless? That’s a question many ask. Trying to balance our food-obsessed culture with a grain free diet and lifestyle is hard, but possible.
Sheet1.Content:
Should I Go Grainless?

That’s a question many of us ask. What makes it harder sometimes is that American culture is not very accepting of a grain free life.   Whether focusing just on gluten or grains in general, it’s hard to balance our food-obsessed culture with a grain free diet and lifestyle.  

So how do you decide?

Let me tell you how I made the decision. I found myself being irritable, constantly tired, moody, dealing with headaches, and unable to lose weight despite following “the right plan.” In talking with a friend about her challenges, I decided going gluten-free was a step that might show some results. Gluten-free eating helped me feel better for a while, but then I started getting sick again. This time I had achy joints and bones, sensitivity to touch, intensely painful stomachaches and heartburn. Unfortunately, I never knew what was causing these symptoms. I also started dealing with high levels of anxiety that affected my energy and attitude at work. I began exploring what these issues could relate to and between talking to a friend of my parents who has severe allergies and reading articles written by The Paleo Mom, I realized going Paleo could be the right choice for me. If you felt any shred of the desperation I felt at this time my life, you'll relate to the sentiment that "You'll try anything (reasonable) to feel better."   I started a Paleo lifestyle and began to feel better. This was by choice, but when it stopped working, I had to ask why. Thus, I sought out a functional medicine doctor who spent 90 minutes with me talking about my life and medical issues. She also had me do about 35 lab tests and a DNA analysis through which an answer was found! The prognosis was not idea., but the first step to healing what knowing my ailments. I had a leaky gut, but was also sick with multiple infections aka Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO).I was fortunate enough to have good health insurance and enough salary to afford the functional medicine doctor. However, not everyone can do that. So how do you determine if a Paleo lifestyle is by choice or necessitated? I initially knew I potentially had a leaky gut and/or an autoimmune disease through an extensive amount of reading and research:
  • Digestive issues? Check.
  • Mood swings?
  • Check. Restless Legs?
  • Check. And so on.
  According to Dr. Amy Meyers, there are 10 signs you may exhibit if you have an autoimmune disorder (i.e. need to look at your diet, specifically gluten & grains):
  1. Joint pain, muscle pain or weakness or a tremor
  2. Weight loss, insomnia, heat intolerance or rapid heartbeat
  3. Recurrent rashes or hives, sun-sensitivity, a butterfly-shaped rash across your nose and cheeks.
  4. Difficulty concentrating or focusing
  5. Feeling tired or fatigued, weight gain or cold intolerance
  6. Hair loss or white patches on your skin or inside your mouth
  7. Abdominal pain, blood or mucus in your stool, diarrhea or mouth ulcers
  8. Dry eyes, mouth or skin
  9. Numbness or tingling in the hands or feet
  10. Multiple miscarriages or blood clots
 

Does this sound like you?

The best action I've found is to start taking inflammatory food items out of your diet. This includes:
  • gluten/grains,
  • dairy,
  • soy, and
  • processed foods.
It’s also beneficial to eat grass-fed meat and organic produce. Sometimes these items can be cost-prohibitive, so there is a list of the dirty dozen and clean 15 organic produce to guide your shopping. When I was told by my doctor that I was to avoid corn, soy, rice, sugar, dairy, peanuts, and gluten, I knew I could no longer be a “as I felt like it” Paleo eater. While her list was shorter in restrictions, I kept to the way I had been eating and have stayed away from all grains – not just gluten, corn, & rice. Further, the gums (xantham, guar, & carrageenan) can be inflammatory so I’ve avoided those as well. Unfortunately, they are in most store-bought items. It’s been exhilarating and frustrating all at the same time.   The Ugly: Eating out with my friends isn’t what it used to be, but I can invite them to have food at my house. At the same time though, I LOVE to cook and bake and have challenged myself to keep a contamination-free kitchen and to create meals and treats that even the biggest gluten and sugar lover (aka...my mother) will like. At first I used cookbooks to learn how prepare grainless food. Now I'm successfully creating my own recipes – which has led me to start my own business – Grainless Gourmet. I’m looking forward to getting my baked goods in coffee shops in the San Francisco Bay Area as well as creating Paleo cooking & baking mixes to be sold online and in local stores. As I develop and expand my business, I am utilizing Kickstarter to get funding to meet my goals. If you agree that having food restrictions doesn’t mean you want to be less social or enjoy food less, we'll get along just fine.   Food Allergies & Health Choices = Seeking equally delicious foods within certain parameters Do you have grain and gluten questions? Leave a comment below or email me, Kelly Lough, at grainlessgourmet@gmail.com

Sheet1.Title: How to Race to Thrive with Nell Stephenson
Sheet1.Meta Description: Today as I review my latest triathlon race results, I reflect on what has led me to the 2015 IRONMAN World Championships.
Sheet1.Content:
The More I Race, The More I Learn

Not just about how best to mentally prepare or what strategies to employ, but about myself. Today as I review my latest triathlon race results, I reflect on what has led me to the 2015 IRONMAN World Championships. It's not always been so obvious that Triathlons give me chances to discover what things I allow to serve as motivators to dig deeper and push harder than I had before. I experience a very direct result of my training on a race course, and I find myself attempting to discern which tactics might have the opposite effect and result in more of a road block, at least until I can sort them out and turn those into a launching pad for further growth and progress in their own right. What we learn about our limitations and capabilities in sport carries through into every other aspect of a person's life, which is yet one more reason why I feel so passionate about educating on the significance on getting moving from an early age, just as much as eating properly. [Tweet "The winner's brain simply doesn't give in."] Looking back over the last decade at myself as an athlete, I can vividly recall being in particular states of mind while getting ready for a race (not all ideal) and how difficult it was to learn how to work through them and come out a more tenacious athlete. My goal: set new physical limits.  I did not want to give up one iota of competitiveness or desire to perform past prior limits. There was what I’d call a beginner’s mindset. I had this mindset for quite a while where I my goal was more to manage completing a race as opposed to doing so in a certain time. At this stage of my running life, I made rookie mistakes which we all do in terms of poor nutrition protocol and improper training. [Tweet "What we learn about our limitations and capabilities in sport has a powerful effect on all other aspects of our life."] Then came the stage...in which I first learned the significance of mental preparation and learned of the work of Tim Naokes: "My unproven hypothesis is that in the case of a close finish, physiology does not determine who wins. Rather somewhere in the final section of the race, the brains of the second, and lower placed finishers, accept their respective finishing positions and no longer challenge for a higher finish." The winner's brain simply doesn't give in.[1] Around the same time, I began dating my now husband, who at the time had transitioned from being a successful marathon runner and fellow IRONMAN triathlete into ultra-running. From those two inputs, I began to learn how to mentally prepare not just for an event, but for training as well. I began to test calming my usual negative reaction to a high heart rate (which would occur when I began to push the pace during a run) and not to dwell on what might go wrong in a race. In a nutshell, it became clear that while we obviously need to put in the time to physically prepare for a race, to not equally prepare mentally could easily result in a day sabotaged by worry, doubt, poor focus and a disappointing outcome. Roger Bannister, the first runner to break the four-minute mile, once said: “It is the brain, not the heart or lungs that is the critical organ. It’s the brain.”[2] From this intermediate racer stage,  a good five years followed during which my race performance began to improve significantly and I began to regularly place in the top three. Sometimes I would even win my age group, but with that came a self imposed level of stress about the performance which resulted in extraordinarily high levels of anxiety and catastrophic fear of something going wrong during the race. It was as if not winning would have been the end all. Fortunately, the stress wasn’t so out of hand that it worked against me and I continued to be able to perform. Still, the emotional wringer I’d put myself through each and every race made the days leading up to it less than pleasant, to say the least. It was downright awful. It was actually at this very race that I'm at now (in 2015), the Ironman Hawaii 70.3, when I had my breakthrough on that front. It was 2009. I had landed in Kona and the race was coming up a few days later. I’d already begun to feel that uncomfortable churning in my stomach and worrying about the cross winds, flatting on the bike, which might cost me a win and blah, blah, blah... The stress was bubbling just below the point of overwhelming as the race was still a few days away. And then, as if by magic, the next morning when I woke to a beautiful morning in paradise, it dawned on me how lucky I was. It sounds simple; Scenery provokes some powerful moods. (Hawaii tourism--here's your new bumper sticker, but I digress.) There I was in Hawaii, with my husband, about to have a chance to race in one of the most special places in the world. And if, for some reason, I didn’t win my age group and earn a slot to World Championships, would it really be the end of everything? This wasn’t to say that I no longer cared about the outcome; rather, just that it took the tiniest bit of pressure off and allowed me to reallocate what would have been wasted energy into positive thought processes. And I preformed better than I had before. So this, all of it, has been part of my own growth as an athlete. And when I sit down to write a race report, I do think it’s fun, perhaps, to share time splits, wattage goals, when I chose to surge on the bike and who had a target on their back for me to pick off during the run; those things all seem less important than the bigger picture. It was indeed a great day at the races; hot yes, and some wind (of course because when is there not some wind in Kona?) and I had a solid plan that I'd thoroughly reviewed with my coach the day before. A new swim strategy, a higher wattage output on the bike a new pacing goal for the run all proved to be successful in my result of an age group win and 4th woman overall. I’m also incredibly proud of Chris, my husband, who also had a great race winning his slot for IM 70.3 World Championships in Austria. We will both race this August. I gave it everything, worked hard throughout each second of the course and am now ready for a couple of days of R&R, which shouldn’t be too hard given the surroundings! As I’ve written before, there’s just something incredibly special about being here on this island that goes beyond the spoken word; a feeling of being part of something bigger. And I feel honored to be a part of it. Aloha!
[1] "Tim Noakes on Fatigue, Cowardice, Winners and Losers." Runner's World. N.p., 24 Apr. 2012. Web. 31 May 2015. [2] Kolata, Gina. "A Little Deception Helps Push Athletes to the Limit." The New York Times. The New York Times, 19 Sept. 2011. Web. 31 May 2015.

Sheet1.Title: IRONMAN 101: A Qualifier Experience Explained
Sheet1.Meta Description: 18--That is the number of triathlons I've completed, so if you are new the sport, this is an IRONMAN 101 experience. How to go from spectator to qualifier.
Sheet1.Content:
My Journey from IRONMAN Spectator to Qualifier

I’m writing this live from the big island today and I’m back to race one of my favorite courses, Ironman Hawaii 70.3, which will take place tomorrow at 7am local time. In years past, this course has served as my qualifier for Ironman World Championships (Worlds), held each year in October just south of where tomorrow’s event will take place, with portions of the bike on the very same route on Queen K then out to Hawaii and back. Due to a change in which races can serve this capacity, it’s no longer an option to win one’s slot to Kona here, but athletes from all walks of life can opt to have a go at what is, in my opinion, one of the best half-ironman races out there. Qualifying for the IRONMAN World Championship is extraordinarily difficult. Just completing one of the 40 full-distance races around the world requires courage, perseverance and dedication. For some, the goal will be to earn a slot to the 70.3 Worlds held this year in Austria and for others the mission may be to complete their very first half. For others still, it’s simply as straightforward as a very enjoyable place to take a vacation with just a little bit of exercise peppered right in the middle! If triathlon doesn’t happen to be your thing, here are some reference points:
  • The race consists of a 1.2 mile swim, followed by a 56 mile bike ride and then a half marathon, which is a run of 13.1 miles
  • Over 2200 entries raced the Kona half IRONMAN course in 2014
  • Earning a IRONMAN qualifying spot puts you among the world's endurance elite; only three percent of age group athletes qualify for Kona.
This will be my 7th Honu (as it’s locally known) and 2015 marks my 18th in the sport; my very first tri being the sprint in Catalina back in 1998, where I committed more than one newbie blunder, the silliest of which was forgetting to take my helmet off during the run! Back then, my reason for racing was simply that I wanted a fun reason to workout, something less stressful than wanting to keep at a certain weight regardless of how that end might be met. I recall a college friend at the time asking me if I’d ever race Ironman and my reply, without missing a beat, was that I’d never in a million years be able to do something like that! Little did I know that a mere two years later, I’d change my tune in a big way. [Tweet "I never in a million years thought I could race an IRONMAN, but two years later I changed my tune in a big way. -Paleoista"] I’d gone to spectate the Ralphs California Half IRONMAN, which in its first two years was a full.   A good friend was racing and I cheered her through her outstanding performance and then chose to carry on watching the other athletes cross the finish line. I saw many a fit-looking person run through the tape, embracing a loved one or kissing the ground in sheer delight for what they’d just accomplished. That was exciting enough but it was what came next that would change my approach on training, racing and affect my life as an athlete in a way more profound than I ever could have dreamed. I saw an athlete cross the finish line in his wheel chair. And I saw a gentleman (Bill Bell), who was over 80 years old at the time, finish as well. And another athlete with a prosthetic leg. And an athlete who was blind with his guide! I couldn’t believe what I was seeing and to this day, even now as I write this, I feel chills down my spine and tears in my eyes when I imagine what their day to day life must be like on its own, let alone the courage it must take to decide to take on the challenge of an IRONMAN race. That was my moment. I realized hard and fast that the idea that “I couldn’t” do that was asinine. There I was, not even 25 years old yet, with a healthy body thinking I couldn’t. [Tweet "I realized hard and fast that the idea that “I couldn’t” do that was asinine. -Paleoista"] So I knew I had to do it and the very next day I signed up for what would be my first Ironman, the 2001 IM California. The rest may be history, but since then, I’ve experienced so much, from the years I still had to work through the terrible sickness that led me to Paleo, to the wonderful people I met through the sport including dear friends, and my husband, to what the sport provided me then and continues to provide me today: an exciting, exhilarating, incredible mode of training, racing, competing and most importantly, a chance to continue to push myself beyond limits for no other reason than “why not”? I’ve probably told this story about a million times, and my reason for sharing it is not that I think everyone needs to be an ironman. It’s because I think we all need a reality check sometimes and it takes something significant to give us some perspective. For me, Ralphs California racers gave me that wakeup call. Consider yourself: what are you doing to take full advantage of the fact that you have a choice in the matter of how you treat your body? There really are no excuses, and the goal I’d have for anyone reading this post is to remember one thing: you’ve got only one body and you can choose to treat it as the proverbial temple by moving it and nourishing it with real food. Or you can choose not to.   If you choose the former, outstanding! Conversely, if you choose the latter, that’s certainly an option as well, but make sure you factor in what you’re taking for granted. So as far as tomorrow’s race is concerned, have I got goals? Do I want to smash my times and those of my competitors as well? Of course! I love some healthy competition and I love seeing how I can improve my own times year on year. I’ve experienced it all on this course- from 2007 when I punctured my tubular so badly it couldn’t be ridden 9 miles out from T2 and lost over twenty minutes waiting for support, to 2010 when I raced my guts out and came across the line as the first female amateur. [Tweet "How will you take full advantage of the fact that it's a matter of choice how you treat your body?"] I have learned, and I continue to learn so much from this sport and it carries over into other parts of my life. This is just another reason I am so keen to recommend sport as something to engage in to my clients as well as children of clients (all ages). I'm ready to share my IRONMAN 101 story to inspire the same transformation in their lives. In particular, there’s just something very special about racing on this island. Whether it’s the fact that these are the hallowed grounds where the big show takes place each year, the warm, welcoming culture or the lure of the tales of the island gods, it’s an honor to be here each and every time and I look forward to a day in which I am present each and every second. Much respect. Aloha!
The race has now ended but to watch the 2015 race replay, visit www.ironmanlive.com

Sheet1.Title: Pacing for Performance: 1 Training Tip to Start ASAP
Sheet1.Meta Description: Do you know how to pace in a race, or has the wind left your sails by the finish line? Condition your body to end stronger with negative splits running.
Sheet1.Content:
To find your optimal cadence, start with negative splits running

To start, answer these two questions if you can:
  • Do you know what your race pace is?
  • Do you find yourself crashing on the second half of a course or race?
In my lifetime of OCR racing, one of the biggest mistakes I see people make during races is misjudging their own pace. This is a very important part of running and ultimately dooms many newbies in the sport. Every race, without fail, I see people that jump out to the front of the pack and lead the race for 400 meters only to finish in 80th place. Running is one of those sports where you can’t play defense. You can’t stop a guy that’s faster than you, its just not allowed. Maybe one day we will have a full contact obstacle course race (which I would absolutely be a fan of), but until then it’s a good idea to find out what your pace is. I pride myself on finishing races strong and it has a lot to do with my training. I always try to have negative splits during my running days. Negative splits running is when your repeats get faster as you get into your workout. For example, I did a workout where I did 4 x 1 mile repeats down on the East River in NYC with a 30 burpees in between each mile and about 90 seconds of rest. But my mile times were: mile 1 6:49, mile 2 6:38, mile 3 6:25, mile 4 5:55. You see my pace increased as the workout went along. First mile was my slowest and the last was my fastest, that’s what negative splits are and it’s a great way to get faster and become a more efficient runner. Our goal here is to teach the body to become faster as opposed to slowing down as the race goes along. Many people go out at a pace that they can’t handle and end up crashing hard and struggle to finish the race. It’s happened to everyone, including myself. Now when I line up at the start line and see guys that are much faster than me I don’t try and keep up with them, instead I go out at my pace and maintain that pace for the entire race. They will go out of the gate at a pace that I won’t be able to sustain and if I try and run with them I will inevitably crash halfway through the race. Again this is why it’s important to know your pace and go at a pace that you can handle. Don’t think I’m telling you to run slow or not push hard, but when you’re heading out on an 10 mile course, you can’t go out at your 5k pace. You have to be smart, realistic and aim to have a solid race start to finish. The goal of a good race for me is to maintain a consistent pace and have a nice kick at the end. You will be surprised how many people you will pass during the second half of a race. Most people will run much slower during the second half of the race, so even though they may jump out ahead of you, don’t panic. Keep your pace and when they start crashing you’ll start passing.

Final advice:

I encourage all of you to start incorporating this negative split theory into your weekly workouts. It can be on quarter mile splits or mile splits or any distance. Get to know yourself a bit better by timing your runs and getting to know your pace so when race day comes you can have a strong race start to finish. Any questions or workout advice? Leave a comment below or you can follow me at JP3OCR.com.

Sheet1.Title: Sophia Elie on Realistic Nutrition That Scales
Sheet1.Meta Description: So, what happens when you approach CrossFit training with Sophia Elie's anti-diet naturopathic roadmap? We cover that in her realistic nutrition interview.
Sheet1.Content:
With a hundred ways to reach your health goals, how do you pick the best and the fastest?

That is just one of the questions Sophia Elie answered in our latest conversation. Sophia Elie, RDN (@eatstraightup) obtained an BS in Nutrition and Dietetics at Bastyr University, the world's leading naturopathic medical university, then corporate nutrition coaching in Washington D.C.. Sophia's private practice was born out of those days in D.C., and has since evolved into an entirely new class: performance nutrition. She is now the owner of Straight Up Nutrition, producers of the rotating Performance Nutrition Seminar along the west coast. Her recent studies go far beyond mere description-she spent considerable time exploring the role of traditional Chinese medicine, therapeutic cooking, and herbal sciences and how we can optimize healthy athleticism, even in healthy adults. So, what happens when you approach CrossFit training with Sophia's anti-diet naturopathic roadmap? Well, that’s just one of many things we cover in this 30 minute conversation at the Verdant Gym. As someone who has felt lousy about her body and has sampled an inordinate amount of food plans searching for a lasting solution, I found Sophia's work to be of incredible importance and promise. She is realistic and blatant in her nutrition approach--even scrutinizing companies like us to be 100% transparent and authentic about helping people. I hope this discussion triggers life changing daily habits in the best possible way. Enjoy!   [audio mp3="https://www.amrapnutrition.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Sophia-Elie.mp3"][/audio]   QUESTION(S) OF THE DAY: Are you skeptical of nutrition advice generally? If so, WHAT are you doing to fact check that advice? If nothing, why? Please share in the comments.

Show Notes

  • MyFitnessPal - Sophia swears by this smartphone app. And she is not the only one. Noah Kagan (AppSumo CEO/ OkDork.com Founder) uses the tech too.
  • Nourishing Traditions - the novel to get your gut in a happy place. Though Sophia won't agree to everything in the book, it is a good starting place.

  • #eatstraightup - Share your realistic nutrition approach, as in daily eating habits that actually work for you, via Sophia's trending hashtag.
